PREFACE OF THE PRESIDENT 4 One of the main objectives of the Court and part of its mission to promote transparency and accountability is to bring the Court of Auditors closer to EU citizens.
I am therefore delighted to welcome you as a reader of the first annual activity report of the European Court of Auditors.
The report aims to provide an overall overview of the Court and to report on its activities in 2007, the year in which it celebrates its 30th anniversary as an external auditor of the European Union, which, according to its mandate, contributes to the improvement of EU financial management and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
The Court makes its main contribution through its audits and reports, which enable the audited body to improve its financial management, and assist the discharge authority (European Parliament and Council) in its monitoring of the implementation of the EU budget.
This report gives an overview of the audit reports published in 2007 and highlights the main conclusions regarding the implementation of the 2006 EU budget and the sound financial management of EU funds.
The Court not only reports on the financial management of past years, but also actively contributes to the establishment of an EU financial control framework.
2007 was an important year for EU financial management.
The Court's position is outlined in the section entitled 'The Court's position' in the Court's view on major developments in Member States' accountability and the Court's contribution to the public consultation on budgetary reform launched by the European Commission.
None of the Court's 2007 results would be conceivable without the commitment, know-how and competence of its 850 staff.
Staff are the main capital of a future-oriented authority, which strives for continuous improvement.
This first annual activity report contains details of the Court's reform process, which was launched in 2006 with a self-assessment.
In 2007, progress was made in implementing the resulting Action Plan, and at the end of the year, a so-called peer review procedure was launched, led by a group of auditors of the national audit courts of Canada, Austria, Norway and Portugal.
A first result of this reform process was the following statement on the Court's mission, mission statement, values and strategic objectives, on which the future activities of which the Court will report in due course will be guided.
I wish you much joy in reading the first annual activity report and I hope it will be of benefit to you.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
6 CONTRACT, GUIDE, VALUES AND STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES CONTRACT GUIDE The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, he contributes to improving EU financial management, while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
7 VALUES Independence, integrity & impartiality Professionalism Added value Excellence & efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and its employees.
provide its addressees with appropriate test results, rejecting any form of influence by instructions or pressure from the outside.
Maintaining a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Preparation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and supporting documents, taking into account the interests of its addressees and containing important and indicative statements.
To contribute to an effective improvement in the management of the EU budget and contribute to the strengthening of accountability for the management of the EU's financial resources.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.
STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES In order to fulfil its mandate, the European Court of Auditors has committed itself to the following strategic objectives: Professionalism Output Involved in further development & growth Strong audit methods, appropriate audit strategy, further development of audit practice in the public sector, development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards for EU funds, cooperation with EU-ORCB, effective ‘Community control framework' to select relevant audit topics, closeness to time, clarity and legibility of reports, quality of economic audits, increasing the impact of the reports Deeper relations with the audited bodies, in order to improve the understanding of the audit process and to improve acceptance of audit results, development of contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as budgetary and discharge authority, effective communication with EU citizens in order to use the experience of the peer review process to strengthen and develop the process, and achieve maximum efficiency, follow-up of an effective and dynamic staff policy; quality vocational training; modernisation of infrastructure; implementation of IT strategies
8 ROLE AND WORK OF THE HOFE WHAT ROLE IS THE HOFE?
The European Union's budget amounts to around EUR 120 billion, representing about 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
This represents a small share compared to national budgets.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in financing public activities, for example, the overall budget volume is approximately the same as in some countries, such as Romania.
The composition of the budget has changed over time, with agriculture and cohesion policy the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
The budget is established annually, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and by the directly elected European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission.
The Commission is responsible for the budget, but shares a significant share of the administrative tasks with the Member States, in particular with regard to expenditure on agricultural and cohesion policy.
Depending on the expenditure regime, national authorities may be responsible for defining expenditure strategies, selecting beneficiaries and projects, and making payments.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on the requests made by the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union.
9 BOX 1 – HOW DOES THE EU DOES THEIR YELLOWERS?
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than national budgets, partly due to different fields of responsibility.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually account for a large part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which usually takes the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has been the main share of budgetary expenditure, albeit at present with a decreasing trend.
In 2008, less than half of the budget is earmarked for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development.
Since the 1980s, a significant part of the expenditure has been devoted to cohesion – regional and social development – to co-financing a wide range of projects, from road construction in Slovakia to training courses for the unemployed in Denmark.
In 2008, expenditure on sustainable growth, of which the lion's share of cohesion, was estimated at 38% of the budget.
This heading also covers a large part of the EU's funding for research.
Some 6% of the budget is spent on the management of the Community institutions.
EU expenditure Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1% The European Union as a global player 6% Administration 6% Cohesion – sustainable growth 38% Agriculture – conservation and management of natural resources 49%
Democratic societies need complete and correct public information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both in order to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
In its role as external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds have been correctly accounted for, regardless of their place of use, and have been spent in accordance with the legislation, with due regard for the optimum use of funds.
The Court's audit results are used by the Commission, Parliament and the Council and by Member States to improve EU financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities are examining EU funds, provided they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
Overview of internal and external control of the EU budget EU level 10 Commission (DG, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing Bodies European Court of Auditors National control authorities National level External control Internal control
What are the audit findings of the Court?The Court applies three different types of audit to 1: audit of the accounts, compliance audit, audit of the accounts, the audit of the audit of the accounts, depending on which of the following three issues is the starting point of the audit: 11 • • • the annual accounts, in all material respects, give an actual picture of the financial situation, results and cash flow for the year, in accordance with the accounting framework in force?
Under the EC Treaty, the Court is obliged to make such a statement, or to give an opinion, on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual Statement of Assurance is generally known under the French acronym DAS (Déclaration d'Assurance).
1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
The Court shall carry out its audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with International Audit Principles (ISAs), which shall apply both in the public and in the private sector.
The Court, together with the national control authorities, actively participates in the further development of international auditing standards promoted by the standardisation bodies (Intosai, IFAC).
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legal and regulatory frameworks, the Court relies on the results of both its investigation of the monitoring and control systems to prevent, detect and correct the errors of legality and regularity, and of a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
If systems are reviewed and found to be reliable, the number of operations that the Court is required to examine to reach a sound conclusion on their legality and regularity shall be reduced accordingly.
In selecting issues for its audit activities, the Court seeks to identify audit areas in which the greatest impact is to be expected in terms of the potential for improvement identified in terms of the economy, economy and effectiveness of EU expenditure.

13 BOX 2 – The Court's PRE-FACE TESTS ON EU BUDGET'S PAYMENTS The Court does not have the necessary resources to examine in detail all the EU budget's operations.
The Court follows these processes up to the final beneficiary of the aid, such as a farmer in southern Germany.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks, such as the measurement of the size of the agricultural area, in order to determine whether the corresponding information in the aid application corresponds to the actual circumstances.

14 GUIDANCE STRUCTURE AND ORGANISATION STRUCTURE OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body of 27 members, each of whom has one member per Member State.
As shown in the organizational chart (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (preserving and managing natural resources – structural policies, transport, research and energy – external policies – own resources, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for "horizontal issues such as coordination in the field of assurance, quality assurance, the development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a Management Committee composed of members of all audit groups shall be responsible for preparing for all administrative matters requiring a formal Court decision.
MEMBERS The members of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a term of six years in accordance with the proposals made by each Member State and shall be eligible for re-election.
In addition to its function within the College, which is responsible for the final decision-making on audits and opinions as well as on further strategic and administrative issues, each member is responsible for its specific tasks, primarily in the audit area.
The member then presents the report in the audit group or in the Court and after its adoption in the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties.
With the accession of Bulgaria and Romania on 1 January 2007, the Court welcomed two new members, Ms Nadeschda Sandolova and Mr Ovidiu Ispir.
One year later, on 1 January 2008, the Court added three new members, Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) and Mr Harald Noack (Germany), as the term of office of its predecessors had expired.
In addition, the Council extended the term of office of four members (Greece, the Netherlands, Austria and the United Kingdom) for a further six years.

16 THE PRESIDENT The European Court of Auditors is headed by the President, who is elected by the members of the Court for a term of three years, with the right of re-election.
The role of the President is that of a Primus inter Pares.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in its relations with the discharge authority, with the other institutions of the European Union and the supreme audit authorities of the Member States and beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, Mr. Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, the Portuguese Member, was elected 11th President of the Court.
THE SECRETARY-GENERAL The Secretary-General shall be the highest-ranking member of the institution and shall be appointed by the Court for a period of six years and shall be eligible for re-election.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the Court's staff and staff management, including continuing vocational training and the Translation Directorate, each with one unit per official language (22), with the exception of Gaelic.
The Secretary-General is also under the responsibility of the General Secretariat.
The term of office of the current Secretary-General of the Court, Mr Michel Hervé, was extended on 1 July 2007.
THE HOFE'S PERSONS The staff of the European Court of Auditors are approximately 850 staff (836 on 31 December 2007) and comprise auditors (484), translators (162) and administrative staff.
The Court's auditors have a wide range of training profiles and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the fields of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit and the legal and economic sciences.
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States.
18 OVERVIEW OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND 3 OPINIONS OF THE HOFE The results of the Court's audits of the accounts and compliance audits are usually incorporated in annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds (EDFs) and in the special annual reports on the Union's agencies and bodies.
The results of the audit work will be published in the course of the year in the form of special reports.
The Court also publishes opinions on draft acts affecting financial management.
ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE 2006 BUDGET ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET As the Court has repeatedly stated in its annual reports on the implementation of the EU's general budget, adequate and appropriate internal control systems established by the Commission and the Member States are key to ensuring proper EU budget management.
In recent years, the Court has recognised the Commission's efforts to promote and apply improved internal control and management procedures, both in terms of the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the operations declared therein.
The 2006 Annual Report continued this tradition by identifying areas where there is – sometimes a significant – need for improvement and by identifying large areas of expenditure where the situation is still unsatisfactory.
The Court concluded that the ‘final accounts of the European Communities, showing the implementation of the 2006 EU budget, give an actual picture of the financial situation and the results of the Communities in all material respects, except for the allocation of excessive amounts in the accounts and in the pre-financing budget in the balance sheet.
Further improvements are therefore considered necessary in order to ensure that the newly introduced accrual accounts are fully operational and that their full potential as a reliable management and control tool can be exploited.
3 This section is used to introduce the Court's reports and opinions to the Court and to the Court's summary of the content.
More detailed information can be found in the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
The Court gives a negative opinion on the legality and regularity of the Court's audit and concludes that these expenditure areas continue to be a major source of errors to the areas of expenditure in the ‘Final accounts of the European Communities', in which most payments are made – agriculture [mainly non-integrated management and control (IPCoS) expenditure], structural measures, internal policies and large parts of external policies.
In the case of payments in these areas, the monitoring and control systems could only partially limit the risk of errors of legality and regularity in the transactions.
The Court stresses that complicated or unclear eligibility criteria or complex legislation have had a significant impact on the legality and regularity of the transactions.
However, the Court noted a significant decrease in the estimated overall error rate in agricultural operations, and concluded that, where properly applied, the IACS is an effective system to reduce the risk of irregular expenditure.
In addition, the Court noted that the transactions underlying the commitments and the revenue were not significantly affected, including payments related to administrative expenditure, the bulk of the pre-accession strategy and parts of external policies (see Box 3). 19

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND (EDF) In 2007, the Court also published an annual report on the European Development Funds (EDF).
While the Court of Auditors was able to give an audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts of the EDFs, the audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions on the basis of payments authorised under the responsibility of the delegations in the beneficiary countries was limited in view of the substantial error rate in these transactions.
Other ANNUAL REPORTS A further 28 special annual reports on the European agencies and other decentralised bodies and an annual report on the audit of the efficiency of the management of the European Central Bank were also published in 2007. 21
SPECIAL REPORTS PUBLISHED IN 2007 The Court published nine special reports in 2007.
The reports covered investigations into financial management issues in many different areas, ranging from VAT cooperation (No. 8/2007) to capacity building in countries as distant as Angola and Vietnam (No. 6/2007).
The Court's tests revealed problems of various kinds with various consequences.
The weaknesses identified by the Court in relation to the building expenditure of the EU institutions (No 2/2007) make clear that not all EU funds have been used in this area in a meaningful way.
The deficiencies identified in the report on the monitoring, inspection and sanctioning systems relating to the rules on the conservation of Community fisheries resources (No 7/2007) could have serious consequences not only for the aquatic resources but also for the future of the fisheries industry.
Despite the different types of use of resources in the various areas of the EU budget, the Court reports reveal several common issues, which can be outlined as follows: 22 • • • Although the use of funds should be both rapid and efficient, efforts to achieve these two objectives at the same time may be both tense.
This is the subject of the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and the report on the Commission's management of the CARDS programme in the countries of the Western Balkans (No 5/2007).
Although planning does not guarantee effectiveness, it is of considerable importance.
Questions relating to strategic and long-term planning were raised in the reports on the building expenditure of the EU institutions (No 2/2007) and on the evaluation of the EU framework programmes in the field of research and technological development (RTD) (No 9/2007) as well as in two reports on external assistance, one relating to the CARDS programme (No 5/2007) and the other to the effectiveness of technical assistance in the framework of capacity-building (No 6/2007).
The Commission's evaluations are a core element of its performance management system when assessing performance and indicating, if necessary, the need for improvement.
Where evaluations take place at an early stage of the programming cycle, this means that progress is insufficient and that insufficient relevant data is available for evaluation purposes.
On the other hand, the possibilities of making timely changes during the current period, and improvements before the start of the next, may be reduced if evaluations are made at a later date.
The issue of the correct timing of evaluations was addressed both in the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and in the report on the R & D evaluation (No 9/2007).
23 • • Evaluation as well as testing are more difficult to carry out when the objectives of the spending programmes are unclear, which was another issue addressed in the latter two reports.
The management and controls of EU expenditure are subject to complex regulations, which must be clearly and unambiguously formulated to ensure that the funds are used for the intended purposes.
The existence of clear definitions and rules is crucial if funds are to be collected or used as planned.
This was the subject of the reports on the European Refugee Fund (No. 3/2007) and on the checks and substitution of the Member States on the export of agricultural products (No. 4/2007).
The lack of common definitions is one of the factors which can affect the completeness, comparability and reliability of the data from the different Member States.
This can have consequences if the data becomes the basis for decisions such as the allocation of funds.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2007 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management by giving opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the adoption procedure of financial regulations 4 or may be submitted at the request of one of the other institutions of the Community 5. Moreover, the Court may, on its own initiative, issue opinions.
The Court's opinions may address issues relating to certain areas of expenditure, such as the two opinions of 2007 relating to new Regulations for the European Development Funds (Nos 2/2007 and 9/2007).
However, they may also cover broader EU financial management issues such as the Court's opinion on annual summaries, national declarations and the audit work of national audit bodies (No 6/2007).
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise on EU financial management in the course of the years in the course of its audits, and in some cases reference is made to certain audits.
For example, in its opinion on ensuring the correct application of the customs and agricultural rules (No 3/2007), the Court refers to a recommendation in a previous special report, according to which the Commission should take measures to improve the reliability of sources of information on fraud.
The need for simplification is a recurring issue in the Court's opinions (see Opinion No 7/2007 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities).
In a 2007 opinion (No 6/2007), the Court presented its opinion on the annual summaries as well as on the so-called national declarations submitted voluntarily by some Member States on their own initiative.
This opinion is discussed in more detail in the section on the Court's position.
Article 279 of the Treaty.
Article 248(4).
Most of the Court's opinions have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on the Court's website.
26 CONTINUING CONTINUING AND EFFECTIVENESS Public financial control plays a key role in modern democratic societies in terms of efficient financial management.
The audit activities shall be held accountable to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to the European citizens, whether their taxpayers' money is spent in a correct and appropriate manner.
In this respect, public financial control is a central element of accountability and is a useful basis for a public debate.
In this respect, the Court's work has considerable potential for impact.
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned – in the European context in the first place the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States.
On the basis of this information, they may take measures, with or without reference to the conclusions of the examination.
Although the Court's audit activity has its main effect on its published reports, it has its own effect throughout the audit process.
In particular, all audits result in the submission of detailed audit findings, which are sent to the audited body in order to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations.
The final text of the report is also subject to a 'contradictory procedure'.
The responses of the audited body – notably the Commission – will be published together with the reports.
In the answers, the audited body often acknowledges the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them.
After completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the audit results will be evaluated and used by the Parliament and the Council to carry out their political task of monitoring the use of the budget.
In the context of the annual discharge procedure, the Court reports form the basis for the Council's recommendation and for Parliament's decision.
The 2006 discharge procedure focused on the Court's conclusions on structural measures.
In its 2006 discharge resolution, Parliament directly refers to an action plan proposed by the Commission as a direct consequence of the conclusions of the Court's annual report, and calls for quarterly reports on its implementation.
Parliament also calls for a better understanding of the corrective measures taken to address the errors and weaknesses.
The special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, in view of the fact that they are published in the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on them have usually taken place earlier in the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
A good example of a possible follow-up measure is provided by the recent special report on building expenditure (No. 2/2007).
Indeed, Parliament had already entrusted its administration with the preparation of a report on the feasibility of creating a European Building Office entrusted with the responsibility of building and maintaining the buildings of the institutions and institutions of the European Union.
The Court's audit report on controls carried out by Member States on the export of agricultural products (No 4/2007) can be given as a further example.
The Council and the Commission responded promptly to the recommendations made by the Court by amending the existing legislation.
The impact of the audit reports can be enhanced by their thematicity in the relevant media, which gives greater attention and stimulates public debate.
The media is the most direct source of information for citizens.
In general, media coverage for the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive, but some special reports have also been followed with interest by the press.
For example, the fisheries report (No 7/2007) has received great attention in the media.
An extraordinary Fisheries Council was convened to discuss the Court's report, and the Commission initiated a procedure which may result in amendments to the legislation to address the shortcomings identified.
This is an example of a report which, due to its relevance and topicality, has made a particularly valuable contribution to the decision-making process.
This section gives some guidance on the impact of the Court reports published in 2007.
More detailed information on the follow-up to the Court's previous observations is given in the respective chapters of its annual report.
The Court's most frequently remark in its last annual report is that, despite the measures taken, the shortcomings in the previous year have only been partially rectified.
Opinions should also be considered when considering the impact of the Court's work.
It is the intention of the Court to analyse to an increasing extent the long-term implications of its work – both its audits and its opinions.
This can be illustrated by the example set out in Box 4.
27 BOX 4 – THE COURT'S OPINION ON THE Single Audit Over the years, the Court has published a number of opinions, showing ways of developing the general internal control system for the EU budget.
The opinion on the "Unique Review" (No 2/2004) in 2004 made a major contribution in this respect.
In this opinion, the Court proposes, the definition and implementation of the entire internal control system into a single integrated control framework, which includes common principles and objectives and ensures that costs and benefits are proportionate.
The opinion on the ‘Single audit' developed into a reference document for the Commission, but also for the Court, for example in 2007 in its comments on the definition of effective and efficient internal control in the updated implementing rules of the Financial Regulation (Opinion No 1/2007).
The integrated audit approach is reflected in the Commission's 2006 Integrated Internal Control Framework Action Plan.
The Commission has taken steps to emphasise the role and responsibilities of Member States in the area of internal control, including the new obligation to present annual summaries of audit opinions, declarations and the audits carried out in accordance with the regulations applicable to each area of expenditure.
28 THE POSITION OF THE COURT'S NATIONAL SUMMARY AND DECLARATIONS The Commission and Member States have taken initiatives to strengthen Member States' involvement in the accountability cycle for EU funds.
In part, the aim is to address the problem of the main error rates, with regard to the legality and regularity of the main areas of expenditure in the budget, particularly in areas where the Commission and the Member States share the management of the budget.
Significant recent developments include the obligation for Member States to submit annual summaries of available audit results and statements, the voluntary initiatives of some Member States to submit national declarations, and the decision of some national control authorities to draw up audit reports on the management of EU funds.
In its opinion No 6/2007, the Court considers that, where properly implemented, all these elements could improve the management and control of EU funds.
The opinion sets out the conditions under which these elements can provide added value and can be used by the Court in compliance with the requirements in international audit principles.
As annual summaries form an integral part of the internal control system, the Court will assess the extent to which they improve the functioning of the internal control system through its usual audit procedures.
Annual summaries can lead to better overall control of EU funds in areas of shared management insofar as they highlight strengths and weaknesses.
National declarations are based on voluntary initiatives by certain Member States and are made at the highest level and made to national parliaments.
Although they do not in themselves constitute conclusive audit evidence, they can be seen as a novel element of internal control and provide valuable information on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court recognises the potential benefits of national declarations and audit work in the Member States to raise awareness of the importance of internal control of EU funds.
The audit work carried out by the national control authorities (national audit reports) on the legality and regularity of the EU expenditure or on the national declarations could provide audit evidence to the Court if the Court is satisfied of the suitability and quality of the audit work in accordance with international audit principles.
In this case, the Court will take into account the records issued by national control authorities in the planning and execution of its own audits.
National declarations and national audit reports contain statements on control systems.
National declarations may also contain certain judgments on the legality and regularity of the transactions.
Experience shows that the main risk to the legality and regularity of the transactions is the reliability of the information provided by the beneficiaries when applying for EU funds, and less in the way in which that information is processed by the Member States and the Commission.
The declaration that systems work as required in EU regulations cannot in itself guarantee the legality and regularity of the transactions in question.
Recognising the need for a stronger role for national control authorities in the overall context of accountability of EU expenditure, the Contact Committee of the EU Supreme Audit Authorities has set up a Working Group for the harmonisation of audit standards and standards tailored in accordance with the EU context.
Joint approaches and methods of examination will increase the Court's ability to rely on the work of the national control authorities, provided that the quality of that work is directly demonstrated.
REVIEW OF THE EU BUDGET In September 2007, the Commission published a consultation paper to launch an open debate on EU finances as part of a far-reaching budgetary review.
The Court made its contribution to the debate at the beginning of April 2008 in which it identified the key principles to be taken into account in the design of new programmes in order to provide European added value in terms of clarity of objectives, the pursuit of simplification, the sense of reality, transparency and accountability.
Among other things, the Court recommended that the following aspects be taken into account: • • • the orientation of expenditure programmes not after input, but after output; better use of the approach of the acceptable risk of the design and adoption of expenditure programmes; degree of discretionary discretion to be granted to national or regional authorities in the management of expenditure programmes and accounting; and whether VAT own resources are still a useful component of the own resources system, the review of all the compensatory mechanisms in line with the guiding principles of the own resources system – justice, transparency, cost-effectiveness, simplicity and contributory power of each Member State. 29

The Court monitors the implementation of the work programme as a basis for improvements in subsequent years.
In 2007, there was a significant increase in the number of specific annual reports adopted on European agencies and other decentralised bodies.
The number of special reports and opinions was similar to those of previous years.
The annual reports on the general budget and on the European Development Funds have been published in accordance with the plan.

ACTION PLAN AND PEER-REVIEW PROCEDURE The Court is constantly seeking improvements in all aspects of its work.
In 2005, the Court decided to submit to a peer review procedure.
In this context, senior officials from a small number of senior audit authorities assess the organisation or the results of a sister body on the basis of professional standards and on the basis of their respective professional experience.
As all Supreme Audit Institutions have comparable tasks, peer review procedures can provide a very valuable contribution to improving audit bodies.
In the course of the preparation of the peer review procedure, the Court carried out a self-assessment in 2006, in which the institution was given the opportunity to examine its strengths and weaknesses.
In 2007, the Court adopted an action plan to address the weaknesses identified.
The plan comprised a total of 23 measures, of which six were the subject of task forces involving the Court's members and staff from different fields and hierarchy levels of the institution: 31 1. Mission statement, mission, strategic objectives, and planning 2. Governance structure (managing), structure and organisation 3. Internal performance indicators 4. Employees and internal communication 5. External stakeholders and communication approaches, external communication strategy 6. Improving reporting quality The results of these task forces presented in 2007 included new declarations of mission, mission statement and values, and strategic objectives for the Court, a new strategy and guidelines for internal communication, and a report on ways to improve reporting quality. The peer review process started at the end of 2007.
QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE IMPROVEMENT OF AUDIT A number of the strategic objectives adopted concern the output of the institution.
The Court strives to make the impact of its audits more visible by the selection of relevant topics, the closeness to time, and the clearer and more reader-friendly design of its reports.
It has also started to increase the number of its impact assessments and to improve their quality.
In 2007, considerable efforts were made to further develop the methodological basis of the Court's work as a vital prerequisite for high-quality audit work.
A new manual for accounting and compliance audits was developed with a high workload and is due to be completed in 2008.
The Court's new audit manual was adopted at the end of 2006 and was thus available for the first time to examiners in 2007.
Additional guidelines were developed and several seminars and training sessions were held to further improve the quality of the Court's work on the audit.
The Court also set new ambitious objectives for the use of information technologies.
In the new IT strategy adopted in 2007, the Court intends to increase its capacity to carry out IT audits and to make the use of computer-aided audit techniques (CAATs) to make auditing accounting and accounting auditing common practice.
It is important that the amount and quality of the output of the farm can be properly assessed.
The Court is in the process of developing performance indicators that should allow it to provide a wide range of performance data in future annual activity reports.
For the future, the Court plans to develop a methodology to assess the cost-effectiveness of the institution. 32
33 30th anniversary of the Court In 2007, the European Court of Auditors celebrated its 30th anniversary as an external audit body of the European Union.
The celebrations began with an increased presence of the Court (seminars, information stands, etc.) in most capitals of the European Union in the context of the activities of the 2007 European Day.
On 17 October 2007, an exhibition was also opened entitled "30 years of Court of Auditors", which included a series of thematic display panels, a sound exhibition with more than 150 photos and video excerpts, and numerous documents.
The Luxembourg central bank issued a silver commemorative coin on this occasion.
On 18 October 2007, the European Court of Auditors organised a seminar entitled ‘The Future of Public Financial Control in the EU' in which a number of high-level experts from EU circles and the institution's executives took part.
IMPROVING UNAUDITIONAL ASPECTS AT THE HOF Many of the tasks set out in the Action Plan relate to communication, to which greater efforts were devoted in 2007.
Among other things, a new website was put into operation and information material was published on the annual report in a more accessible format and the Court approved a new procedure for presenting its special reports to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control.
Other developments, mostly directly or partly related to the Action Plan, related to the modernisation of the Court's accounting system and new staff and IT policy documents.
The Court also started to modernise its information systems in the areas of audit, translation, knowledge and communication, management information and personnel.
In addition, in 2007 the Court made progress in preparing for a second extension of its main building, which is necessary in view of the recent and planned increase in staff.

The annual report for the financial year 2007 will be broken down into categories of policy areas largely but not entirely in line with the new headings of the financial framework.

36 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION COOPERATION WITH THE EU's NATIONAL INSTITUTIONS IN ACCOUNTS According to the EC Treaty, the European Court of Auditors has carried out its audit in the EU's ‘Liaison with the Member States' Supreme Audit Authorities (ORCBs), while the Treaty of Amsterdam has subsequently added: ‘The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies, while respecting their independence, are working together with confidence.' The Treaty of Nice added to this regulation by explicitly inviting the Court of Auditors, in the 18th Declaration of the Final Act, to establish a Committee of Contacts with the national audit bodies in which all the Presidents of the SAIs and the Court meet each year to discuss matters of common interest.
The ongoing contacts are maintained by liaison officers appointed by the individual SAIs.
Working groups have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices.
In 2007, a delegation from the Court attended the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the European Union SAIs in Helsinki, hosted by the Finnish Court of Auditors on 3 and 4 December.
The meeting focused on risk management, acceptable risk and integrated internal control system for management of EU funds, and discussed the role of SAIs in this area.
The Court will host the next meeting of the Contact Committee on 1 and 2 December 2008.
Two liaison officers meetings were held in 2007 in preparation for the Contact Committee meeting.
The first meeting was held in The Hague on 23 and 24 April and the second was held in Luxembourg on 11 and 12 October under the chairmanship of the European Court of Auditors.
Both meetings discussed recent developments in EU financial management and discussed the work of the Task Force "Cooperation" dealing with the Contact Committee itself, its way of working and its possibilities for improvement, and in this context proposals were put forward for a more efficient way of working.
The meeting also dealt with the activities of the various working and expert groups set up by the Contact Committee to deal with specific issues of common interest.
The Court took part in meetings of the network of candidate countries and candidate countries "in spe" (Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Turkey).
The Presidents of the SAIs of the candidate countries and candidate countries "in spe and the European Court of Auditors met in Skopje (former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia) on 11 and 12 June 2007.
An important aspect of all efforts to improve practical cooperation in the audit of EU funds concerns the audit principles used.
Against this background, in 2006 the Contact Committee decided to set up a working group chaired by one of the members of the Court, Mr Josef Bonnici, who "should develop common audit standards and comparable audit standards based on the internationally recognised audit principles and adapted to the EU context."
The first meetings of the European Court of Auditors were held in Luxembourg in 2007.
In December 2007, a progress report was submitted to the Helsinki Contact Committee to the working group and a resolution was adopted.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international audit principles through its membership in European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, namely Eurosai and Intosai.
Within the framework of the Eurosai, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and in the IT Working Group and participates in the Eurosai Training Committee.
The Court hosted a seminar on "Analysis of SAI problems in Luxembourg on 17 and 18 April 2007 and a seminar on "Business Audit – Where do we stand?" from 4 to 6 December 2007.
Since the Court became a full member of the Intosai in 2004, he has been actively involved in the Subcommittee for Guidelines for Auditing Accounting (FAS), the Subcommittee for Auditing Compliance with Legal Standards (CAS) and the Subcommittee for Economic Audits (PAS).
The Court participated in all FAS meetings held in 2007 and provided active contributions to the published and treated guidelines.
The FAS designated the ERH representative (Mr Jesús Lázaro Cuenca) as one of the FAS representatives for the project of the Steering Committee of the Committee for Technical Standards on Quality of Examination. The Court also took part in the CAS meeting in January 2007 in New Delhi.
The Court's Translation Directorate also provided resources for the linguistic revision of a document in Spanish and German.
In addition, the Court took part in the XIX Intosai Congress (Incosai) in Mexico from 5 to 10 November 2007, which discussed two main topics: "Indebtedness, administration, accountability and audit", and "Evaluation systems of economic efficiency in the light of generally accepted key indicators – targets and performance indicators."
In 2008, the Court will continue its active participation in the working groups, seminars and meetings of Eurosai and Intosai.

The visits are generally for central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as for their final beneficiaries.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners and the length of an audit trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of audit and the distance.
In 2007, travel expenses related to audit trips amounted to EUR 0.49 million (compared to EUR 0.43 million in 2006).
This represents a significant investment to ensure a sufficient audit coverage of all levels and locations of EU funds management.

Where the language skills of the team members were insufficient, translators from the language service of the Court provided assistance.

Other audit authorities have also shown interest in the audit, as it provides suggestions and know-how, for example, for an upcoming audit on a similar subject in the Baltic Sea countries.

SERVICE INTERNE REVISION The Internal Audit Service of the Court is designed to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives through the systematic, methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
The Internal Audit Service also makes proposals to increase the efficiency of the Court.
In general it is a question of assessing the performance of individual departments in the implementation of strategies, programmes and measures, with the aim of continuous improvement.
In 2007, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused on the audit of the Court's accounts (including support for the work of the Court's external auditor), the audit of the Court's ex ante audit, the implementation of internal control standards, the Court's recent expansion of the Court's work (the so-called K2 building) and the Court's recruitment procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee, consisting of three members of the Court and one external expert, shall monitor the work of the Internal Auditor and shall ensure the independence of the Court.
It shall also examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and entrust them, where necessary, with specific audit tasks.
The Committee met eight times in 2007.

PREFACE OF THE PRESIDENT The Court of Auditors as an independent audit body of the EU makes a unique contribution to improving EU financial management and to promoting transparency and accountability by providing audit services and providing a role model.
The Court had a significant number of significant progress and important developments in EU financial management in 2008, as detailed in this Annual Activity Report.
The European Court of Auditors' peer review of the Court of Auditors was a defining event, which led to a positive conclusion as to the usefulness of the Court's audit management framework, and the independence and objectivity of the Court's work.
In its annual report on the 2007 financial year published in November 2008, the Court for the first time issued a full audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's accounts.
As in previous years, however, he found too high a quota of errors in legality and regularity in the areas of the EU budget, which account for most of the expenditure.
In 2008, the Court also recognised the developments initiated at EU and national level, which are likely to lead to significant improvements in EU financial management in the future.
Two examples mentioned in this Annual Activity Report concern the ongoing process of reviewing the EU budget to which the Court has made an active contribution and the Commission's communication on the tolerable risk of error.
In the field of international relations, the Court took the lead in the organisation of the deliberations of the European Union's European Union's Chief Audit Institutions' Contact Committee on the EU budget reform and the revised Lisbon Strategy and the hosting role of a recent workshop on the role of the EU's ORC in the context of the measures taken to address the current financial crisis.
As its audit environment is undergoing rapid change, the Court is encouraged to adapt through internal reforms in order to better fulfil its obligations under the Treaty and to fulfil its mandate effectively.
A significant step taken by the Court in 2008 to implement its mission and mission was the development of an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012.
The audit strategy is based on two priority objectives: to maximise the overall impact of the audit and to improve efficiency by maximising the use of resources.
These objectives will be crucial to the Court's work programmes over that period and to its efforts to continually improve and exploit the main challenges and opportunities identified in the peer review process in terms of exploiting potential for improvement.
Thanks to its competence and commitment, the Court's staff have a central role to play in carrying out the audit work carried out by the Court as an independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens in order to improve financial management.
On behalf of the Court and on my own behalf, I would like to thank all the staff for all their dedication and professional work in the past year.
Special thanks are due to our former Secretary-General, Mr Michel Hervé, who resigned at the end of 2008.
I wish you a pleasant reading of this Annual Activity Report, which provides an insight into the Court and an overview of the activities carried out in 2008.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
PROCUREMENT, GUIDELINE AND VALUES PROCUREMENT The European Court of Auditors is, in accordance with the Treaty, responsible for the audit of EU finances.
GUIDELINE An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact of its work, and providing valuable support to its addressees to improve EU financial management.
VALUE Independence, integrity and impartiality Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and its employees.
Professionalism Respect a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Added value Creation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on well-founded findings and evidence, reflecting the interests of its addressees, and containing important and trend-setting statements.
Excellence and efficiency Acknowledgment of the value of the individual, support in further developing special skills and reward of performance.
ROLE AND WORK OF THE HOF THE HOF'S WORK IS THE EU'S BUDGET The European Union's budget amounts to about EUR 120 billion, representing about 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of the 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in the financing of public activities, in line with the overall budget of some Member States.
The revenue of the European Union consists mainly of contributions from Member States derived from their gross national income (GNI – 65.4%) or from VAT collected by the Member States (VAT – 16.9%).
Customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources – 16,5%) also constitute a substantial part of revenue.
The composition of the budget has changed over time, with agricultural and cohesion policy the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
BOX 1 ས HOW DOES THE EU PLAY OUT THEIR DEALERS?
The EU budget is financed by the financial contributions of the Member States (mainly on the basis of national GNI) and by customs duties and agricultural duties.
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than national budget purposes, partly due to different areas of responsibility.
For example, the Union is not responsible for the social security systems, which usually represent a substantial part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which, as a rule, takes the form of payments to farmers throughout the Union, has been the main component of budgetary expenditure, although at present with a decreasing trend.
In 2009, 45.3% of the budget for the conservation and management of the natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development, is earmarked.
Since the 1980s, a significant proportion of the expenditure on cohesion measures, i.e. regional and social development, has been spent on co-financing a wide range of projects, from road construction projects in Poland to training measures for the unemployed in Spain.
For 2009, expenditure on sustainable growth of 39.6% of the budget is foreseen, of which the lion's share is cohesion.
This budget also covers the bulk of the EU's research resources.
In addition, EU funds will be directed to development aid and humanitarian aid, as well as to countries that have close relations with the Union or are candidate countries.
6.7% of the budget is spent on the management of the Community institutions.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice The European Union as a global player Administration Agriculture – preserving and managing natural resources 45.3% 1.2 % 7.2 % 6.7% EU expenditure Cohesion – sustainable growth Source: European Union general budget for the financial year 2009 (OJ L 69, 13.3.2009). 39.6%
The budget is established annually by the Council, i.e. by representatives of the Member States, and the directly elected European Parliament, on a proposal from the European Commission, on the basis of a seven-year financial framework.
The Commission shall draw up the budget and shall also be responsible for its implementation.
The bulk of the budget, particularly in the area of expenditure on agricultural and cohesion policy, is implemented in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on the beneficiaries' own applications, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 8
Democratic societies need complete and accurate publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making with a view to improving financial management as well as ensuring accountability.
The EU, like its Member States, has an external audit body, which has the role of independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens.
In its role as external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that the EU funds, regardless of their place of use, have been correctly entered and spent in accordance with the legislation, taking due account of the optimum use of funds.
The Court's audit work will be used by Parliament, the Council and the Commission and by the Member States to improve EU financial management.
The Court's work forms an important basis for the annual discharge procedure, during which Parliament, on the basis of Council recommendations, decides whether the Commission's responsibility for implementation of the budget during the previous year has been fulfilled.
Despite its name, the Court has no judicial powers.
In the areas of shared management, Member States shall cooperate with the Commission in the establishment of monitoring and control systems, i.e. internal control, in order to ensure the proper use of funds.
Internal control thus has a European as well as a national dimension.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities examine EU funds, provided they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
9 OVERVIEW OF INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROL OF THE EU BUDGET EU level Internal control External control Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) European Court of Auditors Member States Implementing Bodies National control authorities National level
(Economic Audit) HOW does the Court report on its findings?
The Court shall publish the results of its audit work in the following types of report: annual reports, with the results of the audit of the accounts in the form of a statement of assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and on activities in the framework of the European Development Funds3.
Special annual reports – with the results of the audit of the accounts of the agencies and bodies of the Communities.
Special reports – with the results of selected economic and compliance audits.
10 1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
2 Under the EC Treaty, the Court is obliged to make such a statement, or a judgment, on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
In this context, the underlying transactions are, as a rule, payments to the final beneficiaries to the EU budget.
The annual Statement of Assurance is generally known under the French acronym DAS (Déclaration d'Assurance).
Unlike practice in the Member States, the Court makes such a statement on the EU budget as a whole.
3 The European Development Funds (EDF) are based on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States)
The Court shall carry out its audit of the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with International Audit Principles (ISAs) which shall apply in both the public and the private sectors.
However, the existing international auditing principles do not fully cover the Court's compliance audit.
The Court, together with the national control authorities, actively participates in the further development of international audit standards, promoted by the standardisation bodies (INTOSAI, IFAC)4.
In order to ensure that the payments comply with the legal and framework rules, the Court is based on the results of both its study of monitoring and control systems to prevent or to detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and of a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
If systems are reviewed and found to be reliable, the number of operations to be audited by the Court will be reduced in order to reach a sound conclusion as to their legality and regularity.
Other sources, such as the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In the case of the audit, the Court uses a wide range of audit methods to assess the management and monitoring systems and to assess the performance data on the basis of the criteria derived from the legislation in the light of the principles of sound financial management.
When selecting issues for its economic impact assessments, the Court is seeking to identify audit areas where the greatest impact is to be expected, in the form of the potential for improvement in terms of the economy, economic efficiency and efficiency of EU expenditure. 11 has been concluded, as well as decisions of the Council on the association of overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see external relations, development and enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries.
The EDF investment facilities are managed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and are not subject to the Court's audit mandate.
4 INTOSAI (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions – IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) International Association of Accountants.
12 BOX 2  However, the Court's Court's responsibilities in respect of the EU's budget's payments are in no way the way in which the Court's resources are available to examine in detail all operations financed by the EU's budget.
In the context of the preparation of the DAS, it therefore uses statistical sampling methods to obtain a result representative of the population as a whole.
The sample shall be selected by randomly selecting a representative sample of the underlying transactions from all areas of the Union budget, such as agriculture, for a detailed examination.
The Court monitors these transactions until the final beneficiary of the aid, such as a farmer in France.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks – e.g. measuring the size of the agricultural area – to determine whether the relevant information in the application for support corresponds to the actual circumstances.
By referring to a statistical sample, the results can be extrapolated to the relevant population, i.e. a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and can be used as a basis for an overall audit opinion, together with information resulting from the system assessment.
In practice, in order to determine how the audit opinion is to be found, the Court compares the results of its statistical sample audits with a certain upper limit, which it considers to be acceptable, the so-called materiality threshold.

THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS OF AUDITORS AND ORGANISATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State.
All audit reports and opinions shall be adopted by the College.
The Court is divided into five audit groups to which individual members are assigned.
As the organisational chart (see page 17) shows, there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (preserving and managing natural resources – structural policies, transport, research and energy – external policies – revenue, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for "horizontal issues such as coordination in the field of statement of assurance, quality assurance, the development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a Management Committee shall be responsible for the preparatory treatment of all administrative matters requiring a formal decision of the Court.
MEMBERS The members of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a term of six years in accordance with the proposals of each Member State, and shall be eligible for re-election.
Members shall perform their duties in full independence for the general good of the European Union.
In addition to its role within the College, which is responsible for the final decision-making on audits and opinions, as well as for further strategic and administrative issues, each member is responsible for his or her specific tasks primarily in the audit area.
The actual examination work is usually the task of the examiners in the individual examination papers and is coordinated by the relevant member with the support of his cabinet.
The Member shall then present the report to the Audit Group or to the Court and, after its adoption, to the European Parliament, the Council and to other interested third parties.
On 1 January 2008, three new members – Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Harald Noack (Germany) and Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) – replaced their respective predecessors at the end of their term of office.
The Council also extended the mandate of four members – Mr Hubert Weber (Austria), Mr Maarten B. Engwirda (Netherlands), Mr David Bostock (United Kingdom) and Mr Ioannis Sarmas (Greece) – for a period of six years.
THE PRESIDENT The President of the European Court of Auditors will be headed by the President of the European Court of Auditors, who will be elected by the members of the European Court of Auditors for a period of three years, and will be eligible for re-election.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in its relations with the discharge authority, the other institutions of the European Union and with the supreme audit authorities of the Member States and beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, the Portuguese member, Mr. Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, was elected the tenth President of the Court. 14
THE GENERAL SECRETARY The Secretary-General is the institution's senior staff and is appointed by the Court for a period of six years; he may be re-elected.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the management of the Court's personnel and the management of the Court's personnel, including vocational training and the Directorate of Translation, each with one unit per official language (22), with the exception of Irish.
The Secretary-General shall also be responsible for the Court's secretariat.
The former Secretary General, Mr Michel Hervé, left the Court on 31 October 2008.
On 9 October 2008, Mr John Speed was appointed Secretary General m.d.W.d.G.b.
On 10 March 2009, the Court appointed Mr Eduardo Ruiz García as new Secretary-General with effect from 16 March 2009. THE HOFE'S PERSONAL PERSONALITY The budget for the financial year 2008 provides for 858 posts for the European Court of Auditors (as at 31 December 2008).
The Court's auditors have broad training profiles and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the fields of accounting, financial management, internal and external auditing and the legal and economic sciences.
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States, subject to the EU Staff Regulations.

OVERVIEW OF AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS5 ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2007 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET The annual accounts give a true picture of the financial situation as well as the results of the EU as a whole.
The restrictions set out in last year's annual report on the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2006 are no longer valid due to the improvements that have been made for 2007.
In some areas, such as Union administrative expenditure, the Court gives full audit opinions on the legality and regularity of the Court.
However, the Court cannot give an unqualified opinion on most areas of expenditure.
Although most of the Court's audited payments have been made in accordance with the legislation, the Court still considers the error rate in the payments made to final beneficiaries, such as farmers and beneficiaries of EU funded projects, to be too high.
With the exception of cohesion measures with an error rate of at least 11%, the Court estimates the error rate in these themes in the range of 2% to 5%.
In some areas of expenditure, particularly those formerly covered by internal and external policies, the estimated error rate has fallen, but has not been so large that it would change the overall picture.
The result does not imply that these violations of legislation are due to fraud or that most of these transactions are illegal and/or illegal.
THE SITUATION IN CERTAIN AREAS In three areas – administrative and other expenditure, economic and financial expenditure and revenue – the Court's audits of representative samples of operations have revealed low estimated error rates.
In the Union's largest expenditure area – agriculture and natural resources – the estimated overall error rate remains significant.
Rural development, which is often complex, accounts for a disproportionate proportion of this error rate.
For the expenditure of the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the level of the error rate estimated by the Court is just below the materiality threshold of 2 %.
As in previous years, cohesion measures, which account for more than one-third of the budget, are the most flawed.
In view of the random estimate made by the Court of the proportion of the error made, at least 11 % of the total amount of the refunds should not have been made.
5 This section is intended to introduce the Court's reports and opinions to the Court and to the Court's summary of the content of the Court's opinions.
For more information, see the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
19 WAGES TO IMPROVE SUPERVISION AND CONTROL The high error rate in areas such as cohesion is partly due to the inherent risk caused by the high number of beneficiaries applying for EU funding under complex rules and legislation.
The shortcomings in the design and functioning of the systems also contribute to the inadequacies identified.
Most programmes financed by EU funds contain provisions on corrective measures which provide for the recovery of funds unduly paid out on a multiannual basis due to errors.
However, no information is available on the impact of these measures.
This means that it is not possible to determine in concrete terms whether they effectively reduce the proportion of illegal and/or illegal expenditure.
The Commission has been working since 2000 on a reform programme to improve the management of the EU budget, which includes an action plan from 2006.
By the end of 2007, the Commission had implemented two thirds of the sub-measures of the Action Plan.
However, it is too early to assess the impact of these measures.
Improved high-level controls, such as the Commission's monitoring of Member States' control activities, do not compensate for inadequate controls at a lower level, such as on-the-spot checks.
However, the benefits arising from increased on-the-spot checks must be weighed against the costs.
The Court recommends that the Union's political authorities define the appropriate level of risk of error.
To reduce the error rate in EU payments, the Court recommends simplifying rules and legislation, streamlining internal control measures and improving monitoring and reporting.

The selection of topics and their design is at the discretion of the Court and is based on criteria such as risk analysis, potential for improvement and public interest.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2008 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management by delivering opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the adoption procedure of financial rules7 or may be delivered at the request of one of the other institutions of the Community8.
The Court may also submit opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions may address issues relating to certain areas of EU expenditure, such as the amendment of the Financial Regulation of the European Aviation Safety Agency (No 1/2008), or to EU revenue, such as the amendment to the Regulation on the Community's own resources system (No 2/2008).
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise in EU financial management over the years in the course of its audits and in some cases reference is made to some audits or opinions.
For example, in its opinion on the new financial regulation of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor), the Court refers to its annual report on the financial year 2006, in which it had already drawn attention to high risks regarding the legality and regularity of the payments for research aid.
