CONTINUING AND EFFECTIVENESS Public financial control plays a key role in promoting accountability and contributes to public debate.
The audit activities will be held accountable to the recipients at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, whether their taxpayers' money will be spent in a proper and appropriate manner.
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned – in the European context, in particular, the Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States.
On the basis of this information, they may take measures, with or without reference to the examination conclusions.
Although the Court's audit activity has its main effect on the published reports, it has its own effect during the entire course of the audit.
In the replies the audited body often acknowledges the problems detected by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them.
After completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the audit results will be evaluated and used by the Parliament and the Council to carry out their policy role of monitoring the use of the budget.
The Court's reports form the basis for the Council's recommendation and the Parliament's decision in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
29 Examples of this can be found in the 2007 discharge procedure, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to make efforts to simplify and further clarify the rules to reduce the risk of errors, streamline controls and reduce costs.
This applies to areas of shared management, such as agricultural and cohesion spending, as well as to areas of direct management, such as research and culture and education spending.
The special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, due to the fact that they will be published during the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on that have usually taken place at an earlier stage in the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
The impact of audit reports can be enhanced by their thematicisation in the relevant media, which will raise awareness and stimulate public debate.
As a rule, media coverage of the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive, but some special reports have also been followed with interest by the press.
One example is the special report on cross compliance (No 8/2008), which is currently being issued on the approval of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) health check.
Because of the importance of cross-compliance and its central role in the CAP and the timing of its publication, the report received a broad response in the various media: television, newspapers, specialised newspapers, Internet publications (press, agricultural associations, MEP websites, web blogs, etc.).
The report was also discussed in detail in the European Parliament and almost all the Court's recommendations were taken up in the draft discharge report.
Further details on the follow-up to the Court's previous observations are given in the respective chapters of its annual report.
The Court's most frequently commented in its last annual report is that, despite the measures taken, the deficiencies identified in the previous year have only been partially remedied.
The Court's intention is to analyse to an increasing extent the long-term impact of its work – both audits and opinions.
As an example, the Court uses a Commission database of follow-up to its audit recommendations as a basis for assessing the impact of its audits.
The assessment may lead to separate in-depth audits leading to further findings and recommendations.
These may be incorporated into a subsequent special report on the area concerned or may be included in a report on the follow-up and impact of recommendations on financial management.
The Court held in its Opinion No 2/2004 that, in the context of the development of a Community internal control framework, it was the responsibility of the political authorities to decide on the level of risk that they were willing to accept when approving EU spending rules.
The Court proposed that Parliament and the Council agree on an appropriate balance between the costs and benefits of controls, in other words the tolerable residual risk of expenditure errors.
The costs of controls should be proportionate to the benefits they have of monetary and political benefits.
Since the publication of this opinion, both the European Parliament and the Council, in their discharge resolutions, have expressed their desire to pursue the issue and to achieve a common understanding of the tolerable level of risk.
At the end of 2008, the Commission issued a Communication entitled Towards a common understanding of the concept of tolerant risk of error.
The Court welcomed this communication and sent the Commission a response which highlighted certain limits and highlighted the main issues to be considered in the future follow-up to this issue.
In its Communication, the Commission states that any decision on a tolerable risk of error should, inter alia, be based on the potential for further simplification.
The Court also stresses the importance and benefits of further simplification and the potential impact on the reduction of errors and irregularities.
The concept of "tolerable risk of error" must be clearly separated from the concept of the materiality threshold as defined and applied by the Court, the latter being the responsibility of the external auditor10.
The Court considers that the cost-benefit analysis of expenditure programmes could provide information not only for discussions on the tolerable risk, but also for the review of the regulatory framework and the management structure of the programmes concerned.
In this context, the relevant question may not be whether there is a tolerable risk of error, but whether the risk of error is so high that the relevant scheme or programme should be abolished or substantially modified.
The concept of tolerable risk should also be addressed in the design of expenditure (and revenue) schemes or programmes.
It would be useful if, at the time of adoption, sufficient information on the risks involved, as well as the costs of the controls planned, were available on expenditure programmes to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.
In this way decisions would be taken in the knowledge of the facts and taking explicit account of the risks and costs involved.
The budgetary reform process may provide an opportunity to reflect on this issue, as suggested by the Court in its response to the Commission communication entitled ‘Reforming the budget, changing Europe'11.
31 10 The concept of ‘essentiality' is defined in the international audit principle ISA 320 as follows: ‘Information is essential if its omission or incorrect presentation could influence the economic decisions made by the final recipients on the basis of a financial statement.
Materiality depends on the size of the item or the defect resulting from the particular circumstances of omission or incorrect representation.
Thus the materiality is more a threshold or a threshold and less a primary qualitative requirement, which must have information to be useful to it.. to 11 See the European Court of Auditors' response to the Commission's communication "Reforming the budget, changing Europe", April 2008.
The Court shall present its future audit work every year in a work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and made available to the public on the Court's website.

ASSESSMENT STRATEGY The audit strategy is based on the Court's strategic objectives.
33 STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES Professionalism Output Scope of contacts Development and growth Consolidated audit methods, appropriate audit strategy, further development of audit practices in the public sector, development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards of EU funds, cooperation with the EU-ORCB, effective "Community control framework", selection of relevant audit topics, timeliness, clarity and legibility of reports, quality of economic evaluations, increasing the impact of reports Deeper relations with the audited bodies, in order to provide a better understanding of the audit process, and to achieve a wider acceptance of audit results, increasing contacts with the European Parliament and Council as budgetary and discharge authority Effective communication with EU citizens Use the experience of peer-reviewed practices in order to strengthen and further develop the organisation, methods, procedures and results and achieve maximum efficiency of monitoring of effective and dynamic personnel policy High-quality professional training; modernising infrastructure Implementation of IT strategies Zielele of the audit strategy 2009-2012 Maximising the impact achieved with the audits, overall efficiency through the best possible use of resources
The Court's audits and reports aim to help improve EU financial management and protect the EU's financial interests to the benefit of EU citizens.
The following key aspects are taken into account when formulating the strategy which is relevant to the Court's activities: EFFICIENCY REPORTS Review activity Work programme In 2008 the Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 for the implementation of its mission and mission statement.
A summary of this document is available on the Court's website.
The Court's strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of the audits and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a key impact on the Court's work programmes over the same period and on its work towards continuous improvement.
The Court aims to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the period concerned by: • selecting and designing audits focusing on issues of high risk and of greatest interest to the Court's audience; • continuing to provide sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement, and to monitor whether these proposals are being implemented; • carrying out a broader range of audits and presenting new types of audit products to complement the current annual and special reports; • preparing a larger number of special reports and improving the timeliness and ease of use of these reports; • improving its relations with its main users, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public; and the Court aims at improving the efficiency of the period concerned by making the best use of its resources.
These include: • better management; • an effective and dynamic staff policy; • rationalisation of audit tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • development of expertise; • development of relations with audited bodies. 34
AUDIT WORK TO BE BE AUDITED IN 200912 As in previous years, the 2009 work programme includes the preparation of annual reports setting out the results of the audit of the accounts to be carried out by the Court in accordance with the EC Treaty and other EU legislation.
For 2009, the Court has identified a number of audit issues relating to policy developments and issues relating to EU financial management.
As regards developments in EU policy areas, the following topics have been selected: • growth and jobs; • climate change and sustainable development; • Europe as a global partner; • better regulation.
In addition, the Court places particular emphasis on the following issues in the area of EU financial management, which it believes deserve particular attention: • the completion of the expenditure programmes for the period 2000-2006, in particular in the area of the Structural Funds; • the accountability and reform of the EU; • the progress of the Commission's action plan for an Integrated Internal Control Framework, taking into account the concept of tolerable risk; • management and control measures at Member State level.
The Court's aim is to address these issues from 2009 onwards in the context of its annual reports, special reports and some of the new types of reports (see the following).
The Court intends to publish a series of special reports and related novel reports, drawn up on the basis of the audit tasks it has selected.
The planning and implementation of these selected audit tasks and the reporting of these tasks generally cover a period of more than one year.
As a result, most reports published in a given year are based on audit work undertaken in previous years.
Box 5 contains the selected audit tasks that are completed or are pending completion and their results are therefore expected to be published in special reports in 2009 or early 2010.
35 12 A more complete and detailed overview of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2009 work programme, which is available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
Follow-up to the recommendations is an important tool for the Court to actively contribute to improving financial management.
The report will include an analysis of the extent to which our recommendations have been complied with, and, where appropriate, an assessment of the effectiveness of the measures taken.
It is expected to be published at approximately the same time as the annual report. — The other new type of report the Court intends to present is a report on high-risk areas of EU financial management.
The report is aimed at the new Commission, which will start its work at the end of the year, and will serve as a guidance tool.
DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF ACTION PLAN AND ACQUISITIONS In 2006, the Court carried out a self-assessment of its strengths and weaknesses.
An action plan has subsequently been drawn up to address the weaknesses.
The Action Plan included a number of measures which led the Court to: • define its mission, mission, strategic objectives and strategic planning; • develop internal performance indicators which are gradually introduced (see section below); • adopt an internal communication strategy, which is already being implemented and has opened up new channels for the better dissemination of information within the institution; • take a number of measures to improve the quality of its reports, including a new graphic design for the improvement of readability and external evaluations; • adopt a strategy to gradually implement which is to improve the Court's relations with its addressees, the press and the general public.
As part of its efforts to improve, in 2009 the Court will seek to address the observations and recommendations of the International Peer Review Report on the European Court of Auditors, published in December 2008, which is an important stage in the Court's ongoing reform process.
The peer review was carried out by representatives of the national control authorities of Canada, Norway, Austria and Portugal.
The peers carried out their work in 2008 and in this context also contacted the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control. The final report was presented at the end of 2008.
The peer review procedure was aimed at assessing the design and functioning of the Court's framework for the audits. The Court of Auditors and the Court of Auditors of the Court of Auditors of the Court of Auditors of the Court of Auditors and the Court of Auditors of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities and of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities of the European Communities
The audit covered the following areas: • planning and audit procedures for audit of accounts and audit of accounts; • reporting on audit results; • services supporting the Court in achieving its objectives.
The peer review team concluded that the design of the audit framework set by the Court is in line with international audit principles and good practice for the audit authorities.
In addition, the peers noted that • the Court performs its activities independently and objectively; • the Court's audit reports were based on sufficient and adequate audit evidence, as provided for in the international audit principles; • the persons questioned had high confidence in the Court's reports and generally considered them fair, objective and objective.
The Court welcomes the constructive comments and recommendations made by the peers to identify the possibilities to further strengthen their role as the Supreme Audit Authority and to highlight the challenges involved.
This includes, among other things, the need to • develop a culture that focuses on a consistent approach of the Court as an audit body; • strengthen quality assurance and quality control activities to ensure consistent interpretation and application of its audit strategies and methods; • develop risk-based audit strategies to ensure the best use of resources in view of the different needs of the users.
The peer review report acknowledges that most of the recommendations have already been anticipated under the Action Plan drawn up before the procedure.
The Court intends to include the other recommendations in its audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 following an exchange with its staff and addressees and will endeavour to implement them during that period.

CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS In 2008, the Court decided to set up a system of key performance indicators (CLIs) for its audit and non-audit activities in order to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and objectives specified in the Annual Work Programme.
ZLI aims to strengthen internal and external accountability and to improve work efficiency and quality. ZLI will be gradually introduced in 2009 and 2010.
• To inform management of the success of the Court as an institution in implementing what it has undertaken; • To support the decision-making process by focusing the institution's attention on efficiency issues and promoting improvements; • To provide the addressee with information on relevant aspects of the Court's performance.
They are intended to provide information on the performance of the Court as "company" and become an integral part of the Court's management system.
The volume and quality of audit work can also be improved by considering the effects of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They will be developed with a view to their inclusion in the Court's annual work programme for 2010.
The Court has measured the performance in 2008 on the basis of the ZLI 5 and 6.
ZLI 5 – Number of reports adopted compared with the number of reports planned In 2008, the Court adopted 79% of the planned number of reports.
The annual report and most of the special annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the 20 special reports planned, only twelve were adopted.
The remaining eight special reports were still in the drafting phase as at 31 December 2008.
ZLI 6 – Number of reports adopted on time In 2008, the Court adopted 73% of its reports on time.
The annual report and all specific annual reports were adopted on time, and further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of the special reports.
ZLI 7, which measures the number of key audit notifications which have been prepared on time, will provide useful performance information and will be prepared in 2009.
A CLI (8) covers aspects relating to the Court's financial management.
Two ZLI (9 and 10) are intended to help to improve staff satisfaction and to optimise the use of continuing vocational training as an instrument for the ongoing updating of the state of knowledge about the latest examination methods and techniques.

INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION COOPERATION WITH THE EU'S NATIONAL ACCOUNTING INSTITUTIONS Pursuant to the EC Treaty, the ERR has to carry out its audit in ‘in liaison with the Member States' Supreme Audit Authorities (ORCBs), while in the Treaty of Amsterdam it was later added: ‘The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies shall cooperate with the Member States in confidence while respecting their independence.' This arrangement has been extended in the Treaty of Nice by the fact that, in the 18th declaration of the Final Act, the Court of Auditors has been explicitly invited to establish a Committee for contacts with the national audit bodies in which the Presidents of the SAIs and the Court meet each year to discuss matters of common interest.
In December 2008, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the EU-ORKB.
The meeting focused on the reform of the EU budget and the revised Lisbon Strategy for the period 2008-2011.
The Contact Committee shall seek to strengthen cooperation among its members to improve external audit and accountability in the EU.
The role of the Contact Committee has developed over the years in parallel with European integration.
In addition to facilitating the exchange of information between the SAIs and the EAFRD, this body has made considerable progress in the effective cooperation between the various control authorities.
At its meeting in Helsinki in 2007, the Contact Committee recognised the need to tackle emerging or new issues in a timely manner and agreed to provide a permanent agenda item for the consideration of such current issues.
Accordingly, at its 2008 meeting, the Contact Committee discussed the economic and financial crisis and agreed to organise a workshop on the role of the EU at ORCB in the context of the crisis.
A network was then established to promote cooperation in audits in connection with the Lisbon Strategy and with EU crisis management measures.
The Court took part in meetings of the Network of SAIs of Candidate Countries and Candidate Countries ‘in spe the (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Montenegro).
These meetings were held at the same time as liaison officers' meetings in May and October.
A delegation from the Court also attended a workshop organised by the Network on 8 and 9 July in Ankara, Turkey, in order to examine and evaluate systems of internal control of public finances.
Throughout 2008, the Court actively participated in the various working groups set up by the Contact Committee.
The Working Group on Common Audit Standards, the objective of which is to develop common audit standards tailored to the EU environment and comparable audit standards based on internationally recognised audit standards, met four times in 2008 under the chairmanship of the Court.
With effect from December 2008, the Court took over the (rotating) chairmanship of the Working Group on Value Added Tax (VAT), and the Network of Experts on Agriculture resumed its work under the chairmanship of a member of the Court.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international auditing principles and procedures through its membership of European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, namely EUROSAI and INTOSAI.
A delegation from the Court attended the VII EUROSAI Congress, which took place in Krakow, Poland, from 2 to 5 June.
The main topics for discussion included the introduction of quality management systems for examination in a SAIs, the examination of social programmes in the field of training and the vocational integration of the disabled.
The President of the Court presented a contribution to the role of senior management in the implementation of a quality management system for auditing.
Within the framework of the EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and in the IT Working Group and participates in the EUROSAI Training Committee.
It also participates in the working group set up at the VII EUROSAI Congress to draw up a guide to best practice in achieving quality in an SAI.
In addition, the Court is a member of the EUROSAI Task Force on Disaster Aid Assessment. 42
At the EUROSAI Congress, the European Court of Auditors and the Supreme Audit Authority of the Slovak Republic were appointed auditors for the period 2009-2011.
Since becoming a full member of INTOSAI in 2004, the Court has actively participated in the Subcommittee for Guidelines for the Audit of Accounting (FAS), the Subcommittee for the Audit of Compliance with Legal Standards (CAS) and the Subcommittee for Economic Audits (PAS).
The Court contributed to the subcommittee to promote best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on the Accountability and Audit of Disaster Relief (successor of the INTOSAI Task Force Tsunami).
A first meeting of this working group was held by the Court as the host from 30 June to 2 July 2008.
The draft work programme for the period 2008-2010 was discussed and adopted at the meeting.
The main objective is to develop guidelines for accountability and audit in this area and to reach all stakeholders through the relevant standardisation body.
In addition to its coordinating role, the Court has assumed the responsibility for a number of tasks, two of them in cooperation with the Norwegian Court of Auditors.
The chair of this working group also requires the Court to be represented at the meetings of the INTOSAI Bureau. 43

They have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the output of the Court.
As a key performance indicator (ZLI 9) for human resources, the Court has set out the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's staff.
To this end, a satisfaction survey was conducted to provide information on this issue and to support the decision-making process in this area.

In 2008, the Court hired 97 employees: 48 officials, 18 temporary staff and 31 contract staff.
The recruitment depends on whether reserve lists of EPSO competitions are available.
Due to the lack of suitable applicants, the Court was not able to recruit as many new employees as planned in many of its units, so the total number of vacancies (69) was higher at the end of 2008 than at the end of 2007.
However, it should be noted that a significant number of recruitments were underway at the end of the year and that the employees concerned were expected to be in service in the first quarter of 2009.
The Court is currently seeking to reduce the time limits for its recruitment procedures.
TRANSLATION Translation is an important administrative task that enables the Court to achieve its communication objectives and to fulfil its legal obligation to publish in 22 languages.
The volume of translation increased by 17% in 2008, mainly due to the adoption of a higher number of special reports.
The vast majority of translations are done internally and translation assignments to the Translation Centre (CTOU) or to external translation agencies are carried out during peak times during which the normal capacity of the translation departments is exceeded.
In addition, translators participate in audit visits and support the auditors before, during and after audit visits, including the subsequent stages of the drafting of audit reports.
The translators shall provide constant support in the ongoing updating of the contents of the intranet and the website in the English and French languages.
They also support INTOSAI working groups and address other specific needs related to the Court's activities.
The Court's Translation Directorate actively participates in the work of the Interinstitutional Translation and Interpretation Committee (CITI), is a member of international committees and participates in international conferences relating to the development of electronic translation and documentation tools.
TEST TEST In the course of the Court's audit work, the auditors must travel to the Member States and to other recipient countries of EU funds in order to obtain adequate audit evidence.
The visits are generally conducted by central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as by the respective final beneficiaries.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the length of an audit trip may, depending on the type of audit and the distance, be up to two weeks.
Within the EU, the audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member State visited, providing useful logistical and practical support. 47
In 2008, costs of 3.29 million euros were incurred in connection with audit trips.
This substantial investment is necessary to ensure a sufficient audit coverage of all levels and locations of the management of EU funds.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training.
In 2008, the Court's staff completed on average ten days of professional training.
The number of technical training measures increased considerably compared to 2007.
In 2008, the Court reinforced its support for the participation of its staff in ongoing programmes for the acquisition or maintenance of professional qualifications and qualifications in the fields of external audit, internal audit and IT audit.
Language courses accounted for 48% of the total number of training days in 2008 (compared to 52% in 2007).
Without taking into account the language courses, the examiners completed seven days of professional training in 2008.
On the basis of the long-term strategic objective of "Development and Growth" and the 2008-2011 Curriculum of Training and the Training Paths adopted in 2008, the Vocational Training Unit has improved the content of the training and has developed new training courses in line with the priorities adopted by the Court.
In addition, cooperation with the other institutions and interinstitutional bodies, such as the European School of Administration, has been successfully continued.

However, the expenditure pattern was little targeted, and the monitoring and evaluation of the programme was not the basis for an assessment of the overall quality of the programme.
During the programme period, relatively high administrative costs (for the Commission, the Agency and the participants) were incurred, such as the amount paid to the participants during the same period.

Staff resources account for around 52% of the total budget in 2009.

4 PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT 4 Welcome to reading the annual activity report of the European Court of Auditors for 2009.
The aim of this report is to provide readers with an overview of the main results and progress made by the Court during this year and to provide them with information on the main developments in its audit environment and in its internal organisation.
2009 was an important year of renewal for the EU, characterised by the election of a new European Parliament, the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and the start of the process for selecting a new European Commission.
The new Treaty confirms the role and mandate of the Court and its status as an EU institution and introduces changes to the management and control of EU funds, strengthening the role of the European Parliament and underlining the responsibility of the Member States for the implementation of the budget.
The Court expects these developments to provide good opportunities to improve EU financial management.
The section entitled ‘The Court's position' provides a summary of our opinion on the risks and challenges the new Commission will face.
The quality of EU spending is being improved by being given a high priority.
During this year, we have made considerable progress in implementing our 2009-2012 audit strategy and on the way to achieving our goals, in order to increase the impact of our work and improve the use of our resources.
A decisive step was our decision to submit to the Council of the European Union a new Rules of Procedure for approval to streamline our procedures for the adoption of reports and opinions.
In addition, the number of reports prepared by the Court increased from 42 in 2008 to 57 in 2009.
I am also pleased to report that our core product, the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, once again received a positive welcome from our main institutional addressees, the many of our recommendations agreed.
During 2009, the Court continued its active cooperation with the Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCs) in order to develop common approaches to the audit of EU funds and to consider how the SAIs can help governments to deal with the financial and economic crisis.
The Court's achievements depend on the competence and motivation of its 880 employees.
Their satisfaction is a key factor in the success of the Court, and it is the first time that this report has been quantified.
I would like to thank the Court's staff for their tireless and dedicated work to enable the Court to carry out its mission.
6 6 PROCUREMENT, GUIDE, VALUES AND STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES PROCUREMENT GUIDE VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances, in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

8 ROLE AND WORK OF THE HOFE 8 AND OF THE WORK OF THE HOFE IS THE EU BUDGET The EU budget (2010) amounts to around EUR 123 billion, representing about 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in financing public activities, and the overall budget is considerable compared to the GNI of several Member States.
The European Union's revenue consists primarily of contributions of Member States derived from their gross national income (GNI – 76%), from customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources – 12%) and from a contribution based on VAT collected by Member States (VAT – 11%).
BOX 1 – WHAT IS THE EU ENTRYING OUT OF THE EU?
The EU budget is financed by financial contributions from the Member States (mainly on the basis of the national GNI), customs and agricultural duties and VAT contributions.
The EU budget is largely used for uses other than national budgets, partly due to the different areas of responsibility.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1, 1% Conservation and management of natural resources (mainly agriculture) 47,3% The EU's largest single spending area is agriculture and rural development, mainly in the form of payments to farmers, accounting for almost half of the budget expenditure.
Cohesion measures – regional and social development – which co-finance a wide range of projects, from road construction projects in Latvia to training for the unemployed in the Netherlands – are also a major part of the project.
This sector accounts for about one third of budgetary expenditure.
The European Union as a global player EU expenditure Source: European Union general budget for the financial year 2010. Administration 6.4% 6.3% Sustainable growth (mainly cohesion) 38.8%
The budget is established annually by the Council, i.e. by representatives of the Member States, and by the directly elected European Parliament, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework.
The European Commission shall draw up the budget and shall be responsible for its implementation.
The majority of the budget, in particular in the area of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure, is implemented in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on the beneficiaries' own applications, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 9
10 WHAT ROLE HAS THE HOF?
Democratic societies need correct, publicly accessible information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both for improving financial management and for ensuring accountability.
In its role as an external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds have been properly accounted for regardless of the place of use and spent in accordance with the relevant legislation and with due consideration of the requirement for optimum use of funds.
The Court's audit results are used by the Commission, Parliament and the Council, as well as by the Member States to improve EU financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities examine EU funds to the extent that they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
OVERVIEW OF INTERNATIONAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROLS OF EU BUDGET Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing Bodies European Court of Auditors National Control Authorities National Level Internal Control External Control
(ACCOUNT OF ACCOUNTS) 2. Are the financial operations in all essential respects in line with the relevant legal and other regulatory framework?
(COMPLIANCE TEST) 3. Is budget management sound, i.e. has the use of resources been kept to a minimum (sparability), has the results been achieved with the minimum possible use of resources (economic) and has the objectives achieved (effectiveness) been achieved?
The Court shall publish the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: annual reports – the results of the audit of the accounts in the form of a statement of assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and on the activities of the European Development Funds3.
Specific annual reports – with the results of the audit of the accounts of the Union's agencies and decentralised bodies.
11 1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
2 In accordance with the TFEU, the Court is obliged to make such a statement, or an audit opinion, on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual Statement of Assurance is generally known under the French acronym DAS (Déclaration donymy of Assurance).
12 HOW IS THE HOF PREPARED IN HIS TESTS?
The Court shall carry out its audit of the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with international audit principles in force in both the public and the private sectors.
However, the existing international auditing principles do not cover the Court's compliance audit.
The Court, together with national control authorities, actively participates in the further development of international auditing principles, driven by the standard-setting organisations (INTOSAI, IFAC)4.
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legal and other regulatory framework, the Court draws on the results of both its investigation of the monitoring and control systems to prevent, detect and rectify errors of legality and regularity and of a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Other sources, such as statements by the management of the audited bodies in the form of the annual activity reports of the Commission's Directors-General and the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In the case of economic audits, the Court uses a variety of audit methods to assess the management and monitoring systems and to assess performance data on the basis of the criteria derived from the legislation and on the basis of the principles of sound financial management.
When selecting subjects for its economic audits, the Court strives to identify areas of audit for which the greatest impact is to be expected, in terms of the potential to improve the economy, the economy and the effectiveness of EU expenditure, in terms of its potential for improvement.
3 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are based on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and on Council decisions on the association of overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries.
4 INTOSAI (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) – International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions; IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) – International Accountants Association.
BOX 2 – TESTING OF A SAMPLE OF PAYMENTS FROM THE EU BUDGET BY THE HOF 13 The Court does not have the necessary resources to verify in detail all the operations relating to the EU budget.
It therefore uses statistical sampling techniques to provide a representative result for the populations concerned.
The Court follows these processes up to the final beneficiary of the grant, for example a promoter in Italy.
Subsequently, the Court checks – often on the spot – whether the application complies with the actual circumstances.
As a representative sample, the results can be extrapolated to the relevant population, i.e. a specific revenue or expenditure area, to serve as the basis for an overall assessment assessment, together with information resulting from the assessment of management and control systems and other sources.

14 TASKS AND RESPONSIBILITIES5 14 RESPONSIBILITY AND ORGANISATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State. The members are appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a term of six years.
Members shall elect a President from among them for a period of three years, with the possibility of re-election as well.
Five audit groups to which individual members of the Court are assigned prepare the reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
The organization chart shows that there are four subject-related audit groups covering different budgetary areas and another audit group dealing with "horizontal" questions.
Furthermore, a Management Committee, composed of members of the Court, is responsible for preparing the Court's administrative decisions.
At the end of 2009, the Court sent the Council a proposal to amend its rules of procedure to allow certain categories of Court opinions and reports to be adopted instead of the entire College of Chambers.
These amendments will streamline and make the Court's decision-making more efficient by, inter alia, reducing the time taken to adopt decisions.
Each Chamber has two areas of competence: the first has the adoption of special reports, special annual reports and opinions, the second has the preparation of draft observations for the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds, and draft opinions for adoption by the College.
As with the Court, decisions are taken by a majority of the members of the Board.
Members may attend meetings of all chambers, but may vote only in the chamber to which they have been assigned by the Court.
Of course, the whole College will continue to meet to discuss and adopt the documents for which the Court is solely responsible, for example the annual reports on the EU's general budget and the European Development Funds.
The role of the Management Committee will be strengthened.
The Committee shall be composed of the President of the Court of the Presidency and the Doyens of the Chambers.
Administrative matters, the consideration of which requires a Court decision, and decisions on procedural, policy or strategic matters, shall be prepared by the Committee before being submitted to the Court for adoption.
The Member shall then present the report to the audit group and to the Court and, after the adoption of the report, shall also present it to the European Parliament, to the Council and to other interested third parties.
5 Further details are available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
THE HOFF'S PERSONNEL The budget for the financial year 2009 provides for 880 posts for the European Court of Auditors (as at 31 December 2009).
The Court's staff working in the audit area shall be responsible for the planning and execution of audits and the preparation of the resulting draft reports.
The auditors work in teams of different sizes: For some specific audits, a team includes four or five auditors, while some of the Court's wider audits (e.g. audits of the accounts/compliance audits in the area of agricultural and cohesion expenditure with a view to the preparation of the annual statement of assurance) involve 20 or more auditors.
In general, auditors must obtain audit evidence, by means of audit procedures in Luxembourg, visits to the European Commission, and on-the-spot visits to the Member States, where the revenue accruing to the EU budget is generated and the actions financed from the EU budget are carried out.
The Court's reports and opinions must be accessible to readers throughout the Union, and the Court must also maintain contacts throughout the Union with public authorities and other bodies in the course of its audit work.
This would not be possible without the Court's translators translating his reports and opinions (in almost all cases in English or French) into 22 of the official languages of the Union.
They also translate correspondence between the Court and other bodies as required and, in some cases, assist the auditors in carrying out verification visits in the Member States.
The Court's administrative staff are responsible for a wide range of support tasks carried out in a multinational body operating in the EU context.
This concerns finance, accounting, budget, buildings, information technologies, transport, security, etc. The Secretary-General is the highest-ranking staff of the Court and is responsible for the Court's staff management and management. 15

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET: SIX KERN ASSESSMENTS • The European Union's annual accounts give a true picture of the financial situation and results. • As regards the legality and regularity of operations, the overall results for 2008 reflect the improvements made in the financial management in recent years. • The overall progress made in 2008 is mainly due to the better results in the main theme of "Agriculture and Natural Resources improvements".
In the field of rural development, the estimated error rate is lower than in previous years, but still essential.
For the first time, the Court does not give a negative opinion on the subject of 'Agriculture and natural resources' as a whole. • The second, 'Cohesion', which accounts for almost a third of the budget, remains problematic as the most flawed budget.
The Court's estimate that at least 11% of the total amount of the reimbursements should not have been paid. • The recommendations made by the Court in the past in order to improve monitoring and control systems remain valid.
They should be considered as part of an ongoing process, in which the relevant measures can only be considered effective after some time. • In addition, special attention should be paid to those areas of expenditure in which the Court has to continue to complain of a high error rate.
In many cases, errors are a result of excessively complex regulations and regulations.
Therefore simplification remains a priority objective. 19
20 Unrestricted audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts The Court concluded that the annual accounts of the European Communities for 2008 give a true and fair view of the financial situation of the European Communities and of the results of its operations and cash flows for 2008 on all essential points.
Unrestricted audit judgements In 2008, the Court issued full audit judgements on ‘receipts', commitments on all themes, and payments on ‘education and citizenship' and ‘administrative and other expenditure' themes.
Limited audit opinions Payments in the "Agriculture and natural resources" theme, with the exception of rural development, were lawful and correct in all essential respects.
Payments in the theme 'Economy and finance', with the exception of the expenditure for the Sixth Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development (FP6) of this theme, were lawful and correct in all essential respects.
Negative review assessments The Court gave negative review opinions on the subjects of cohesion, research, energy and transport and external aid, development and enlargement.
Payments in these themes have been affected by errors to an essential extent, albeit varying in extent.
Improving monitoring and control systems The monitoring and control systems in the areas of research, energy and transport, external assistance, development and enlargement, and education and citizenship, were ineffective in preventing, detecting and correcting the reimbursement of excessive or ineligible costs.
In the case of the ‘Agriculture and natural resources' theme, the Court also concluded that the monitoring and control systems were sufficiently effective.
However, he pointed out that the Integrated Management and Control System (InVeKoS) remains an effective control system in general.
However, improvements are needed in some areas, in particular rural development, where there are shortcomings.
In the case of the 'Economy and finance' theme, the monitoring and control systems have been found to be effective in two of the three areas examined.
In the third field, "Companies", systems were considered to be limited effective, mainly due to shortcomings in FP6.
In the case of cohesion, the Court found that the Member State systems devoted to the correction of errors detected in national controls were, in most cases, at least partially effective.
The Commission, the Member States and other beneficiary countries need to continue their efforts to implement the necessary improvements in the above-mentioned themes, in order to adequately control the risk of illegitimate expenditure.
BOX 3 – INTERPRETATION OF AUDIT DOCUMENTS 21 An auditor may issue the following types of audit opinions: • a full audit opinion if it is proven that the accounting is reliable or that the underlying transactions, i.e. the payments, are lawful and lawful in all essential respects; • a negative audit opinion if the error rate in the underlying transactions is substantial and comprehensive or the accounting is unreliable; • a refusal of the audit opinion if the auditor is unable to obtain sufficient and adequate audit evidence to support his audit opinion, and the possible effects are both substantial and comprehensive; a limited audit opinion if no full audit opinion can be delivered but the effects of differences or limitations in the scope of the audit are not sufficient or comprehensive to require a negative audit opinion or a refusal of the audit opinion.

Each agency has a specific mission and manages its own budget.

24 SPECIAL REPORTS7 The selection of topics for economic and compliance audits and their design is based on criteria such as the risk of the profitability of certain revenue and expenditures or their compliance with the legislation, the volume of expenditure, the date of the final audit, the upcoming developments regarding the regulatory or operational framework, and the political and public interest.
Since cost-effectiveness and compliance tests are complex and require a lot of detailed work, their full implementation, from the preliminary study to the final reporting, usually takes more than a year.
The Court adopted a total of 18 special reports in 2009.
The special reports are available directly on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) and a reference to their publication is published in the Official Journal.
As in previous years, the reports related to investigations into financial management in many different areas, ranging, for example, from EU food aid for the most deprived (No. 6/2009) to cash management at the Commission (No. 5/2009).
In addition to the 18 special reports, the Court analysed the use of EU funds in 2009 in order to move the Chernobyl site to an environmentally safe state.
Recommendations on how to improve the management of the EU funds made available through the EBRD were sent to the President of the Commission in a (unpublished) letter from the President of the Court.

26 Have the market management instruments for the market in milk and milk products achieved their main objectives?
The Court took stock of the functioning of the market in milk and milk products since the introduction of milk quotas in 1984 and examined the Commission's approach to the management of the gradual deregulation of the dairy sector in 2003.
The situation at the end of 2008 is the basis for the Court's recommendations to the Commission: to prevent new overproduction, to monitor the process of price formation in the food chain, to deepen the reflection on the future of producers in disadvantaged areas and on the impact of the geographical concentration of milk production on the environment, to continue to focus milk production on meeting the needs of the European internal market and milk products with high added value, which can be exported without budget support to the world market.
EU CITIZENSHIP, FREEDOM, SECURITY AND JUSTICE • No 2/2009 ‘The European Union Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective way to better health?' European Union Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective way to better health?
The Court analysed the European Union Public Health Programme (PHP) for the period 2003-2007.
The Court's audit was intended to establish whether the framework conditions for projects financed by the EU budget were defined in a way that effectively complements Member States' measures to protect and improve public health.
The report shall contain detailed conclusions and recommendations on the design, implementation and management of the programme.
In the light of the Court's findings, the Court questions the benefits of certain part of the programme of European public health programmes, such as PHP.
The Commission and the Member States are invited to reconsider the EU's public health funding approach.
THE EU AS GLOBALER PARTNER • No 1/2009 "Banking activities in the Mediterranean region under the MEDA programme and the previous protocols • No 4/2009 "Administration of the involvement of non-state actors in Community development cooperation by the Commission • No 12/2009 "The effectiveness of Commission projects in the field of justice and home affairs in the Western Balkans • No 15/2009 "The EU's assistance provided through United Nations organisations: decision-making and monitoring • No 16/2009 "The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey • No 18/2009 "The effectiveness of EDF assistance for regional economic integration in East Africa and West Africa" 27 The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance for Turkey The Court examined the management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission.
In particular, the first period of implementation of the pre-accession assistance (2002-2006) was characterised by many weaknesses that had already occurred in previous pre-accession programmes.
The objectives set by the Commission in respect of grants were not sufficiently concrete to allow an assessment of the impact of the project and the Commission did not have the information necessary to demonstrate the effectiveness of the pre-accession assistance.
Nevertheless, the estimated outputs of the projects examined, and the results of the projects are likely to be sustainable, have been achieved.
The Commission has already made some significant improvements, but the Court has made recommendations for further corrective action.
Areas where improvements are most necessary include the definition of strategic objectives for financial assistance, the definition of more realistic deadlines for achieving objectives, and monitoring of actual project performance and results, using clear objectives and appropriate indicators.
28 MANAGEMENT • No 5/2009 ‘Commission management of funds' • No 9/2009 ‘Economic efficiency and effectiveness of staff selection activities of the European Personnel Selection Office' Economic efficiency and effectiveness of staff selection activities of the European Personnel Selection Office' The Court focused on the question of how the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) managed the sharp increase in the number of competitions resulting from the enlargement of the European Union and whether it provided timely aptitude lists containing the required number of successful candidates and was geographically balanced.
He concluded that the EPSO had successfully managed the increase in the number of competitions that resulted from the enlargement of the European Union.
However, the following weaknesses were noted: the staffing needs of the institutions were not reported to the EPSO in time, the staff selection process took too long, the selection process produced on average only two-thirds of the planned number of successful applicants (which were included in the aptitude list) and the management information was not consistently reliable or complete.
OPINIONS A further contribution of the Court to improving EU financial management is to deliver opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
Such opinions shall be required as part of the procedure for the adoption of financial provisions8 or may be made at the request of one of the other institutions of the Union9.
In 2009, the Court adopted an opinion on the proposal to amend the Regulation of the Budget Committee of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market on the Office's financial rules (‘the Financial Regulation').

29 CONTINUING FOLLOW-UP AND EFFECTIVENESS The Court's audits are a direct source of information to decision-makers in the institutions concerned, in the European context primarily the European Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States.
On the basis of this information, they may take measures, with or without reference to the Court's conclusions on the audit.
Although the Court's audit activities have their main effect on the reports and opinions published, they themselves have a certain effect throughout the course of the audit.
The replies from the audited body, particularly the Commission, will be 29 together. Examples of the impact of the Court's work will be the measures taken by the Commission in response to the 2007 discharge resolution (which, in the main, took effect in 2009): in the field of agricultural expenditure, the management and control system for expenditure under the newly created European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) has been aligned with the EAGF guarantee system, so that the largely recognised benefits of that system will also apply to EAFRD expenditure (see point 5.54 of the 2004 annual report and point 5.57 of the 2007 annual report).
In the area of cohesion The Commission is continuing to work on the revision of the rules applicable to 2007-2013 to simplify the system of reporting irregularities, and is committed to the preparation, at the beginning of 2010, of a report on the measures implemented in 2009 and the initial impact of all the measures in its action plan to strengthen the Commission's supervisory role in the management of structural measures (see points 1.53 and 6.36(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of external policies In order to strengthen controls at the level of the implementing organisations, the Commission plans to develop a specific instrument to better support these organisations in the management of EU funds and compliance with EU rules (see point 8.33(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of internal policies, including research The Commission has developed a multiannual control strategy for the Sixth Framework Programme based on the detection and correction of errors, which could not be detected prior to the implementation of the payment by file checks.
In order to simplify the procedures of the Seventh Framework Programme, the Commission introduced a Participant Guarantee Fund to significantly reduce the number of ex ante financial controls and the safeguard measures to be introduced (see points 7.43(b), 10.34 and 2.42(a) of the 2007 annual report).
Source: Commission report to the European Parliament on the follow-up to the 2007 discharge decisions.
The special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
Due to the fact that they are published during the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on them have usually taken place at an earlier stage at the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
The impact of the audit reports can be enhanced by their thematicisation in the relevant media, which brings greater attention and stimulates public debate.
As a rule, media coverage of the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive.
This was also the case in 2009, with the media focusing mainly on improvements in agricultural spending.
Several special reports were also followed with interest by the press.
For example, the special report on the milk market (No 14/2009) assessing the extent to which the management tools for the market for milk and milk products have achieved their main objectives was the subject of intensive discussions in the Council and Parliament, and in response to a wide variety of problems in the media and to the professional groups concerned.
The Court is working to further analyse the impact of its activities.
In 2009, it started to develop a systematic follow-up to its special reports to identify and document progress made by the audited bodies in addressing the weaknesses identified and in implementing the recommendations made.
This procedure will provide the Court, as well as Parliament and other interested parties, with additional feedback on the impact of its activities.
31 POSITION OF THE COURT OPINION No 1/2010 – IMPROVEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION'S FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT: RISKS AND CHALLENGES In February 2010, the Court's first opinion on measures that could reduce the level of irregular payments at EU level and improve the quality of expenditure (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court concluded that, in order to enhance recent progress in reducing the level of irregular payments, legislation in high-risk areas needs to be simplified and more cost-efficient control systems established.
Such reforms should be carried out in the context of the ongoing broader review of EU spending arrangements.
The Court considers that improving the quality of expenditure is of high priority, which can be achieved by applying the European added value approach to the definition of expenditure priorities and by addressing the specific problems identified by the Court in the selection, design and implementation of expenditure programmes and grant schemes.
OBJECTIVES ON THE FIELDS CONCERNED ON THE STRENGTH OF SPECIFIC PAYMENTS Although the level of irregular payments from the EU budget as a whole has declined, it remains high in the areas of cohesion and external aid, development and enlargement, as well as in the framework programme of research and technological development and in the expenditure on rural development.
Most irregularities are due to the notification of ineligible expenditure by the beneficiaries, the notification of ineligible expenditure and the non-compliance with payment conditions, for example in the area of public procurement rules.
They are primarily due to the complexity of the rules and the terms and conditions of payment and to the shortcomings in the systems to manage the risks at the level of the final beneficiaries.
SIMPLIFICATION OF SIMPLE LEGAL FRAMEWORK CONDITIONS AND IMPROVEMENT OF MONITORING AND CONTROL The Commission should address the specific system deficiencies identified by the Court in the high-risk areas and improve its oversight.
But with an increasing number of controls and correspondingly falling error rates, the point at which the cost of controls is no longer proportionate to the benefit achieved is at some point reached.
Simplification should therefore remain a priority objective.
Clearly interpreted and easy to apply rules and legislation can reduce not only the risk of errors but also the control costs. 31
32 IMPROVING THE CONCEPT OF EXPENDITURE PROGRAMMES In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure that clear targets are set when revising existing and designing new measures.
Often more sense of reality, greater transparency and accountability are needed.
To this end, the Commission could further strengthen existing procedures for the development of future policies, in particular the ex ante evaluation and impact assessment.
The Court proposes to clarify the concept of European added value in an appropriate political statement or in EU legislation in order to provide guidance to the EU political authorities in the definition of expenditure priorities.
The Court considers that the Commission should complete the budget review as soon as possible and take into account the results of the preparation of the financial framework that starts in 2014.
Improving the quality of expenditure should be of high priority for the institutions of the European Union and should therefore be the main objective of the new Commission.
33 PROPOSALS FOR 201010 The Court presents its future audit work each year in a work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, which is available to the public on the Court's website.
The work programme shall provide interested parties with information on new and ongoing audits and on planned reports.
The Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012, based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of the audits and improving efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
These objectives will be decisive in the Court's 2010 work programme and its efforts to improve continuously.
The Court aims to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the period concerned by: • selecting and developing audits focussing on issues from risk areas and of the Court's greatest interest to the audience; • continuing to provide sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement; and monitoring the implementation of these proposals; • carrying out a broader range of audits and presenting new types of audit products complementing the current annual and special reports; • developing a larger number of special reports and improving their proximity and ease of use; • developing relations with its main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public; and the Court aims to improve efficiency by making the best use of its resources over the period in question.

34 The Court has selected certain audit priorities for the 2010 work programme, including: • the multi-annual nature of the bulk of Community expenditure, including flat-rate corrections and recoveries; • innovation and the internal market; • human capital; • sustainable energy; • the Commission's strategy to simplify the legal framework for businesses and citizens.
FOURTH FOURTH FOUNDATION FOR A NEW BUILDING On 1 July 2009 the foundation stone for a new building, the second extension of the European Court of Auditors, was laid in Luxembourg.
Vítor Caldeira, President of the European Court of Auditors, Claude Wiseler, Luxembourg Minister of Buildings, Patrick Gillen, President of the Fund d'urbanisation et d'aménagement du Kirchberg, and Eduardo Ruiz García, General Secretary of the Court, signalled the start of the construction work with the symbolic groundbreaking ceremony.
This extension of the European Court of Auditors' two-building complex will enable the staff recruited as part of the successive Union enlargements.
The Court will endeavour to extend its range of audit-related reporting types in 2009-2012.
To this end, it will coordinate with its main external addressees in order to ensure that it will gain a clear understanding of their different needs and of how it can best meet its expectations in order to fulfil its mandate under the Treaty.
A considerable proportion of the resources available to the Court will be used to audit the accounts with a view to drawing up a Statement of Assurance (the so-called 'DAS').
This requires the examination and examination of the accounts and the operations of the general budget of the EU for each financial year.
The European Development Funds and each of the 40 European agencies and agencies will be subject to separate declarations of assurance.
The audit work runs from June of year n to June of year n+1 in order to publish annual reports in accordance with the Financial Regulation in November of year n+1.
The Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2009 will therefore be drawn up and published in 2010 and the Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2010 will start at the same time11.
The Court's work aims at presenting clear conclusions on the level of accounting and budgetary management in the various areas of the general budget and at presenting appropriate and cost-effective recommendations where improvements are possible.
The Court's annual report on the general budget for the financial year 2009 will continue to be in line with the structure established in 2007 and taking into account the redeployment of the budget12.
The findings are presented in chapters relating to coherent groups of policy areas, which are largely, but not entirely, in line with the headings of the new financial framework.
Furthermore, the Court will be particularly concerned to make its results and conclusions clearer and more coherent in order to make them more comprehensible and readable, and to make it easier to compare within and between the themes and between them and between the financial years.
35 11 Further information on the DAS approach is available on the Court's website at www.eca.europa.eu.
12 The Court has set up a DAS think tank to review various aspects of the DAS review approach. In this context, it has also been considered to redefine the areas of the specific assessments.
36 36 MEASUREMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS In 2008, the Court decided to establish a system of central performance indicators (CLI) for its audit-related and non-audit-related activities to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and the objectives set out in the annual work programmes.
ZLI serves to strengthen internal and external accountability and to enhance work efficiency and quality. WOZU CENTRAL SERVICES INDICATORS? • To inform management of how successful the Court as an institution implements what it has undertaken; • To support the decision-making process by focusing the institution's attention on efficiency issues and promoting improvements; • To provide the audience with information on relevant aspects of the Court's performance.
The CCIs primarily concern the achievement of the Court's strategic objectives as they cover the quality of the audit, the output, the impact and the economic management of the Court's resources.
They provide information on the Court's performance as "company " and are an integral part of the Court's management system.
THE CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS OF THE COURT 37 ZLI 1 Evaluation of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the main addressees of the Court's reports ZLI 2 Assessment of the quality and impact of the audit activities of the Court by the audited CLI 3 Evaluation of the content and presentation of the Court's reports by a panel of external experts ZLI 4 Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audited CLI 8 External audit of the Court's financial management: a) Assessment of the audited CLI 5 Number of reports accepted by the audited CLI 6 Number of reports accepted by the CLI 6 Number of reports accepted on time ZLI 7 Percentage of audit reports issued on time ZLI 8 External audit of the Court's financial management: a) Assessment of the independent auditor's audit opinion b) Decision of the discharge authority ZLI 9 Degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff ZLI 10 Average number of training days per person Quantity and quality of audit work can also be improved if the Court's financial management effects and opinions are considered.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They were included in the Court's 2010 annual work programme.
38 Number of reports adopted compared with the number of reports planned In 2009, the Court adopted 91 % of the planned number of reports.
The annual report and all special annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the planned 24 special reports, only 18 were adopted.
The remaining six special reports were still in the final drafting phase as at 31 December 2009.
Number of reports adopted on time In 2009, the Court adopted 67% of its reports within the specified timeframe.
The annual report and all special annual reports were adopted on time.
Due to delays in the special reports, the Court failed to meet the target set for the CLI 6. Further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of the special reports.
Measurement of the number of key audit notices prepared on time The Court shall transmit its preliminary audit results to the audited body in an audit notice.
It aims to increase the proportion of the audit notifications submitted on time by 10 % per year, the long-term objective being to produce 80 % of the audit notifications within the given timeframe (two months after the final audit visit).
In 2009, the number of audit notices issued on time increased by 16% compared to 2008.
External evaluation of the Court's financial management: a) independent auditor's audit opinion, b) decision of the discharge authority The independent auditor of the Court delivered a full audit opinion on the annual accounts and the use of resources, and the European Parliament, on a positive recommendation from the Council, gave discharge.
Degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff In an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, 86% of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their work (target: 80%), while the overall level of staff satisfaction was 2.8 on a scale of 4 (target: 2.5).
Average number of days of training for examiners (excluding language courses) In accordance with guidelines published by IFAC (International Federation of Accountants), the Court strives to provide the examiners with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training.
In 2009, the average was four days.
39 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its international cooperation through the following bodies: • The Contact Committee, composed of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States and the Court, • the Network of Supreme Audit Institutions of the Countries applying for EU membership, • the European Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI) and • the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI).
The Court contributed to the annual meetings of these organisations and to the improvement of international audit principles and procedures and was also actively involved in the committees and working groups set up by these organisations.
In particular, he took on the following tasks: • Chair of the Working Groups "Common Audit Standards" and "VAT"; • Participation in the Working Groups "Reports of National SAIs" and "Structural Funds" set up by the Contact Committee; • Participation in the EUROSAI Environmental Working Group and the IT Working Group; in the EUROSAI Group, which prepares a guide on best practices in achieving quality, in the EUROSAI Training Committee and in the EUROSAI Task Force on the Audit of Disaster Aid Funds; • Chair of the INTOSAI Working Group on Accountability and Audit of Disaster Aid; • Participation in the INTOSAI Subcommittees on Guidelines for Auditing Accounting, Audit of Compliance with Legal Standards and for Economic Audits; and in the Task Force on the Global Financial Crisis.
40 40 PERSONAL AND SUPPORT SERVICES The Court's most important capital is its employees.
As of 31 December 2009, the staff of the Court amounted to 880 staff (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the staff, 525 (including 115 staff in the members' cabinets) were in charge of audit tasks, 163 were in the capacity of translators, 171 were in charge of administrative support, and 21 were in the capacity of the President.
The Court's employees have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
DECEMBER 31 DECEMBER'S PLANTS (occupied and vacant posts) Translation Administrative support The Court has committed itself to achieving its strategic goal of improving efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
In 2009, it therefore continued to explore and exploit the potential for efficiency gains in all its activities by simplifying procedures and streamlining services.
In particular, the resources of the support services, which have become available through efficiency gains, have been deducted as far as possible from these services and made available for audit-related tasks.
This process has not yet been completed and its impact will be even more evident in 2010.
For human resources, the Court, as a central performance indicator (ZLI 9), has established the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's staff (see page 37).
A satisfaction survey was carried out to provide information on this subject and to support the decision-making process in this area.
The Court is currently implementing measures to ensure that opportunities to achieve better results are fully exploited in the coming years.

Most of them, however, work in the Translation Directorate and in the Administrative Services.
The increase in the number of women in the AD function group reflects the results of the recent recruitment wave.
