TERMINATION The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff of both officials and temporary staff.
General selection procedures for Court posts are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
The Court also provides placements for a limited number of university graduates for periods of three to five months.
In 2009, the Court hired 112 employees: 69 officials, 14 temporary staff and 29 contract staff.
The recruitment depends on whether reserve lists of EPSO competitions are available and sufficient.
In 2009, the Court succeeded in recruiting an adequate number of new staff.
73 vacancies not filled at 31 December 2009 could be reduced by 33% to 49 by 26 January 2010. The number of vacancies will continue to fall sharply in the coming months, as the latest recruitment wave will see the number of additional audit staff coming into service.
At 31 December 2008, 68 posts were not filled.
The reserve list for recruitment on the basis of the EPSO AD/126/08 selection procedure was published in August, and the first successful candidates first entered the Court in early November, i.e. only three months later.
VOCATIONAL TRAINING The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training.
In addition, due to the specific circumstances of the audit environment of the Court, the auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2009, the Court's staff completed an average of nine days of professional training.
Language courses accounted for 64% of the total number of training days in 2009 (compared to 48% in 2008).
Without taking into account the language courses, the examiners completed four days of professional training in 2009 (see ZLI 10 on page 38).
This figure is expected to increase in 2010 as new staff are required to undergo a mandatory training programme.
Based on the long-term strategic objective of "Development and growth" and the 2008-2011 Curriculum for continuing education and training and the continuing education pathways adopted in 2009, the "Vocational training" Unit has improved the content of the training and developed new training courses in line with the priorities adopted by the Court.
Cooperation with the other institutions and with interinstitutional bodies such as the European School of Administration has also been successfully pursued.
Box 5 provides a portrait of the staff of the examination staff within the Court in order to give the reader a picture of the work carried out and the persons involved. 43
44 BOX 5 – THE TEAM COMPETENT TO THE TEST ON "JUSTIC AND ONLY IN THE ESTAL BALKAN" The Western Balkan region was characterised by violence in the past.
The European Union's interest in this region is to promote security and long-term stability.
The rule of law, border security and the fight against corruption are essential prerequisites for EU accession and are a major challenge in the Western Balkans.
The European Commission is the main donor of funding in the region.
The Court's 2009 report on the effectiveness of Commission projects in the field of justice and home affairs in the Western Balkans (Special Report No 12/2009) provided an insight into the situation in this particularly important area.
The audit covered investment projects as well as institutional building projects in the four areas of asylum, integrated border management, justice and police.
33 completed projects were assessed on the spot, including an asylum centre, a prison in Albania, and a court in Bosnia and Herzegovina responsible for human rights and war crimes.
In addition, several EU-funded border crossing points in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia were visited to assess whether EU action has led to improvements.
The team responsible for conducting the audit worked closely with the rapporteur, Maarten B. Engwirda.
The heads of the audit unit were Raija Peltonen and Ossi Louko, and the team leader was Jussi Bright.
The examiners involved were Enrico Grassi and Miroslav Matej, with Horst Fischer and Jan Pieter Lingen from Maarten B. Engwirda's cabinet also playing an important role.

TRANSLATION Translation is an important activity of audit support that allows the Court to fulfil its mission and to fulfil its communication objectives.
In 2009, the total volume of translation increased by 5.2% compared to 2008.
The proportion of translation services provided on time was over 95 %.
The linguistic support of the auditors in connection with audit visits and in the drafting of reports has been increased.
Furthermore, the Directorate of Translation, INTOSAI working groups, supported other specific needs related to the audit activities of the Court.
In January 2010, a new computerised application (Artemis) for the more efficient management of translation work was introduced.
INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology provides the auditors with essential tools and services.
In 2009, the main developments were as follows: • the simplification of processes and the continuation of the changeover to a paperless office through the application of automated permits and electronic forms, the introduction of electronic signatures and the introduction of work to establish an archive database; • the improvement of the security of the Court's IT infrastructure through the establishment of a data recovery centre and the introduction of a more advanced version of the Lotus Note platform, the Court's basic structure for the Court's news and audit documentation/archiving systems; • the adoption of a long-term IT plan for the period 2010-2012, to align information technology with the Court's main audit strategic objectives and to continue efforts to provide high-quality services. 45
46 MANAGEMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE The Directorate "Finance and Support Services" is responsible for administrative services and infrastructure.
These include internal controls and accounting and administrative and logistical services.
In 2009, the Directorate focused on reorganising its services to improve efficiency and effectiveness and to release staff to reorganise to the benefit of audit services.
This reorganisation led to a reduction in the number of units in the Directorate (from five to three) and the implementation of several posts in audit services.
An important activity of the Directorate concerned the construction of a new courtyard building (the K3 building).
In 2009, a project manager was appointed after a call for tenders.
Construction will start in March 2010 and is expected to be completed in 2013.
The time and cost framework set for the project will continue to be respected.
TEST TEST In the course of the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and to other recipient countries of EU funds in order to obtain adequate audit evidence.
The visits are usually carried out by central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as by their final beneficiaries.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners, and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of audit and the distance.
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member State visited, which provide useful logistical and practical support.
The following graph gives an overview of the number of audit visits carried out by the Court in 2009 in the EU Member States (300).
In addition, 36 verification visits took place outside the Union in 2009.

In 2009, the overall budget implementation rate was more than 92 %.
For Title 1 (members and staff of the institution), this rate is 88%, the lowest in Chapter 14 (other staff and external services) (82 %), mainly due to the non-or under-employment of posts and the savings achieved.
For Title 2 (buildings, furniture, equipment and miscellaneous operating expenditure), the average execution rate is close to 100%.

The first tranche of financing for this project, which amounted to EUR 55 million, was approved for the 2009 budget, this amount being committed and partly paid in 2009.
The remaining funds for the K3 building were transferred to 2010 and are intended to cover the costs incurred by the project manager on behalf of the Court on the basis of contracts with construction companies.
The funds will be used in the manner set out in the Court's request to the European Parliament and to the Council at the end of 2008.

50 SERVICE "INTERNE REVISION" The "Internal audit" department of the Court is intended to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives by a systematic and methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service makes proposals to increase the efficiency of the Court.
This requires a continuous evaluation of internal control systems within the Court to assess their effectiveness.
In 2009, the Court's Internal Audit department focused its work on auditing the accounts (audit of accounts), auditing ex-ante controls, auditing the salary list and deposit accounts, monitoring of contracts and public procurement procedures, and analysis of the promotion procedure.
Most of the audit recommendations issued by the Internal Auditor in 2009 were accepted by the audited bodies and included in corrective action plans.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee shall monitor the activities of the Internal Auditor and ensure the independence of the Court.
It shall also examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and, if necessary, entrust them with specific audit tasks.
In 2009, the Internal Audit Service was audited and certified by an independent auditor, Deloitte S.A.
EXTERNAL AUDIT OF THE HOFES The report of the independent auditor on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2008 was published on 23 October 2009 in the Official Journal of the European Union (OJ L 73, 23.3.2009, p.
In its audit opinion, the Court's independent auditor (PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL) concluded on the following: ‘As regards the annual accounts, we believe that accounts give a true picture of the Court's financial and financial position as at 31 December 2008 as well as of the financial position and cash flows for the year ending on that reference date, in accordance with Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 of 25 June 2002 and Commission Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 2342/2002 of 23 December 2002 laying down detailed rules for the implementation of the above Council Regulation and of the Court of Auditors' accounting rules.' For the use of resources and the control procedures: ‘Based on our work described in this report, we have not encountered any facts on which we should conclude that, in all the essentials and in the light of the above assessment criteria, the resources allocated to the Court have not been used for the purposes in question, and (b) the control procedures in place do not give the necessary assurance that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the rules in force and the regulations.

This sufficient security shall be based on the assessment of the undersigned and on the information available to him, such as the results of ex post controls, the internal auditor's reports and the reports of the independent auditor on previous financial years.
The undersigned confirms that he has no knowledge of any unreported circumstance that might harm the interests of the institution.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2010
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS DIRECTORY VALUES The Court of Auditors is committed to the following values: The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to the improvement of EU financial management and, at the same time, acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors of integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact, and providing its users with valuable support for improving EU financial management.
INDUSTRIALITY, INTEGRATION AND INDUSTRIALITY PROFESSIONALITY VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution whose members and staff produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, take into account the concerns of its addressees and address important and indicative statements, include recognition of the individual's value, support in the further development of special skills and reward of performance, support for team spirit through effective communication, delivery of its addressee circle, with appropriate audit results, rejecting any form of influence through external guidance or pressure, safeguarding a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of its work, active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU level and worldwide, increasing efficiency in all aspects of its work, participation in effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and contribution to strengthening accountability for the management of EU financial resources

4 PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the fourth edition of the Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors. This year we took the opportunity to regroup the content, namely the two main sections, "Our Activities", and "Our Management", and, for the first time, provide an overview of all the performance indicators.
In 2010, the Court of Auditors had two important opportunities to participate in the debate on the reform of EU financial management.
At the beginning of the year, the Court presented an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges of improving EU financial management and at the end of the year an opinion on the Commission's proposals to amend the financial regulation applicable to the EU's general budget.
With a view to 2011, the Court will continue to implement its values and will continue to expand the performance and results achieved.
We will once again present high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions, which will contribute to improving EU financial management and to promoting accountability and transparency, and the Court will, in particular, continue to closely monitor developments in the EU's economic governance and will address the new legislative proposals that will affect EU financial management after 2013.
We plan to publish 45 annual reports, i.e. the annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European Development Funds, as well as the special annual reports on the agencies, institutions and other bodies.
Special reports provide an important opportunity to achieve added value by focusing on areas at high risk and on issues of particular relevance to the target group.The Court intends, in particular, to report on the quality of EU expenditure in a wide range of areas ranging from financial instruments and the SME Guarantee Facility to EU-funded projects in the field of eGovernment and the Single Payment Scheme in agriculture.
In further implementing its strategy for 2009-2012, the Court hopes to fully capitalise on the benefits of its recent reforms, including the streamlined decision-making process, the Court will continue its efforts to recruit appropriate staff, to limit vacancy to a minimum, and to promote the professional development of its staff.
Without the commitment and professionalism of all the staff of the farm, we would not have achieved what we have achieved in 2010.

9 OUR ACTIVITIES AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are the following: o Annual reports – with the results of its audits of the accounts and compliance audits of specific financial years (including the specific annual reports of the agencies, bodies and other bodies of the European Union, published separately); o Special reports – with the results of its selected audits, with the main focus on economic audits to assess the economy, economic efficiency and effectiveness of selected EU revenue and expenditure sectors; o Opinions on draft legislative acts with financial implications.

The main statements of the annual report were as follows: • The annual accounts of the European Union are accurate in terms of the financial situation and the results of transactions and cash flows in all essential areas. • With the exception of two expenditure areas ("Economic and Financial Affairs", and "Administrative and other expenditure"), the budget payments continue to be substantially affected by errors. • The Court estimates that the most likely error rate in expenditure in the cohesion issue was significantly lower than in previous years and the budget as a whole lower than the error rate estimated by the Court in recent years. • The Commission has improved its report on the recovery of unduly paid amounts and other corrections.
However, this information is not yet fully reliable, and the Commission's information on corrective action does not allow a meaningful comparison to the error rate estimated by the Court. In the report, the Court makes recommendations on how financial management could be improved by strengthening administrative systems and simplifying rules and regulations.
The Annual Report on the European Development Funds for 2009 The Court published its Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for the financial year 2009 on 9 November 2010, together with the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for 2009.
The special annual reports on EU agencies, bodies and agencies for 2009 In December 2010, the Court published 40 special annual reports on EU agencies, bodies and bodies for the financial year 20092.
The Court concluded that the monitoring and control systems ensure the regularity of payments and that the Court recommended that some aspects of EDF financial management be improved, such as the cost effectiveness of expenditure controls, the control of the annual audit of completed projects and the control of the use and monitoring of budget support.
12 Special reports adopted in 2010 When selecting and designing its tasks for profitability and compliance audits, the Court is always concerned with achieving the greatest possible impact and the best possible use of the resources made available for these tasks.
In selecting the topics, the Court takes account of the following factors: • the risks of economic viability or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the level of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the time elapsed since a possible prior examination; • forthcoming developments within the relevant legal or operational framework; • the political and public interest.
In order to obtain the necessary audit evidence, the selected cost-effectiveness and compliance checks must be carefully planned and carried out. In addition, the Court gives the audited bodies, prior to the publication of the report, the opportunity to comment on its findings and the formulation of answers.
As a result, these examinations usually take more than a year.

In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of the ‘Design Studies' and ‘New Infrastructure Development' support measures in the Sixth Research Framework Programme (Special Report No 2/2010) – In the light of ‘Design Studies', feasibility aspects will be examined in potential future research institutions, and the ‘New Infrastructure Development' action aims to support the development of new or improved existing infrastructures.
In the course of the audit, the Court examined whether the two measures have effectively contributed to achieving the objectives of the 6th Framework Programme for Research Infrastructures for 2002-2006. • Impact assessments in the EU institutions: do they help in decision-making?
(Special Report No 3/2010) – Impact assessments are one of the cornerstones of better regulation policy for improving and simplifying EU legislative proposals. The assessment of whether the Commission's impact assessments have effectively supported decision-making in EU institutions and the comments of this report are also relevant for other budgetary areas.
• Are the Leonardo da Vinci programme's design and management of the mobility measures likely to produce effective results?
(Special Report No 4/2010) – The mobility projects of the Leonardo da Vinci programme enable organisations active in the field of vocational education and training to arrange for participants to study in another European country. The measures are part of the integrated lifelong learning programme. In the course of the study, an evaluation of the design, management and implementation of the measures by the Commission and the national agencies was carried out in order to assess whether the measures are likely to achieve their objectives. • Improving transport performance on the trans-European rail axes: Did EU investments in rail infrastructure have an effective effect? (Special Report No 4/2010) – The mobility projects of the Leonardo da Vinci programme make it possible for organisations active in the field of vocational training and training to make it possible for participants in another European country to make study visits.
(Special Report No 8/2010) (see box ‘Introduction of an economic audit'). • Is EU spending on structural measures in the water supply of households used in an optimal way?
(Special Report No 9/2010) – The Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund have allocated more than EUR 4 billion over the 2000-2006 programming period to support projects in the field of water supply infrastructure to households. e Court assessed whether these resources have been allocated effectively in order to address a number of needs, such as increasing water availability, increasing geographical coverage, improving the cost-effectiveness of water supply systems and improving the quality of services.
16 RECOVERY OF A RECOVERY TEST IMPROVEMENT OF TRANS-EUROPEAN RECOVERY ASSESSMENT: ARE EU INVESTMENT IN THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF THE IRON ASSISTANCE?  -SPECIAL REPORT NO. 8/2010-- The audit focused on EU co-financing of rail infrastructure, examining whether an effective contribution to the increase in the performance of the trans-European axes has been made.
In the light of the review of the TEN-T guidelines due to take place in 2011, the Court's report was presented at a particularly favourable time.The Court recommended that the Commission: • cooperate with the Member States and the railway authorities in order to identify the trans-European corridors in which there is a significant need and to develop knowledge and improve the analytical basis to the extent necessary; • strengthen the emphasis on reducing practical constraints on international rail transport; • promote and facilitate cooperation between Member States' railway sector bodies so that developments can be planned together and joint solutions to practical problems can be achieved.
17 "The test presented a number of challenges to the team," reports Gareth Roberts, head of the test team. "We had to get to know the conditions of European rail transport very quickly, and we had to see some examples of the success of fantastic modern railways, but also some network sections, which seemed to come from a different age.
We wanted to explore to what extent the European rail system gradually develops from a patchwork to a network.
Up to 10 examiners were involved in the work on the ground, as we had to cover many different languages."I really enjoyed the work on the test.
Since then, I have become something like a railway fan!, says Andrej Minarovič, the inspector responsible for the work in Germany and Austria.
At the end of the test, Fernando Pascual Gil, the team's nickname, "Mulwurf", was that he had spent a long time in railway tunnels in the Alps and the Pyrenees. The audit team visited eight Member States and examined the impact on trans-European rail transport of 21 railway projects co-financed by the European Union in the framework of trans-European transport networks and cohesion policy.
The team members traveled with freight trains over and through the Alps and visited large tunnel construction sites.
These visits were a valuable complement to the findings gained by the auditors from a review of reports, surveys of railway employees and the usual financial analyses.
18 Conservation and management of natural resources In the light of the EUR 413 billion allocated for the period 2007-2013, the EU has extensive powers and political responsibilities in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. Three-quarters of the resources will be spent on agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers, financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the ‘first pillar' of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of the expenditure is dedicated to support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second ‘pillar' of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Implementation of the Leader approach to rural development (Special Report No 5/2010) – Leader is a bottom-up approach to support rural development based on local partnerships. In the course of this review, it was assessed whether the Leader approach was implemented in such a way as to achieve additional benefits compared to the traditional top-down approach, while minimising the risks of a sound financial management. • Has the sugar market reform achieved its main objectives?
(Special Report No 6/2010) – In 2006, the EU carried out a profound reform of its sugar sector, aimed at ensuring the competitiveness of the EU sugar industry, stabilising markets and ensuring supply and ensuring a fair standard of living for the agricultural population.
The EU as a global partner The EU has three main objectives in the field of external relations in addition to enlargement: to achieve stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood (the EU and its neighbourhood policy), to actively support sustainable development at the international level (the EU as a partner for sustainable development), and to promote global political governance and to ensure strategic and civil security (the EU as a global player).
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its central services or delegations.
• Commission management of the system of veterinary checks on meat imports following the 2004 health legislation reform (Special Report No 14/2010) - Veterinary controls on imports are an integral part of the EU's food safety policy and help to reduce the risk of outbreaks of diseases and health crises, and are likely to lead to a high cost to the EU budget, to the EU's management of veterinary checks at border inspection posts following the reform of legislation on food hygiene, which came into force in 2006.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Commission management of general budget support in ACP countries, Latin American and Asian countries (Special Report No 11/2010) – In general, many donors, including the European Commission, consider that general budget support is the most effective way of providing development aid.
The audit examined whether the Commission effectively managed its budget support programmes in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and Latin America and Asia. 19
20 • EU development assistance for basic education in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia (Special Report 12/2010) – The EU and the international donor community committed themselves to ensuring primary education for all children, eradicating gender inequalities and improving the quality of education through the Education for All and the Millennium Development Goals initiative. The review examined whether EU development assistance has contributed to the achievement of these objectives in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia and whether the Commission has managed its interventions satisfactorily.
Revenue The European Union budget is primarily financed by own resources and other revenue. Traditional own resources – mainly customs – account for around 12% and VAT-based own resources for an additional 12% of total revenue. The majority of the EU own resources (70%) come from the own resources derived from the gross national income, which, as a residual income, ensure that the budget is always balanced. • Has the new European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument been successfully launched and is achieving results in the southern Caucasus (Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia)?
(Special Report No 13/2010) – The European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument (ENPI) provides a framework for the planning and implementation of assistance for partner countries and regions.
Since 2007, more than 311 million euros have been made available to three countries in the Southern Caucasus. In the course of the examination, the ENPI was examined whether it was successfully launched there and whether it was the result.
In 2010, the Court adopted a special report on • Simplified customs procedures (No 1/2010) – in the case of simplified customs procedures, authorised economic operators benefit from accelerated customs clearance and from a simplified system of payment of the duties, which are among the EU's revenue.
The audit assessed the effectiveness of the legal framework and the control approach of the Commission and of the Member States.Opinions delivered in 2010 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management in its opinions on proposals for new or amended instruments with financial implications.

Other forms of cooperation The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international auditing principles and procedures through its membership in European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the INTOSAI5 and its European regional group EUROSAI.
A delegation of the Court took part in the XXth INCOSAI Congress, which took place in South Africa from 22 to 27 November 2010.
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of the INTOSAI, it has been actively involved in the subcommittees on the various types of examinations. In addition, the Court has contributed to the subcommittee "Promoting Best Practices and Quality Assurance through Voluntary Peer Reviews" and has supported the increased activities of the INTOSAI members in the field of strengthening their expertise.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Accountability and the Audit of Disaster Relief.
An important aim of this work group is to develop guidelines in the area of accountability for disaster relief and to identify and disseminate best practices, focusing on activities aimed at stakeholders (multilateral institutions, relief organisations, governments, private auditors).The interim report of the working group was presented to the INTOSAI Congress in November 2010.
In 2010, the Court also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force on the Global Financial Crisis. In the context of the EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and in the IT Working Group and is involved in the EUROSAI Training Committee.
The Court also took part in the working group set up at the 7th EUROSAI Congress in 2008 to set up a guide to best practices to achieve quality within a SAI. The Court is also one of the auditors of EUROSAI. 25
26 OUR MANAGEMENT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STRATEGY FOR 2009  THE 2012 In recent years, after a self-assessment and a peer-review procedure (2008) on the framework conditions for its audit management, the Court has initiated an internal reform process.
A strategy for the 2009-2012 period6 was developed to address the identified weaknesses, with overall objectives for the period being: to maximise the overall impact of the audits; to improve efficiency by making the best use of resources.
Many of the priority measures foreseen in the strategy have already been completed and the other measures will be implemented in 2011 and 2012. Key achievements achieved in 2010 include: o the achievement of the target of submitting 12 to 15 annual reports on economic audits; o the development of new products – a document on risks and challenges for the new Commission (Opinion No 1/2010) and the establishment of a new system for reporting on the follow-up to the Court's recommendations from 2012; o the revision of the Court's rules of procedure for streamlining decision-making procedures through the introduction of chambers and strengthening the management structure; o the establishment of an overview of all performance indicators; o the development of the approach for the annual audit of the EU budget (declaration of reliability) on the basis of recommendations from an internal expert body supported by external experts; o the development of a set of posts from support services for audit services.
6 The audit strategy 2009-2012' is available on the Court's website.
27 INTRODUCTION OF INTRODUCTION OF INCOME IN THE NEW RULES OF PROCEDURE One of the main recommendations of the Court's reform process was that the Court should make use of the possibility provided for in Article 287(4) of the Treaty of allowing certain categories of reports and opinions of chambers to be adopted while maintaining the collegiality principle.
Following the Council's approval of the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure, Chambers were set up on 1 June 2010 and are composed of Court members and adopt special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft acts. Prior to this, all these reports and opinions were adopted by the whole College, and this is still the case with annual reports on the EU budget and the EDFs.
Although most of the Court's reports are now accepted by the Chambers, the Chambers have the option of transferring their documents to the Court for adoption.
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they are not members without voting rights.
Members of the Court
28 MEASUREMENT DATA ON THE HOUSE IN 2010 Since 2008, the Court has gradually developed a set of key performance indicators (CPIs) to inform o the management of the progress made in the implementation of the 2009-2012 targets; o support the decision-making process; o provide performance-related information to the Court's audience.
Since for the first time a survey of all the indicators is available for 2010, this year serves as the reference year for future assessments of progress. The Court is very pleased with the results of its 2010 key performance indicators, in particular the quality and impact of its work.
More important, however, is the fact that the indicators clearly show the areas in which progress is needed and which problems need to be addressed in order to achieve a future performance increase.
29 Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments by the addressees and on the basis of expert reviews and follow-up of its recommendations.
Assessment by addressees By means of a survey, the Court asked the main addressees of its reports (the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgets of the Council) and of the main audited bodies (mainly European Commission staff) to assess the quality and impact of the annual reports published in 2009 (the general budget and the EDF) and special reports.
The assessment should be based on a five-stage scale (1 – very bad, 2 – bad, 3 – appropriate, 4 – good, 5 – very good).
2010 Objective Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's reports by a principal addressee 4.2 ≥4 Evaluation of the quality and impact of the Court's audit work by the audited body The result shows that the main addressees of the Court's reports find these on average for "good".
The Court strives to maintain or improve this level of performance.
Experts' reviews Two external bodies have reviewed the content and presentation of a sample of the Court's reports published in 2009 and 2010 and have assessed eight special reports and the annual report on the general budget and on the EDFs for both years and assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale of "significantly impaired" (1) to "qualitatively high-quality" (4).
2010 target 3.0 ≥ 3 3.7 ≥4 External experts review of the Court's content and presentation The outcome shows that the reviewers consider the Court's reports to be "satisfactory".
The reviews have provided valuable insights and the resulting recommendations will be used to improve the quality of future reports.
30 Follow-up of recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations in order to contribute to the improvement of financial management. In order to make changes, the Court's recommendations must first be accepted by the audited bodies and subsequently implemented.The indicator is based on the recommendations published in 2009, i.e. the latest available annual and special reports.
2010 target 90 % ≥ 90 % Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audited body The Court strives to maintain or even improve this high level of acceptance of its recommendations.
In 2010, the Court established a system for monitoring the implementation of the recommendations by the audited bodies.
In the coming years, this system will serve as a basis for a further indicator of the extent of the practical implementation of recommendations and will lead to improvements.
It will also provide the Court with valuable insights to improve the quality of its recommendations and thus to increase their acceptance by the audited bodies.
31 Efficiency and effectiveness of resource use The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources according to its ability to submit reports and audit findings on time, to meet its financial management obligations, and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff. Timeliness of reports The Court strives to accept all planned reports within the time limits set.
The publication of the annual reports and of the specific annual reports shall be subject to the deadlines laid down in legislation.
In the case of special reports where the publication date is not specified in the legislation, the date of the planned adoption shall be deemed to be the date.
2010 target Number of reports adopted compared to the number of reports planned 90% 100% Percentage of reports adopted on time 80% 100% Overall, the Court missed the target in 2010.
The Court adopted fewer reports in 2010 than planned, with performance comparable to the previous year (91% in 2009), and, while the proportion of reports adopted on time increased in 2010 (80% compared with 67% in 2009), further improvement is needed.
While all annual reports and all special annual reports were adopted and published on schedule except for one, this was only the case with three special reports.
Six special reports delayed adoption until 2011.
The Court strives to achieve the targets by introducing further measures to improve the governance of the procedures of special reports by the end of 2012.
2010 Target percentage of audit notices prepared on time 54% 80% by 2012 The performance achieved in 2010 is not yet at the required level, but significant progress has been made over the past two years in achieving the target (43% in 2009 and 27% in 2008).
The Court will continue its efforts to achieve the target. External assessment of the financial management The Court will seek to obtain a full audit opinion on the annual financial statements and the use of resources from its independent auditor and discharge from the European Parliament on the basis of a favourable recommendation from the Council.

Professional Training In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), the Court strives to provide the auditors with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training.
2010 target Average number of training days per person 5.7 days ≥ 5 days 33 In 2010, the required level of performance was reached, which means an improvement over 2009 (average of 4 days).
Staff satisfaction 86 % of the Court's employees were generally satisfied with their work in an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, with a total employee satisfaction level of 2.8 on a scale of 1 to 4. Each of the figures above 2.5 indicates general satisfaction. The Court strives to maintain or improve this result when a similar survey is conducted at the end of 2012.
34 AUDIT ASSISTANCE The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by the Court's specialised services, providing the logistical, technical and technical know-how that allows the Court to, o to recruit, retain and motivate its staff and develop its professional skills; o to disseminate the audit results in all the official languages of the EU; o to make the best use of information technologies; o to manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; o to carry out audit trips to all countries where EU funds are spent.
Staff Staff allocation The Court's most important capital is its staff. At 31 December 2010, the Court's staff was 889 (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 557 are in audit chambers (including 123 staff in members' cabinets), 151 in the Translation Directorate, 157 in administrative support services and 24 in the President's services. In 2010, in view of the objective of the best possible use of resources, possible efficiency improvements in all activities were explored and implemented through the simplification of procedures and the rationalisation of services.
If possible, job vacancies released outside the audit area were transferred to the audit service, thus increasing the number of vacancies used for audit tasks by 6 %. This process will continue in 2011.

37 Continuing vocational training The training of the examiner requires continuous training in order to keep pace with new developments and to acquire new skills.
In 2010, efforts were made to implement the staff redeployment plan adopted by the Secretary-General to move posts and staff from the translation service to the audit service in 2011. Based on the 2008-2011 plan for training and the training pathways adopted in 2009, the training department made improvements to the content of the training in 2010 and developed new training courses in line with the priorities adopted by the Court.
In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate provided valuable linguistic support to examiners on missions and the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
In addition, INTOSAI's Translation Directorate supported working groups and met other specific needs related to the Court's audit activities.
Work on the Artemis project to improve the functions of this important IT application for translators continued in 2010. In addition, the Directorate „Translation" of the Court actively participated in interinstitutional and international specialised bodies.
38 Information Technology Information Technology (IT) plays a key role in implementing the overarching objectives of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy. The following developments were noted in 2010: • the establishment of a cooperation platform in line with the strategic IT plan 2010-2012 in support of knowledge exchange in particular in the audit area; • the continuation of efforts to optimise and simplify internal procedures through electronic workflows to increase efficiency and effectiveness; the management and infrastructure task of the Financial and Support Services Directorate (Finance and Support Services) is to provide the Court's auditors with support in an efficient, efficient and timely manner and to ensure that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2010, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness in order to release resources to the audit service. • Use of smart phones and laptop com-puters to enable the efficient execution of audit work at any location and at any time, including in the context of the Court's contingency plan.

The Court's Internal Audit Service is to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives by means of a systematic, methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures. Furthermore, the Court's Internal Audit Service, on the basis of assessments on the effectiveness of the Court's internal control systems, makes proposals to increase the Court's efficiency.
In 2010, the "Internal Audit" department of the Court focused its work on the follow-up of its recommendations from previous years, the review of the Court's system of ex-ante reviews, the review of the Court's implementation of the Court's SOS II/SAP system, and the conformity of the video surveillance system with data protection rules and requirements.
In 2009, the "Internal Audit" department of the Court was audited and certified in accordance with the internationally recognised standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
The auditor's audit report – PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL – on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2009 was published in October 20107.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2011
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS DIRECTORY VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances under the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, he contributes to the improvement of EU financial management and, at the same time, acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors of integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact, and providing valuable support to its audience to improve EU financial management.
INDUSTRIALITY, INTEGRATION AND INDUSTRIALITY PROFESSIONALITY VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff.
impartiality which, while taking into account the positions of the bodies concerned, rejects any form of interference by instructions or external pressure.
To maintain a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
contributing to the further development of public financial control at EU and global level.
Preparation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports, based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the concerns of its addressees and containing important and forward-looking statements.
Involve in the effective improvement of EU management and contribute to strengthening accountability for the management of EU financial resources.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.
Increasing efficiency in all aspects of his work.

4 PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to the annual activity report 2011 of the European Court of Auditors.
In 2011, the economic and financial crisis saw significant developments in the EU's economic governance, which have a significant impact on the future use of public funding.
Against this background, the Court published a position paper in May highlighting the impact on accountability, transparency and public financial control of the measures taken in response to the financial and economic crisis.
Later that year, the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs) of the EU Member States and of the European Court of Auditors called on EU decision-makers to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control are properly respected whenever public funding is involved.
In particular, the euro area SAIs called for appropriate arrangements for public external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
This resulted in a decision to set up an Audit Committee for the Stability Mechanism to which a member proposed by the Court will be a member.
In 2011, the results of our key performance indicators are also encouraging, particularly as regards the follow-up of the recommendations accepted by our audited bodies, as well as the evaluation of our audit work by the addressees and external experts.
We were able to increase our output in terms of the number of audit reports and opinions adopted in 2011, but we were unable to achieve the ambitious targets we set ourselves in terms of the punctuality of reporting.
Our annual reports now contained more detailed information and a new chapter on performance aspects. We also produced 42 special annual reports and 16 special reports along with seven opinions and a position paper.
The scope of our institution's audit powers on Union revenue and expenditure, in particular on VAT own resources in the Member States, was confirmed by the European Court of Justice in November 2011.
From 2012 onwards, we will be able to report on to what extent our recommendations will be done in practice.
We will also conduct our methods of economic assessment under a peer review process with the aim of continuing to improve the process of producing our special reports.
In 2011, we published ethical guidelines to further strengthen the Court's audit management framework and revised Court's audit strategies and audit guidelines to streamline the audit process and the reporting process.
We will also launch a new employee satisfaction survey in 2012.
With a view to the future, we will complete the preparation of our strategy for the period 2013-2017 in 2012.
Some of the most important challenges have already been identified: the EU's regulatory framework will continue to develop, and we must continue to insist on proper compliance with the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control.
The need for a high quality and timely guarantee for the use of EU funding is constantly increasing and we need to further develop our audits and reports accordingly.
Since the EU is undergoing a continuous process of change, we will also endeavour to make the best possible use of our audit experience to support policy-makers in improving financial management.
Strengthening the EU's financial accountability is a goal that we have in common with other actors and we will try to pool our efforts by entering into strategic partnerships.
Finally, like the other EU institutions and bodies, we need to be prepared to achieve more with less to improve the efficiency of our organisation.
Meeting these challenges will depend to a significant extent on the efforts of all the Court's staff.
The development of the excellence of our employees – a fundamental value of our institution – is and remains an important concern for us.
With regard to the professionalism, commitment and results achieved by our employees in the past, I am confident that the Court will be able to achieve these future goals.

This led to the publication of the 2010 Annual Report, including the seventeenth Statement of Assurance (DAS), on 10 November 2011.
The 2010 Annual Report introduced some changes to improve clarity and information.
These include the reshaping of the themes (and the related annual chapters) among which the Court groups expenditure, the publication of estimated error rates by policy area (see below), increased attention to recommendations to improve financial management, and a new chapter on performance aspects.
For the first time, the Court published estimated error rates for both the EU budget as a whole and for individual themes.
The error rates are calculated by extrapolating the quantifiable errors detected in the samples of operations examined.
The Court compares the estimated error rate with a materiality threshold of 2 % to determine whether the error is material, with further proof.
Error rates are not a measure of fraud, but reflect the Court's estimate of the violation of the rules governing expenditure.
This includes non-compliance with public procurement rules, non-eligible or miscalculated costs claimed by EU co-financed projects, or excessive area data provided by farmers.
The key statements of the 2010 annual report were as follows: o The annual accounts for the financial year 2010 constitute the financial situation of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year as a whole.
On the other hand, the payments underlying this annual accounts are considerably affected by errors, with the estimated error rate for the EU budget as a whole being 3.7%.
The control systems were partly effective to ensure the regularity of payments as a whole. o The Court's estimate of the error rate of cohesion, energy and transport expenditure (the EU's most error-hit expenditure area) was 7.7% higher than in 2009. o In the other EU expenditure areas, the error rate remained relatively stable.
In the field of agriculture and natural resources, the estimated error rate was 2.3% and was thus above the materiality threshold.
However, direct payments to farmers did not show significant errors. o The share of advance payments – pre-financing – within the EU budget has increased significantly.
The accounting rules and supervisory arrangements have not been adjusted accordingly. o When planning EU spending programmes, the Commission and the Member States should pay greater attention to defining SMART objectives, i.e. concrete, measurable, achievable, appropriate, and a date, but also to identifying and mitigating potential risks during the implementation.
ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR 2010 In its Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for the financial year 2010 (published on 10 November 2011), the Court concluded that the 2010 financial statements of the EDFs represent the financial position of the EDFs and the results of its operations and cash flows in accordance with the financial rules in all material respects.
EDF revenue is not subject to substantial errors.
EDF commitments were lawful and lawful, regardless of the non-quantifiable errors detected in the procurement sector.
However, the EDF payments for projects were significantly affected by errors, with an estimated error rate of 3.4%.
The errors identified concerned non-compliance with eligibility requirements.
The Court assessed that the control systems established by the EDF only partially guarantee the regularity of the payments as a whole.
SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS ON AGENCIES, DECENTRAL BODIES AND OTHER EU INSTITUTIONS FOR 2010 In December 2011, the Court published special annual reports on the 2010 financial year for all 42 agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. Joint Undertakings) and other EU bodies (in particular, the efficiency of the management of the European Central Bank).
The Court gave an unqualified opinion on all audited entities, with the exception of the European GNSS Agency, on the grounds that certain assets were not included in the accounts, and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking, on the grounds that the accounts were not included in the accounts.
The EU agencies and decentralised bodies have been set up by the EU legislator to carry out specific tasks.
Each Agency shall have a mandate, a Management Board, a Director, staff and a budget.
The agencies are active in a number of areas, such as security, health, research, finance, migration and travel.
