12 SPECIAL REPORTS ADOPTED IN 2011 In addition to its annual reports, the Court shall, during the year, publish special reports containing the results of the Court's economic and compliance audits on specific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice.
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is anxious to achieve maximum impact and to make the best use of its resources.
In selecting the subjects, the Court shall take into account the following factors: i) the risks to the economy or to compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; ii) the level of revenue or expenditure concerned; ii) the time elapsed since any prior examination; ii) future developments within the relevant legal framework; ii) the political and public interest.
In 2011, the Court adopted 16 special reports on a number of topics, which represents an increase on the 14 special reports adopted in 2010.
These special reports are presented below in a concise form under the relevant headings of the financial framework – the EU's multiannual budget.
The special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu in full or available from the EU Bookshop.
SUSTAINABLE GROWTH 13 Sustainable growth focuses on growth and jobs and focuses on two issues: competitiveness includes the promotion of research and technological development, the networking of Europe, education and training, promotion of competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, the social agenda and the dismantling of nuclear installations.
EU expenditure on growth and employment in 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 89.4 billion, i.e. 9.2% of the total funding, of which nearly two thirds is in research and development. Cohesion for growth and employment is mainly in the form of cohesion policy, which is implemented in the form of European Social Fund, Cohesion Fund and European Regional Development Fund.
The appropriations shall be allocated by shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
The EU budget for cohesion for the period 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 348.4 billion (35.7% of the total EU budget).
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: the effectiveness of the SME Guarantee Facility (Special Report No 4/2011) in the light of its design and planning, and the management of its related operations and the achievement of its objectives.
The SME Guarantee Facility (SMEG Facility) is a financial instrument managed on behalf of the European Commission by the European Investment Fund. It provides financial intermediaries with guarantees or guarantees for loans made to SMEs by financial institutions, thereby increasing the availability of debt finance. o Effectiveness of the tourism projects cofinanced by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (Special Report No. 6/2011) in terms of expected results, sustainability, European added value and project design.
The audit was based on a broad-based survey of projects in new Member States and 26 regions.
During the period 2000-2006, the ERDF provided EUR 4.6 billion of EU funds for real investment in tourism projects, selected and managed by managing authorities in the Member States.
14 o The effectiveness of eGovernment projects funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (Special Report No 9/2011) with a focus on the 2000-2006 programming period and the four Member States of Spain, France, Italy and Poland.
The audit evaluated whether the co-financed projects were selected on the basis of the needs identified, whether they were carried out as planned, and whether they were appropriate and sustainable.
This EUR 6.7 billion ERDF resources for the information society should be used to develop new safe technologies, to develop infrastructure and to link regions through broadband. o the effectiveness of the Commission's management of State aid control (Special Report No 15/2011).
The examination has examined whether the procedures and systems ensure that the Commission handles all relevant aid cases, the cases are dealt with effectively and within the deadlines laid down, and the Commission is able to monitor the impact of its State aid control.
It is up to the Commission to ensure that State aid granted by the Member States is compatible with the internal market of the European Union.
Member States must only notify aid measures to the Commission and obtain the Commission's approval before granting State aid. o Implement EU financial support for the decommissioning of nuclear power plants in Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia (Special Report No 16/2011) to assess whether the measures of the nuclear decommissioning programmes have been adequately designed, whether they have been carried out as planned, and whether the structures for accountability and administration have been designed to ensure the effective use of EU funds.
Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia committed themselves to early shutdown and subsequent decommissioning of eight non-refitable nuclear reactors during their EU accession negotiations.
In view of the exceptional burden, the EU provided €2.9 billion of support for the three country programmes for the period 1999-2013.
The EU has a high political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 413.1 billion, i.e. 42.3% of the total budget.
Three quarters of the expenditure relates to direct payments to farmers and support to agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) – the ‘first pillar' of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of the expenditure is allocated to EU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second "pillar of the CAP".
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
The Court adopted the following special reports in this area in 2011: o Single payment scheme under the Common Agricultural Policy (Special Report No 5/2011) – See box: ‘Initiating an economic impact assessment' o How good is the design and management of the agri-environmental measures supported? (Special Report No 7/2011).
This report assesses whether agri-environment policy is designed and accompanied in such a way as to provide a significant environmental benefit, whether farmers are adequately supported by adequate guidance and adequate amounts of aid, and whether specific environmental needs are taken into account in the management of agri-environment policy.
The aim of agri-environmental policy is to meet the increasing social demand for environmental services by encouraging farmers to introduce or maintain production processes compatible with the protection and improvement of the environment.
This area is subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States. o Recovery of irregular payments under the common agricultural policy (Special Report No 8/2011) to assess the effectiveness of the recovery schemes established and operated by the Member States.
The audit examined whether the Member States had been able to properly collect and process claims, whether the measures taken by the Member States to recover identified unlawful payments, whether the Member States had acted properly in the Member States' unremitting claims and whether the Commission's supervision and supervision had been effective.
The European Union spends some EUR 55 billion per year on agriculture and rural development, and some of the funds are wrongly paid out on the basis of illegal or incorrect applications. 15
16 o The effectiveness of the "school milk" and "school fruit" programmes (Special Report No 10/2011) to assess whether EU aid has a direct impact on the beneficiaries' consumption and whether the programmes are suitable for implementing the educational impact and for impacting future eating habits.
These EU programmes aim to encourage children to eat healthy food through the consumption of milk products and fruit and vegetables and to contribute to the improvement of the market conditions for these products.
The EU is currently providing an annual budget of EUR 180 million for these two programmes. o Making it possible to design and manage the geographical indications scheme that it is effective? (Special Report No 11/2011).
The audit assessed the reliability of the control system, the attractiveness of the system for producers and the consumer awareness of the system.
The objective of the EU scheme for geographical indications is to protect the names of products for which there is a link between their characteristics and the geographical area from which they originate.
The scheme has economic potential for farmers and food producers and can have a positive impact on the rural economy in the regions of the EU. o The effectiveness of EU measures to adapt fishing fleet fishing capacity to existing fishing opportunities (Special Report No 12/2011).
The audit examined whether there was a clear framework for the reduction of fleet capacity and whether the specific measures were and were implemented.
The investigation took place at the Commission and in Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Poland, Portugal and the United Kingdom.
The aim of the EU's common fisheries policy is to promote sustainable fishing by achieving a balance between fisheries and the fishing fleet in order to avoid overfishing.
For many years, the overcapacity of the fishing fleet has been a problem, jeopardising both the sustainability of fish stocks and the long-term viability of the fisheries sector.
The European Fisheries Fund will provide EUR 4.3 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period.
17 APPROVAL OF AN ECONOMIC ASSESSMENT SPECIAL REPORT No 5/2011 OPERATING PREMIUM REGULATION: REPORTING ASSESSMENTS ASSESSMENT OF A BETTER FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT This audit covered the sound financial management of the payments under the single payment scheme, which is currently being applied in 17 of the 27 EU Member States.
Expenditure related to this scheme amounted to around 28.8 billion euros in 2009.
The introduction of the single payment scheme was a key element of the 2003 reform of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this scheme was to encourage farmers to respond better to market demand and to provide income support.
In the course of the reform, the link between support and production was dissolved ("decoupling").
Instead, farmers must have eligible agricultural land and ‘payment entitlements'.
From 2006 onwards, the Court carried out a series of audits of the procedures set up by the Commission and the Member States to ensure the accuracy of payment entitlements and the correctness of payments to farmers.
These audits covered all 17 Member States applying the scheme and the results of these audits were included in the 2006 and 2007 annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court decided to carry out, on the basis of these results, an economic audit focusing on the following aspects: (i) the beneficiaries of the scheme, access to single payments and the definition of eligible areas; (ii) the contribution of the scheme to the objectives of income support to farmers and to the preservation of agricultural land in good agricultural and environmental conditions; (iii) the specific consequences of the application of the different models to implement the scheme.
Test visits were held in 2009 and 2010 at the Commission, as well as in France, Italy and the United Kingdom.
The conclusion of the resulting Special Report No 5/2011 was that the single payment scheme contributed to the achievement of the two main objectives of the common agricultural policy: to encourage farmers to respond better to market demand and to support the income of the agricultural sector as a whole.
However, in general terms, the implementation of the scheme has led to a number of questionable features concerning the definition of the beneficiaries of this policy, the nature of the eligible parcels and activities, the environmental impact of the scheme, the distribution of aid from Member State to Member State and within Member States and the specific impact of the historical and regional model.
18 The Court recommends in the report that it is better for the single payment to be paid to active farmers and that non-agricultural parcels and activities that do not help to increase agricultural productivity or the active preservation of the ecological value of the land be excluded from the support.
In addition, the Court recommends that the level of the single payment should take into account the costs of environmental and other external effects, and that a more balanced distribution of the aid among farmers should be sought.
The calculation of the single payment should be based on the current management conditions.
The examination was carried out by a multidisciplinary team of eight examiners of Chamber I. The examination work provided not only further information regarding the concept of the decoupled single payment but also regarding the impact of the conversion process on the current scheme from the previous coupled support scheme.
According to team leader Sven Kölling, the examination of the various models and variants existing under the single payment scheme, together with the coexistence of national and regional administrative strategies and their impact on the profitability and effectiveness of the premium, was a particular challenge.
Test visits to final beneficiaries and on-the-spot checks at the premises proved to be indispensable to obtain the verification evidence to support the findings and conclusions.
Many of the Court's recommendations were reflected in the Commission's proposals for reform of the common agricultural policy after 2013 (at the time of the preparation of this report in the discussion), including the definition of an "active farmer" and of minimum activities on certain areas, the distribution of premium payments among beneficiaries, the reduction in the number of implementation models for the single payment scheme, and the better consideration of environmental external effects in the calculation of single payments.
Tester team from left to right: (first row) Heike Walz, Court Member Michel Cretin, Aurelia Petliza, (second row) Pietro Puricella, Dirk Pauwels, Sven Kölling, Sylvain Lehnhard
EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER 19 The EU's external relations activities focus on enlargement, the achievement of stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood, active support for sustainable development at international level, and the promotion of global political governance and security in its strategy and in its neighbourhood.
The EU has allocated EUR 55,9 billion, i.e. 5,7 % of its planned total expenditure, to these objectives, for the period 2007-2013.
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its central services or delegations.
Some support measures are also managed together with international organisations.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Has the deconcentration of the management of external aid from the Commission's central departments to its delegations led to a better provision of aid?
(Special Report No 1/2011).
The audit covered the examination of administrative modalities and their impact on the speedier delivery and better quality of assistance and the creation of stable financial procedures.
The EU is the world's largest donor of development assistance, with a large part of this assistance (EUR 8.4 billion in 2009) being managed by the Commission within the framework of its administrative system, with powers being delegated to the Commission's external offices in the partner countries from 2002 onwards. o Economic efficiency and effectiveness of EU contributions (Special Report No. 3/2011) by United Nations agencies in conflict-affected countries, with a focus on projects in Afghanistan, Iraq and Sudan in the period 2006-2008.
EuropeAid provided around 4 billion euros through UN organisations in the period 2005-2009.
The EU may provide funds as the sole donor or as a joint donor, as contributions to trust funds, without providing funds for specific activities or objectives, or as a contribution to the general budget of a UN organisation. o Effectiveness of EU assistance in improving Croatia's ability to manage post-accession funding (Special Report No 14/2011) to assess the Commission's planning of assistance and whether the intended results of projects financed by EU funds have been achieved.
The objective of the EU pre-accession assistance is to assist the candidate countries in building up their administrative capacity to prepare them for the management of the larger EU aid to which they will be entitled as Member States.
EU pre-accession assistance to Croatia has been worth EUR 150 million annually since 2007.
The budget of the European Union is primarily financed from own resources and other revenue.
Traditional own resources – mainly customs duties – represent around 12% of total revenue and the VAT own resources represent an additional 12% of total revenue.
The bulk of the EU's own resources (70%) comes from the own resources derived from gross national income, which ensure that the budget is always balanced.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Management of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) (Special Report No 2/2011) to assess the measures taken to implement the recommendations of the previous Special Report No 1/2005 of the Court on the subject.
The starting point for the audit was whether OLAF has now shifted the focus of its activities to its investigative role and whether the investigations of OLAF are more effective, how to demonstrate the effectiveness of its investigative activities and whether the role of the Supervisory Committee has been clarified.
OLAF's role is to combat fraud and other illegal activities to the detriment of the EU budget.
The Office is affiliated to the Commission, but has full independence in the conduct of its investigations and employs around 500 staff, the annual expenditure being around EUR 50 million.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: o Is the Court able to prevent and detect VAT evasion through the control of customs procedure 42? (Special Report No 13/2011) In the course of this audit, the Court examined whether a sound legal framework exists to combat VAT evasion under customs procedure 42.
Belgium, Denmark, Spain, France, Austria, Slovenia and Sweden tested.
Customs procedure 42 is a mechanism used by an EU importer to obtain a VAT exemption.
The procedure shall apply when goods imported from outside the EU into one Member State are transported to another Member State.
In such cases, VAT shall be due in the Member State of destination.
OPINIONS AND POSITIONS POSITIONED IN 2011 The Court's opinions on proposals for new or amended acts with financial implications also contribute to improving EU financial management.
These opinions will be delivered at the request of the other EU institutions and will be used by the legislative authorities – the European Parliament and the Council – in their work.
The Court may also issue position papers on other issues on its own initiative.
In 2011, the Court adopted seven opinions: o 1/2011: Proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 215/2008 on the financial regulation applicable to the 10th European Development Fund on the European External Action Service o 2/2011: Financial Regulation of the Clean Sky Joint Undertaking o 3/2011: Proposal for a Regulation amending the Financial Regulation of the European Schools o 4/2011: Commission Green Paper on the modernisation of European public procurement policy o 5/2011: Proposal for a Council Regulation (Euratom) on the rules for the participation of undertakings, research centres and universities in indirect actions under the Framework Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community and for the dissemination of research results (2012-2013) o 6/2011: Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1073/1999 on investigations carried out by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and repealing Regulation (Euratom) No 1074/1999.
The contribution from the EU budget to achieving the Europe 2020 objectives is therefore highly dependent on the economical, efficient and effective use of these funds.
This will also affect the credibility and legitimacy of EU action.
The EU continues to face the challenge of achieving good quality results through a system of prior allocation of funds to the Member States and of the use of these funds as an implicit objective.
The effective monitoring and accountability of the Commission would help Member States to use the funds successfully.
The opinions are available in full on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu in all the official languages of the EU. 21
22 HOFE'S POSITION PAPER: CONSOLIDATED TO THE CURRENT FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC CRISIS FOR THE PUBLIC PUBLIC AND PUBLIC FINANCIAL CONTROLS FOR THE EU AND THE HOFE'S ROLE The ongoing global financial and economic crisis had far-reaching consequences for the European Union.
To address the crisis, the EU took measures to ensure the long-term sustainability of the financial sector, to promote economic recovery and growth, to provide financial assistance to Member States and to strengthen financial and economic coordination between Member States.
Furthermore, these measures have a decisive influence on how public funds, i.e. EU citizens' taxpayers' money, are used in the Union.
These changes to the Union's regulatory structure present new challenges in terms of accountability, transparency and public financial control.
The Court considers that, when implementing these new measures, the principle is that appropriate procedures for transparency, public accountability and public financial control should be laid down whenever public funding is involved.
The Court therefore adopted a position paper on 19 May 2011 on the impact of the current financial and economic crisis on public accountability and public financial control in the EU and on the role of the Court.
In this position paper, the Court concluded that it would include the new supervisory authorities, the support mechanisms with EU budget guarantees, and, where possible, the Commission's activities under the European Semester in its audits.
The Court considers that the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism should provide for a form of external public financial control.
Finally, the Court notes that, in a number of cases, accountability and transparency issues need to be considered by the relevant EU institutions, in particular by the European Parliament and the Council.
COOPERATION WITH OTHER SAIs The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCs) mainly in the following bodies: o Contact Committee of the SAIs of EU Member States; o Network of the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; o International organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and their European Regional Group (EUROSAI).
CONTACT COMMITTEE In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies shall cooperate with each other with confidence, while respecting their independence.
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of the EU Member States within the Contact Committee.
The Contact Committee shall meet once a year between the Presidents of the EU-ORKB and the Court.
The Contact Committee shall provide a forum for cooperation and the exchange of expertise and experience in the field of the examination of EU funds and other EU issues.
Working groups have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices.
In 2011, the Court was acting Chairman of the Contact Committee, continued to provide administrative support to the Committee and actively participated in the various working groups and networks.
The annual meeting of the Contact Committee in 2011 took place on 13 and 14 October 2011 on the premises of the Court.
The meeting focused on a seminar on the impact of the European Semester and other recent developments in the EU's economic governance on the EU and the Court of Auditors.
In this context, the Commission addressed, inter alia, the regulation and supervision of financial systems and financial institutions, state aid to the financial sector and the examination of the mechanisms to deal with the euro crisis.
The Contact Committee adopted a declaration addressed to the European Parliament, the European Council and the European Commission, and to the parliaments and governments of the EU Member States.
In addition, the Contact Committee adopted a resolution to take account of the reputation of the SAIs of the euro area countries for adequate external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
Declaration and resolution are available on the website of the Contact Committee (www.contactcommitte.eu).

The organisational structure of the network is comparable to that of the Contact Committee and includes regular meetings of the presidents of the SAIs and liaison officers as well as working groups, seminars, workshops and parallel audits.
The main objective is to promote the use of audit methods and procedures consistent with international standards and best EU methods.
A meeting of the network presidents took place in Istanbul on 8 and 9 March 2011.
The Turkish Court of Auditors and the European Court of Auditors had the joint chair at this meeting, which led to the adoption of the Istanbul Agreement, including a work programme for future activities, to be implemented with active support from the European Court of Auditors, SIGMA and representatives of the EU ORKB.

An important objective of this working group is to develop guidelines and to identify and disseminate best practice in the field of disaster response accountability, focusing on the activities aimed at stakeholders (multilateral bodies, relief organisations, governments, private auditors).

28 OTHER ACTIVITIES POWERS OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS IN THE COOPERATION OF VAT OWN RESOURCES On 15 November 2011, the Court of Justice delivered its judgment in Case C-539/09 Commission v Federal Republic of Germany on the audit powers of the European Court of Auditors in the field of own resources in the field of value added tax (VAT).
The case stems from the refusal by the German Federal Ministry of Finance in 2006 to allow the European Court of Auditors to carry out audits of the administrative cooperation of Member States in the field of VAT in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 in Germany.
In preparing its Special Report No 8/2007, the Court decided to carry out audits in eight Member States, including Germany.
The German authorities objected to the Court's right to carry out the examination in question.
The German Government argued that the cooperation between the managing authorities of the Member States, as provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003, was not directly linked to the EU's revenue as VAT was to be distinguished from VAT own resources.
The latter are determined according to a series of calculations and represent a relatively small proportion of the amounts collected by the Member States as value added tax.
The Court rejected the argument of the German Government based on a strict distinction between the VAT revenues of the Member States and the Union's own resources.
On the basis of the arguments put forward by the Commission, the European Parliament and the European Court of Auditors, the Court of Justice stressed the dependence of VAT own resources on the VAT receipts of the Member States.
The Court confirmed that the scope of Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 on administrative cooperation in the field of value added tax covered the definition of cooperation mechanisms between Member States that would allow them to combat VAT evasion more effectively and to impose VAT more effectively.
This also affects the availability of VAT own resources for the EU budget.
Where cooperation between national authorities is carried out effectively and in accordance with the Regulation, it may contribute to a reduction in fraud and to the effective collection of VAT in the Member States, and to the retention of VAT own resources at the level to which they have to have under the various relevant EU acts, in order to maintain the overall balance of own resources.
The Court concluded that the Court of Auditors had the power to carry out the planned examination in the context of administrative cooperation in the field of value added tax, since it had the power to carry out the audit in the field of VAT, since it concerned the EU's revenue in terms of its legality and sound financial management and was therefore directly related to the powers conferred on the Court by the Treaty.
In Case C-539/09, the Court of Justice had for the first time to decide explicitly on the scope of the Court's powers of scrutiny.
The Court's judgment is valuable and encouraging because it clarifies and underpins the institution's powers of examination vis-à-vis the Member States.

31 OUR MANAGEMENT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STRATEGY FOR 2009 STRATEGY 2012 In recent years, the Court has launched an internal reform process.
This included the development of its first strategy for the period 2009-20122 with the following overarching objectives: o maximising the overall impact of the audits; o improving efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
Many of the priority actions foreseen in the strategy have already been completed and the remaining actions will be completed in 2012 in 2 The audit strategy 2009-2012 is addressed at www.eca.europa.eu. The main achievements achieved in 2011 are: o an increase in the number of special reports; in 2009-2011 an average of 16 special reports have been published per year, exceeding the target of 12-15 reports per year; o important contributions to the reform of the EU budget; o an incentive to prepare regular follow-up reports on previous findings, including an overall follow-up report to be prepared for the first time in 2012; o revised audit strategies and audit directives; o increasing emphasis on core activities, by shifting staff from support services to the audit services; o publication of a position paper on the impact of the current financial and economic crisis on public accountability and financial control within the EU and on the role of the Court.
ETHIC GUIDELINES FOR THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS Following the recommendation of the 2008 peer review, the Court strengthened the framework of its audit management by adopting ethical guidelines based on the INTOSAI's obligations and code of conduct and the International Standard for Quality Control within the SAIs3.
In this context, the Court has established a procedure to provide, on an annual basis, sufficient certainty that its auditors will comply with the relevant ethical requirements.
Respect for the values laid down in the ethical guidelines, such as impartiality, objectivity, loyalty and professional secrecy, ensures that the Court's employees act in the public interest in the absence of external pressure and of any personal or financial interest.
The Court's professional behaviour framework promotes the credibility of the information submitted to its addressee.

EFFICIENCY AND EFFICIENCY OF RESOURCES The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources according to the extent to which it is able to present reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its employees.
POSSIBLE REPORTS The Court endeavours to adopt all audit reports within the specified time limits.
For the annual reports and special annual reports, the dates laid down in the legislation must be observed.
In the case of special reports where there is no publication date specified in legislation, the planned date of acceptance shall be considered as the time-scale of punctuality.

The audit reports shall contain details of the specific audit findings and shall be prepared after verification visits to Member States or to the Commission.
The Court uses them to confirm the factual accuracy of its findings by the audited bodies. The audit reports therefore constitute an important stage in the audit process.
The Court has previously established that there is a considerable need for improvement in the preparation of the audit communications in terms of punctuality. The target to be achieved by the end of 2012 is to produce 80% of the audit notifications within two months of the audit visit in question.

36 EXTERNAL ASSESSMENT OF THE FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT The Court strives to obtain a full audit opinion from its independent auditor on the annual accounts and the use of resources and to obtain discharge from the European Parliament on the basis of a favourable Council recommendation.
VOCATIONAL TRAINING In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), the Court strives to provide auditors with on average 40 hours (five days) of professional training (without language courses).
GRAD TO THE SAFETY OF THE PERSONAL In a 2009 internal employee satisfaction survey, 86% of the Court's employees were generally satisfied with their work, with a total of 2.8 employees' satisfaction on a scale of 1 to 4. Each figure of more than 2.5 indicates general satisfaction.
The Court aims to maintain or improve this outcome when a similar survey is conducted in 2012.
VOLUNTARY ASSISTANCE The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by the Court's specialised departments.
These services provide the logistical and technical know-how which enables the Court to o recruit, retain and motivate its staff and develop its professional skills; o disseminate the audit results in all the official languages of the EU; o make the best use of information technology; o manage its budget and manage its infrastructure; o carry out audit visits to obtain evidence on the spot in the countries in which EU funds are collected and spent.
37 PERSONAL PERSONAL ASSESSMENT The Court's most important capital is its employees.
As of 31 December 2010, the staff of the Court amounted to 887 staff (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 564 are in audit chambers (including 123 in members' cabinets), 148 in the Translation Directorate, 148 in administrative support services and 27 in the President's services.
In 2011, with a view to achieving the best possible use of resources, all of the departments once again explored and implemented ways to increase efficiency by simplifying procedures.
Where possible, efficiency gains outside of the audit area have shifted posts to the audit service, which has contributed more than half to the 12,6 % increase in audit posts in the audit area since 2008.

38 TERMINATIONS The staff of the Court have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff of both officials and temporary staff.
The European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) organises general selections for European Court posts.
In addition, the Court, like the other EU institutions, like the other EU institutions, promotes a policy of equal opportunities within the framework of its staff policy and in the case of recruitment.
After continuous growth in the proportion of women over the years, the Court has now reached a balanced proportion of men and women among its employees.
In 2011, the Court hired 75 employees: 23 officials, 24 temporary staff and 28 contract staff.
In particular, the Court succeeded in recruiting new personnel to audit posts.
On 31 December 2011, 25 vacancies were vacant – much less than in 2010 (44).
This meant that for the first time the vacancy rate fell below 3%.

In 2011, the volume of translation was comparable to the volume of work of 2010.

40 INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology (IT) plays a key role in implementing the overall objectives of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy.
In 2011, the Court took the following steps: the reinforcement of its investment in knowledge management by launching the development of a new version of the impact support instrument (project called ‘Assyst2') on the basis of the recently established cooperation platform; the active continuation of its efforts to streamline internal operations through electronic operations in areas such as the management of missions and training; and the electronic archiving of staff files in order to continuously increase efficiency and effectiveness; and the continued support for mobility through the use of smartphones and laptop computers; and the launching of an Extranet project, which will also play a key role in simplifying electronic exchange with a wide range of Court partners (including audited bodies, budgetary authorities, newly recruited staff, suppliers).
These developments were carried out while strengthening operational security and emergency procedures to ensure the necessary availability and quality of all the Court's IT services.
MANAGEMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE The role of the Financial and Support Services Directorate is to provide the Court's auditors with efficient, effective, timely and appropriate support and to ensure that the necessary financial, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2011, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness to release resources to the audit service.
Following an agreement reached with the budgetary authority (Parliament and Council) at the end of 2008 on the financing of the K3 building, a key activity in 2011 was the construction of the second extension building to the main building of the courtyard.
The construction work was completed in the course of 2011, and the shell was made weatherproof at the end of the year.
A great deal of progress has been made in interior design.
The time and budget framework of the construction project is respected.
The yard is expected to take possession of the building at the end of 2012 and the relocations are expected to take place in the first quarter of 2013.
Analysis carried out in 2009 and 2010 led the Court to conclude that its safety objectives could be best achieved and that the most efficient and cost-effective management of risks could be achieved in the in-house delivery of the reception and security services.
This was achieved in April 2011 by replacing the external contractor for security services with a small team of contract staff.
The annual costs will be more than 0.5 million euros lower in 2012 than in 2009.
TEST TEST In the course of the Court's audit work, the auditors must travel to the Member States and to other recipients of EU funds as well as to the headquarters of international organisations such as the United Nations.
The purpose of these verification visits is to obtain direct proof of verification.
The visits are usually carried out by central and local authorities involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EU funds, as well as by the respective final beneficiaries.
Within the EU, the audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member State visited.
The audit teams typically consist of two to three auditers and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and the distance.

46 TESTING AND ACCOUNTING INTERNAL VERIFICATION The role of the Internal Audit Service is to provide independent and objective assurance and advisory services designed to provide added value to the Court's activities and to improve them.
It assists the Court in achieving the institution's objectives by applying a systematic and rigorous approach to the evaluation and presentation of recommendations to improve the effectiveness of risk management, control and governance processes.
In carrying out its task, the Internal Audit Service acts in accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, the legislation applicable to EU officials and the International Standards for the Professional Practice of Internal Audit.
In 2009, the "Internal Audit" department of the Court was audited and certified in accordance with the internationally recognised standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
EXTERNAL AUDIT OF THE COURT The annual accounts of the European Court of Auditors shall be audited by an independent auditor.
This is a key element of the Court's efforts to ensure that it applies the same transparency and accountability principles to itself as to the bodies it assesses.
In 2011, the Court's Internal Audit Service presented reports on the state of implementation of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy; implementation of key performance indicators; establishment of the Court's new K3 building; use of the trust account for payments to eligible beneficiaries; follow-up to previous recommendations.
The Internal Audit Service assisted the Court's independent auditor in the Court's audit in every respect with regard to the certification of the Court's annual accounts and the effectiveness of its internal control procedures.
The Court's Committee for Internal Audit advises on internal audit issues and monitors the internal control environment associated with it in the context of the institution's risk management procedures.
In 2011, the Internal Audit Committee and the Internal Audit Committee analysed the results of the Internal Audit Service's audits, the implementation of the action plans affecting the internal control environment and the risks to the governance of the institution.
The auditor's audit report – PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL – on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2010 was published in September 20116.

STRUCTURE OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State.
Its members shall be appointed by the Council for a six-year term after consulting the European Parliament.
Members shall elect a President from among them for a term of three years, with a possibility of re-election.
The Court is organised according to chambers to which the members are assigned.
The Chambers shall prepare reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
The examination chambers I to IV cover various revenue and expenditure areas, while the fifth, the CEAD chamber, is responsible for horizontal matters.
The chambers are supported by examination directions.
Since the Court's amendment of its Rules of Procedure in 2010, certain categories of reports and opinions of the Court may be adopted by Chambers rather than by the College of the Court as a whole.
The Management Committee shall meet under the chairmanship of the President and shall consist of the Doyens of the Chambers and the Secretary-General (responsible for the Court's administrative and support services).
The Committee has a coordinating role and prepares Court decisions on strategic planning, performance management and administrative matters.
Each member is responsible for specific tasks, primarily in the audit area.
Members shall submit proposals for examination and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible to the relevant Chamber and the Court.
After the adoption of a report, the report is presented to the European Parliament, the Council and other relevant stakeholders by the rapporteur.
The members are supported by their cabinet staff and by the examiner team appointed for the examination task. 49

3 EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS PROCUREMENT PROCUREMENT BALANCE VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to the improvement of EU financial management, promotes accountability and transparency, and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
INDEPENDENTITY, INTEGRITY AND INTEGRITY PROFESSIONALITY VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its staff.
To maintain a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
The preparation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and supporting documents, taking into account the concerns of its addressees, and including important and forward-looking statements.
To contribute to an effective improvement in the management of the EU budget and contribute to an increase in accountability in the management of EU funds.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.
5 CONTENTS Page 6 PREVENTION OF THE PRESIDENT 8 2012 AT A BENEFIT 9 OUR ACTIVITIES 9 AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS 30 COOPERATION WITH OTHER OUR BENEFIT ACCOUNT AUTHORITIES 34 OUR MANAGEMENT 35 EXCHANGES IN THE COURT'S COLLECTION 36 MEASUREMENT DATA BENEFIT THE COURT 44 SUPPORTING THE AUDIT ACTIVITIES 49 FINANCIAL INFORMATION 52 AUDIT AND ACCOUNTS 53 DECLARATION OF THE COLLECTIVE ADVICES 54 35 YEARS IN THE SERVICE OF A BENEFIT FUNCTIONING THE EU 6 PREVENTION OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the 2012 Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors!
In 2012, an important focus of the Court's work was to prepare the Union for the key challenges of financial management after 2013.
At the beginning of the year, the Court adopted its opinion on some of the proposals for regulations on the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the most famous EU policy.
The draft regulation was part of the package of legislative proposals related to the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020.
With a number of opinions and reports published in 2012, the Court actively contributed to the strengthening of the new arrangements to which the EU's revenue and expenditure will be subject in that period.
In addition, the Court continued to closely monitor the impact of developments in EU economic governance on public accountability and financial control in 2012.
This year, the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism entered into force, and the Audit Committee of that new body, including a representative of the Court, met for its first meeting.
In December 2012, the Council of the European Union adopted its position on the establishment of a single supervisory mechanism to ensure oversight of euro area credit institutions and the Court announced its position on public accountability and financial control to EU policy-makers.
Many changes in economic governance and in the EU budget result from the need to improve policy outcomes with lower public resources while strengthening democratic legitimacy and accountability.
Due to its unique powers and perspective on the one hand, and the experience gained in the course of its 35 years of experience, and the partnerships established, on the other hand, the Court is well positioned to support the EU in addressing these challenges.
Based on its achievements in recent years, the Court's objective is to maximise the Court's contribution to improving the EU's accountability in the 2013-2017 period.
The court is currently celebrating its 35th anniversary.
Europe has changed radically since the Court began its work in 1977.
The structure of the Court and the way in which it performs its tests reflect these changes.
With the accession of new Member States, the transfer of competences to the Union and the establishment of numerous bodies at EU level, the audit area of the Court has expanded.
The Court has also grown as an institution, from nine members and 120 employees in 1977 to 27 members and nearly 900 employees in 2012.
This growth enabled the farm to build a professional, committed and experienced workforce.
2012 was the last year the Court's strategy for the period 2009-2012 was for.
The Court has shown encouraging results over the course of this period.
This Annual Activity Report shows that output has been increased, that external experts consider the quality of our reports to be good, and that the main institutional stakeholders find it useful.
The level of acceptance of the Court's recommendations by the Commission is consistently high and the Court's new follow-up report highlights the positive impact of the recommendations.
The Court can also demonstrate efficiency gains in the area of administration and translation, which led to the deployment of 40 additional employees in the audit area at the end of the period.
To achieve the targets for the 2013-2017 period, the Court will give priority to products to improve the EU's accountability obligation and will expand and expand its partnerships, professionalism and efficiency.
In 2013, an international peer review team will examine the Court's peer review practice and follow up on the results of the previous peer review of 2008.
Other key actions launched in 2013 include streamlining the Court's reporting procedures and making even better use of our shared knowledge base, expertise and expertise.
These and other initiatives will help the EU address its growing challenges in the area of public accountability and financial control in the coming years.
Mr Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 7
8 2012 AT A GLANCE OF OUR ACTIVITIES o Annual reports on the EU general budget and on the European Development Funds for the financial year 2011, improving clarity and information. o 50 specific annual reports on the various agencies, decentralised bodies and other EU bodies for the financial year 2011. o 25 special reports on certain budgetary areas or management issues. o 9 opinions on financial reform, such as the reform of the common agricultural policy and a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the fight against fraud against the financial interests of the European Union.
OUR MANAGEMENT o Adoption of a new strategy for 2013-2017, which will guide the Court's activities during this period, with the aim of maximising the value of the Court's contribution to the EU's public accountability. o Our key performance indicators for the period 2008-2012 show an improved performance; for the first time, they measure the proportion of our recommendations that has been implemented. o Further development of the Court's personnel policy and the continuation of the sourcing of the audit service, through efficiency gains in the administrative and translation sectors, have increased the Court's ability to fulfil its mission. o Construction work on the K3 building – the Court's second extension – has been completed, allowing the Court's entire staff to be accommodated at a single location.
9 OUR ACTIVITIES REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are the following: o Annual reports – with the results of its audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the budget of the European Union and of the European Development Funds (EDF); in addition, special annual reports on agencies, decentralised bodies and other bodies of the EU are published separately; o Special reports – with the results of its selected audits on specific budget or management areas in the course of the year, with their main impact assessments; o Opinions on draft legal acts with impact on financial management and statements and position papers on other issues on the Court's own initiative.
Since 2008, the number of the Court's special annual reports and special reports has increased considerably.
The annual reports have also been further developed: more analytical information is now available, the presentation of the data has been more standardised to facilitate the comparison between areas and over time, and a new chapter on performance-related issues has been added.
The significant increase in the opinions issued is due to the fact that the Court has been consulted on the large legislative proposals relating to the new financial framework (2014-2020).

10 TEST TESTS IN 2012 While the vast majority of the audit work is carried out on the Court premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also make visits to the EU institutions, agencies and decentralised bodies, the authorities of the Member States and other recipients of EU funds (including the headquarters of international organisations such as the United Nations in Switzerland).
The audit visits shall normally apply to central and local authorities involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EU funds, as well as to the respective final beneficiaries.
The audit visits within the EU are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member States visited.
The audit teams typically consist of two to three auditors and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and the distance to be carried out.
In 2012, the Court's auditors spent 6 816 days on-the-spot audits – 6 054 in the Member States and 762 outside the EU – and obtained audit evidence for the annual reports, the specific annual reports and the selected audit tasks.
They spent a similar amount of time at the EU institutions and bodies in Brussels and Luxembourg.

11 The key statements of the 2011 Annual Report o The financial statements for the 2011 financial year are the financial situation of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year in question.
The revenue and commitments were not significantly affected by errors.
However, payments were substantially affected by errors, with the estimated error rate for the EU budget as a whole being 3.9%.
This error rate is comparable to that of 2010, which was 3.7%. o All EU expenditure areas assessed individually are error-free except for external relations, external assistance and enlargement, as well as administrative expenditure.
This shows that improvements are still needed in the management of EU funds. o The Court's estimate of the error rate of rural, environmental, fisheries and health expenditure (the most error-prone area of expenditure) was 7.7 %.
The estimated error rate for regional policy, energy and transport remained high at 6.0%. o The Commission's reservations have seen an increase, with the Commission's directors-general's risk-weighted amount rising from EUR 0.4 billion in 2010 to EUR 2.0 billion in 2011.
This is due to the fact that the Commission has recognised the existence of a high risk of error in a number of areas, in particular rural development, cohesion and research. o Overall, the control systems examined are only partially effective to ensure the regularity of payments and do not provide for the prevention or detection and correction of errors to the extent that this would actually be possible.
Many cases have been identified in which controls have failed. o The self-assessment carried out by the Commission in the light of its performance has resulted in further developments which have resulted in welcome improvements compared with previous years.
Nevertheless, in 2011 the Court's audit carried out an audit of the Court's performance, which found that the quality of the quality of the needs of the Court was often lacking, that weaknesses in the programme's design had to be ineffective in reporting the results and effects, and that the Commission had to demonstrate European added value.
ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET FOR THE 2011 BUDGET The Court devoted most of its audits to accounting and compliance audits to the implementation of the 2011 EU budget during 2012.
The 2011 Annual Report, which emerged from this work, was published on 6 November 2012.
The objective of the annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in evaluating the quality of EU financial management and to recommend appropriate improvements by submitting findings and conclusions.
The 18th Annual Statement of Assurance (DASprocess) on the reliability of the EU accounts and the regularity of the underlying transactions is the key element of the annual reports for the financial year 2011.
The annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2011 included two new chapters that included more focused results for agriculture and cohesion.
The former chapter on agriculture and natural resources was replaced by the chapter on "Agriculture: market support and direct payments" and "Rural development, environment, fisheries and health".
In addition, the separate chapters on regional policy, energy and transport, and on employment and social affairs, replace the earlier chapter on cohesion, energy and transport.
12 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR 2011 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are funded by EU Member States, but managed outside the EU budget, subject to their own financial rules.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of operations financed from EDF resources.
From the European Development Funds (EDF), the European Union grants development cooperation assistance to the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and to the overseas countries and territories (OCTs) on the basis of the Cotonou Agreement signed in 2000.
This expenditure is aimed at reducing poverty and finally defeating it, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the global economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars, namely development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2011 annual report on the EDF was published in parallel with the annual report on the EU budget on 6 November 2012.
The Court noted that the financial statements of the EDFs in 2011 were in line with the financial situation of the EDFs and the results of their operations and cash flows.
However, 33% of EDF operations were affected by errors, including an estimated 5.1% of error payments.
SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS ON AGENCIES, DECENTRAL BOARDS AND OTHER EU BOARDS FOR 2011 In 2012, the Court published 50 special annual reports, most of which were for the 2011 financial year, on the agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. Joint Undertakings) and other EU bodies.
EU agencies and decentralised bodies shall be established on the basis of EU acts to carry out specific tasks.
President Caldeira at the presentation of the 2011 Annual Report at the plenary session of the European Parliament (November 2012)
SPECIAL REPORTS ADOPTED IN 2012 In addition to its annual reports, the Court shall publish special reports throughout the year, containing the results of the Court's audit of the efficiency and compliance, on specific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice.
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is committed to achieving maximum impact and thus to making the best use of its resources.
In selecting subjects, the Court takes account of the following factors: the risks of economic viability or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure in question; the amount of revenue or expenditure in question; the time elapsed since a previous audit; and the following developments within the relevant legal framework; and the political and public interest.
In 2012, the Court adopted 25 special reports covering a wide range of topics.
This represents a marked increase compared to the 16 special reports adopted in 2011 (and the 12 in 2008).
All special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website http://eca.europa.eu in full or on the EU Bookshop.
The following pages present the topics of the special reports adopted in 2012 under the relevant headings of the 2013-2017 Financial Framework – the EU's multiannual budgeting.
14 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – SUSTAINABLE GROWTH EU spending on sustainable growth covers two areas: Competitiveness includes promoting research and technological development, Europe's networking through EU networks, education and training, promoting competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, the social agenda and the dismantling of nuclear installations.
The EU budget for growth and employment for 2007-2013 amounts to 89.4 billion euros, 9.2% of the EU budget, of which nearly two-thirds is for research and development.
Cohesion for growth and employment mainly concerns cohesion policy implemented through funds for specific activities: the European Social Fund (ESF), the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF).
The EU budget for cohesion for the period 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 348.4 billion and 35.7% of the total EU budget.
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Financial instruments for SMEs co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (No 2/2012) – This special report assessed the effectiveness and effectiveness of the ERDF co-financed financial measures in the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods; the audit covered a sample of projects in Germany, Portugal, Slovakia, Hungary and the United Kingdom and also included an audit of the Commission and Member States' administrative, monitoring and information systems.
The Court concluded that the effectiveness and efficiency of the expenditure of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) on financial instruments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have been impaired because the regulatory framework did not provide an adequate basis for the use of the various types of financial instruments.
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the EU economy and provide employment, innovation and prosperity.
However, SMEs may not be able to cover their financial needs, in the form and amount they need.
To support them, the EU is implementing its corporate and cohesion policy, mainly in the form of aid, and increasingly in the form of financial instruments under the ERDF.
Financial instruments are repayable revolving instruments.
According to the Commission figures, ERDF allocations for financial instruments amount to EUR 1.6 billion and EUR 10.4 billion for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods, respectively.
o Structural Funds – Has the Commission responded effectively to shortcomings identified in the Member States' management and control systems?
(No 3/2012) – This special report examined the extent to which the Commission initiated appropriate corrective action, ensured its timely implementation, and had sufficient assurance that its action had achieved appropriate financial corrections to past irregularities and improvements in the systems in order to avoid the recurrence of irregularities.
The examination was primarily based on a review of 40 programmes where significant deficiencies had been identified.
The Court noted that the Commission was fairly successful in ensuring the correct application of financial corrections in relation to the shortcomings in Member States' management and control systems, but that it was only to a lesser degree certain that its actions resulted in improvements in Member States' systems.
Structural Fund expenditure is subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
Member States shall draw up multiannual programmes, which shall be examined and approved by the Commission and subsequently implemented by the Member States.
In the event of significant deficiencies in the management and control systems of the Member States, the Commission seeks to ensure that irregularities are corrected and systems are improved. o Use of the Structural and Cohesion Funds to co-finance transport infrastructure in seaports: an effective investment?
(No 4/2012) – This special report assessed the effectiveness of the objectives and outputs of 27 projects co-financed by the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund during the period 2000-2006 under the reporting code of ‘Transport infrastructure'.
The Court found that investment in maritime port infrastructure in cohesion policy was only effective for 11 of the 27 projects audited.
Maritime transport is the second most important mode of transport in the EU.
The Commission forecasts growth of 3.8 billion tonnes in 2006 to 5.3 billion tonnes in 2018.
Since 2000, the EU has provided some 6.2 billion euros from the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund for co-financing the seaport infrastructure.
15 Review of EU transport expenditure
16 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – SUSTAINABLE GROWTH o Does support for urban waste management infrastructure projects under structural measures provide effective support to Member States in achieving the objectives of the EU waste policy?
(No 20/2012) – This special report assessed the performance of 26 sampled infrastructure projects for waste management, the achievement of the objectives of the EU waste policy and the implementation of accompanying measures in the eight regions where the infrastructure is located.
The Court noted that the effectiveness of the promotion of urban waste infrastructure under EU structural measures has been affected by the inadequate implementation of accompanying measures and by weaknesses in EU legislation and guidelines.
In 2010, each citizen of the 27 EU Member States generated an average of about 500 kg of waste which, if not properly collected, treated and disposed of, can lead to negative environmental impacts.
The EU has introduced common standards and targets in the form of directives for the management of municipal waste and has co-financed infrastructure for waste management in certain regions.
During the period 2000-2013, the EU earmarked EUR 10.8 billion for waste management infrastructure. o Cost-effectiveness of energy efficiency investments under cohesion policy (No. 21/2012) – This special report assessed the cost-effectiveness of energy efficiency investments under cohesion policy by examining the energy efficiency projects carried out in public buildings by examining whether the right conditions had been created for planning and financing, in order to enable cost-effective energy efficiency investments, and whether the energy efficiency projects carried out in public buildings had been cost-effective.
The Court noted that the average payback period of EU investments in energy efficiency is more than 50 years (up to 150 years in extreme cases), which means that the means could be used more cost-effectively for this type of investment.
The costs of increased energy consumption, the exhaustion of fossil fuels and the impact of human action on global climate change are the drivers of the recent EU policies to increase energy efficiency.
Since 2000, the European Union has spent almost EUR 5 billion on co-financing energy efficiency measures in the Member States in the framework of cohesion policy. o Has the revitalisation of industrial and military breaks been successfully supported in the framework of EU structural measures?
(No 23/2012) – This special report examined whether the project objectives were met, whether the EU funding target was based on sound criteria and whether the results achieved were achieved at the lowest possible cost to the EU budget.
The Court assessed the performance of 27 projects for the revitalisation of waste land, using EU co-financing for the total of EUR 231 million, and analysed the instruments for revitalisation of waste land, which form the framework for the specific co-financed measures, in Germany, Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and the United Kingdom.
(The conclusions of this special report are to be published on 18 April 2013.)
In recent decades, more and more industrial and military areas have become available (so-called "waste areas").
Many areas of waste are contaminated.
Revitalisation and re-use of wasteland will be encouraged through EU structural measures with the aim of promoting the protection of human health and the environment and combating the sprawl of the landscape.
EU funding for this sector amounted to EUR 5.7 billion in the years 2000-2013.
o Response of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the earthquake in Abruzzo in 2009: relevance and cost of the actions (No 24/2012) – This special report assessed whether the actions financed were in line with the EUSF Regulation and whether the "CASE" project, to which the bulk of the expenditure was incurred, was well planned and planned, and carried out with due regard for the aspect of economy.
The Court noted that while the other projects financed were eligible, the CASE project was not in line with the EUSF Regulation.
Furthermore, there were weaknesses in the planning of the CASE project and in ensuring thrifty in its implementation.
The 2009 earthquake centred on the Italian region of Abruzzo caused more than 10 billion euros of damage.
The European Union supported Italian disaster management with a contribution of 0.5 billion euros from its solidarity fund, which was used for rescue, emergency shelter and temporary schools and for the CASE project for the construction of earthquake-proof houses.
The Cathedral of LІAquila in Italy almost four years after the 2009 earthquake o Are there instruments for monitoring the effectiveness of the expenditure of the European Social Fund for older workers?
(No 25/2012) – This special report examined whether and to what extent the Member States and the Commission have developed and used adequate instruments to assess the achievement of the targets for older workers.
Six programmes worth EUR 222 million were selected, covering four Member States: Germany, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
The Court noted that neither the Member States nor the Commission could comment on the extent to which measures supported by the ESF had a real beneficial effect on older workers.
Between 2007 and the end of 2013, ESF expenditure to support Member States in the area of employment will be more than EUR 75 billion, representing around 8% of the total EU budget.
One of the most important disadvantaged groups is older workers.
