18 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – SURVEILLANCE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES The EU has a high political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 413.1 billion, i.e. 42.3% of the total EU budget.
Three-quarters of the expenditure relates to direct payments to farmers and support to agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) – the "first pillar" of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
Another fifth of the expenditure is the support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second "pillar of the CAP".
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Reform of the common organisation of the market in wine: progress made so far (No 7/2012) – This special report assessed the progress made in achieving one of the main objectives of the wine reform, namely the progress made in achieving a better balance between supply and demand.
The focus of the study was the measures "Rodition premium" and "Restructuring and conversion of vineyards", which are the two largest areas of expenditure and are of crucial importance for achieving the objective of achieving a better balance between supply and demand.
The Court noted that these two measures were in conflict with each other and that the structural surplus in supply was not significantly reduced.
The EU budget of EUR 1.1 billion was made available for the three-year period of the application of the grubbing-up measure (2008/2009 to 2010/2011).
For restructuring and conversion, EUR 4.2 billion was allocated for the ten-year period up to 2010. o Aid for the modernisation of agricultural holdings was directed towards specific objectives (No 8/2012) – This special report examined whether the EU aid to modernise agricultural holdings was directed towards EU priorities and specific needs in the Member States.
The Court noted that the measure to modernise agricultural holdings would have been potentially more effective by more targeted use of funds to achieve EU priorities and specific needs in the Member States, on the one hand, and by the effective use of selection procedures on the other.
This aid concerns the financing of investments in agricultural holdings, ranging from investments in simple items such as agricultural equipment or wooden crates for fruit to investments in complex projects such as biogas plants.
The EU budget for this aid (derived from the EAFRD) amounts to EUR 11.1 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period, representing around 11 % of all EU rural development expenditure. o Review of the control system, which regulates the production, processing, distribution and import of organic products (No 9/2012) – The special report examined whether the control system for organic products provides sufficient assurance that the key production, processing, distribution and import requirements for organic products are met.
The various bodies involved (the EU Commission and competent authorities of the Member States, accreditation bodies and control bodies) have been involved in the implementation of their tasks within the EU and in the management of the import arrangements.
The Court noted that the competent authorities in the Member States encountered difficulties in ensuring traceability of organic products, in addition to the weaknesses in the system that need to be addressed in order to ensure that the system works efficiently, and in order to ensure that consumer confidence is not undermined.
The objective of the EU legal framework for organic production is to provide a basis for the sustainable development of organic production, to ensure fair conditions of competition, to protect consumer interests and, at the same time, to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market.
A control system has been established to control and certify each operator in the supply chain. o Direct aid for suckler cows and ewes and goats in the context of the partial implementation of the single payment scheme (No 11/2012) – This special report examined whether the aid was directed towards the most relevant regions in the Member States, whether it was effective in maintaining specific production and thus to avoid negative social, economic and environmental impacts, and whether it was the subject of appropriate monitoring and evaluation by the Commission and the Member States.
The Court noted that direct CAP support for dams did not deliver better results than decoupled aid.
Following the 2003 CAP reform, agricultural aid previously granted through direct payments linked to the production of certain agricultural products (so-called ‘coupled' aid) should no longer be paid after the introduction of the single payment scheme (i.e. decoupled).
However, for certain sectors and regions, a number of derogations from the full decoupling have been provided for in order to limit the potential negative effects of an immediate transition to such a scheme.
The total budget available for this direct aid for 2011 was EUR 1.0 billion.
19 On-the-spot verification of a beneficiary holding in Spain
20 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – SURVEILLANCE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES o Implementation of EU hygiene rules in slaughterhouses of countries that have joined the EU since 2004 (No 14/2012) – This special report examined whether the Commission and the Member States concerned have taken the necessary measures to ensure that the appropriate adjustments have been made in slaughterhouses to EU hygiene rules.
The monitoring, guidance, implementation and financing of the measures to comply with the hygiene rules were reviewed.
The Court examined slaughterhouses in Poland, Romania, Slovenia, the Czech Republic and Hungary, which had received EU funding.
While the Court found that the systems of the Commission and the competent authorities set up for the monitoring of hygiene rules were generally appropriate, the examination revealed a number of shortcomings in the implementation of these systems, which set out the need for a greater severity at all levels in order to reduce risks.
Member States that joined the EU since 2004 had to ensure that their slaughterhouses complied with EU health legislation.
As these rules generally contained much stricter requirements than the respective national rules, EU funds were allocated to help slaughterhouses to comply with the hygiene requirements and the related modernisation.
The Special Programme for Pre-Accession for Agriculture and Rural Development (Sapard Programme) provided around EUR 117 million for 241 slaughterhouses.
The support was then continued under the EAGGF and EAFRD. o The effectiveness of the single area payment scheme as a transitional scheme to support farmers in the new Member States (No 16/2012) – This special report examined the main weaknesses, such as the payments to beneficiaries of the single area payment (or only marginal) agricultural activity, the payments of abandoned areas or areas used for non-agricultural activities, payments to public authorities as well as aid, which concentrated on only a few large beneficiaries.
The Court found that some of the aid had been paid to beneficiaries who had only had only a marginal or non-agricultural activity, including public bodies, and that the distribution of the aid did not take into account the regional specificities of the agricultural activity or the contribution of farmers to the production of public goods.
In addition, the vast majority of farmers receive very small amounts of aid.
The single area payment scheme is a simplified income support scheme for farmers in the Member States that have joined the EU since 2004.
In 2011, payments amounted to around 5 billion euros.
HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – FREEDOM, SECURITY AND LAW In 2012, the Court adopted the following Special Report in this area: o Does the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund contribute effectively to the integration of third-country nationals?
(No 22/2012) – This special report assessed whether the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund, which are part of the EU General Programme "Solidarity and Management of Migration Flows" (SOLID) for the period 2007-2013, have contributed effectively to the integration of third-country nationals into the EU, whether the results have been supported by an efficient monitoring and evaluation of the programme, whether the Fund's design has contributed to the effective implementation of the funds, and whether the systems for implementing integration measures under the SOLID programme have been properly managed.
The Court found that although positive results were found for individual projects that were audited, systems that were inappropriate to measure the success of the funds had been put in place.
The effectiveness of the Funds was reduced by the design of the programme and coordination with other EU funds was insufficient.
The EU supports measures to integrate third-country nationals in EU Member States and increases solidarity through the distribution of financial burdens arising from the management of common external borders and the implementation of common policies in the areas of asylum and immigration.
The total expenditure under the EU budget for SOLID for the period 2007-2013 is expected to be EUR 4.0 billion.
21 This policy area has been established to ensure the free movement of persons and to provide citizens with a high level of protection.
It ranges from the administration of the EU's external borders to judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters.
It includes asylum and immigration policy, police cooperation and the fight against crime.
Expenditure in this area in the period 2007-2013 is expected to be EUR 12.2 billion.
22 HEAD OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – THE EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER The EU's external relations activities focus on enlargement, achieving stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood, active support for sustainable development at international level, promoting global political governance and ensuring strategic and civil security.
The EU has allocated EUR 55.9 billion, i.e. 5.7% of its planned total expenditure, to these objectives for the period 2007-2013.
Expenditure is largely managed directly by the Commission through its central services or delegations.
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Effectiveness of the European Union's development assistance in sub-Saharan Africa (No 1/2012) – This special report examined the effectiveness of the development aid in sub-Saharan Africa in the European Union in terms of food security, analysing whether EU development assistance in the area of food security is relevant to the needs and priorities of the countries, and whether the EU's actions have been effective.
The review focused on EU direct development assistance for the three pillars of food security: food availability, access to food and balanced nutrition.
The Court concluded that EU development assistance for food security in sub-Saharan Africa is predominantly effective and makes an important contribution to food security.
However, the Commission did not take sufficient account of the possibilities for EU support to other countries, which are also affected by chronic food insecurity, and did not give the food aspect an appropriate priority.
Food security is a major and persistent problem in sub-Saharan Africa, where 30% of the population is affected by hunger.
Over the period 2002-2010, the EU financed food security measures in this region, totalling more than 3.2 billion euros, from the European Development Fund (EDF). o The Joint RELEX Information System (CRIS) (No 5/2012) – This special report examined whether CRIS had been designed to meet the Commission's needs effectively and whether the information it provided was reliable.
The audit included a review of the CRIS documentation available to the Commission and a review of the data contained in CRIS.
The Court concluded that CRIS met most of the Commission's information requirements on external action effectively.
However, after ten years of development, it still has weaknesses.
CRIS is the information system set up by the Commission to support the management of external actions.
The functions of the system have been continuously extended since its commissioning in 2002.
It is now the main reference information system for the management and documentation of external actions and related reporting and is financed by both the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund (EDF).
o European Union assistance to the Turkish Cypriot Community (No 6/2012) – This special report examined whether the Commission was developing an assistance programme in line with the objectives of the instrument, whether an appropriate programme of implementation was in place, and whether the individual projects reached their respective objectives.
The purpose of the examination was not to assess whether the programme had contributed to the achievement of the political objective of reunification.
The Court noted that the programme met its objectives as a financial support instrument for the Turkish Cypriot community and that it had generally established appropriate modalities, despite considerable constraints.
Some results have already been achieved, but their sustainability is often questionable, and the most extensive project in the programme has not been established.
About one third of this amount was assessed by the Court by means of its sample of contracts. o European Union development assistance in the field of drinking water and basic sanitation in the sub-Saharan region (No 13/2012) – This special report assessed whether the Commission had managed EU development assistance in order to improve sub-Saharan Africa's drinking water and basic sanitation in a way that had achieved effective and sustainable results.
The Court noted that EU assistance has improved access to drinking water and basic sanitation.
On the other hand, less than half of the projects examined have met the needs of the beneficiaries, and the benefits will only be met if the revenue does not depend on taxes.
Improvements in water and sanitation are critical to achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
Supply of clean drinking water and sanitation contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction.
EU spending on water and sanitation in the sub-Saharan region in the period 2001-2010 amounted to approximately EUR 1.0 billion, and since funding for water and sanitation is also provided for in other areas of assistance, the Commission has provided a larger total amount.

24 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – THE EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER o Contribution of the European Development Fund (EDF) to a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa (No 17/2012) – This special report examined whether the EDF has made an effective contribution to the sustainability of the road network in sub-Saharan Africa, whether the EDF-funded road infrastructure is sustainable and whether the sustainability of road infrastructure has been effectively promoted by the Commission.
The audit focused on the technical, financial and institutional sustainability of the road infrastructure, and 48 programmes have been audited, supported by the eighth, ninth and tenth EDFs in six partner countries since 1995.
The Court concluded that the Commission's support for a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa was a conditionally effective one.
The partner countries visited by the Court do not make sufficient efforts to ensure the sustainability of road infrastructure, which affects the road to varying degrees of premature wear and tear.
Roads and other transport infrastructures are essential for regional integration, economic growth, social development, effective public administration and security.
In sub-Saharan Africa, road transport is the most important mode of transport for passenger and freight transport and accounts for more than 80% of the total transport of goods and services, with the demand for transport rising rapidly.
The EU committed approximately 7.4 billion euros of EDF funds in this region in the period 1995-2011. o The EU's rule of law assistance to Kosovo (No. 18/2012) (see "Beginning of an economic audit").

25 ACCESSION OF ECONOMIC ASSESSMENT EU Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo Kosovo Police and EULEX in Kosovo's border patrol © EULEX, 2011, Photo by Enisa Kasemi In its examination of EU rule of law assistance to Kosovo, the Court first highlighted a Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) mission.
Kosovo is the world's largest per capita recipient of EU financial assistance and the scene of the largest civilian crisis management operation ever launched by the Union (EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX –EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEX – EULEXEU
Court Special Report No 18/2012 addressed the question of whether EU assistance to Kosovo was effective in the field of the rule of law.
The audit focused on the four sectors of police, justice, customs and the fight against corruption.
The Court also examined coordination with other donors and the implementation of EULEX.
The examination of such a complex area was a challenge.
Four verification visits have been carried out in Kosovo.
Officials from EULEX and the European Commission were also interviewed, as were local officials, representatives of the international donor community and civil society organisations.
The audit team investigated projects of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and Stability Instrument projects, as well as monitoring, guidance and guidance (MMA) activities carried out by EULEX.
Meetings were held in Brussels with the Commission, the European External Action Service, the Council Secretariat and NATO.
A panel of experts also assisted the Court.
The Court noted that EU aid was not sufficiently effective.
Although the EU has contributed to capacity building, especially in the customs field, the success of the assistance in the field of police and justice has been modest.
The level of organised crime and corruption in Kosovo remains high.
The judiciary continues to suffer from political influence, inefficiency and a lack of transparency and enforcement.
The limited ability to protect important witnesses within Kosovo and the difficulty of moving witnesses abroad are important shortcomings.
In the words of Gijs de Vries, the Court's member responsible for the report, the Kosovar authorities do not give sufficient priority to the rule of law, and EU aid should be more effective.
Francisco de Miguel Rodriguez, head of the audit team, says that there is no other place around the world, like Kosovo, where so many international donors could be found in such a small area for capacity building.
The Court concluded that the EU coordination mechanisms, including coordination with the international community, need to be improved.
Unlike the rest of the Western Balkans, the lack of a common EU position on independence threatens the incentive to join the EU, in the case of Kosovo.
In terms of communication, this examination took new paths.
It was the Court's most cited report in 2012: more than 130 articles in print and electronic media were published on it.
A video was also published on the Court's website which summarised the report.
This was a first for the court in which his aspiration to reach a wider audience was reflected.
The European Commission and the European External Action Service have accepted the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The report was presented to the European Parliament and to the Council's working groups.
On the basis of the importance of his findings, the British House of Lords has decided to look into the report in detail.
26 EU INSTITUTIONS, AGENCIES AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: the administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (e.g. salaries and pensions) as well as on buildings, equipment, energy, communication and information technology.
Total expenditure for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 55.9 billion and 5.7% of the total EU budget. o Effectiveness of the measures to further develop staff at the European Commission (No 10/2012) – This special report examined whether the Commission has agreed to further develop its staff to the needs of the organisation, to provide further development opportunities to its staff, to create an environment that encouraged staff to develop their skills and to apply them at the workplace.
The Commission's annual allocation for external trainers and teaching materials amounted to EUR 26.6 million in 2010. The annual investment in learning and development also consisted in 2010 of 230 000 days of staff for training activities and an equivalent of 310 staff for the management and implementation of training and career development activities. o Has the Commission and Eurostat improved the procedures for producing reliable and credible European statistics?
(No 12/2012) – This special report assessed whether the procedures for the production of reliable and credible statistics have been improved by the Commission and Eurostat.
Improvements are directly related to compliance with the Code of Conduct for European Statistics, which sets the standards for the development, production and dissemination of statistics, and with the implementation of the European statistical programme.
An evaluation of the reliability of specific statistical results did not take place.
The Court noted that the Commission and Eurostat have not yet fully applied the Code of Conduct for European statistics and that Eurostat had not conceived the European statistical programme 2008-2012 as an effective planning, monitoring and accountability tool.
Reliable and credible statistics are crucial to the performance of the tasks entrusted to the European Union.
Statistics are needed in almost all areas to formulate, apply, monitor and evaluate the tasks and objectives laid down in the Treaties and are needed to collect and allocate EU funds.
European policy decisions are increasingly based directly on statistics, and statistical indicators are increasingly used as triggers for policy decisions or sanctions. o Conflict of interest of selected EU agencies (No. 15/2012) – This special report assessed whether the selected agencies handled conflicts of interest adequately, whether there are adequate policy guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflicts of interest situations, and whether the selected agencies have adequately implemented their policies and procedures for dealing with conflicts of interest situations.
The audit assessed the policy guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflict of interest situations in the case of four selected agencies that make influential decisions affecting the safety and health of consumers.
The Court concluded that the selected EU agencies did not adequately manage conflicts of interest.

29 OPINION No 1/2012 ON THE COMMISSION'S LEGISLATIVE PROPOSALS FOR THE REFORM OF THE COMMON AGRICULTURAL POLICY FROM 2014 The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is to be reformed by 2013.
In October 2011, the Commission published a proposal containing the main elements of a regulatory framework for the CAP for the period 2014-2020.
The new legal framework proposed maintaining the current two-pillar structure of the CAP and thus the two existing European financial instruments of agricultural policy, namely the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
The Court recognised the efforts made by the Commission to simplify the provisions of the CAP (e.g. to avoid the different implementation models of the current single payment scheme, the introduction of a simplified scheme for small farmers).
Through its proposals, the Commission has received a number of comments from Parliament, the Council and the Court.
Nevertheless, the legislative proposals remain basically aimed at expenditure and its control, and, contrary to the stated intention, continue to comply with legislation on performance.
The Court took note of the Commission's objective of paying out CAP aid to "active farmers" and of its attempt to achieve a more balanced distribution of direct payments among the beneficiaries.
However, the Court doubted that the proposed measures could be effectively implemented without imposing an excessive administrative burden on the administrative authorities and farmers.
In his view, the solution may consist of a combination of general principles laid down in the Regulation and a systematic monitoring and expert monitoring of its implementation by the Commission.
He noted that the so-called ‘covering' (fixing of the aid which exceeds a certain ceiling) would have a limited impact on the redistribution of the aid.
This opinion had a significant impact on the future of the CAP.
More than 2,000 articles have been published in the media on this subject.
The Court was invited by numerous NGOs, agricultural trade fair organisers and other industry forums to present the opinion to the audience, and the European Parliament invited representatives of the Court to participate in working groups on the subject.
Members of the European Parliament have included most of the recommendations in their own legislative proposals.
The legislative package will be voted on after the adoption of the multiannual financial framework.

COOPERATION COMMITTEE OF THE EU MEMBER STATES' COOPERATION AUTHORITIES 31 In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies shall cooperate with each other in confidence and in accordance with their independence.
The Court works actively with the SAIs of the EU Member States within the Contact Committee.
The Contact Committee shall meet once a year with the Presidents of the EU-ORKB and the Court.
Working groups and task forces were set up to support the development of common positions and practices.
In 2012, the Court assisted the President-in-Office of the Contact Committee (ORCB of Portugal) in the preparation and holding of the 2012 annual meeting in Estoril (Portugal) on 18 and 19 October 2012.
The meeting focused on two main issues, namely the challenges facing SAIs in preparing for the next EU financial framework (2014-2020), and recent developments in the responses to the financial crisis and the SAIs' experience in the field of audit.
At the meeting, the Contact Committee decided to set up a task force to analyse the tasks and role of SAIs, taking into account recent developments in the EU in the development of a new economic, budgetary and financial architecture and the possible impact on SAIs.
The Court is a member of this task force to report to the Contact Committee in 2013.
In addition, the Court also provided administrative support to the Contact Committee in 2012 and actively participated in the various working groups and networks.
In 2012, the Court also supported the initiative of the Euro area SAIs with a view to ensuring adequate external public financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
A common position on a proposal for a Statute on Article 30 of the Treaty establishing the Mechanism was sent to the Secretary-General of the Council of the European Union in April 2012.
The final version of the Statutes is broadly in line with this common position with regard to the Audit Committee.

34 OUR MANAGEMENT: A STRATEGY FOR THE PERIOD 2013-2017 The Court adopted and published its strategy for the period 2013-2017 in 2012.
The Court's objective for this period is to maximise the value of the contribution the Court makes to the EU's public accountability.
The main priorities for achieving this objective are: o to focus the Court's products on improving EU accountability; o to cooperate with other actors to enhance the Court's contribution to EU accountability; o to develop as a professional audit body; o to make the best use of the Court's wealth of knowledge, expertise and expertise; and to demonstrate the Court's ability to perform and perform its accountability.
The Court will use its unique powers and views, knowledge, expertise and partnerships, which it has built up during the 35 years of its existence, to, o make a positive contribution to future developments in the EU's governance mechanisms, policies and financial management; o help the other parties involved in the accountability process at EU level to identify the risks to EU accountability and to make easier use of audit results; o strengthen its professionalism by contributing to the development and application of new audit standards and best practices; o further streamline the processes for producing its reports and opinions; o improve its performance and the accountability framework, in accordance with the EU institutions and SAIs; o implement budgetary discipline measures, in accordance with the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, including the need to shorten the establishment plan during the financial framework of this strategy.
During the period 2013-2017, the Court will focus its reports, opinions and comments on the following issues: (i) strengthening public accountability and audit arrangements; (ii) improving financial management and reporting on the implementation of the EU budget and its impact; and (iii) improving the way in which EU policies and spending programmes are designed.
EXCHANGE IN THE HOFE'S COLLECTION Pursuant to the Treaty, the term of office of the members of the Court is six years and the term of office of the members of the Court can be reappointed.
In 2012, five new members of the Court were appointed: Henrik Otbo (Denmark), Pietro Russo (Italy), Ville Itälä (Finland), Kevin Cardiff (Ireland) and Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain).
REworked Code of Conduct for the Members of the Court In February 2012, the Court adopted a new Code of Conduct for Members, which takes account of the changes that have occurred since the adoption of the previous Code eight years ago.
In addition, the Court is now publishing the declarations of interest of its members on its website, which will make a significant contribution to transparency. 35
36 MEASUREMENT DATA ON THE PERFORMANCE OF THE OF THE HOFE CONCLUSION OF THE STRATEGY 2009-2012 In 2008, the Court published its first strategy.
This strategy was applied for the period 2009-2012 and aimed to maximise the impact of the Court's audits and to increase efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
Overall, the Court succeeded in implementing its strategy in 2009-2012.
The Court's recommendations were largely accepted: according to the Commission, about half of the recommendations issued in 2011 were implemented, and the Court's key institutional addressees were satisfied with its annual and special reports, the quality of which was assessed to be good and improved by external experts, and the Court was able to increase the number of staff in the audit chambers by 60 in efficiency gains (501 in 2008 compared to 564 in 2011), and to reduce the number of administrative and translation staff by 40.
For the 2009-2012 strategy period, the Court set out a set of key performance indicators, for the purposes of: o informing management of progress in the implementation of the objectives; o supporting the decision-making process; o providing performance-related information to the audience.
The key performance indicators are used to measure core parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, taking into account the position of key stakeholders and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources.
As 2012 was the last year of the 2009-2012 strategy period, the results of the key performance indicators, if available, are presented for every four years.
The Court will update the key performance indicators to be applied in the 2013-2017 strategic period, in order to reflect its new or revised priorities and to demonstrate its performance and accountability as a professional audit body.

40 EFFICIENCY AND EFFICIENCY OF RESOURCES The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its resource use according to its ability to provide reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff.
REPORTING REPORTS The Court monitors the effectiveness of its reporting process by comparing the number of reports planned for the year with the number of reports adopted and by checking whether these reports have been adopted within the deadlines for each of them.

The result ranged from 67% to 73% between 2008 and 2012, thus remaining below the 90 % target set for this indicator.
The main reasons for this were an ambitious planning for the special reports and unpredictable events in the audit process.
The Court notes that while the accuracy of the planning of audit assessments and the efficiency of audit implementation can be further improved, during the period 2008-2012, not only did it succeed in significantly increasing the number of special reports issued, but also in increasing the period during which they were drawn up to the target of 18 months.
In the period 2008-2012, 85 special reports were adopted (compared with 51 special reports in the period 2003-2007) and the average lead period was reduced from 25 months in 2008 to 20 months in 2012.
The Court's 2013-2017 strategy includes a new initiative to further streamline reporting to improve reporting punctuality and efficiency.
FUNCTIONALITY OF THE TEST TESTING TESTS The Court uses the audit reports to confirm the factual accuracy of the specific audit findings by the audited bodies.
Thus, audit statements are an important stage in the audit process.
In accordance with the Court's internal rules, audit reports should be drawn up within two months of the relevant audit visit, with an annual assessment of the extent to which that deadline has been complied with.
70 % 60 % 50 % 40 % 30 % 20 % 54 % 58 % 61 % 90 % of the 2012 target 27 % 2008 2009 2010 2011 Outcome of the objective PUBLICITY OF HOFE's AUDIT SECURITY 43 % The Court has found that there is a significant need for improvement in the preparation of the audit communications in terms of punctuality.
When the Court started the measurements in 2008, it set two targets for the punctuality of audit notifications, namely the improvement of performance by 10 percent per year and the assurance that 80% of the audit notifications will be produced on time by the end of 2012.
The result for this indicator ranged from 27% to 61% for the period 2008-2012.
Although performance has improved significantly and the annual targets have largely been met, 2012 results are still below the long-term target of 80%.
The Court will continue to seek to achieve even better performance in this area. 41

VOCATIONAL TRAINING The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training in order to keep pace with new developments and to acquire new skills.
Furthermore, due to the particular circumstances of the audit environment of the Court, the auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2012, the Court staff (auditors and other staff) completed on average 8 days of professional training (9.3 days in 2011).
Language courses accounted for 52% of the total number of days of further education (compared to 54% in 2011).
Translation is an audit support activity which enables the Court to fulfil its mission and to fulfil its communication objectives.
In 2012, the translation volume reached a peak of 158,861 pages, which was 11 % higher than in 2011.
More than 99% of the translations were completed on time.
Information technology is a major contribution to the effectiveness and efficiency of the Court.
2012 was a successful year: o In the area of knowledge management, the Court's first version of the new audit support instrument (ASSYST2) was set up and a pilot phase was launched in a audit area.
In addition, a first knowledge network (Community of practice) on the subject of financial crisis was supported by the provision of information technology and content. In 2012, the content of the training was improved and new courses were developed to meet the priorities in the audit area.
In addition, the establishment of a new paperless system and the development of e-learning enabled more efficient management of the training activities.
TRANSLATION INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY The Court's Translation Directorate also provided linguistic support to auditors in the Member States' audits and the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
It also supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the audit activities of the Court. o The automation of administrative processes was actively pursued through the introduction of ECAdemy to support the Court's training policy, through the decentralisation of time recording, saving personnel resources, and through the complete digitisation of personnel files. o It was a great success to move the Court's data centre to the new K3 building.
The commissioning of the new building was also accompanied by a new telephone system and a new data network. 47
48 MANAGEMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE In 2012, the Financial and Support Services Directorate continued to provide: (a) provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and fulfil its strategic objectives, and (b) ensure that the necessary financial, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all the Court's activities.
In order to provide the farm staff with a safe, comfortable and ergonomic working environment, and to ensure that all the farm staff working in one location, a second extension building was commissioned in 2003.
The yard took the building down in November 2012, and the first moves took place before the end of the year.
In 2012, the Directorate's activities were even more efficient and economical.
In October 2012, the Court's office in Brussels was moved to another location.
It is now located in the MTS (Montoyer-Science) building in Rue Montoyer 30/ Rue de la Science in Brussels.

Supplementary work will be carried out in 2013 in the other buildings in the courtyard.

54 35 YEARS IN THE SERVICE OF A BETTER FUNCTIONING OF THE EU The European Court of Auditors has been the external auditor of the EU for 35 years. It provides continuous added value for the financial management of the Union and ensures public accountability for the use of taxpayers' money.
The Court was founded at a time when the European Community (the forerunner of the European Union) was developing towards more democracy and became more accountable to its citizens.
Two important steps were the enlargement of the European Parliament's budgetary control powers and the full financing of the European Community's budget from its own resources.
The Community recognised the need for an independent external auditor to assist Parliament and the Council in ensuring the democratic control of finances.
Mr Heinrich Aigner, Chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, who, since 1973, has been strongly in favour of an external audit body at Community level, opposed the initiative leading to the establishment of the European Court of Auditors by the Treaty of Brussels on 22 July 1975.
The Court began its activities in October 1977, with its headquarters in Luxembourg.
Hans Kutscher, then President of the Court of Justice, acknowledged the Court as the Community's financial conscience.
With the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty on 1 November 1993, the Court of Justice acquired the status of a fully-fledged European institution, guaranteeing its independence and authority as an equivalent institution.
The Maastricht Treaty has also introduced what is now a core product of the Court, namely the DAS (Déclaration d'assurance) on the accounts of the EU and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts.
The Court's role was strengthened with the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam on 1 May 1999, with the aim of strengthening the Court's independence and extending its audit powers to other policy areas.
The Treaty of Nice of 1 February 2003 confirmed the principle that the Court should be a member of each Member State and stressed the importance of the Court's cooperation with national audit bodies and that the Court should be given the possibility of giving itself a chamber structure.
Since its establishment, the Court has consistently promoted cooperation with the Member State's supreme audit authorities in the audit of EU funds, in particular through its involvement in the EU's Presidents' Contact Committee.
In its role as SAIs, the Court also sought to help shape developments in the field of public sector audit by working with other SAIs in the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its EUROSAI regional group to define technical standards and best practices.
The Court was early on on on the peer review procedure as an instrument for the development and dissemination of best practice within the SAIs' Community.
During its 35th anniversary, the Court sought to contribute to the improvement of EU financial management by presenting high-quality products reflecting the EU's developments and the changing needs of its users.
Over the past 35 years, the EU has taken in new Member States, given new powers and created new institutions at EU level – all of which the Court had to take into account in its work.
As a result, the Court's output has increased significantly compared to the two opinions it issued in the first year of its activity.
The Court's products today include annual reports, special reports, statements of assurance, special annual reports, opinions and position papers.
The number of outputs has increased to 87 publications in 2012.
For a number of years, the Court has given a higher priority to examining the results achieved in the implementation of EU policies and to providing guidance to improve economic efficiency.
Like the EU, the Court has developed.
Based on nine members and 120 employees in 1977, the Court now has 27 members and almost 900 employees.
Like the Union itself, the success of the Court depends on close cooperation between members and employees from all the countries of Europe.
The Court is proud that since 1977 it has been able to build up a dedicated, professional and experienced staff, to promote the protection of the financial interests of the citizens.
In the coming years, the Court will devote itself to contributing to the improvement of accountability of the funds allocated to the achievement of the objectives to citizens.
55 Members of the Court's First College, November 1977

In memory of our colleague Henrik Otbo, member of the Court, who unexpectedly died on 1 February 2015, Henrik Otbo was born in 1949 and had Danish nationality.
From 1995 to 2012, he was President of the Danish Court of Auditors and from 1 March 2012 he was Member of the European Court of Auditors of the CEAD Chamber (coordination, evaluation, quality assurance and development) with special responsibility for audit development and evaluation.
His lifelong commitment to public financial control, in particular his leading role in the establishment of International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions as Chairman of the INTOSAI Committee for Technical Standards, was particularly valuable to the Court, his former colleagues to the Danish Court of Auditors and the entire audit sector.
01 European Court of Auditors 02 Mission The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to the improvement of EU financial management, promotes accountability and transparency, and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
Mission Statement An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact, and providing valuable support to its audience for improving EU financial management.
Values Independence, integrity and impartiality Professionalism Added value Excellence and efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its staff.
Non-partisan examination, which takes account of the views of the the Court's addressees, but rejects any form of influence by means of instructions or external pressure.
Maintaining an exemplary level of professionality in all aspects of his work.
Active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
To produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound evidence and evidence, taking into account the concerns of its district, and including important and indicative statements.
To contribute to the effective improvement of the EU financial management and to the strengthening of the accounting obligation for EU financial management.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.

Foreword by President 04 Dear reader, 2014 was a year of profound change for the EU and its finances.
The EU entrusted the European Central Bank with the responsibility for the oversight of the major banks in the euro area.
It was the first year of the new multiannual financial framework relevant to the implementation of the EU budget for the period 2014-2020.
The elections of Members of the European Parliament and the replacement of the top positions in the Council and in the European Commission were also of particular importance. The European Court of Auditors (EuRH) also welcomed six new members.
In 2014, our institution produced 91 reports, opinions and other products – more than ever before.
They are the result of our audits of the accounts, compliance audits and the audits of the economy, which include the audits that fall within the scope of our new responsibilities with regard to financial and economic governance.
They contain a number of important findings, conclusions and recommendations to improve the financial management and accountability of the EU in the 2014-2020 programming period.
Some of its key messages are contained in this annual activity report.
We also aim to provide our audience with the widest possible possible knowledge of the main challenges facing the EU in the financing and implementation of its policies, based on our audit experience.
To this end – and to contribute to this time – we introduced a new product, the so-called "Landscape-Analyses", in 2014, to contribute to this, a new and new time, marked by innovation.
In addition, at the request of the European Parliament, we have published an overview of the results of our audit of the accounting and compliance procedures of the agricultural and cohesion expenditures of the period 2009-2013.
The Court also works with its addressees to ensure that the addressees can make the most of the results of its work.
Among others, the Court appointed in 2014 a member in charge of institutional relations and a speaker.
It also organised several events to provide a forum for exchanges with high-level stakeholders from the EU and the Member States.
This conference brought together a large number of people in charge of managing and controlling EU funds, including Members of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Supreme Audit Institutions and representatives of the scientific community.
The vice-president of the European Parliament and former EU Commissioner Olli Rehn gave a preliminary speech.
A visit to Lithuania by a delegation of members of the Court of Auditors, meeting with Members of Parliament, members of the government and representatives of the National Court of Auditors and the Lithuanian Central Bank, should also be highlighted.
Preface of President 05 Throughout the year, our 2013-2017 strategy has been groundbreaking for our work and for the actions taken to reform our institution.
In 2014, we shortened the average time we needed to prepare our special reports, and we reduced the number of our staff, as required by an interinstitutional agreement.
We also made fundamen for future efficiency and effectiveness gains by launching an internal reform project.
This project coordinates the implementation of the recommendations of internal working groups and the recommendations of the independent, external peer review on the practice of our economic assessment and the European Parliament's report on the future role of the Court.
The Court is based in Luxembourg, but our test teams travel wherever EU funds are spent, as part of their work in obtaining audit certificates.
This activity report provides an overview of the audit visits and the reports we have produced.
A special spotlight will be given to our examination of EU support for European airport infrastructure.
It is a clear example of our efficiency audits for assessing the impact and added value of EU funding, and of the Court's efforts to fulfil its mandate.
Furthermore, this audit demonstrates the commitment and professionalism of the Court's staff, on whose expertise and commitment the Court, in the interests of the Court, can always rely.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President
2014 at a glance 06 Our activities • Annual reports on the EU general budget and on the European Development Funds for the financial year 2013. • 51 special annual reports on the various EU agencies, decentralised agencies and joint enterprises for the financial year 2013 and two summary reports. • 24 special reports on particular budgetary or management issues, ranging from European banking supervision to EU-funded airport infrastructures. • Seven opinions and other statements on financial management issues, from the reform of the EU's own resources system to an analysis of possible savings from the integration of the European Parliament's activities at a single place. • Two landscape analyses: one on the resources requirements for accountability and public financial control in the EU and another on the risks to EU financial management. • Organising a high-level conference on accountability and public financial control in the EU. • Organising the meeting of the European Commission's Presidents of the Court of Auditors and the other on the issues of the Court's financial control.
Our management • In 2014, the court welcomed six new members: Alex Brenninkmeijer, Danièle Lamarque, Nikolaos Milionis, Phil Wynn Owen, Klaus‐Heiner Lehne and Oskar Herics.
The College of Members of the European Parliament elected Vítor Caldeira again as President of the Court for a third three-year period and appointed Ville Itälä as President of the Court for institutional relations. • The Court's 2013-2017 strategy provided impetus for changes in the organisation: the Court launched an internal reform project aimed at streamlining the audit process and ensuring a more flexible organisation of resources. • Further improvement in administrative efficiency, based on procedural simplifications and on the shift of staff working in the field of support services to the audit field.
An action plan in the area of equal opportunities has also been implemented.
Building of the Court in Luxembourg.
Our activities 07 Audit reports and other products The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: • Annual reports – with the results of its audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the European Union budget and the European Development Funds (EDF).
In addition, special annual reports on EU agencies, decentralised bodies and Joint Undertakings are published separately. • Special reports – which can be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits of specific budgetary areas or management issues.
These are essentially economic assessments. • Opinions – on new or amended acts that affect the financial management and other analytical products that are produced either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative.
In 2014, the farm produced more products than ever before and also introduced new products.
The annual accounts are still provided with a wide range of analytical information, and provide a comprehensive presentation of the results of our annual audits of the accounts and compliance audits.
In 2014, a greater focus was placed on economic audits so that additional knowledge on the quality of the implementation of the EU budget plan was made available to the EU budgetary authority.
In addition to the annual reports, for the first time, we published a summary of our audit results on agricultural and cohesion expenditure under shared management for the period 2009-2013, to allow for a multi-annual perspective.
Another important development was a new product called a landscape analysis.
In landscape ana-lysis, information and analyses on key issues are presented on the basis of our expertise in the audit area.
In 2014, we published two landscape analyses: the first focuses on the main challenges for the EU in terms of accountability and public financial control; the second focuses on the risks to EU financial management.

Our activities 08 audit visits in 2014 While most of the audit work is carried out on our premises in Luxembourg, our auditors also carry out audit visits to the authorities of the Member States, other recipients of EU funds (including at the headquarters of international organisations such as the World Health Organisation in Switzerland) and to the EU agencies and bodies.
The purpose of these visits is to obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the authorisation, management and payment of EU funds, as well as from the respective final beneficiaries.
Our audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners, and the duration of an audit visit is up to two weeks depending on the type of audit and the distance.
Within the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in coordination with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member States visited.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in the individual Member States and recipient countries depend on the type of audit and the results of the sample selection.
Therefore, the number and duration of the visits may vary from country to country and from year to year.
In 2014, the Court's auditors spent 4 915 days with on-the-spot audits in Member States and outside the EU, and obtained audit evidence for the annual reports and selected audit tasks (son-the-spot reports).
They also spent some time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg and with the decentralised agencies and bodies throughout the EU.
In 2014, our auditors used fewer days on-site than in previous years.
This is due to more efficient working methods and the increasing use of technologies such as videoconferencing.
EU inspectors used EU inspectors for testing for maritime freight installations.

Our activities 10 Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013 Most of its audits of accounting and compliance audits were devoted by the Court during 2014 to the implementation of the EU budget for 2013.
The 2013 Annual Report was published on 5 November 2014 and presented to our audience, including the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Economy and Finance), national parliaments and governments, and the media.
The aim of the annual report is to help the European Parliament, the Council and the citizens to assess the quality of EU financial management by presenting findings and conclusions.
The core element of the 2013 annual report is the 20th Annual Statement of Assurance ("DAS"), on the reliability of the EU accounts and the regularity of the underlying transactions.
That report provided more information on the efficiency of EU expenditure and on the Commission's performance reporting.
Estimated error rate for the EU budget: 4.7% President Caldeira at the handing over of the annual report for the financial year 2013 to the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz.
Our activities 11 The key statements of the Annual Report 2013 ο The Court has issued a full audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts of the European Union for 2013.
Total revenue for 2013 was legal and correct, including commitments. ο The payments for 2013 were largely flawed.
The Court has therefore delivered a failed opinion on its legality and regularity.
This figure is close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8%) and is consistently above the materiality threshold of 2 %. ο The two spending areas for regional policy, transport and energy with an estimated error rate of 6.9% and rural development, the environment, fisheries and health with an estimated error rate of 6.7%.
In the case of shared management as a whole, the estimated error rate was 5,2 %. ο Overall, the monitoring and control systems examined – with significant differences between the Member States – ensured the regularity of the payments.
As in 2012, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors in a large part of the error-related operations in the areas of shared management before the Commission had requested a refund. ο Correction and recovery by the Member States' authorities and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Without these measures, the estimated overall share would have been 6.3%. ο For the use of EU funds, absorption would have been the priority of the programming period 2007-2013 (use it or lose it – non-use of waste) and compliance with the legislation and not a good performance.
This lack of focus on performance is a crucial weakness in the way in which a large part of the EU budget is built.
