Our activities 13 Agriculture and Cohesion: An overview of EU expenditure for the period 2007-2013 In parallel with the annual reports, the Court for the first time published a background document, in 23 official EU languages, in order to provide a multi-annual perspective on the findings underlying the Statement of Assurance in the two main areas of expenditure on agriculture and cohesion.
It drew lessons on problems encountered in EU financial management and control in the past period of expenditure, summarising audit results, and on challenges related to the new period of expenditure 2014-2020.
In addition, it complied with the European Parliament's wish to obtain country-specific information on shared management with this overview, with the key words: 'Except for direct aid and market support measures for farmers in the agriculture sector, the pressure to make use of the funds is a key aspect of the risk of shared management expenditure.' The main risks to the regularity of agricultural expenditure are that the areas or animals or the costs on which the aid payments are based are not eligible, that the beneficiaries of the aid do not meet the conditions and that the aid is not calculated correctly.
Infringements of agri-environmental requirements, specific requirements for investment projects and public procurement rules are important factors which increase the risk of spending on rural development. ο Infringements of EU and/or national public procurement rules are the biggest risk of cohesion spending.
The second second risk is that expenditure (or projects) is not eligible for EU funding. ο Although control systems require significant improvement, the main challenge is to take action to simplify the management of the programmes.
The Court notes errors in all EU Member States.
Many errors have occurred due to the complexity of the overall architecture for management and control. ο Despite improvements in the reporting of risks and errors by the authorities of the Member States, it remains very difficult for the Commission to ensure the reliability of this information. ο The changes to the regulations for the new programming period may not have a significant impact on the level of risk.
Our activities 14 Annual Report on the European Development Funds for 2013 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are financed by the EU Member States and are subject to their own financial regulation and are managed outside the EU's general budget.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of operations financed from EDF resources.
Under the EDF, under the Cotonou 2000 Agreement, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
Expenditure is aimed at reducing poverty and ultimately defeating it, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars: development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2013 annual report on the EDFs was published on 5 November 2014 in part on the annual report on the EU budget.
It contains the 20th Statement of Assurance on the EDFs.
The Court noted that the annual accounts of 2013 represent the financial position of the EDFs, the results of their operations and cash flows, and the changes in the net assets as a whole.
The Court estimated the error rate in EDF expenditure operations for the financial year 2013 to be 3,4 %, which is an increase compared to 2012 with a rate of 3,0 %.
Special annual reports on the financial year 2013 In 2014, the Court issued and published 51 special annual reports on the financial year 2013.
The reports covered the 41 decentralised bodies, executive agencies and other EU agencies, the seven EU Joint Undertakings active in the field of research, the European Central Bank, the European Schools and the Sisnet communication infrastructure.
The Court also published two summaries with an overview of the results of its annual audits for the financial year 2013 – one on EU agencies and other bodies, the other on the EU research community.
These two analytical and comparative summaries were submitted to the President of the European Parliament, the Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
Together with the special annual reports, these summaries are available on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu).
EU agencies, bodies and joint ventures will be set up on the basis of EU legislation in order to carry out specific tasks, and their seats will be located throughout the European Union.
They are active in many areas, such as security, health, research, finance, migration and travel.
They all have a mandate, a board of directors, a director, staff and a budget.
While the agencies, bodies and Joint Undertakings, with respect to the EU budget as a whole, are at relatively low financial risk, the risk of reputation is high for the Union, as they are clearly visible in the Member States and have a significant impact on policy making, decision-making and the implementation of programmes in areas of major importance to the citizens of Europe.
51 special annual reports during the year
Our activities 15 The Court gave the 41 agencies and other agencies full audit opinions on the reliability of the 2013 accounts.
The procedures underlying these financial statements were legal and orderly for all agencies and other bodies except for two in all essential matters. The Court issued limited audit opinions for the EIT (European Institute of Innovation and Technology) and Frontex (European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union).
In addition, the 2013 accounts were reliable for all seven Joint Undertakings, but the Court gave a limited audit opinion for three Joint Undertakings in respect of the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying their annual accounts: Artemis (embedded ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and IMI (Innovative Medicines Initiative).
With regard to the European Schools, the Court was unable to conclude whether the consolidated annual accounts for 2013 were free of material misrepresentations, as the schools still lack accounts and control.
The Court examined the management of the European Central Bank's carbon footprint and noted that the Bank has taken measures to reduce the negative impact of its administrative activities on the environment, but that further efforts and measures are needed.
Special reports adopted in 2014 In addition to its annual reports and special annual reports, the Court publishes special reports throughout the year, containing the results of its economic and compliance audits on specific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice.
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is committed to achieving the maximum impact and thus making the best possible use of its resources.
In selecting issues, the Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks of irregularity or reduced economic viability in the expenditure or policy area; • the potential to achieve added value in the course of the Court's audit; • the political and public interest. 24 special reports in 2014
Our Activities 16 The main stages of a selected audit audit audit planning on-the-spot audit Preparation of the report Coordination of the report Adoption Publication Determination of the expeditability and feasibility of a proposed audit; determination of the scope, objectives, approach, methods and timing of the audit Multi-disciplinary teams carry together on-the-spot audit evidence in the Commission's central services and in Member States and recipient countries Clear, structured presentation of the main findings and conclusions; preparation of recommendations Confirmation of the facts and findings of the audited bodies Adoption of the report by the audit chamber or by the entire Court College Publication of the special report in 23 official languages together with the audited report The following pages briefly present the topics of the Court's 24 special reports in 2014 under the relevant headings of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework, the EU's multiannual budget.
Our activities 17 Smart and inclusive growth Smart and inclusive growth comprises two areas: competitiveness for growth and jobs includes funds for research and innovation, education and training, trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, social policy, enterprise development, and so on.The EU funds earmarked for growth and jobs for 2014-2020 amount, at current prices, to EUR 142 billion and 13% of the total EU budget.
Economic, social and territorial cohesion includes regional policy, which aims to help the most developed countries and regions in the EU to follow the rest, in order to strengthen the competitiveness of all regions and to develop cooperation between them.
The EU funding for cohesion for the period 2014-2020 – at current prices – is EUR 367 billion and 34% of the EU budget as a whole.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of EU funded projects in the field of public transport (No 1/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed the implementation and effectiveness of projects in the field of public transport co-financed by EU Structural Funds in order to determine whether the projects met the needs of the users and met their objectives.
The audit found that two thirds of the local transport projects co-financed by EU structural funds were insufficiently used.
This development has been primarily due to weaknesses in project design and inadequate mobility policies.
However, this inadequacy was generally not pursued by the promoters or the national authorities.
As a rule, infrastructure and vehicles have been established for most projects in line with project specifications.
Significant delays and cost differences were noted, but after completion, almost all the projects audited were in line with the needs of users.
European cities need to improve mobility and reduce congestion, accidents and pollution through local mobility strategies.
The co-financed projects supported the cities in setting up local transport systems such as metros, trams and buses.
Trams and buses are important means of transport for public transport.
Our activities 18 • Did cohesion policy funds contribute to the production of renewable energies to achieve good results?
(No 6/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the two main sources of funding for the promotion of renewable energy, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF), had achieved good results and examined whether funding for the period had been allocated adequately prioritised, cost-effective, and mature renewable energy production projects which had had good objectives and to what extent the funds had achieved good results which contributed to the achievement of the EU 2020 renewable energy target.
The audit found that improvements were needed to ensure that EU funding made the greatest possible contribution to the achievement of the objective.
The projects examined provided the outputs as planned and most projects were sufficiently mature and ready to be implemented at the time of their selection.
There were no significant cost overruns or major delays and renewable energy production capacities were installed as planned and were operational as planned.
However, the results in terms of energy production have not always been achieved or measured correctly.
Overall, the use of the funds was only limited, as the cost-effectiveness of the planning and implementation of the projects was not the guiding principle and expenditure had a limited EU added value.
The EU Council has set a binding EU target of 20% for the share of renewable energy in the gross final energy consumption by 2020.
In the period 2007-2013, some 4.7 million euros were made available for renewable energy from the ERDF and the CF. • Was the ERDF successful in supporting the development of incubators?
(No 7/2014) – In this special report, the Court analysed whether the incubators co-financed by the ERDF had successfully supported start-up companies with significant growth potential.
The audit found that the EU has made a significant financial contribution to the creation of incubators' infrastructure, in particular in Member States where this type of business support is relatively rare.
However, the performance of the audited incubators left too much to be desired.
The provision of business-related services was rather limited due to the financial constraints and the limited scope of the business-related activities.
This situation was mainly due to a lack of expertise in setting-up support procedures and due to a lack of administrative systems.
Incubators pursue the goal of supporting new companies in their successful establishment and further development.
Support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has thus become an increasingly political priority over time.
EU spending in this area amounted to €38 billion in the period 2007-2013.
The building "Delta " in the Wrocław Technology Park, co-financed by the ERDF.
Our activities 19 • Is the ERDF effective in funding projects for the direct promotion of biodiversity under the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020?
(No 12/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the ERDF funds available for the direct promotion of biodiversity have been used by the Member States.
The audit showed that Member States are lagging behind in the use of ERDF funding to finance projects compared to other ERDF spending areas.
In order to continue to be useful to the ERDF for the implementation of the EU biodiversity reduction strategy by 2020, the Commission should help Member States to implement specific conservation and management plans for natural habitats and species.
The co-financed projects were generally in line with the biodiversity priorities set at national and EU level.
However, the assessment of the effectiveness of these projects was hampered by the fact that most Member States did not, either through performance indicators or through monitoring systems, assess the development of natural habitats and species.
The protection of biodiversity is one of the EU's most important priorities.
Following the failure of the previous target of halting the loss of biodiversity in Europe by 2010, the Council approved a new strategy for 2020. The direct promotion of biodiversity and nature conservation has been allocated €2.8 billion of ERDF funding for the programming period 2007-2013. • Has ERDF support to SMEs been effective in the field of e-commerce?
(No 20/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether operational programmes provided a good basis for the effective support of e-commerce measures for SMEs, whether the managing authorities properly selected and monitored e-commerce projects and whether the e-commerce projects co-financed by the ERDF have been successfully implemented and have provided measurable benefits.
The Court noted that ERDF support for SMEs in the field of e-commerce – purchasing and selling goods over the Internet – helped to increase the online availability of business services.
However, due to monitoring deficits, it was impossible to assess the extent to which ERDF support has contributed to the achievement of the IT objectives of the Member States and the EU.
Insufficient selection procedures by Member States mean that a good cost-benefit ratio for a large number of projects is unlikely.
Programme managers focused more on the use of the resources (outputs) than on achieving results.
The Commission is promoting e-commerce through its Digital Agenda for Europe. In the framework of the ERDF budget, EUR 3 billion of EU funds for improving the use of ICT by SMEs were allocated for the period 2007-2013. The Court's video of Special Report No 20/2014 "Is the ERDF effective in financing projects directly promoting biodiversity in the framework of the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020?" – EU AuditorsECA on Youtube.
Our activities 20 Close-up of an economic impact assessment: EU-funded airport infrastructures – insufficient cost-benefit ratio (No. 21/2014) Closed part of the oversized terminal at Fuerteventura airport.
Although EU aviation policy aims to overcome capacity problems by building additional infrastructures, making better use of existing structures, optimising services at the airport and better connecting to other modes of transport, Europe will not be able to meet much of this demand because of the lack of runways and ground infrastructure.
In Europe, there are more than 500 airports, where one million people are employed directly or indirectly, contributing more than EUR 140 billion to Europe's economic performance, together with the airlines.
Airport-related infrastructure projects are an important part of the EU budget: projects of this nature the EU allocated some EUR 4.5 billion in the 2000-2013 programming period, of which more than EUR 2.8 billion were allocated from the Cohesion Policy Funds.
In its audit of this support, the Court examined whether the investment was clearly needed, whether the respective time and cost frameworks of the construction projects were respected and whether the newly built or modernised infrastructure was fully used.
The Court assessed whether the investment led to higher passenger numbers and improved customer service and whether the airports supported were financially viable.
The auditors carried out their work between May 2013 and October 2014, with a focus on 20 EU-funded airports in Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and Spain.
In total, more than EUR 600 million has been allocated to these airports for the period 2000-2013.
The team conducted an audit of the relevant legislation, air traffic planning in the five Member States and of the publications of the main interbranch organisations.
In particular, the auditors visited the 20 airports in order to assess the outputs, uses, results and impacts and the economic situation of the airports and to obtain direct evidence of this.
The Court concluded that the cost-benefit ratio for EU-funded investments for airports was not the right one.
Too many airports, often close together, received financial support for similar infrastructure, and in many cases it was found that these infrastructure was oversized.
Only half of the airports audited managed to increase their passenger numbers.
Improvements in customer service or regional socio-economic benefits, such as the creation of additional jobs, have not been measured or evidence has not been provided.
The investigation also revealed that seven airports were not financially self-supporting and would have difficulties not having any further public support.
At most of the airports audited, the audit team found significant delays in the construction and provision of infrastructure.
Nearly half of airports exceeded costs, so that Member States had to contribute almost 100 million euro more from their national budgets than originally planned.
Our activities 21 The funding was not well coordinated by the Member States: in most Member States there was no strategic long-term airport development plan.
In addition, the Commission has inadequately monitored the financing, which is generally not known which airports receive funding or which amounts are involved.
As a result, it does not have a complete picture of all EU airport investment and has limited options for monitoring and ensuring that policies are properly designed and implemented.
On the basis of these findings, the Court recommended that the Commission, from the 2014-2020 programming period onwards, ensure that Member States only use EU funds for airport infrastructures that are financially viable and whose investment needs have been adequately assessed and demonstrated.
Another recommendation was that Member States should have coherent plans for airport expansion at regional, national and supranational level to avoid overcapacity, duplication and uncoordinated investment in airport infrastructure.
In its reply, the Commission has confirmed that lessons have been learned from this experience.
As a result, it has ensured that a fundamentally different approach has been adopted in the relevant legislation for the 2014-2020 programming period.
The report was presented to the European Parliament, which fully supports the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The publication of the report met with great media interest.
The media reaction was highest in Spain, but also included headlines in major international newspapers, television coverage, and social media.
From left to right: Afonso de Castro Malheiro, Jasmine Mitterbuchner, Patrick Weldon, Mircea Radulescu, Pietro Puricella, Joël Costantzer, George Pufan (member of the Court responsible for the report), Fernando Pascual Gil, Luc T'Joen, Tomasz Plebanowicz, Lorenzo Pirelli, Efstratios Varetidis, Jelena Magermane, Erki Must.
Our activities 22 Sustainable growth: natural resources The EU has a high political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for the period 2014-2020, at current prices, amounts to EUR 420 billion, or 39% of the EU budget as a whole.
Three quarters of the expenditure relates to direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) – the ‘first pillar' of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
Another fifth of the expenditure is the EU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the "second pillar of the CAP".
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2014 the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Integration of the objectives of the EU water policy into the CAP: a partial success (No 4/2014) – In this special report the Court assessed whether the objectives of the EU water policy were successfully integrated into the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
The audit showed that the EU can only achieve partial success in integrating the objectives of water policy into the CAP.
The two instruments for integrating water-related issues (cross compliance and rural development) have shortcomings and the implementation of the Water Framework Directive is characterised by delays and weaknesses.
The CAP instruments have so far had a positive impact on supporting the policy objectives of improving the quantity and quality of water.
However, these instruments are limited compared to the ambitious objectives of the CAP.
For example, neither of these two instruments allows the full application of the "polluter pays" principle in the allocation of CAP funds.
Moreover, it is not sufficiently clear at the level of the EU institutions and in the Member States what pressures the water resources are exposed to and what developments these pressures are.
The EU gives high priority to the protection of European water resources.
Agriculture, one of the largest consumers and polluters of water resources, plays a key role in sustainable water management.
For the CAP, almost 40% of the EU's budget is raised (over 50 billion euros in 2014), the EU is working under the CAP to influence the agricultural processes that have an impact on water resources.
Our activities 23 • Has the Commission managed effectively the integration of coupled support into the single payment scheme?
(No 8/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed how well the Commission managed, after the 2008 CAP health check, the inclusion of the EU support linked to production volumes (e.g. farmed land or livestock numbers) in the single payment scheme.
The audit found that the Commission did not adequately monitor in the 2010-2012 period how Member States calculated farmers' entitlements to EU support payments for agricultural holdings under the farm payment scheme.
While most Member States had correctly used the reference data of farmers, there were serious deficiencies in the correct application of the calculation rules and principles.
The Commission did not use its mandate to ensure that the criteria for the allocation of available support were always in line with the EU principles, that they were in line with the principle of sound budgetary management and that they had no potential impact on market conditions.
The Commission's framework did not provide clear enough rules on what controls Member States should carry out and Member States' control systems were of varying quality.The main objective of the single payment scheme was to shift the orientation of the CAP from market support to decoupled income support for farmers: farmers should be able to adapt their production to market demand and their income should be stabilised.
The single payment scheme, which has so far been introduced in 18 Member States, accounts for 54% of the total EU budget for agriculture and rural development. • Is EU support for investment and promotion in the wine sector well managed, and is there any evidence of results in terms of the competitiveness of EU wines?
(No 9/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the investment and promotion measures were adequately designed and the Court also assessed the available monitoring and evaluation data in order to assess whether the Commission and the Member States achieved the desired results in an efficient manner.
The audit found that the management of the support for investments and promotion in the wine sector was hampered by the lack of design and implementation and that the impact on the competitiveness of EU wines could not always be demonstrated.
The specific investment measure for the wine sector is not justified as support is already provided under the EU rural development policy.
EU support for the promotion of wines often served to consolidate existing markets rather than to develop new markets or to reconquer old ones.
The impact of the investment measure cannot easily be separated from the investment in rural development.
The EU is the world's largest wine producer.
EU support is intended to improve competitiveness and to ensure a better balance between supply and demand.
Member States spent EUR 522 million on the promotion measure and EUR 518 million on the investment measure during the period 2009-2013.
In 2014-2018, the resources allocated to Member States under this measure have increased significantly.
Our activities 24 • Effectiveness of the support for aquaculture provided by the European Fisheries Fund (EFF) (No 10/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the aquaculture support measures were well designed and adequately implemented at EU and Member State level and whether the EFF provided the appropriate cost-benefit ratio and supported the sustainable development of aquaculture.
The audit showed that the measures to support aquaculture by 2013 were not well designed and implemented at EU and Member State level, that the EFF did not achieve an adequate cost-benefit ratio and that the sustainable development of aquaculture was not effectively supported.
The current framework was not suitable for concrete implementation of the EU's objectives for the sustainable development of aquaculture and the results were not sufficient.
Measures to support the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Member States were not well designed and implemented.
The national strategic plans and operational programmes of the Member States were not sufficiently clear and the Member States did not have a coherent strategy for the sector.
The EFF funding has often not been sufficiently targeted for aquaculture projects and the audit has shown that these projects usually did not deliver the planned results or provide a good cost-benefit ratio.
Every year, around 1.3 million tonnes of fish are produced in the EU by aquaculture, with a turnover of EUR 4 billion.
One of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) for the period up to 2013 was to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture.
By May 2013, the EFF provided more than EUR 400 million to finance measures to promote productive investment and environmental and health measures in the aquaculture sector. • Economic measures: to maintain control over the costs of EU-funded rural development aid (No 22/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the approaches adopted by the Commission and the Member States were the most effective to control the costs of rural development aid.
The audit showed that EU Member States could achieve significant savings in support for rural development projects, while allowing for a more efficient use of funds.
The auditors identified practical and cost-effective approaches that could be more widely used in Member States' control of the cost of rural development aid.
The Member States' control systems were designed to control the prices of goods or works listed in the aid applications without the same attention being paid to the question of whether the goods themselves were appropriated.
Some price controls were time-consuming or provided little certainty that the approved costs were reasonable.
At the beginning of the programming period, the Commission did not provide sufficient guidance nor did it ensure the dissemination of recommended procedures.
It did not ensure that Member States' systems were effective, but that they were widely approved prior to such aid.
Around half of the EU rural development expenditure for the period 2007-2013, totalling EUR 100 billion, has been implemented in the form of grants for the costs of investment projects and other projects implemented by farmers, agricultural enterprises, associations and local authorities.
Our activities 25 • Errors in rural development expenditure: what are the causes and what is being done to remove them?
(No 23/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined compliance with applicable laws and other legislation applicable to the implementation of rural development and described the main causes of the high error rate in this area.
The audit found that most errors in rural development policy were due to non-compliance with conditions established at Member State level.
Member States' control authorities could and should have been able to detect and correct most of the errors in investment in rural development.
Member States' control systems are inadequate, as controls are not comprehensive and are based on insufficient information.
The average error rate for rural development expenditure over the last three years was 8.2 %.
Errors in investment measures accounted for two-thirds of the error rate, while area-related aid accounted for one-third of the error rate.
Only 16% of the error rate was due to non-compliance with the provisions contained directly in the EU regulations, while the largest proportion of the rate – 84% – was due to non-compliance with conditions at Member State level.
The EU and the Member States allocated over EUR 150 billion for rural development policy in the 2007-2013 programming period, almost equally allocated to investment and land-based aid.
These expenditures are particularly flawed. • Are EU aid for the prevention and remedying of forest damage caused by fires and natural disasters well managed?
(No 24/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) support measure for the reconstruction of forest potential and the implementation of preventive actions (measure 226) has been well managed and whether the Commission and the Member States can demonstrate that the objectives of the aid have been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
The audit showed that the funding the EU has provided for the prevention of forest fires and the restoration of forests damaged by natural disasters and fires has not been managed well enough.
The Commission and the Member States cannot prove that the results envisaged in the financial framework have been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
In the last 30 years, on average, 480 000 hectares of forest in the EU have been destroyed annually by fires.
Preventive actions accounted for more than 80% of EU funding of 1.5 million euros for the period 2007-2013.
Our activities 26 Security and Citizenship This policy area has been established to ensure the free movement of persons and to provide citizens with a high level of protection.
It ranges from the administration of the EU's external borders to judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters and includes asylum and immigration policy, police cooperation and the fight against crime.
Expenditure in this area in the period 2014-2020 is expected to be 18 million euro and less than 2% of the total budget.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this field: • Findings from the European Commission's development of the second generation (SIS II) information system (No. 3/2014) – In this special report the Court examined why the Commission provided SIS II more than six years later than planned and costed eight times more than originally estimated.
It was assessed whether there was a viable business case for SIS II for the entire duration of the project, taking into account major changes in costs and expected benefits.
The audit found that the delays and excessive costs were due to weaknesses in management by the Commission.
The initial deadline was unrealistic and the Commission was unable to effectively manage the main task for development before 2009.
In the initial cost estimates, the actual level of investment required was significantly underestimated.
The total cost of SIS II was EUR 189 million, which was originally estimated at EUR 23 million.
The Commission did not fully demonstrate that SIS II provided it with the best cost-benefit ratio.
However, it has gained lessons from its experience during the first phase of the project, and has already used some of these lessons for other large-scale IT projects.
The Schengen Information System is used by border protection, police, customs, visa and judicial authorities throughout the Schengen area.
It contains information (an alert) on persons who may or may not have been involved in a serious crime or who have the right to enter or reside in the EU.
It also includes calls for tenders for missing persons and lost or stolen property. • The External Borders Fund contributed to more financial solidarity, but results must be improved and additional EU added value created (No 15/2014) – In this Special Report, the Court assessed the effectiveness and EU added value of the External Borders Fund and assessed the extent to which the objectives of the co-financed projects and programmes have been achieved.
The audit showed that the External Borders Fund contributed to the management of the external borders of the EU and to increased financial solidarity between the Member States.
However, its additional EU added value was limited and the overall results could not be measured due to weaknesses in the monitoring by the competent authorities and serious deficiencies in the assessments at the Commission level and at the level of the Member States.
Member States' programmes were not embedded in national border control and visa policies and contained neither SMART targets nor measurable indicators.
Project selection procedures have not ensured that the actual needs of the Member States have been met.
Unfinished procurement procedures in the Member States pose a risk to the sound management of the budget.
In the Member States most affected (Greece, Spain, Italy and Malta, too, in the first years of support), the Fund's management was seriously weak.
The EU's main financial instrument to support the management of external borders was the External Borders Fund, which was endowed with EUR 1.9 billion for the period 2007-2013.
Its overarching objective was to support current and future Schengen States in ensuring uniform, effective and effective controls at their common external borders.
Our activities 27 Europe in the world The EU's external relations activities focus on: enlargement, the achievement of stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood, active support of sustainable development at international level, the promotion of global political governance, and the securing of strategic and civil security.
The EU has allocated EUR 66 billion for the period 2014-2020 – at current prices – or 6 % of its planned total expenditure for these objectives.
Expenditure is managed by the Commission mainly directly through its central services or delegations.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • The establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) (No 11/2014) – In this special report the Court examined whether the establishment of the EEAS has been adequately prepared, whether its resources have been efficiently prioritised, organised and allocated, and whether it has been effectively coordinated with the Commission and the Member States.
The audit identified the need for the EEAS to increase its efficiency and to do more for the EU and its citizens.
The establishment of the EEAS was speedily and was not prepared well enough.
Inefficiencies in prioritisation, organisation and allocation of resources reduced its efficiency.
Coordination between the EEAS and the Commission was only partially effective, mainly due to the lack of effective coordination mechanisms and the lack of a rigid financial and administrative framework at the level of delegation.
Coordination with Member States can be further developed to exploit synergies in the area of information exchange or common accommodation and to improve consular services, including the protection of EU citizens.
The EEAS has its headquarters in Brussels and has a worldwide network of 140 delegations.
For 2014, the EEAS had a budget of EUR 519 million, divided between headquarters (41%) and delegations (59%). • EU rehabilitation assistance after the earthquake in Haiti (No 13/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the EU's rehabilitation assistance in the country was well-designed and adequately implemented, and whether the Commission ensured a proper link between emergency aid and rehabilitation and development.
The audit found that the EU's rehabilitation assistance after the 2010 earthquake in Haiti was overall well-designed and focused on the country's urgent needs, but that the programmes were not implemented effectively enough and that the link between emergency aid, rehabilitation and development was not enough.
Most of the programmes audited had the output of the programme on schedule or the delivery of the programme was on the horizon, although almost all of the programmes had been delayed.
While the Commission was aware of the difficult situation, it has not adequately addressed a number of the major risks that threatened the implementation and achievement of the programme objectives.
The programmes have been monitored, but the Commission and the EEAS have not taken timely action to increase the resources of the EU Delegation in Haiti.
In March 2010, 55 donors pledged $5.4 billion for 2010-2012 for rehabilitation and development and a further $3.0 billion for 2013 and beyond.
The EU was one of the most important donors with a commitment of a single amount of 1.2 billion euros.
Our activities 28 • Effectiveness of combining financial assistance from regional investment facilities with loans from financial institutions (mixed financing) to support EU foreign policy (no. 16/2014) – This special report dealt with the establishment and management of the investment facilities, and examined whether mixed financing had achieved the desired benefits.
The audit has shown a positive view on mixed financing, i.e. on combining financial aid from regional investment facilities with loans granted by financial institutions in support of EU foreign policy in terms of structure and overall effectiveness, but the Court also points to a number of key issues that need to be addressed urgently.
While the facilities were well-structured, the potential benefits of mixed financing were not fully realised due to shortcomings in the Commission's management of the facilities.
In nearly half of the projects examined, there was insufficient evidence that the grants were justified.
In some cases, investments would probably have been made without the EU contribution.
The Commission should ensure that the allocation of funds is based on a thorough and documented assessment of the added value of achieving the objectives of the EU's development, neighbourhood and enlargement policies.
Since 2007, the Commission has created eight regional investment facilities.
These combine financial assistance from the EDF and the EU's overall budget with loans from mainly European development finance institutions.
Mixed funding is usually intended to exploit investment opportunities in the form of large infrastructure projects that could be financially viable but for which sufficient resources could not be mobilised in financial markets. • Can the EU Initiative of the Centres of Excellence contribute effectively to the containment of chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) risks that originate outside the EU?
(No 17/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the initiative was based on a sound analysis of the situation existing before 2010, whether the organisational structure of the initiative was appropriate to address the identified challenges, and whether there was an appropriate administrative system and whether it was applied.
The Court's assessment was generally positive as regards the contribution of the Centres of Excellence to the reduction of CBRN risks.
The initiative is in line with the priorities set in the framework of the European Security Strategy and the EU Strategy against the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction.
It provides for the participation of all of the stakeholders in the partner countries in order to improve the sustainability of the measures taken.
The organisational structure is generally appropriate, but its complexity has contributed to the delay in the start-up of project activities.
The Excellence Centres initiative is aimed at establishing regional platforms in different regions of the world in order to counteract CBRN risks.
It is the largest individual measure of the long-term component of the Instrument for Stability and has been allocated a budget of EUR 100 million for the period 2010-2013.
Our activities 29 • EuropeAid for evaluation and results oriented monitoring (ROM) systems (No 18/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether these systems are reliable, whether their structure and resources are adequate, and whether they ensure that relevant and meaningful findings are made and that the findings are of maximum benefit.
During the audit, the Court made a critical assessment of the reliability of these systems.
The evaluation and performance-oriented monitoring bodies are well organised, but more attention should be paid to the efficient use of resources.
The systems do not provide sufficient information on the results achieved and do not ensure that the findings are made as much as possible.
The evaluations of projects and programmes organised by the Commission delegations and carried out in partner countries are not managed satisfactorily: the overall monitoring is not appropriate, there is uncertainty about the level of resources used and there is a lack of access to the results.
Two key elements of the European Commission's European Commission's European Commission's framework of accountability for the evaluation and the results-oriented monitoring of the results are their systems.
The total annual cost of the schemes is estimated at 34 to 38 million euros.
The annual development expenditure covered by these systems is estimated at around EUR 8 billion. • EU pre-accession assistance to Serbia (No. 19/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined the effectiveness of the Commission's management of pre-accession assistance to Serbia in the period 2007-2013, assessing its support to the key area of governance.
Together with other forms of support, the resources provided by the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) helped Serbia implement social and economic reforms and improve public financial management.
On the basis of the experience gained with other IPA beneficiary countries, the Commission is increasingly focusing on governance issues in the planning of financial and non-financial assistance to Serbia.
The Commission has effectively managed non-financial assistance to Serbia in the areas of governance and the fight against corruption.
As regards Serbia's preparations for the decent management of EU funds, the Commission has also provided effective support, but only in the limited area of the IPA administrative structures.
A quarter of the IPA funding for Serbia has been channelled into governance, which, according to the Commission, has the greatest challenges for Serbia.
The EU complements the IPA fi nancing with a number of non-financial resources to help Serbia prepare for EU membership.
Our Activities 30 Administration The administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on personnel, salaries and pensions, and on buildings, equipment, energy, communication and information technology.
The planned budget for the period 2014-2020 – at current prices – amounts to EUR 70 million and to 6% of the total EU budget.
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report in this field: • How do EU institutions and bodies calculate, reduce and compensate their greenhouse gas emissions?
(No 14/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the EU institutions and bodies had strategies to reduce the impact of their administrative activities on the environment and whether these strategies had been effectively implemented.
In the report, the Court called on the EU institutions and bodies to develop a common policy approach to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions (CO2 footprint).
The introduction of the eco-management and audit system is slow and the available information on the actual level of emissions is incomplete.
Few bodies and bodies systematically use environmental procurement.
While EU institutions and bodies have managed to reverse the trend of increasing greenhouse gas emissions associated with energy consumption in their buildings, there were no clear trends in the reduction of emissions from other sources of emissions, such as missions, in the light of the available data.
More than half of the EU's audited institutions and bodies had not set any quantified targets for reducing their emissions.
EU environmental policy aims at a high level of protection.
The Treaty (TFEU) requires that environmental protection requirements be included in the definition and implementation of Union policies and measures to promote sustainable development.
Our activities 31 revenue/own resources Own resources are the revenue of the EU to finance its expenditure.
There are three types of own resources: traditional own resources (customs duties applied to imports from outside the EU, production levies on sugar), own resources based on VAT and own resources derived from GNI (the largest source of revenue of the EU budget).
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: • Will preferential trade arrangements be managed appropriately?
(No 2/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the Commission assessed the economic impact of preferential trade arrangements appropriately, and whether the controls effectively ensure that imports were not incorrectly subject to preferential duties, with the result of a loss of EU revenue.
The audit found that, while the Commission has improved the quality of its impact assessments over time, the economic impact of preferential trade regimes has still not been sufficiently analysed.
The EU escapes revenue due to weaknesses in Member States' customs controls: these controls do not prevent certain imports from being unduly subject to preferential customs duties.
Through unilateral preferential trade arrangements, the EU grants preferential treatment to developing countries in order to offer them duty-free access to the EU market and thus contribute to the eradication of poverty and to the promotion of sustainable development.
In 2011, the value of the goods imported into the EU under preferential trade arrangements was more than EUR 242 billion, representing 14% of imports into the EU.
Our activities 32 Financial and economic governance The European Union's framework for economic governance aims to prevent and correct problematic economic developments, such as excessive government deficits or debt levels, which can inhibit growth and expose the sustainability of public finances to risk.
In 2014, the Court adopted its first special report in this area: • The European Banking Authority is taking shape – EBA in a changing environment (No 5/2014) – In this special report the Court examined whether the Commission and the European Banking Authority (EBA) have exercised their responsibilities in a satisfactory manner in the establishment of new regulatory and regulatory and supervisory arrangements in the banking sector and how effectively these arrangements have worked.
The audit showed that the Commission-led reform of banking legislation and the establishment of EBA were the first major responses to the financial crisis.
EBA has laid the foundations for a new regulatory and supervisory system for the banking sector.
The identified weaknesses related to cross-border banking supervision, the assessment of the resilience of EU banks and the promotion of consumer protection.
In connection with the implementation of the 2011 stress test, which was carried out at EU level without financial protection measures, the EBA had only a limited legal mandate and scarce human resources.
Although the 2011 stress test resulted in the recapitalisation of many banks, it also made it clear that such stress tests could be restricted if they were not accompanied by an assessment of the quality of the overall assets.
Questions remain as to the future role of the EBA in banking supervision as well as the respective roles and responsibilities of the EBA and the ECB.
As a result of the financial crisis, the Commission has launched measures to stabilise the banking sector, aimed at strengthening the regulatory framework and banking supervision, in particular in the case of cross-border banks.
In the course of the detailed proposals for regulatory changes, EBA was set up in 2011.
EBA plays a role in overseeing European banking regulation and consumer protection.
Our activities 33 Opinions and other statements adopted in 2014 The Court's opinions on proposals for new or amended acts with financial implications help to improve EU financial management.
These opinions will be delivered at the request of the other EU institutions and will be used by the legislative authorities – the European Parliament and the Council – in their work.
The Court may also, on its own initiative, issue position papers and analyses on other issues.
At the Court's initiative, the European Court of Auditors' position on the Commission's report on the fight against corruption was presented, while the study on possible savings in the EU budget was carried out by pooling the European Parliament's activities in a single place at the request of the European Parliament.
7 comments in 2014
Our activities 34 Landscape analyses The year 2014 was marked by profound innovations for the European Union.
Against the background of this change, the Court has designed and created a new product: the Landscape Analysis.
On the basis of the Court's work and its wealth of knowledge and experience, each analysis will cover a wide range of topics.
The analyses should serve as a basis for consultation and dialogue with the Court's address group and should help the Court to present comments on important issues, which are not subject to review.
The first Landscape Analysis, published in September 2014, addressed issues relating to EU accountability and public financial control rules (see box), which was the main basis for the EU accountability conference which took place in October 2014 (see page 42).
The second analysis entitled The optimal use of EU funds: A landscape analysis of risks to EU financial management was published in November 2014.
It provides an overview of the EU's financial flows and a summary of the issues to be addressed, inter alia, to ensure that EU taxpayers can be offered a better cost-benefit ratio to the EU budget (see box).
The opinions and landscape analyses are available in full in 23 official EU languages on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu).
2 2 Landscape analyses in 2014
Our activities 35 gaps, overlaps and challenges: A landscape analysis of EU rules on accountability and public financial control This landscape analysis aims to raise awareness of an issue of utmost importance for the democratic legitimacy of the EU's institutional system, and to give impetus to the discussions on this issue.
It describes the main features of a framework of accountability, the role of public financial control, the key elements of a sound chain of accountability and financial control, and six key areas where challenges in terms of accountability and public financial control at EU level exist, and analyses the accountability and financial control arrangements in relation to the various new EU and intergovernmental instruments developed in response to the financial crisis.
Making optimal use of EU funds: a landscape analysis of risks to EU financial management At a time when Member State governments and taxpayers want to see a higher benefit from the resources they contribute, this Landscape analysis summarises the Court's comments on all aspects of EU financial management.
Based on the Court's 35-year experience in the audit of EU revenue and expenditure, this Landscape Analysis provides an overview of EU financial management and a summary of the issues to be addressed in order to ensure a better cost-benefit ratio with the EU budget.
This analysis is complemented by detailed data sheets on the main characteristics and issues linked to the different areas of revenue and expenditure, and suggestions for improvements are made.
Our activities 36 The analysis identifies a number of key points which deserve special attention: ο overly complex eligibility schemes and other conditions for EU support which make it difficult to understand, manage and control and lead to different interpretations; ο rules and procedures for public procurement that are not always complied with – either intentionally or because they are not properly understood – and which lead to higher costs or delays for EU funded projects; ο insufficient capacity for national authorities to manage and disbursement EU funds that increases the risk of errors and the risk of low quality of expenditure; ο poor coordination of EU budget and national budgets; lack of funds for co-financing by Member States; and a greater emphasis on the compliance with the rules than the achievement of results; and ο a high volume of commitments from the previous period of expenditure to be financed from the EU budget.

Our activities 37 Relationships with the addressees The value of the Court's contribution to the EU's accountability obligation depends to a large extent on the benefits of its key partners in the accountability process from its work results and its products.
These partners are the political bodies responsible for public oversight of the use of EU funding (i.e. the European Parliament, the Council of the EU and national parliaments).
Through its 2013-2017 strategy, the Court is required to step up its preparations to monitor external developments and to actively shape relations with its partners.
The President and the members of the Court shall maintain regular contacts with the committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control.
In 2014, President Caldeira attended two meetings of the Committee on Budgetary Control and a number of plenary meetings of the European Parliament.
This included the presentation of the annual work programme and the annual reports.
The Court's strategic objectives include strengthening the partnership with its main stakeholders, including the various specialised committees of the European Parliament and the Council.
In April 2014, the Court transferred the newly created function of the member responsible for institutional relations to Ville Itälä, which helped to strengthen our institution's relations with other EU institutions with a strategic perspective and to increase the opportunities for a greater impact with our work.
In 2014, further Court members, in conjunction with the Court's annual reports and special reports, were in the presence of the Committee on Budgetary Control, in 17 meetings 64 times.
The resulting discussions resulted in reports drawn up by individual members of the Committee on Budgetary Control on special Court reports, including a draft report on special reports related to the 2013 discharge procedure.
In 2014, the Committee on Budgetary Control started to systematically invite the specialised committees to the ideas of our Sonderberichte at its meetings, thus contributing to the increased impact of our work.
In early 2014, the European Parliament adopted a report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors.
The Court welcomed the view expressed in this report that any reform should be considered in the wider context of the challenge of improving the EU's accountability.
This applies in particular to the Court's work, its relations with the addressees and its use of resources.
The progress made in relation to these issues was highlighted in the 2014 peer review report (see "Important events").
Our activities 38 In many cases, the Court has already launched a series of initiatives to improve the implementation of its 2013-2017 strategy, including streamlining the audit and reporting process and the more flexible organisation of resources.
This led to more reports being drawn up in the course of the year and the average time needed to do so was reduced.
Further efficiency gains and increased effectiveness of the audit process are expected from the internal reform project launched in 2014.
In a resolution adopted in November 2013, the European Parliament asked the Court to present a comprehensive analysis of the potential savings to the EU budget that would arise if the European Parliament had a single seat, taking account of the savings that had been made due to a reduction in the loss of working time and due to greater efficiency.
The Court presented the outcome of this work in July 2014 and concluded that a move from Strasbourg to Brussels could lead to a significant increase from Luxembourg to Brussels due to an additional move.
In 2014, the Court continued the regular cooperation with the Council in its various configurations and activities.
President Caldeira presented the annual reports to the ECOFIN Council in December 2014 and the Court was regularly invited to present special reports to the various Council committees and working groups.
Ensuring effective relations with national parliaments is another priority for the Court.
The committees of the national parliaments responsible for European affairs and financial control are regularly informed of the Court's activities.
During the year, delegations from several national parliaments visited the Court, including the visit of a delegation from the French Senate in July 2014.
In addition, the Court invited the main addressees to the annual seminar of its members in December 2014 in order to present their views on the challenges of accountability in the EU.
The Court works with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to fight fraud to the detriment of the EU budget.
It shall forward to OLAF any evidence of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity, to the detriment of the EU's financial interests, to which it is subject or which it is informed by third parties, by the examination carried out by it.
In 2014, the Court informed OLAF of 16 cases in which fraud, corruption or illegal activities were suspected in the course of the audit work.
Our activities 39 Cooperation with other Supreme Audit Institutions The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs) mainly in the following fora: • contact committee of the SAIs of the EU Member States; • network of SAIs of the candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • international organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the international organisation of the Supreme Audit Authority (INTOSAI) and its European regional group (EUROSAI).
In September 2014, the Court revised and updated its international cooperation strategy (see box).
EUROSAI Congress, The Hague, June 2014.
Court's Strategy for International Cooperation The Court's Strategy for Cooperation, in line with its overarching strategy for 2013-2017, aims to make the greatest possible contribution to the EU's public accountability, in particular through enhanced bi- and multilateral cooperation with relevant partners, such as national Supreme Audit Institutions and international audit organisations.
As the Court's audit obligations cover areas that are pan-European (e.g. fiscal governance) and global (e.g. climate change) impacts, our international cooperation activities are even more important than in the past.
The Court's cooperation strategy has the following priorities: ο Cooperation at EU level within the Contact Committee and individual cooperation with the SAIs of the EU Member States will continue to be the main priorities.
This may include participation in joint audits and joint work on accountability relevant to the EU budget and other EU policies. ο In the context of EU enlargement, the Court will continue to support the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries in their work on the development of relevant competences. ο As a member of international audit organisations such as INTOSAI, the Court will increase its participation in cooperation activities on the definition of technical standards, as this organisation is of great importance to the development of expertise and the exchange of knowledge in the public financial control sector.
Through its cooperation strategy, coupled with other recent actions, such as the newly established high-level conferences and meetings, the Court will help raise awareness of EU financial management and accountability.
Our activities 40 Contact Committee of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States Under the EU Treaty, the European Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies cooperate with confidence, while respecting their independence.
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of EU Member States within the Contact Committee, including an annual meeting, and the various working groups, networks and task forces set up to address specific issues of common interest.
In October 2013, the Court took over the chair of the Contact Committee for a year.
As chairman, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the Contact Committee, which took place in October 2014.
The main agenda items included a seminar on strengthening cooperation, in particular in areas related to the Europe 2020 strategy and the Banking Union, reporting on the activities of the Contact Committee and its professional partners, and audits carried out by the Contact Committee members on EU-related matters.
The Court also cooperates with the SAIs of the EU Member States on a bilateral basis.
A good example of this is a project jointly carried out by the Court and the SAIs of Poland, Najwyższa Izba Kontroli, in which the auditors of the Polish SAIs actively participated in our audit work in Poland on the eradication, control and monitoring of animal diseases.
In addition, in the context of the Chapter on Results of the 2014 Annual Report, the Court cooperates with the SAIs of Poland and Portugal on Europe 2020.
Meeting of the Contact Committee in Luxembourg on 15-17 October 2014.

Our activities 42 Key events International expert review of the Court In 2013, the Court asked the SAIs of France, Germany and Sweden to carry out peer review of their practice of economic assessment.
The peer review was based on the experience of all three partners and was a very useful exercise for both the court and the peer reviewers.
The methodology was based on generally accepted criteria for the work of SAIs and was based on the guidelines set out in international standards.
The peer review was published on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu) in 2014.
The peers concluded that the Court had made considerable progress since the last peer review in 2008.
The Court had examined the challenges posed by the complex institutional framework of the EU and had taken a number of steps to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of its audits and the quality of its audit reports.
International auditing principles encourage the implementation of international peer reviews.
They allow Supreme Audit Authorities to obtain a voluntary assessment of the performance of their tasks based on international standards.
In 2014, the Court headed the peer review of the Supreme Audit Authority of Lithuania and was asked to review the Swiss Federal Financial Control and participate in peer reviews of the SAIs of Spain and Latvia.
High-level conference on improving accountability in the EU From left to right: Jacques Sciberras, Head of the Cabinet, Kevin Cardiff, Member of the Court, President Vítor Caldeira and EP Vice President Olli Rehn.
In October 2014, the Court organised a high-level conference to which a large number of people were invited to ensure that the European Union complied with its accountability with regard to the public funding used to achieve its objectives.
The conference focused on the gaps, overlaps and challenges at EU and Member State level identified in the Court's Landscape Analysis on EU accountability and public financial control rules (see page 35).
The conference provided an opportunity for discussion among participants, including members or representatives of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court, the European Central Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Stability Mechanism, the national Courts of Auditors and the scientific community. It discussed how these arrangements should be developed in response to developments in economic, budgetary and monetary integration.
The focus was on accountability within the EU, in particular on central banks and supervisors, post-crisis structures, increasing the leverage of EU funding through external participation and increasing the focus on the EU's performance.
The conference participants agreed that there was a need for greater cooperation between governmental authorities, parliaments and auditors at EU and Member State level in order to provide the public with a better picture of the achievements of EU policies and programmes.
Our activities 43 Strengthening partnerships with national authorities in Lithuania A high-level delegation from the Court visited Lithuania in September 2014 in order to strengthen partnerships with Parliament, the Government, the Central Bank and the SAIs in the country and to promote the best use and control of EU expenditure there.
The Court and its partners in Lithuania exchanged views on the priorities for improving EU accountability and on how they can best contribute to the added value of EU spending through their cooperation and help policy-makers and Parliament in Lithuania to make the best use of the Court's audit results.
During the visit, the Court delegation took an active part in the Lithuanian Parliament's conference on the challenges in the area of accountability and audit of the public sector.
In addition, the delegation and its partners discussed issues relating to financial and economic governance and the benefits of Lithuania's accession to the euro area on 1 January 2015.
Lithuania was the first of a number of EU Member States the Court intends to visit in the coming years in order to strengthen partnerships with the national authorities responsible for managing and controlling EU funds.
Our Management 44 The College of the Court The College of the Court is composed of one member from each Member State.
The term of office of the members of the Court shall be six years in accordance with the contract, and the term of office of the members of the Court shall be renewable.
Members are assigned to one of five chambers.
The boards adopt audit reports and opinions and take decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member is responsible for his or her own tasks, which are primarily audit-related tasks.
The audit work is carried out by the Court's auditors and is coordinated by the competent member, assisted by his cabinet.
The Member shall then present the report for adoption by the Chamber and/or by the whole College of the Court and later the report to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties, including the media.
In accordance with the proposals of its Member States and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union appointed six new members of the European Court of Auditors in 2014.
Four of these members – Alex Brenninkmeijer (Netherlands), Danièle Lamarque (France), Nikolaos Milionis (Greece) and Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom) – welcomed the Court on 1 January, two others – Klaus‐Heiner Lehne (Germany) and Oskar Herics (Austria) – were welcomed on 1 March 2014.
On 23 January 2014, the 28 members of the Court of Auditors again elected Vítor Caldeira the President of the Court for a third three-year period.
The President shall be responsible for supervising the performance of the Court's mandate and shall represent the institution outside the Court.

Our management 46 Court strategy for 2013-2017: progress achieved in 2014 was the second year in which the Court implemented its strategy for the period 2013-2017.
The aim is to maximise the value of the Court's contribution to the EU's public accountability.
In order to achieve this objective, the Court shall, in the first place, prioritise the following priorities: ο to focus the Court's products on improving the accountability of the EU; ο to cooperate with other actors to strengthen the Court's contribution to the accountability of the EU; ο to develop the Court as a professional audit body; ο to make the best use of the Court's knowledge and expertise and expertise; ο to demonstrate the Court's performance and accountability.
In 2014, the strategy initiated a major overhaul of the Court's organisational structure.
Two internal working groups dealing with the strategy ("Strengthening the audit process", and "Improving the definition of tasks and responsibilities") presented their results.
This coincided with the European Parliament's report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors and the results of the peer review procedure to which the Court has subjected itself.
The various recommendations were summarised in a far-reaching reform project, whose implementation started at the end of 2014 and will last until mid-2016.
In the case of special reports, this means that they are to be produced in a shorter time, and in the case of the annual report, greater focus and resource savings are sought.
Two things are to be done to transform the farm into a task-based organisation.
This will make it better able to make targeted use of resources for those audits and analyses that provide the greatest added value for EU citizens.
Our Management 47 Measuring the Court's performance Since 2008, the Court has been applying central performance indicators (ZLI) to inform management of progress towards its objectives, support the decision-making process and provide information to its addressees on performance.
The CSOs reflect the Court's priorities and reflect its performance and accountability as a professional audit body.
The indicators are used to measure core parameters for the quality and impact of the Court's work, taking into account the points of view of key addressees and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources.
The ZLI have been updated for the period covered by the 2013-2017 strategy.
Appraisal by addressees Applicability of reports Probable impact of reports Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments by the addressees and by experts.Another assessment criterion is the actions taken on the basis of its recommendations to improve EU financial management.
In addition, the court measures its media presence.
Assessment by addressees The Court has asked its main addressees – the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Council's Committee on Budgets, the main audited bodies of the Commission and the EU agencies and the Presidents of the EU Committee on Budgetary Control – to assess the relevance and impact of its reports published in 2014 on the basis of a five-tier scale of "very high" to "very low".

Our management 48 expert reviews Each year, independent external experts review the content and presentation of a sample of Court reports to assess the quality. In 2014 the reviewers assessed eight special reports and the 2013 annual reports.
They assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from "substantially impaired" (1) to "high-quality" (4).

Some recommendations can be implemented quickly, while others require more time due to their complexity.

Our Management 49 Media Presence The indicator relating to the Court's media presence reflects the Court's effect in the media.
It concerns the strategic objective of raising awareness of the Court, its products, its audit findings and conclusions.
In 2014, the Court identified more than 5 100 online policies based on its special reports, the annual reports 2013 and the institution in general.
40 % of these covered audit reports, while in the other articles reference was made to the institution and its work in general.
Over 800 articles have been published on the Special Report on the EAFRD Airports Implementation of the work programme The Court plans its audits and other tasks on the basis of the annual work programme and monitors progress during the year.
In 2014, the Court carried out 95% of the tasks of its work programme (90 % in 2013).
While the work on the annual reports and on specific annual reports was carried out on schedule, this was the case for the special reports for 85% (2013: 70%).
The economic audits that were not completed in 2014 were carried over to 2015.

Our management 50 Preparation of special reports In order for special reports of the Court to have an effect, they must be submitted promptly.
In recent years, the Court has managed to shorten the time required for the examinations.
The aim of the 2013-2017 strategy is to achieve further improvements and this strategy is expected to produce measurable results in the coming years.
Processing of the 2014 Special Reports In 2014, the Court prepared 24 Special Reports, of which 42 % (2013: 37 %) were completed within the 18-month timeframe of the Court's objective.
On average, 19 months were needed for the preparation of the special reports adopted in 2014 (2013: 20 months).

Supporting audit activities Staff resources Personnel allocation As a result of the difficult situation of public finances in Europe, the Court continued the reduction of staff per year of 1% over a period of five years (2013-2017), as laid down in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013.
As a result, staffing in 2014 was reduced from 891 to 882 temporary staff (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the posts, 561 are allocated to the audit posts (including 113 staff in the members' cabinets).
With a view to achieving the best possible use of resources, in 2014, opportunities to increase efficiency were once again identified and implemented in all activities by the establishment of procedures.
The relocation of staff from the support services to the audit services was also continued in 2014.
However, this was compensated by the transfer of certain support services from members' cabinets to an administrative pool and the transfer of the communication and institutional relations unit to the President's services.
51 Attitude The staff of the Court have a broad academic and professional background and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff consists of both civil servants and temporary staff.
In 2014, an internal selection procedure for grade AST 1 and a selection procedure with a view to recruiting a speaker were carried out.
The Court also provided placements for 77 university graduates for periods of three to five months in the course of the year.
The Court recruited 78 staff in 2014, 31 officials, 29 temporary staff, 13 contract staff and five seconded national experts.
The number of vacancies has been close to 3% since 2011 (on 31 December 2014 there were 27 vacancies).
