The Court's Conference on Energy Security in the EU On 5 May 2015, we held a conference on energy security in the EU in Brussels to provide stakeholders from EU institutions, Member States, the energy industry and universities with a neutral and independent platform on which to discuss the challenges facing the EU in the field of energy security.
Our President Vítor Caldeira opened the conference, and Maroš Šefčovič, one of the Commission's Vice Presidents, gave an introductory lecture.
Our members Szabolcs Fazakas and Phil Wynn Owen From left to right: Szabolcs Fazakas, Maroš Šefčovič, Vítor Caldeira and Phil Wynn Owen. headed the conference, which included panel discussions on the two main areas: obstacles to the completion of the internal energy market and Ukraine's important contribution to European energy supply as an important transit country.
We organised this conference because the EU is facing a number of major challenges in this area, which are related to each other.
These include the creation of an internal energy market to improve the competitiveness of the European economy, the fight against climate change and the increase of energy security.
In our tests, we are increasingly focusing on energy and climate issues.
We have already produced special reports on issues such as the internal energy market and the security of energy supply, energy efficiency and renewable energy.
In addition, further reports, including EU support to Ukraine and EU spending on climate action, and a landscape analysis on energy and climate issues in the EU are planned in this area.
Our aim is to add value to the EU's energy policy, and with this conference we have shown that we also want to support a democratic debate on these issues.
Our activities 36 Conference of the Court on the Future of Development Assistance From 20 to 21 October 2015, on the occasion of the European Year of Development, the adoption of the new United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council, we organised an international conference on European Development Assistance after 2015.
In the beginning of the two-day conference chaired by our member Danièle Lamarque, our President Vítor Caldeira took the floor, followed by the Luxembourg Minister of Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Affairs Romain Schneider, on behalf of the EU Presidency, and by the President of the Development Committee of the European Parliament Linda McAvan, the EU Commissioner for Development Neven Mimica and the United Nations Under-Secretary-General Grete Faremo.
The conclusions of the conference were summarised by Marc Angel, the Chairman of the Committee on Foreign and European Affairs and the Defence of the Luxembourg Chamber of Deputies.
The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and cooperates with many public and private partners, including international organisations, foundations, non-governmental organisations and states.
It is becoming increasingly important to ensure the effectiveness of the aid, which can be achieved by strictly respecting the criteria for its allocation and evaluation.
In this context, the Court plays a major role.
The new Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations for the period 2015-2030 are more ambitious than the previous Millennium Development Goals, and are "incentived to think and act differently."
The participants agreed that development aid must be aligned with environmental, energy and migration policies and other policies and that new stakeholders must be involved.
In addition, development agencies need to adapt to the increasing diversification of funding and financial instruments: innovative funding instruments contribute to a greater leverage effect and a greater convergence with market conditions, but also make it more difficult to make financial decisions and to determine the added value of aid.
The European Commission gave a presentation on what a results-oriented budget should look like, on which a clearer definition of how EU funds are spent and on what results are achieved.
The Court also participates in the joint interinstitutional working group set up for this purpose.

Our Management 41 The College of the Court The College of the Court is composed of one member from each Member State.
Members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a term of six years, in accordance with the proposals of each Member State.
Under the Treaty, the members shall carry out their duties in full independence and for the general good of the European Union.
The President shall be elected by the members of the Committee from among the members for a period of three years.
The terms of office of the President and the members shall be renewable.
Most of the members are assigned to one of the five chambers; the chambers accept examination reports, opinions and position papers, and take decisions on strategic and administrative issues, to the extent to which they extend the scope of their decisions.
In addition, each member is primarily responsible for his or her own duties in the audit area.
The member shall coordinate the respective audit teams with the support of his/her cabinet.
It then presents the reports, opinions or position papers for adoption by the Chamber and/or by the entire College of Court and then by Parliament, the Council and other relevant addressees, including the media.
In selected cases and at the initiative of the members, a report may also be presented to the authorities of the Member States concerned.
One of the members – Ville Itälä – is responsible for institutional relations.
In 2015, the Council of the European Union, acting on a proposal from the Member State and after consulting the European Parliament, appointed Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) a Member of the Court.
The mandate shall apply from 1 September 2015 to 28 February 2018, i.e. for the remainder of the term of office of the previous Danish member Henrik Otbo, who died suddenly in February 2015.

Our management 45 Flexible response in a rapidly changing environment We have developed a new work planning process that allows us to plan our work on the basis of existing priorities for the entire Court and a comprehensive risk assessment.
In planning our work, we now systematically take into account the views of the addressees in order to ensure the greatest possible relevance of our reports.
With the support of our institutional member, our President and Members will work with EU addressees, including the committees of the European Parliament.
Flexible provision of resources for key audit tasks We have organised our staff in flexible teams around specific tasks instead of in units in order to be able to assign tasks more easily to priority tasks.
This means that we can now use the right person for the right job and use that person's skills and potential to the full.
The reform also led to a tighter administration of the Court: Head of Unit became senior managers, who, under the leadership of the director, shared management tasks and shared their expertise in the areas of quality and supervision.
We also strengthen our expertise in audit areas and introduce knowledge transfer tools to further improve our knowledge management processes.
Timely delivery of products We have streamlined our testing procedures and simplified our task management so that we can deliver products promptly.
In recent years, we have constantly reduced the average time needed to prepare our special reports, and the reform will allow for a further reduction.
This is particularly important in the context of the entry into force of the new Financial Regulation.
Better communication about our role and work We have revised our annual report to refer to the headings of the multiannual financial framework and thus make it easier to use and read it more easily.
In the annual report, we are now reporting on the main areas of expenditure and the performance for several years.
Furthermore, we strengthened the functions in the areas of communication and relations with the addressees and discontinued a speaker.
Our Management 46 Measurement of Performance Since 2008, we have been using Central Performance Indicators (ZLI) to inform management of the progress made with regard to our objectives, to support the decision-making process and to provide information about the performance to our users.
They reflect our priorities and reflect our performance and accountability as a professional audit body.
The indicators are used to measure core parameters for the quality and impact of our work, with particular regard to the position of important recipients, as well as the efficiency and effectiveness of our resource use.
The ZLIs have been updated for the period covered by the 2013-2017 strategy.
Quality and impact of our work We evaluate the quality and impact of our reports on the basis of assessments by the addressees and by experts.
In addition, we measure our presence in the media.
We asked our main addressees – the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Council's Committee on Budgets, the main audited bodies of the Commission and the EU agencies, and the Presidents of the EU's ORCB – to assess the relevance and impact of our reports published in 2015 on the basis of a five-stage scale of "very low to "very high".
The replies show that 90% of our main recipients rate the value of our reports as relevant to their work (compared to 94% in 2014). 92% believe that our work has an impact (91% in 2014).
Evaluation by addressees 10% 21% 45% 24% 2% 0% very low 20% medium high 40% very high relevance of reportsProbable effect of reports 60% 80% 100% 6% 23% 45% 24%
Our management 47 expert reviews Every year, independent external experts review the content and presentation of a sample of our reports for quality assessment. In 2015, the reviewers assessed four special reports and the annual reports for the financial year 2014.
They assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on the basis of a four-stage scale from "significantly impaired " (1) to "high-quality " (4).
The experts' assessments in 2015 were higher than ever in the last four years, with a total average of 3.3 for both reporting types.
Follow-up to recommendations We primarily contribute to improving the financial management of the EU by submitting recommendations to the Commission and other audited bodies in our reports.
Some recommendations can be implemented quickly, while others require more time due to their complexity.
We regularly check to what extent our recommendations have been implemented by the audited bodies.
By the end of 2015, 73% of the more than 600 recommendations we had made in 2012-2015 had been implemented.
This represents an increase in the implementation rate of 69% for the recommendations issued in 2011-2014 compared to the rate of implementation recorded in 2014.

It concerns the strategic objective of raising awareness of the Court, its products, its audit findings and conclusions.
In 2015, we identified some 3,400 online articles related to our special reports, annual reports and the Court in general.
54% of these covered our audit reports; in the other articles reference was made to the Court and its work in general.
In 2015, the media reported almost twice as much about our annual reports as in 2014.
However, the number of media reports on our special reports has decreased compared to 2014, largely due to the interest in a specific report from this year (EU-funded airport infrastructure (No. 21/2014, on which more than 800 articles were published).
Efficiency and effectiveness of resource use We assess the efficiency and effectiveness of our resource use according to our ability to implement our work programme, carry out audits in a timely manner and ensure the expertise of our employees.
Implementation of the Work Programme We plan our audit and other tasks on the basis of the annual Work Programme and monitor progress during the year.
In 2015, we implemented our work programme to 88%.
While work on the annual reports and special annual reports was carried out on schedule, this was 69% in the case of special reports, compared to our very ambitious planning.
The completion of the remaining special reports, which has been delayed due to remaining audit evidence or unexpected complexity, was transferred to the beginning of 2016.
These special reports mainly concern new or innovative tests, the completion of which, of course, can take more time.
The Court's reform project, which is assessed under the heading "other tasks', progressed as planned.

Our management 49 Preparation of the special reports In order for our special reports to have effect, they must be submitted promptly.
In recent years, we have been able to shorten the time needed for audits, largely based on initiatives resulting from the 2013-2017 strategy.
In 2015, we prepared our 25 special reports over an average of 17 months (19 months in 2014), i.e. for the first time in less than 18 months.
We will continue to work to shorten the time needed to prepare our special reports, which will, in particular, respond to the new principle introduced in the amended Financial Regulation.
Professional Training In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we strive to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training (excluding language courses).
The objective for the professional training of examiners was again exceeded, as it is evident that we attach great importance to the development of personnel.
When taking into account the language courses, an examiner accounted for an average of 9.4 training days in 2015.

Support for 50 audit activities Personnel resources Personnel allocation In 2015, we continued the staff reduction of 1% per year for a period of five years (2013-2017), as laid down in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013.
As a result, in 2015 the staffing was reduced from 882 temporary staff to 872 (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and interns).
The inspectors involved 562 staff, including 113 staff in the members' cabinets.
Recruitment The Court's employees have a broad academic and professional background and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
Our recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions, and the staff is made up of both officials and temporary staff.
In 2015, we hired 63 staff: 30 officials, 17 temporary staff, 11 contract staff, four seconded national experts and one consultant.
We also provided internships for 74 university graduates for periods of three to five months.
On 31 December 2015, the Court had only 15 vacant posts (1.7% of the total number of posts).

Supporting audit activities 51 Balance between men and women Like the other EU institutions, we have a policy of equal opportunities in terms of human resources management and recruitment.
For several years we have been able to maintain a balanced proportion of men and women among our employees.

Our action plan on equal opportunities aims to achieve a balanced proportion of men and women at all levels.
According to the latest recruitment waves, 50% of the employees in grades AD 5 to AD 8 are women (an increase compared to 48% in 2014).
Renewal in the upper and middle levels of management and the growing proportion of women in the AD function group are expected to increase in the future.

Support services Professional further training The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training in order to keep pace with professional developments and to acquire new skills.
In 2015, our employees completed an average of 7.3 days of professional training.
The proportion of language courses in the total number of training days continues to decline.
Language courses accounted for 35% of the total number of training days in 2015 (compared to 43% in 2014).
Our main activities in the field of vocational training concern the modernisation of our training programmes and closer cooperation with learning opportunities in and outside the EU institutions and bodies.
We started a cooperation with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France) in order to offer a postgraduate course of study "Audit of public organizations and policies" and a master course "Management of public organisations".
Cooperation continued with the European Commission, which offers language courses for our staff, and with the European Administrative Academy, which has supported us in organising the training on "soft skills" and the ECA training day.
In addition, we have expanded our range of courses even further through individually tailored e-learning courses and training courses in the form of integrated learning (blended learning).
In addition, we continued our successful series of presentations held by internal and external experts on audit developments and other subjects related to the work of our auditors.
Finally, we introduced a framework for Performance Recognition Awards, which aims to award special training outside the Court for the performance of non-executive staff.
Support for audit activities 54 Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables us to fulfil our mission and fulfil our communication goals.
In 2015, the total volume of translation was as high as never before: almost 200,000 pages, an increase of almost 3% compared to 2014.
Around 99% of the translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, our translators also provided language support and interpretation services to internal events and meetings during 26 inspection visits throughout the EU.
They also supported the drafting of preliminary observations and special reports, thereby increasing their involvement in the Court's central audit procedures.
Following the review of the translation workflow and the reform of the Court of Auditors, the Translation Directorate improved its structures in 2015 through the introduction of assistant pools.
A major project of the Directorate, GroupShare, will lead to significant improvements by further streamlining the work of the assistant pools to create space for efficiency improvements and automation, and to standardise the procedures of all language teams.
Information technology In 2015, the Information Technologies Directorate focused its efforts on adapting our administrative information systems to support the successful implementation of the Court's reform and the preparation of developments in the field of knowledge management in support of the Court's new organisational structure.
In addition, all functions of the full version of the Assyst2 audit documentation system have been introduced for work on the Statement of Assurance, Economic Audits and related reports, which concludes this major project.
Our new audit management system (AMS) has been put into operation: more than 300 plans have been drawn up in the system and 180 audit tasks have been defined and monitored with the instrument.
Building on the technical basis for mobility introduced in the last few years (delivery of the WLAN network in all the premises of the yard, equipment of all staff with laptops), the Directorate is currently focusing on global mobility, i.e. access to all content at any place, at any time and on all devices.
The project with regard to the development of a solution that ensures that employees can access our information on all devices will contribute to maintaining the business of the farm and to increasing efficiency and effectiveness.
The maintenance of business operations during the development and deployment of IT solutions was ensured, resulting in 99.82% availability of critical systems.
Supporting audit activities 55 Administration and infrastructure The role of the Finance and Support Services Directorate is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its strategic objectives.
The Directorate shall also ensure that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all the Court's activities.
In 2015, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economic.
Because of the extraordinary situation following the terrorist attacks in Paris in November and the subsequent crisis situation in Belgium, we intensified our security measures and acquired the necessary security equipment in the context of public procurement procedures.
Information on public procurement is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Buildings The yard currently owns three buildings ("K1, "K2 ("K3") and offers small areas for its IT center for the recovery of data and a meeting room.
He also provides three offices in Brussels and one office in Strasbourg from the European Parliament.
In order to ensure the cost-effectiveness of our building policy, we take into account three factors: purchase or rental, follow-up costs and interinstitutional cooperation.
In developing and implementing our building policy, as in all our areas of activity, we strive to establish and meet the highest standards of transparency and accountability.
Community Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) The Community Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) is a management tool developed by the European Commission for companies and other organisations to assess, report and improve their environmental performance.
We started in 2014 with the development of an environmental development system2, which is in line with the principles of the European EMAS standard provided for in the 2009 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council3.
Our goal is an EMAS certification by the end of 2016.
In 2015, the EMAS project made the planned progress.
2 The EMAS project at the Court was launched in July 2013.
Regulation (EC) No 1221/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the voluntary participation of organisations in a Community environmental management and audit scheme (EMAS).

Our budget accounts for around 0.087 % of total EU expenditure and 1.51% of total administrative expenditure.

Supporting audit activities 58 Auditing and accountability discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2015, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the 2013 financial year, which means that our financial statements for 2013 were finally approved.
We have carefully analysed the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility and have also taken appropriate measures within the framework of our reform.
We have reported on our follow-up to the European Parliament.
Internal and external audit Internal audit of the Court The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk control matters by giving opinions on the quality of management and internal control systems and recommendations to improve the management of our operations and to promote sound financial management.
The department also supports the work of the external auditor, whose mission is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
Finally, the Internal Audit Service provides information on significant risks and corporate governance issues.
The Internal Audit Service is supervised by an Internal Audit Committee composed of three members of the Court and an external expert.
The Committee regularly monitors the progress made in the various tasks defined in the Internal Revision Work Programme of the Internal Revision Service.
The Committee also ensures the independence of the Internal Audit Service.
In 2015, the Internal Revision department prepared special reports on strategic issues such as changes in our annual report, mid-term review of the implementation of our 2013-2017 strategy and follow-up of the implementation of the peer review and European Parliament recommendations.
Taking into account the recommendations of the 2014 Internal Revision Service that the internal control cycle should be strengthened, we updated our IT security system and formalised the existing risk management framework and existing guidelines.
The Internal Audit Service monitored the implementation of the new guidelines and ensured that their recommendations were taken into account.
We report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
External audit of the Court Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the bodies it is examining.
The auditor's report – PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à r.l. – on our financial statements for the financial year 2014 was published on 15 September 2015.
Supporting audit activities 59 audit opinions of the independent auditor – Financial year 2014 As regards the annual accounts: "We believe that the annual accounts give a true picture of the European Court of Auditors' financial and financial position as at 31 December 2014 and its earnings and cash flows for the year ending on that reference date in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules for the application of the Financial Regulation.

This security shall be based on the assessment of the undersigned and on the information at his disposal, such as the reports and statements of the authorising officers, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's audit reports on previous financial years.

European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the external auditor of the EU and one of the seven institutions of the Union.
The College of the Court consists of 28 members, one from each EU Member State.
The Court employs some 900 staff from all EU nationalities, made up of auditors and administrative staff.
It was built in 1977 and is based in Luxembourg.
The Court's tasks The Court checks that the EU provides proper accounting, ensures the correct compliance with its financial rules and that EU policies and programmes make optimal use of resources.
Through its audit work, the Court contributes to improving the financial management of the EU and to promoting accountability and transparency.
It warns against risks, provides audit security, indicates weaknesses and successes, and provides guidance to EU policy-makers and legislators.
The Court submits its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, the national parliaments and the general public.
The buildings of the European Court of Auditors at the Kirchberg Plateau in Luxembourg, 2017

Preface of the President 04 Dear reader, dear reader!
In 1977, the European Court of Auditors started its work – 40 years later, we look back on many of the successful contributions we have made to public accountability and to EU financial management.
In October 2017, on the occasion of the occasion of the Court's jubilee, an official ceremony attended by your Royal Highnesses of the Grand Duke and the Grand Duchess of Luxembourg, the President of the Republic of Estonia Kersti Kaljulaid, the President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani and the President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker.
Their participation in the event is a sign of the great importance of the Court as a ‘financial of the European Union'.
In the course of the year, however, we also looked forward to the future.
We discussed and agreed on a strategy for the remaining three years of the current Multiannual Financial Framework by the end of 2020.
Our citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that they do not lose their confidence in the EU and its institutions.
People must be able to see that the EU is dealing with integrity, the rule of law is respected, the use of public resources is prudent, that it has clear political objectives and that it has achieved the results it has promised.
As an external auditor of the Union, we are well positioned to examine these aspects and report on them accordingly.
Throughout the year, we have published special reports on a wide range of EU policies and programmes, as well as analysis-based publications such as landscape analyses and rapid analyses.
In addition, we have drafted several opinions on legislative proposals and, as we have done every year, we have produced our annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds and on the EU agencies and on many other institutions of the Union.
This activity report provides a comprehensive overview of our activities in 2017 and contains important information about the Court, its budget and its staff.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President
2017 at a glance 05 Our activities Our management • 28 special reports analysing the effectiveness and • the added value of EU policies and programmes in areas such as youth unemployment, environment, migration and banking union; • a landscape analysis of EU activities in the areas of energy and climate change and a rapid analysis of the reduction of staff in the EU institutions; • • five opinions on new or amended EU legislation with a significant impact on financial management, including an opinion on the Financial Regulation for the • EU budget and an opinion on the financing of European political parties; • annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget as well as on the activities under the European Development Funds, together with the accompanying summary report "2016 – brief information on the EU audit; • 55 special reports on the annual accounts of the EU agencies, institutions and joint undertakings, which are based in different Member States, including two summary reports; • meetings, seminars and conferences with our institutional addressees and colleagues, such as the meetings of the meetings of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the European Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions, and conferences on youth unemployment and energy assessment, climate change.
We welcomed two new members: Juhan Parts (Estonia) on 1 January 2017 and Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary) on 1 September 2017. • We issued a new multi-annual strategy that will guide our work and management in the period 2018-2020. We also reviewed our work planning to ensure a more strategic, more coherent approach to the planning of our audit priorities, and reviewed our risk management policy and strengthened our financial procedures. • We continued the reduction of posts agreed among the EU institutions and, at the same time, implemented the policy of equal opportunities in recruitment and human resources management.
Our activities 06 Audits We perform various types of audits in the various budgetary areas of the EU: • Audits – the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of EU policies and programmes.
The focus of these audits of optimal use of funds is on specific management or budget issues, which we select on the basis of criteria such as public interest, potential for improvement, risk of insufficient performance or irregularities; • Audits on accounting and compliance audits – the reliability of the annual accounts, the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions (especially in the context of the Statement of Assurance) as well as assessments of whether the systems or operations in specific budgetary areas are in compliance with the relevant rules and regulations.
On the basis of the evidence obtained from our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which the EU's policy objectives have been achieved, as well as on the state of the Union's budgetary and financial management.
This information helps us to make useful and relevant recommendations from the point of view of cost efficiency.
Test visits in 2017 The majority of the examination work takes place in the premises of the Court in Luxembourg.
At the same time, our auditors also carried out numerous audit visits to the other EU institutions, agencies and agencies, EU delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, and to international organisations such as the United Nations, which are involved in the award of EU funds in the course of 2017.
We also carry out checks on recipients of EU funds on the ground within and outside the European Union.
These checks provide us with direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of EU policies and programmes and the collection and disbursement of EU funds, as well as from the beneficiaries concerned.
Tests are our core activity Frequency and intensity of our audit work in each Member State and recipient country depend on the type of audit we carry out.
In 2017, our auditors spent 3,670 days with on-site inspections in Member States and outside the EU (2016: 4,246 days).
Within the EU, our on-the-spot checks are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions (ORKBs) of the Member States visited.
3 670 days on-the-spot audits in the Member States and outside the EU in 2017 In addition, our auditors spent 2 300 days (2016: 2 510 days) with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralised agencies and bodies throughout the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations and the OECD, as well as audit firms.
In order to obtain and validate test certificates, we are increasingly making use of video conferencing and other information technologies (such as the secure exchange of data and documents).

Our activities 08 Detecting fraud In the fight against fraud against the EU budget, we work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
These cases will then be followed up by OLAF, which will decide on possible investigations and, if appropriate, cooperate with Member States' authorities.
In 2017, we forwarded 13 suspected fraud cases identified during our audits to OLAF Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, our audit work occasionally encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities.
In 2017, we forwarded 13 such cases (2016: 11 cases) in which there was a suspicion of fraud to OLAF. Suspects of fraud arose as part of our audit activities for the Statement of Assurance for the financial years 2016 and 2017 as well as for other audit tasks.
Publications Our publications: Special reports, annual reports, opinions and analysis-based publications Our audit reports and opinions form an important link in the EU's accountability chain, as they are used to hold the EU's audit bodies accountable, in particular in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
In areas of shared management, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role, as in expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures. Approximately 80% of the EU budget is implemented in this way.
Our range of publications includes • special reports presenting the results of selected audits of specific policy or expenditure areas or on budgetary or management issues; • annual reports containing mainly the results of audits of the accounts and compliance audits on the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Funds, but also on aspects of budgetary management and performance aspects; • specific annual reports on the EU agencies, decentralised bodies and Joint Undertakings, published separately; • opinions on new or amended legal acts with significant effects on financial management, either at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative;
Our activities 09 • Analysis-based publications: • Landscape analyses are descriptive and analytical documents on complex, broad policy areas or management issues, in which, in many cases from a cross-cutting perspective, we present our experience and our accumulated knowledge on the selected topic; • Topic papers are similar to Landscape analyses, since they are also descriptive and analytical documents on policy or management, but their topics are more limited; • Rapid case reviews present facts which are related to very clearly defined specific topics or problems.
All publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
In addition, all 2017 special reports, opinions and analysis-based publications are listed at the end of this report.

Our activities 10 Annual reports Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016 In our Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016, we examined how the EU funds had been used for the financial year under consideration and showed the areas in which the risk of EU funds not being used properly was greatest.
In addition, we have specifically assessed all important areas of the EU budget, on the basis of the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020, and have provided information on budget and financial management and performance-related information.
Furthermore, we analysed why errors had occurred and made recommendations on possible improvements.
Audit of around 1,000 payments made from the EU budget to beneficiaries in 2016 Our auditors investigated around 1,000 payments to beneficiaries made in the various expenditure areas of the EU budget.
This means that we analysed around 1 000 different cases where EU funds were used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.
The discharge procedure begins with the presentation of our annual report on the financial year 2016 The publication of our annual report begins with the discharge procedure on the implementation of the EU budget carried out by the European Parliament.
On 28 September, we presented our annual report to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) and, subsequently, to the plenary session of the European Parliament and the Ecofin Council and the national parliaments of the Member States.
Our activities 11 EU annual accounts give a true picture; share of irregular expenditures fell further in 2016 Main conclusions s The 2016 annual accounts were drawn up in accordance with international principles and give a true picture of EU finances in all material respects.  in 2016 the revenue in 2016 was not a material error.  and over the past few years the estimated error rate in payments from the EU budget has improved continuously: in 2016: 3.1%, in 2015: 3.8% and in 2014: 4.4%.
In 2016, a significant proportion of audited expenditure – claims-based payments (as opposed to reimbursement-based payments) – was not substantially affected by errors.  - In most areas, the Commission's reporting on regularity is largely in line with our results.
However, the Commission should simplify performance measurement, for example by reducing the number of targets and indicators.
Without these measures, the overall error rate we estimated would have been 1.2 percentage points higher.
However, sufficient information was available to prevent and detect and correct a significant proportion of the errors.  was available, the total amount of payments to which the EU committed itself under future budgets was as high as never before and is expected to continue to rise.

Our activities 14 Annual Report on the European Development Funds The European Development Fund (EDF) provides financial assistance to the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and the overseas countries and territories.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and, in some cases, by the European Investment Bank (EIB).
Around one third of the total EDF error rate is due to the failure to comply with procurement rules.
Other important types of error concern, inter alia, expenditure which is either not actually incurred or not eligible.
Our annual report on the EDFs is published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca. europa.eu).
Special Annual Reports EU agencies and other bodies and European Joint Undertakings are based in different EU Member States, carrying out specific tasks in areas of greatest importance to EU citizens, such as health, security, freedom and justice, and research.
In 2017, the Court examined whether the agencies' annual accounts were reliable and whether the underlying transactions were in line with the rules.
In the formation of our audit opinions on the annual accounts of the agencies, we, if available, took into account the audit work carried out by audit firms.
We also examined Sisnet's communications infrastructure, the European Schools, the contingent liabilities of the Single Resolution Committee and the liquidation of the Galileo Joint Undertaking.
We have worked on consolidating the results and are expected to issue a single report for the agencies in 2018. i Key data EDF budget 2016 3.4 billion euros Audited amount 2.8 billion euros Audited amount 2.8 billion euros Audited amount Reliable revenue Non-permissive payments Substantial error rate (estimated error rate 3.3%) i Key data Audited by the Court 45 agencies and other EU agencies, 8 joint enterprises Total 2016 budget 5.2 billion euros Total 2016 staff Some 11,000 staff The Court publishes 55 special annual reports, including two summary reports
Our activities 15 agencies (budget of 3.4 billion euros, 10 364 employees) Our audit showed that the annual accounts of all 41 agencies give a true picture of the situation.
The financial operations underlying the annual accounts were legal and proper for all agencies, except for the European Asylum Support Office, for which we gave a limited opinion, due to the non-compliance with the public procurement principles.
Joint Undertakings (budget of 1.8 billion euros, 633 employees) The annual accounts of all eight Joint Undertakings were reliable.
They appropriately presented the assets and financial position of the Joint Undertakings and the results of their transactions and cash flows for the year 2016 in all material respects.
Furthermore, the transactions underlying the annual accounts for seven Joint Undertakings were in line with the relevant legislation, except the ECSEL Joint Undertaking, for which we gave a restricted audit opinion, as we were unable to secure a sufficient level of certainty as to the reliability of its internal controls for FP7 grants.
All special annual reports and the two summary reports are available on our website (eca. europa.eu).
Special Reports In 2017, we published 28 special reports.
In these reports, we examined in particular whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved in an effective and economic way, and whether the EU funds have created added value.
We also made recommendations for improvements in terms of financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste or achieving the desired policy objectives more cost-effectively.
Special reports focus on the effectiveness, effectiveness and economy of EU policies and programmes Our special reports focus on issues relevant to the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, the creation of growth and the promotion of inclusion, the challenges associated with migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, as well as ensuring the accountability and economic viability of the European Union.
Here we will look at two of these 28 special reports: a special report on food waste, on whether EU policies were appropriate to tackle this problem throughout the food supply chain, and a special report on the Greek financial crisis, on how the EU responded to the financial and debt crisis in one of its Member States through its economic adjustment programmes.

Our activities 17 Special Report: Combating food waste: an opportunity for the EU to improve the resource efficiency of the food supply chain Food waste is a global problem Food waste is a global issue, which has become the focus of public and political debate in recent years, especially in view of the need to feed the growing global population.
Current estimates indicate that around one third of food produced for human consumption is wasted or is lost around the world, resulting in high economic and environmental costs.
The EU auditors examined the role the EU can play in the fight against food waste The Court's auditors examined in particular the measures taken so far and the way in which the EU's various policy instruments have worked in order to reduce food waste.
The focus was on avoiding food waste and facilitating food donation, as these two aspects were given the highest priority in the fight against food waste.
Our auditors interviewed the Commission staff responsible for the policy in question, carried out file checks and carried out audit visits in five Member States: Italy (Lazio), the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania and Finland.
They visited the relevant ministries and made on-site visits.
They also consulted relevant stakeholders in the areas of food production, retail trade, research and charities. "The EU can and should do more to combat the food waste effectively," said EU auditors, the auditors concluded that while food waste could and should be combated through a number of EU policies, this potential is not exploited.
The present approach is still fragmented and inconsistent, and coordination at Commission level is deficient.
Our report identified a number of untapped opportunities and potential improvements that would not require new legislation or additional public resources, and recommended that auditors better adapt existing policies and set a clear policy objective of reducing food waste.
The report was submitted to the Committee of the European Parliament on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, as well as to the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU, and a number of national parliaments across the EU.
Both the European Parliament and the Council welcomed the report and agreed with the conclusions contained therein.
The report has also received a strong response from the media, especially the social media.
Our Activities 18 Special Report: The Commission's role in the Greek financial crisis Greece needed support to ensure its financial stability The 2008 financial crisis followed an economic downturn and a debt crisis in Europe, which exposed the weaknesses of the Greek economy.
In April 2010, Greece was no longer able to finance itself on the financial markets on a sustainable basis, and was therefore seeking financial assistance from the euro area Member States and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
Since then, Greece has participated in three economic adjustment programmes, managed by the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the IMF, the so-called "troika".--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The third programme also involved the European Stability Mechanism (ESM).
The total amount of support of EUR 368.6 billion was conditional on political conditionality, which was jointly established by the Greek authorities and the lenders.
These programmes aimed at stabilising the economic situation in Greece by meeting the financial needs of the Greek economy by preventing the crisis from spilling over to the rest of the euro area.
In return, Greece committed itself to carrying out far-reaching structural reforms.
The EU auditors examined whether the Commission had adequately managed the economic adjustment programmes This review is in line with the Court's economic audits in recent years with regard to the actions and reforms to be undertaken in response to the 2008 financial crisis.
Our auditors assessed how the Commission handled the first two programmes for Greece and how the third programme had been designed.
They reviewed the documents on EU financial assistance programmes, analysed programme conditions and interviewed Commission staff, national authorities (such as specialized ministries), the Bank of Greece, business associations and stakeholders as well as IMF, ESM and OECD staff. "Economic adjustment programmes for Greece: despite shortcomings, progress in the reform process, " EU auditors concluded that economic adjustment programmes for Greece had offered financial stability in the short term and had made progress in the reform process.
However, in Greece, the programmes produced only a limited recovery.
In addition, the auditors found that the Commission had no experience of managing such a process, that the conditions of the programmes were not sufficiently prioritized according to the meaning or that they were embedded in a broader strategy for Greece, and that the macroeconomic assumptions of the programmes were on clay.
This special report was submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and to institutional stakeholders in Greece.
The report was the subject of comprehensive media coverage and was the largest media response of all the special reports we published in 2017.

Our Management 26 The College of Members of the Court The term of office of the Members of the Court is six years; the term of office of the Members of the Court is renewable.
Members shall perform their duties in full independence for the general good of the EU.
When they take office, they take an appropriate oath before the Court of Justice of the European Union.
The College has 28 members, one from each Member State.
Each Member shall be appointed by the Council of the EU after consulting the European Parliament in accordance with the proposals of the respective national government.
In 2017, the Council appointed two new members: • Juhan Parts (Estonia), who took office on 1 January 2017; • Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary), who took office on 1 September 2017.
President Members elect a President from among their number for a period of three years; re-election is allowed.
The role of the president is that of a primus inter pares ("first among equals").
In addition to its other responsibilities, the President shall supervise the performance of the Court's tasks and shall represent it to the outside world.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany) was elected President.
Examination chambers and committees The members are assigned to one of the Court's five examination chambers.The chambers adopt examination reports, opinions and other analysis-based publications.
The Chambers shall be headed by a Doyen elected from among the members.
Each member is responsible for his or her specific audit tasks.
Members are supported by their cabinet.
As of December 2017, the five examination chambers were headed by the following Doyens: Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom), Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria), Karel Pinxten (Belgium), Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain) and Lazaros S. Lazarou (Cyprus).
Danièle Lamarque (France) chaired the Quality Control Committee in the audit area.
Rimantas Šadžius (Lithuania) was responsible for coordinating the Court's interinstitutional relations.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President.
The members of the Court of Auditors met at 21 College meetings in 2017.

Our management 28 Strategy The next three years will be a crucial period for the European Union in which essential decisions will have to be taken.
We are aware that EU citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that the EU can meet the challenges that arise successfully.
Citizens must be able to see that the EU acts with integrity, preserves the rule of law, uses taxpayers' money prudently, pursues clear objectives and achieves the results it has promised.
We, as external auditors of the EU, can make a contribution to this.
Our Strategy for 2018-2020: Strengthening trust through external financial control In July 2017, we published our strategy for the period 2018-2020, in which we set four strategic goals: • Deliver clear statements for our target group; • Focus more on the performance aspects of EU action; • Improve the added value of the Statement of Assurance; • Focus our overall organisation on our products.
Ultimately, the EU is not about figures, but about people Through the external financial control it has exercised, the Court is able to show what is and what is not, it can support EU citizens in answering the question of whether the EU institutions are delivering them results and thus help to strengthen confidence in the EU.
In this sense, the Court's audits must also address the concerns of European citizens, its most important addressees at last instance.
The 2018-2020 strategy will identify five priority areas for the Court's work in the coming years.
Sustainable management of natural resources and combating climate change Investments for cohesion, growth and integration Challenges related to migration, security and global sustainable development A functioning internal market and a stable monetary union Financing and management of the Union, while respecting accountability and economic efficiency
Our management 29 In the course of the development of our strategy, we placed strong emphasis on internal and external consultation.
We discussed the strategy with our staff and addressed members of the European Parliament, representatives of the EU Member States, the European Commission, other Supreme Audit Institutions and non-institutional stakeholders such as scientists, think tanks, non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and private sector auditors.
The Court's strategy for 2018-2020 is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Work planning In January 2017, we decided to introduce new work planning procedures, which we applied for the first time to our annual work programme for 2018, which was published in October last year.
The main changes with regard to our work planning: • drawing up a list of audit tasks for the whole Court; • centralised procedure for selecting audit ideas, possible audit tasks and final audit proposals; • a more flexible allocation of resources to and allocation of resources between the audit chambers taking into account the workload; • an extension of the product range to include audit tasks resulting from analysis-based publications; • a high-priority audit task for which shorter deadlines apply.
We also agreed with the Conference of the European Parliament's Committee Chairs a procedure in which all Parliament's standing committees can propose to the Court possible subjects of examination.
The Court's 2018 work programme is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Performance Measurement In the period 2013-2017, we used seven key performance indicators (KPIs) to inform management of the progress we have made, to support the decision-making process, and to provide information to our stakeholders about our performance.
The indicators were used to measure core parameters regarding the quality and impact of our work, taking into account the position of key stakeholders and the efficiency and effectiveness of our use of resources.
A revised set of performance indicators, valid for the period 2018-2020, will be introduced in 2018.
Quality and impact of our work We evaluated the quality and impact of our reports on the basis of assessments by addressees and by experts. Another assessment criterion was the follow-up to our recommendations to improve EU financial management.
Our management 30 assessments by the addressees We asked our main institutional addressees and peers – the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Council's Committee on Budgets, the main audited bodies of the Commission and the European Agencies, as well as the presidents of the European Commission – to evaluate our reports.
As in previous years, the vast majority of respondents assessed the relevance and impact of our reports in 2017 with "high" or "very high".
Expert reviews Every year independent external experts review the content and presentation of a sample of our reports to assess their quality.
In 2017, the auditors assessed six special reports* and the annual reports for the financial year 2016.
They assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on the basis of a four-stage scale of "significantly affected" (1) to "high-quality" (4).
Results have changed only slightly in recent years, with the quality of our reports being "satisfactory". * In 2017, the reviewers assessed our special reports No. 3/2017, No. 4/2017, No. 5/2017, No. 10/2017, No. 14/2017 and No. 17/2017.

Overall, the number of media reports on our special reports increased by 11% compared to 2016.
The Court's reports, which received the largest media feedback in 2017, were the special reports on the Greek financial crisis, registration centres for migrants (hotspots), fisheries control, greening and the Natura 2000 network.
Our management 32 140 120 100 80 60 40 20 Special Reports of the Court – average number of online articles per Special Report 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 The increase in media reports of our special reports in 2017 is in line with a trend that has been observed for several years.
While less than 1,500 online articles were published in 2013, this number increased to almost 7,000 in 2017, with the average number of articles written per special report increased from an average of less than 30 in 2013 to almost 130 in 2017.
Our Special Report on the Greek Financial Crisis, focusing on over 2,000 online articles and contributions on social media, the largest media echo, has produced our special report on the Greek financial crisis, the use of resources in our performance measurement, and in particular our ability to carry out audits in a timely manner, to implement our work programme and to ensure the expertise of our employees.
Examination period In 2017, an average of 14.6 months passed from the start of an examination to the adoption of a special report.
This is the shortest processing time since the beginning of the period 2013-2017.
It took us less than 13 months to produce eight reports (29%) published during the year.
It took on average 16 months to publish the reports, about two months less than in 2016.
This positive trend suggests that measures will bear fruit in achieving the 13-month target set in the Financial Regulation.

Our management 33 reports published In 2017, 65% of our special reports were published in accordance with the original plan.
The remaining reports have been postponed and will be published in 2018.
In addition, our annual reports and all special annual reports have been published according to plan.
Professional Training In accordance with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we strive to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training per year.
In 2017, we again exceeded this target with 6.7 training days per examiner.
If the language courses required for the efficient work of our auditors in all EU Member States are also taken into account, an examiner in 2017 accounted for an average of 8.3 training days.
For the other employees, we have set ourselves the goal of providing on average 16 hours (two days) of professional training (without language courses).
In 2017, this target was met with an average of 2.3 training days.

Our staff 34 Human resources allocation In 2017, we completed the five-year staff reduction (2013-2017) of 5%, as stipulated in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013.
At the end of 2017, 853 officials and temporary staff worked at the Court. 548 of them worked in the Chambers of Examination, including 118 employees in the Cabinets of Members.
Recruitment The staff of the Court have a broad academic and professional background.
With our recruitment policy, we follow the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and promote equal opportunities at all levels.
Staff include both officials and temporary staff.
General selection procedures are usually organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
In 2017, the Court hired 72 staff: 29 officials, 13 temporary staff, 24 contract staff (of whom seven left the Court by the end of the year) and six seconded national experts.
In addition, we provided 71 university graduates with internship places for periods of three to five months.

Our employees 35 Age profile The age profile of the active staff on 31 December 2017 shows that almost half of our employees are 44 years old or younger.
31 of the 68 directors and directors of the Court (46%) are 55 years of age or older.
As a result, the next five to ten years, when these employees retire, will result in a renewal in senior management positions.
Balance between men and women The Court pursues a policy of equal opportunities, which relates to all stages of the career of its employees.
Overall, we have achieved a balanced proportion of men and women among our employees; 43% of our auditors and boards of directors are women.
In recent years, we have succeeded in increasing the proportion of women in management positions in our examination chambers from 7% in 2015 to almost 20% in 2017.
We continue to strive to achieve a balance between men and women at all levels of management.
In addition, our equal opportunities policy for the period 2018-2020 addresses issues related to age and disability.

We continued our successful series of presentations held by internal or external experts on audit developments and other subjects related to the work of our auditors.

Translation The Directorate for Translations, Language Services, and Publication of the Court translated and revised more than 211 000 pages.
We continued our efforts to streamline translation and reduce the costs involved.
For example, all our translation teams are now using a collaborative working platform to increase efficiency.
We strive to increasingly involve our translators in our core activities and to create further synergies with our auditors.
In particular, in 2017 the translators increasingly supported the auditors in the linguistic preparation of the special reports and the annual report.
In addition, they provided our examiners with linguistic support at 38 test visits.
Information technology Our IT directorate makes a decisive contribution to our audit processes by optimising information flows using modern and secure technologies.
We made further progress in document management and were able to fully digitise production, acceptance and publication processes.
We introduced a simplified tool to facilitate remote access via mobile devices.
We also carried out a system upgrade (installation of Windows 10 and SharePoint 2013).
In order to make even better use of interinstitutional synergies, we introduced new systems of audit, mission and training, which are currently being used by other EU institutions.

K1 The K1 building, which was opened in 1988, has offices for up to 310 members of staff and meeting rooms.
The basements have parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, the library and the main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical facilities.
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 in order to bring it into line with national health, safety and environmental requirements.
As far as possible, the technology in the K1 building was adapted to achieve compatibility with the K2 and K3 buildings.
As a result, the three buildings form a single integrated technical unit.
K2 The K2 building was opened in 2003.
The basements have parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms and the fitness centre.
The entire top floor is used for technical installations.
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees, with meeting rooms, a conference room with interpreting booths, video conference rooms, a cafeteria and a basic kitchen area.
The Court commissioned a study to assess the feasibility of setting up activity-related areas of work and the modernisation of the K2 technical installations.
The study shows that the design of the work areas could be improved and that some technical facilities need to be modernised.
A detailed study of this project will be carried out in 2018 and work is expected to begin in 2019.
As approved by the Council and the European Parliament in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining funds in the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation.

Support for audit activities 39 K3 The K3 building was opened in 2012.
The basements contain parking spaces, technical facilities, storage facilities, unloading areas, waste storage facilities, printing facilities, kitchens and archives.
The ground floor consists of the canteen, a cafeteria and training rooms.
In addition, there are offices for 503 employees, meeting rooms and an IT room in this building.

Project for safety at work In 2017, the project aimed at strengthening the safety of the court and its employees was continued according to plan.
The new security control center, the external accreditation center and access control center for employees and visitors will be put into operation in 2018.
Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, we consider it our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all activities and we strive to reduce the environmental impact of the Court continuously.
In 2017, we received the certificate for the Eco Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS).
We now successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
Our goal is to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions.
In 2017, we analyzed – for the third consecutive year – the greenhouse gas emissions generated by our activities (i.e. our carbon footprint).
The results of this study are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

In 2017, the Court's budget amounted to around 141 million euros.
This represents less than 0.1% of total EU expenditure and approximately 1.5% of total EU administrative expenditure.
The share of appropriations used in the budget for 2017 was 98%.

Court's accountability 42 Risk management During the year, we reviewed the risk assessments prepared for each Directorate, as required by the Financial Regulation.
The results of these controls shall be included in the annual statement by the authorising officer by delegation in the annual activity report and shall be used in the risk assessments of the following year.
As far as necessary, we prepared action plans for ex ante and ex post controls.
In September 2017, after carrying out these reviews, we strengthened internal controls and financial procedures related to travel expenses and the management of service vehicles.
Internal and external audit Internal audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It shall deliver opinions on the quality of the administrative and internal control systems and shall report to a Committee on Internal Audit, composed of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee regularly monitors the progress made in the various tasks defined in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and ensures the independence of the Service.
In 2017, the department examined the implementation of the Court's 2013-2017 strategy, the operational structure of the President's Services Directorate, and the management of our software licenses and products.
It also examined the implementation of the Court's risk management policy and monitored the implementation of its recommendations to ensure that the action plans take shape.
The Internal Auditor considers that in 2017, the existing governance, risk management and internal control procedures as a whole provide sufficient assurance that the Court's objectives will be met.
We report annually to Parliament and to the Council on the results of the internal audit work.
External audit Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the bodies it is examining.
The auditor's report – PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à r.l. – on the Court's financial statements for the financial year 2016 was published on 31 October 2017.
Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2017, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary-General in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2015.
This means that our financial statements for 2015 have been finally approved.
As in every year, we have carefully analysed the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility, taken appropriate measures and reported to the European Parliament on our follow-up.

European Court of Auditors 4 About the Court The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the external auditor of the European Union.
It was established in 1977 and is one of the seven institutions of the EU.
The Court is based in Luxembourg and employs around 900 staff from all EU nationalities, composed of auditors and staff in horizontal services and administration.
The College of the Court shall be composed of one member from each EU Member State.
The Court's tasks The Court shall verify that the EU ensures proper accounting, that its financial rules are correctly applied and that its policies and programmes achieve the objectives and that the financial resources are used optimally.
Through its audit work, the Court contributes to improving the financial management of the EU and to promoting accountability and transparency.
The Court makes its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, national governments and parliaments and to the general public.
Foreword of the President 5 Dear reader, dear reader!
We are now increasingly focusing on assessing the performance of EU measures, conveying our statements in a clear form to the Hof's audience and increasing the value of our work for our stakeholders.
In this activity report, we provide an overview of our work in 2018, in which we published the highest number of special reports, analyses and comments so far.
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances.
Our reports offer an impartial assessment of the Union's policies and programmes and of the quality of EU financial management within and outside the European Union.
We are examining whether EU expenditure is in line with the rules and whether the Union's policies and programmes ensure optimum use of resources.
We will be delighted to work with the newly elected European Parliament and the new European Commission to further improve EU financial management and ensure that the EU achieves results.
In this report, our determination to continue to adapt the Court's organisation in order to continue to "sustain our preparation for the future" and to continue to shape developments in the field of public sector audit.
