Our activities Strategy 2018 is the first year of our current strategy, which covers the period up to and including 2020.
Our strategic objectives for this three-year period are: to improve the added value of the Statement of Assurance with a view to the current EU financial management; to improve the focus on the performance aspects of EU measures; to provide clear statements for our audience.
In addition, we have agreed to align our overall organisation even better with our products.
In order to implement our strategy, we have agreed an action plan for these objectives in order to continue to be among the frontrunners in developments in the field of public sector audit.
At the end of 2018, all of these measures were under way.
At the same time, we have already commissioned an independent peer review process for the implementation of our strategy. The review will be completed at the end of 2019 – more information in the Chapter on the Court's Accountability.
Progress towards our strategic objectives 7
The focus – the communication activity around our products Communicating clear statements for our audience Communication is crucial if we are to achieve our strategic goal of conveying clear statements for our audience. This consists of the political bodies of the EU and of the Member States responsible for the control and management of the policies and programmes of the Union, of the other supreme audit authorities, of companies and industry organisations, of scientists and not least of the general public – our most important stakeholder.
In 2018, we experienced the media's interest in our work.
Above all, our special reports met with great interest in the media and were also discussed more and more in national and EU-oriented media channels – further information in the chapter on media presence.
In 2018, we published 12 audit previews (previously referred to as "background papers") which are intended to serve as a source of information for all those interested in specific policy areas or programmes for which audits are in progress.
The information presented in it is based on the preparatory work prior to the start of an ongoing examination task.
Audit previews have contributed to the stable and balanced output of the Court's publications throughout the year: 2018 was the first year in which there was not a single month without a publication of the ECA.
We will continue to publish these types of communication products in 2019. 8
Journal While our findings and recommendations for improving EU financial management are set out in our audit reports, the Court Journal focuses on our working methods and our staff who produce reports on various areas.
Now each issue is dedicated to a different parent theme.
In 2018, the Court's journal targeted a range of topics such as EU pre-accession assistance, Parliament's financing and audit and EU financial and economic governance, as well as our special reports, our work programme, our international cooperation and our forward-looking actions, with the aim of "equiping the Court for the future".
An insight into our facility 9 Downloads 2018 2017 9 314 16 357
Assessments More focused on performance We carry out different types of audits in the different areas of the EU budget: o Economic Assessments – The effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes are considered here.The focus of these audits on the optimum use of funds is on specific management or budget issues.
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court shall consider the risks to the economy or compliance, the level of revenue or expenditure and the political and public interest concerned; o Audits of the accounts and compliance audits shall be considered here the reliability of the annual accounts, and the legality and regularity of the underlying financial operations, in particular in the context of the Statement of Assurance, as well as the assessment of the compliance of the systems in specific budgetary areas with the rules.
Our random sampling procedure ensures the same probability of testing for each euro spent.
Our audits focus on issues that reflect issues relevant to the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, the challenges of migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, as well as ensuring that the European Union is accountable and economically viable.
On the basis of the evidence obtained during our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which the EU's policy objectives have been achieved, as well as the state of the Union's budgetary and financial management.
Our audits are in line with internationally recognised auditing principles for the public sector.
The examination work is divided into the following phases: 10
PLANTING Identifying the usefulness and feasibility of a proposed audit.
On-site audit work On-site multi-disciplinary teams gather audit evidence in the Commission's central services and in Member States and recipient countries.
CONSOLIDATION 03 04 05 06 11 01 02 Clear, structured presentation of the main findings and conclusions.
CLARification Confirmation of the facts and findings by the body examined.
Acceptance of the report by the Chamber of Examining or the whole College of Court.
PUBLICATION Publication of the special report in 23 official languages together with the reply of the audited body.
Work planning Audit priorities are based on the main interests of the EU Our work programme is adopted annually by the members of the Court.
In January 2018, President Lehne presented the work programme for 2018 to the Conference of Committee Chairs of the European Parliament and asked all parliamentary committees to propose potential audit topics for the 2019 work programme as part of the annual stakeholder consultations.
12 In October 2018, we published the first work programme under the new strategy. In this work programme for 2019, we presented our audit priorities and the 36 reports and analysis-based products the publication of which is planned for this year.
These tasks covered, at least in part, 29 of the 69 proposals submitted by Parliament (42%) (2017: 32%).
Our audits will continue to focus on key issues such as the sustainable use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, migration, security and global development, the internal market and the accountability and economy of the EU to determine whether the EU achieves what it has promised.
On-site exams 3 761 days of examination work – inside and outside the EU The majority of our examination work takes place on the premises of the Court in Luxembourg.
At the same time, our auditors also carry out numerous audit visits to the European Commission, the main body audited by the Court, including the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and EU delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, and international organisations to which EU funds are directed.
In addition, we carry out on-the-spot audits on recipients of EU funds within and outside the European Union.
These audits will enable us to understand the audit path and to obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes and the collection or disbursement of EU funds, and from the respective beneficiaries. 13
The frequency and intensity of our audit work in the individual Member States and recipient countries depend on the type of audit we carry out.
In 2018, our auditors spent 3 761 days (2017: 3 670 days) with on-site audits in Member States and outside the EU.
Within the EU, our on-site audits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited.
In addition, our auditors spent 2,723 days (2017: 2,300 days) with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, with decentralised agencies and bodies throughout the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations and the OECD, as well as with auditors.
To obtain and validate audit evidence, we are increasingly making use of video conferencing and other information technologies, such as the secure exchange of data and documents. 14

Fighting fraud against the EU budget Nine cases of suspected fraud In the fight against fraud against the EU budget, we work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
These cases will then be followed up by OLAF, which will decide on possible investigations and, if necessary, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
Although our tests are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities.
In 2018, we forwarded nine such cases (2017: 13 cases) that we suspected of fraud to OLAF.
Additional information on the nature of fraud suspected of OLAF and the related recoveries, as recommended by OLAF, can be found in our annual reports on the general budget of the EU. 16
Publications New record: highest number of publications in 2018 Our audit reports, analyses and opinions form an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
They help the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to monitor and verify the EU's achievement of its policy objectives and to bring to account the EU's bodies responsible for the budgetary management, in particular in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
These are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies.
National, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role in areas of shared management in which the bulk of the EU budget is spent, including agricultural and cohesion measures.

For our publications: special and annual reports o special reports describing the results of selected audits of specific policy or expenditure areas or of budgetary and management issues; o annual reports focusing on the results of the audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the European Union budget and on the European Development Funds, but also on aspects of budgetary management and performance aspects; o special annual reports on EU agencies, decentralised bodies and joint undertakings published separately.
Opinions and analysis-based publications o Opinions on new or amended acts with a significant impact on financial management which are either mandatory under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) or are drawn up at the request of another body or at the Court's own initiative; o Thematic papers are descriptive and analytical documents on policies or management which focus on specific issues; o Landscape analyses are similar to thematic papers, but focuss on complex, broad policy areas or management issues, often from a cross-cutting perspective; o Rapid Case Reviews, which put together facts related to very clearly defined specific issues or problems; if necessary, they include an evaluation which allows a better understanding of these facts.
Finally, we present background information about future or ongoing audit tasks in the form of audit previews – additional information in the chapter on communication activity around our products.
All the Court's publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu) and are listed at the end of this report. 18

Special Reports We assess the performance of the EU actions in our Special Reports In line with our strategy for 2018-2020, we are increasingly focusing on assessing the performance of the EU actions in order to ensure the best use of EU citizens' resources.
In 2018, we published 35 special reports (2017: 28 special reports) on the various areas of EU expenditure in which we addressed the challenges facing the EU, such as air pollution, the high-speed rail network, the Refugee Facility in Turkey, banking supervision and the financing of non-governmental organisations (NGOs).
In these special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved in an effective and economic way, and whether EU funds have provided added value – i.e. whether they have achieved more than they can be achieved by action alone at national level.
We also make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste, or more cost-effectively achieving the policy objectives sought.
At this point, we will examine two of our 2018 special reports: a special report on high-speed rail transport in the EU and one on the Facility for Refugees in Turkey.
In accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, we strive to produce our special reports within 13 months. 20

Special report in focus European high-speed rail network: not a reality, but an ineffective patchwork High-speed rail transport has many benefits for passengers.
It is a convenient, secure, flexible and environmentally sustainable mode of transport.
Improved links between regions in the EU will also make them more competitive and contribute to European integration by bringing people closer to each other.
In this way we analyzed the various connections, travel times and prices for business and private travellers.
We also examined whether the co-financed investments in high-speed rail links were cost-effective and effective and well thought out and planned.
The Court concluded that the European high-speed rail network was only an inefficient patchwork of lines in each Member State that were not sufficiently interconnected.
There is no realistic long-term plan for connecting the various parts of the existing EU network; high-speed lines crossing national borders are not the priorities of the individual Member States and the European Commission does not have the powers to force Member States to do so.
In such circumstances, EU co-financing for high-speed rail transport will achieve little added value.
However, there is also a good news: the number of passengers using high-speed rail in Europe is growing steadily. Thus, there has been an increase from around 15 billion passenger-km in 1990 to over 124 billion in 2016.
Both institutions welcomed the report and agreed with our conclusions.
We also presented it to numerous national authorities and SAIs as well as to researchers, industry stakeholders and the media.
Throughout the EU, the media, in particular EU-oriented media and financial media, dealt extensively with this report, in particular in Spain and Germany.
DE – Time: Rail lines: development of fast rail lines in EU too expensive and too slow IT – La Repubblica: Alta velocità nell'Ue, la Corte dei Conti europea boccia la rete UK – Financial Times: Bloc critical over high-speed rail strategy ES – El cinco días: Los auditors de la UE criticalan la incoherencia de los trazados del AVE
Special report in focus The Facility for Refugees in Turkey: Support is helpful, but optimal use of funds can only be achieved with improvements Turkey has received as many refugees as no other country in the world, with almost 4 million people.
About 3.5 million of these refugees are Syrians, most of whom live outside refugee camps.
Support under the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, which the EU and its Member States have endowed with a total of €6 billion, covers humanitarian and non-Humanitarian activities for refugees and host communities.
As a result of the political agreement, Turkey was required to end irregular migration from Turkey to the EU.
Humanitarian projects have met the basic needs of refugees, but in some cases the expected optimal use of the funds or the aim of the Facility, an effective coordination of this support, has not been achieved.
Support for refugees has been provided through the humanitarian projects audited.
For example, the Social Security Network for Emergency Situations helped 1.3 million refugees through cash aid.
However, half of the projects have not yet achieved the expected impact – a lasting positive impact that can be sustained without further financial support – and nine out of ten projects had to be extended.
The time-consuming implementation of projects managed by NGOs was mainly hampered by the difficult working environment.
This was due to the refusal of the Turkish authorities to provide access to the data of the eligible beneficiaries of the two cash assistance projects in our sample, totalling EUR 1.1 billion.
We presented our report at a joint meeting at which the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament participated, and subsequently also the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.
It was also presented to the Enlargement and Candidate Countries Group of the EU Council and the press.
In Germany in particular, this report has attracted a great deal of media interest, but also in Denmark, Austria, the Benelux and the Mediterranean countries, and in the EU-oriented media.

Annual reports Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2017 Annual accounts, full audit opinion on revenue, limited audit opinion on expenditure Every year, we review the revenue and expenditure of the EU budget and examine whether the annual accounts are reliable and the revenue and expenditure operations are in line with the financial rules at EU and Member State level.
In addition, we assess all the key areas of the EU budget specifically, on the basis of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) headings for the period 2014-2020, and provide information on the budgetary and financial management and performance-related information.
Furthermore, we analyse why errors have occurred, make recommendations on possible improvements and examine whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been put into practice.
As part of our most recent annual report on the EU budget for the 2017 financial year, our auditors examined a sample of some 700 payments, worth a total of 100 billion euros to beneficiaries in the various areas of EU budget expenditure.
This means that we analysed some 700 different cases where EU funds were used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.
26 Key data EU expenditure 2017 EUR 137.4 billion Audited amount EUR 100.2 billion (703 payment transactions) Auditing According to actual circumstances – Reliability confirms revenue Legally and properly – Unqualified audit opinion Expenditure Restricted (and no failed) audit opinion, except for legal and legal reimbursements
The downward trend in estimated error rates continues This extensive work forms the basis for our Statement of Assurance, which we must submit to the European Parliament and to the Council, in accordance with our mandate set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
As in previous years, the Court gave an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and the revenue of the EU.
Furthermore, for the second year in a row, we were able to present a limited (and not a failed) assessment of EU expenditure.
A significant part of the audited expenditure in 2017 did not have a significant error rate.
In addition, the estimated error rate for the payments for 2017 was 2.4%, compared with 3.1% in 2016 and 3.8% in 2015.
Parliament's discharge procedure is launched The publication of our annual report is at the beginning of the discharge procedure carried out by the European Parliament, in which the EU's legislative and budgetary authority, on the recommendation of the Council, decides whether the Commission's and other bodies' management of the EU budget is satisfactory.
We presented our annual report to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control on 4 October at the same time as it was published, and subsequently to the plenary session of the European Parliament and the ECOFIN Council, as well as to the national parliaments and authorities of 14 Member States.
Mr Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors, and Mr Lazarou, Member of the Court, at the presentation of our annual report at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg in November 2018 28
For cohesion expenditure, we assessed the 2014-2020 control and reliability framework and the reliability of the information provided by the Commission to demonstrate regularity.
This was a first step towards the potential design of the Statement of Assurance as a test-oriented audit.
With the revised approach and the transition to a testat-oriented audit, we generally intend to take greater account of the different internal control levels of the European Commission and of the authorities of the Member States responsible for managing EU expenditure.
It is therefore clearer where weaknesses remain both within the European Commission and within the Member States, enabling us to contribute to the promotion of accountability and to the further improvement of EU financial management.
This approach will only apply if the relevant conditions laid down in international auditing principles are complied with. 29

33 Main Conclusions Overall, our review of the agencies confirmed the positive results of previous years for the year ending 31 December 2017.
We gave unqualified opinions on the reliability of the accounts for all the agencies; unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts of all the agencies; and full opinions on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts of all the agencies, with the exception of a failed opinions on the accounts for the European Asylum Support Office, which identified a number of problems.
Main conclusions o We have drawn up the accounts of all the EU Joint Undertakings for the financial year 2017 and confirmed their reliability. o Seven Joint Undertakings received full audit opinions on their revenue and payment transactions; the Joint Undertaking "Electronic Components and Systems for the Leadership of Europe" received a limited audit opinion, since the auditors have identified problems that have in some cases been countered by effective internal control.
Opinions We also contribute to improving the EU's fiscal governance by publishing opinions on Commission proposals for new or amended legislation.
In the case of acts with significant financial implications, the Court's opinions are required under EU law.
These are mainly used by the legislative authority – the European Parliament and the Council – in their work.
Opinions may also be initiated at the request of other institutions or at the Court's own initiative.
In 2018, we published ten opinions – the highest number so far – on various areas of EU governance.
First, they concerned mainly the Commission's legislative proposals for the new MFF, such as the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the effectiveness of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and its cooperation with the future European Public Prosecutor's Office (EUStA), and the linking of EU funding with respect for the rule of law and the protection of whistleblowers.
Focus – Opinion on CAP reform A more environmentally friendly and consistently performance-based CAP, focusing more on accountability When the European Commission published its legislative proposal for the new CAP after 2020, it stressed that environmental and climate objectives would be given a very high priority.
However, in our opinion on the reform of the CAP, we pointed out that many of the policy options proposed differed only slightly from the current CAP regime.
In particular, most of the budget will still be direct payments to farmers based on the number of own or used hectares.
We also noted that this instrument is not the most economical way to support a decent income and that it does not take into account many environmental concerns.
Moreover, the Commission's assessment of the contribution of the CAP to the EU's climate change objectives seemed unrealistic to us, and the Court therefore recommends more environmentally friendly and consistently performance-based plans for the next CAP, which should also focus more on accountability. 34
In accordance with the procedure we apply in our reports, this opinion was presented to the committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council, stakeholders in the environmental and agricultural sectors and the press. 35
Analysis-based publications: Landscape analyses, subject papers, and rapid case reviews Analytical overview of publicly available information and the Court's own work Landscape analyses In 2018 we produced two Landscape analyses.
In the first, the Court examined the application of Union law in practice and explained that the Commission's supervisory activities in relation to the application of Union law by the Member States should be strengthened.
In the second landscape analysis, we dealt with mobility and transport and considered it the cornerstone of European integration.
However, we expressed concerns about the investment backlog, as the modernisation of the EU transport network is hampered by the decline in investment in transport infrastructure.
Topic papers In 2018, we published a total of six thematic papers: five on the Commission's proposals for the future MFF and one on the integration of migrants in the EU.
The Court's comments on the MFF focused in particular on the proposed procedure for setting expenditure priorities for the EU, the flexibility of the EU budget, the performance orientation and the simplification of administration and the accountability and audit arrangements.
We welcomed the Commission's efforts to modernise the EU budget after 2020, but at the same time highlighted several potential risks, identified a number of weaknesses and suggested concrete improvements.
We pointed out that effective parliamentary scrutiny of sound accountability rules is needed, and that the Court should, in principle, be the external auditor for all the institutions created by the EU.
Rapid Case Reviews In the only rapid analysis we presented in 2018 on cohesion, we found that the reimbursement of value added tax (VAT) is prone to error and does not always represent an optimal use of EU funds.
We felt that the reimbursement of VAT to public bodies for expenditure co-financed by the EU should no longer be possible for the period after 2020. 36

Our Management The College of Members of the Court The term of office of the Members of the Court is six years, the term of office being renewable.
The College shall be composed of one member from each Member State.
The ECA does not play any role in the appointment and appointment of members.
In 2018, the Council appointed four new members: o Eva Lindström (Sweden), Tony Murphy (Ireland) and Hannu Takkula (Finland) on 1 March 2018 and Annemie Turtelboom (Belgium) on 1 May 2018.
In addition, the Council extended the terms of office of five members: o Pietro Russo (Italy), Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain), Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) and João Figueiredo (Portugal) until 29 February 2024 and Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria) until 31 December 2024.
In 2018, the College of Court Members met 18 times (2017: 21 times).
46th meeting of the College of Court Members in Luxembourg on 28 February 2019
The role of the President is that of a first among equals (Primus inter Pares).
Its remit includes the institution's strategy, planning and performance management, communication and media work, legal issues and internal audit.
He also represents the Court in all its external relations.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected President in September 2016.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne, President of the Court, at his speech at the annual meeting of the College of Court Members and the College of Commissioners in Luxembourg in February 2018 47
The President and Members 48
Examination chambers and committees The members are assigned to one of the Court's five examination chambers.
They shall be headed by a Doyen or a Doyenne elected by the members of the group.
Each member is responsible for his or her specific duties and is assisted by his or her cabinet.
The examination work is carried out by professional examiners who work for the boards of the examination chambers.
As of December 2018, the five examination chambers were headed by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Milionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Neven Mates and Lazaros S. Lazarou.
Danièle Lamarque was chair of the Committee on Quality Control, Oscar Herics headed our Ethics Committee, and Samo Jereb headed our Audit Committee, while Rimantas Šadžius was the member responsible for institutional relations.
Decisions on wider strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President.
The European Court of Auditors comprises 10 Directorates for all its activities, of which five are of the audit chambers, one of the audit quality control, another of the president and three are of the Secretary-General.

Performance Measurement Our new key performance indicators in the 2018-2020 strategy Since 2008, we have been using Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform management of the progress made towards our goals, support the decision-making process, and provide our users with information about our performance.
We have not only defined our strategy for 2018-2020, but have also adjusted our KPIs for this period.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Thus, 2018 is the first year in which we can report on these indicators.
These five KPIs provide a comprehensive overview of how we conduct our work in terms of dissemination, impact and perception. o KPI 1 – Implementation of our recommendations o KPI 2 – Stakeholders' feedback on our work o KPI 3 – Our response in the European Parliament, Council and national parliaments o KPI 4 – Number of special reports (and similar products) published (number of special reports (and similar products)) o KPI 5 – Our presence in the media (court's media presence) 50
51 Number of Special Reports and Similar Products in 2018 We monitor the number and timing of the reports published throughout the year.
This provides an indication of the accuracy of our planning.
Of the 47 reports planned for 2018, 44 were published: 35 special reports, six thematic papers, two landscape analyses, and a quick analysis.
In addition to the selected reviews provided for in our work programme, we delivered ten opinions.
Special reports and similar products 50 45 40 35 30 25 20 15 10 5 0 44 30 2017 2018 Our appearances in the European Parliament, the Council of the EU and in national parliaments Most of our audit reports will be presented to the relevant committee of the European Parliament and the Council of the EU.
In addition, most of the Court's members present our annual reports to the national parliament of their respective Member States.
In 2018, representatives of the Court spoke to the European Parliament 133 times (2017: 91), to the Council 65 times (2017: 47) and to national parliaments 50 times (2017: 19).
This represents a significant increase compared to 2017.
Appearances of the Court in 2018: European Parliament, Council and national parliaments 52 European Parliament 91 Council of the EU 47 133 65 50 National Parliaments 19 2017 2018 Media presence Number of online articles and contributions in the social media almost tripled Since 2018, we have been in closer contact with the media and non-institutional stakeholders and are much more active in the social media.
We have published o 76 press releases in 23 EU languages (2017: 57) and o 20 press briefings in Brussels (2017: 16), including press briefings for the annual report, including briefings in the sector and in the Member States concerned.
We also received journalists from Brussels and the Member States, and offered industry stakeholders, NGOs and think tanks several briefings on selected reports.
53 Visits to Luxembourg by Member State journalists in November 2018 We follow the media coverage of our work and our institution, which can vary significantly depending on the topic and complexity of a report.
At the same time, we must take into account that external factors can strongly influence the media's interest in our publications.
If, for example, the date of the publication coincides with an important event or political development, public interest in the subject in question may increase significantly.
The total number of media reports, including social media, has almost tripled: while there were around 15,500 online articles and social media contributions in 2017, their number has increased to more than 44,000 in 2018.
Social media posts posted by the Court's official accounts regarding our publications were posted around 11 million times in 2018, almost 18 times more than in 2017.
Special reports are clearly our flagship product in terms of media coverage As far as communication and media coverage are concerned, the special reports have clearly become our flagship product. Twelve of the Court's 15 most successful publications in 2018 were special reports.
In that year there were more than 11,000 online articles on our special reports, which means that the number has increased by more than double the number compared to 2017.
On the other hand, the total number of online articles in 2013 amounted to 1,500 – the year we started to pursue media coverage.
Compared to 2017, there was also an increase of 60% of the average number of media reports per special report.
This means that our presence in the media has increased not only because of a higher number of reports, but also because of a greater interest in our publications.

The impact and perception of our work Our reports – useful and effective We evaluate the impact and perception of our work on the basis of assessments by the addressees.Another evaluation criterion is the follow-up measures taken on the basis of our recommendations to improve EU financial management.
At the beginning of 2018, we started to ask our stakeholders (from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, from EU agencies, permanent representations of the Member States, Member States' public bodies, national SAIs, NGOs, science, the media, etc.) for feedback on the usefulness and likely impact of our reports.
These feedbacks concern selected special reports and analyses, as well as the Court's annual reports, and are collected by anonymous electronic surveys by all those who have previously received a copy of those reports.
This survey also enables stakeholders to provide qualitative feedback on reports and make general proposals on the Court's work.
Overall, 87% of respondents confirmed the usefulness of our reports for their work and 78% agreed with them.

Follow-up to our recommendations Most of our recommendations have been implemented Since 2018, we have been using a follow-up of our auditors as a basis for this indicator instead of the European Commission's management statement.
For 2018, we analysed the recommendations made in our 2014 special reports and the annual report of the same year.
This analysis shows that 74% of the recommendations we have made in our 2014 Annual Report and 94% of the recommendations have been fully, largely or partially implemented in our 2014 Special Reports.

Our staff staff at the end of 2018 employed 834 temporary officials and staff at the European Court of Auditors.
The Court's establishment plan included 853 permanent and scheduled posts, including 541 in the examination chambers, including 112 posts in the members' cabinets.
Our staff's areas of activity: Examination services, translation, administration and services of the President 58 Examination services 541 Translation Administration President's services 135 Altogether 853 129 48 In addition, at the end of the year 76 contract staff and 15 seconded national experts were employed at the Court.
Recruitment of staff The staff of the Court have a broad academic and professional background.
With our recruitment policy, we follow the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and promote equal opportunities at all levels.
In 2018, the Court recruited 79 staff: 15 officials, 32 temporary staff, 22 contract staff and ten seconded national experts.
We also provided 60 university graduates with internships for periods of three to five months.
Age profile The age profile of the active staff on 31 December 2018 indicates that almost half of our employees are 44 years old or younger.
30 of the 64 directors and the Court's directors (47%) are 55 years of age or older.

Support for audit activities Professional further training further training: for example, we prepare our staff and the Court for the future In line with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants, IFAC, we strive to provide on average 40 hours (five days) of professional training per year to each auditor.
In 2018, we were once again above this target with 6.9 training days per examiner.
We have continued to expand the range of training courses that we offer to employees both within and outside the examination area, and have helped examiners to obtain various certifications.
We continued our successful series of presentations held by internal or external experts on audit developments or other subjects relating to the work of our auditors.
We continued our "Performance Recognition Awards" program, which allows non-managerial employees to participate in specific external training courses.
Average number of training days per year 7.0 6.7 6.9 Objective ≥ 2 days 2016 2017 Per examiner 2018 4.0 2016 2.3 3.1 2017 2018 Objective ≥ 5 days Per non examiner 62 days
Successful cooperation with educational institutions We have signed a partnership agreement with the College of Europe (Bruges, Belgium) which provides for cooperation in a number of areas, including training, traineeships and the drafting of reports.
We have also concluded cooperation agreements with the European Institute for Public Administration and other organisations, which allow our staff to attend training, organised by these organisations.
We continued our cooperation with the University of Lorraine and further expanded our cooperation: we offered the postgraduate course "Audit of public organisations and policies" and the master course "Management of public organisations" (Management of public organisations). We also designed a new postgraduate program called "Fundamentals of statistics applied to audit" (Fundamentals of statistics in the examination area).
Finally, auditors from other SAIs took part in our internal training, some of them sharing their experience in illustrating reports on the annual Court Training Day, in which more than 450 people participated.
Interactive public online courses We made our online business audit training available to the public and held two interactive seminars with a capacity of more than 150 participants from all over the world.
Translation The Court's Translation, Language Services and Publication Directorate translated and revised more than 251 000 pages in 2018, an increase of more than 18% compared to 2017.
This increase also led to a higher outsourcing rate.
In addition, all our translation teams are now using harmonised working methods.
Translators have been increasingly involved in the Court's audit activities by providing linguistic support during audit visits and in the preparation of most reports.
As a result, we managed to create further synergies with our auditors.
The team responsible for publication is now an integral part of the Directorate.
Review of originals for translation and finally for publication, integrated into a single, optimized workflow.
Information, Work Environment and Innovation Our Information, Work Environment and Innovation Directorate supports our employees in the effective and efficient use of information technologies, through the promotion of innovation and knowledge management.
Information Management We have launched a new initiative called tECAway, which gives our employees access to the network on the go.
This will allow them to access the Court's digital resources and services on all devices, anywhere and at any time.
The Court has created a new harmonised document management system and has created multi-function printing, photocopiering and scanning equipment.
We expect these devices to have a positive impact on information security and paper consumption.
We have also introduced a new governance model on cybersecurity and are currently working on implementing the cybersecurity plan.
All IT projects and IT solutions have taken due account of the maintenance of business operations, ensuring the unrestricted availability of critical systems.
Innovation We have also set up the ECAB, an interdisciplinary innovation laboratory, whose focus is on the digitalisation of the audit area through the use of data and technology.
ECAB tests the use of technologies such as artificial intelligence, natural language processing and text mining for real test tasks.
This support has already benefited from several tasks and publications.
We also carried out a pilot project on the application of blockchain technologies for the notarial certification of audit evidence and publications.
The resulting prototype, the ECA registry, was selected by the European Blockchain Partnership, set up by EU Member States and the Commission, as part of the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure, which will be developed as of 2019.
Knowledge Management In July 2018, our first annual annual summer course in the field of public financial control took place, which we organised together with the University of Pisa and the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA).
45 people from SAIs, EU institutions and universities took part in the summer course, whose focus was on data analysis for exams.
We also held a conference on blockchain, where we explored the possibilities offered by this technology and its practical applications for controlling EU expenditure.
This conference was mainly aimed at participants from other EU institutions.
Building The yard currently has three buildings ("K1, "K2" and "K3") which form a single integrated technical unit.
In addition, the Hof also offers office space for its Centre for the Recovery of Data in Luxembourg.
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees, with meeting rooms, a conference room with interpreting booths, video conference rooms, a cafeteria and a basic kitchen area.
A detailed study of this project will be carried out in 2019 and work is expected to begin at the end of this year.
As approved by the European Parliament and the Council in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining resources of the K3 construction project, which was completed a few years ago, to finance this modernisation.
K3 The K3 building was opened in 2012.
Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method (BREEAM), the K3 building, was rated "very good" based on the world's leading methodology for assessing and certifying the sustainability of buildings.
A new security control centre and an external accreditation and access control centre for employees and visitors was put into operation in September 2018.
The main EurH building "K1" and the new safety control centre on Rue Alcide De Gasperi, Luxembourg Environmental Management As an institution of the European Union, it is our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all activities.
We are therefore endeavouring to reduce the environmental impact of the farm steadily.
We now successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
As part of our goal of systematically reducing our CO2 emissions, we regularly examine the greenhouse gas emissions caused by our activities.
Our greenhouse gas emissions in 2017 amounted to a total of 10 451 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), which represents a reduction of 3% compared to 2016.
2018 was the fourth consecutive year for which the Court examined its carbon footprint.
67 Court accounts Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union, the budget of which falls within the scope of administrative expenditure.
In 2018, the Court's budget amounted to around 146 million euros.
This represents less than 0.1% of total EU expenditure and about 1.5% of total EU administrative expenditure.
The share of the 2018 budget appropriations used was 96%.

Internal and external audit Internal audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It provides independent and objective assurance and provides advisory services designed to increase and improve the value added of the Court's activities.
In addition, that department shall report to the Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee shall regularly monitor progress on the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and shall ensure the independence of the Service.
In 2018, she conducted an audit of the Court's cybersecurity systems and the construction of its perimeter protection.
The department also examined the implementation of the Court's risk management policy and the statements made annually by the authorising officers by delegation.
It also monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations to ensure that the agreed action plans had taken shape.
In 2018, the audit carried out by the service did not reveal any deficiencies which, because of their nature or extent, seriously jeopardise the reliability of the internal control systems as a whole; these control systems had been introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations.
We report annually to the European Parliament and to the Council on the results of the internal audit work.
External control Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same transparency and accountability principles to itself as to the bodies it is examining.
The auditor's report — PricewaterhouseCoopers Sàrl. — on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2017 was published on 17 May 2018. 70
The Court's annual accounts: "In our opinion, the annual accounts give a true and fair view of the European Court of Auditors' financial and financial position (hereinafter referred to as "the Court") as at 31 December 2017 and of the results of its operations, its cash flows and changes in net assets for the year ending that date in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (OJ L 966, 31.10.2012, p.
1), and its retrospective amendments, hereinafter referred to as "the Financial Regulation", and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 laying down detailed rules for the application of the Financial Regulation and its retrospective amendments.';
As regards the use of resources and the control procedures of the Court: "In our work described in this report, we have not encountered facts, from which we would have to conclude that in all essential respects and in the light of the above assessment criteria, the funds allocated to the Court have not been used for the intended purposes and that the established control procedures do not provide the necessary assurance that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations."
Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is also subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2018, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2016.
As in every year, we have carefully analysed the problems raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility, taken the appropriate measures and reported our follow-up to the European Parliament in detail.
On 26 March 2019, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary-General for the financial year 2017.
This means that our financial statements for 2017 were finally approved.
Peer Reviews Peer Reviews mean independent and transparent expert assessments of the capabilities of a given SAIs, which are carried out by other SAIs.
Each SAI participating in the peer review shall continue to respect the independence of the other SAI during the implementation.
We asked the SAIs of Estonia (Leading SAIs), Denmark, the Netherlands, and the United States of America in 2018 to assess whether the Court is in the process of achieving its strategic objectives at the mid-term of the 2018-2020 period and whether it is likely that the measures we have implemented so far to implement the strategy will have the desired effect.
The peer review report is expected to be published in early 2019.
At the same time, we began the preparation of the peer review of the SAIs of Lithuania, together with the SAIs of Poland and the United Kingdom.
The main objective of this expert assessment will be to assess whether the assessment approach of the SAIs of Lithuania complies with international standards.
In addition, we commissioned an external and independent evaluation of the Court's ethical framework during the year.
This peer review is carried out by the audit offices of Croatia and Poland.
The audit report is expected to be available in 2019. 72
Declaration by the authorising officer by delegation I, the undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declare in his capacity as authorising officer by delegation, o that the information contained in this report is accurate and accurate, and o confirms with reasonable certainty that o the funds provided for the activities described in this report have been used for the purposes provided and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, o the control procedures established provide the necessary assurance for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and for the proper handling of fraud or suspected fraud, o the costs and benefits of the controls are proportionate.
