European Court of Auditors 5 Who we are o external auditors of the European Union; o established in 1975 by the Treaty of Brussels; taking up office in October 1977; since the Maastricht Treaty of 1993 full-fledged EU institution; o head office in Luxembourg; o one member per EU Member State appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament; o some 900 employees of all EU nationalities.
Our role o We ensure that the EU ensures proper accounting, that its financial rules are applied correctly and that its policies and programmes achieve its objectives and that the financial resources are used optimally. o We contribute to the improvement of the EU's financial management and to the promotion of accountability and transparency. o We warn of risks, provide audit certainty, point to weaknesses and successes, and provide guidance to policy-makers and legislators of the Union. o We make our comments and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council, national governments and parliaments and the general public. Foreword of the President Dear Reader, Dear Readers!
The year 2019 was marked by many changes for the Union: elections for the European Parliament took place and a new European Commission took office.
The strategic priorities have been redefined and important packages of action have been launched, such as the "European Green Deal" or the "European Digital Future" (beginning of 2020).
Towards the end of the year it became clear that we would now be a Union of 27 Member States.
At the same time, the EU is at an important crossroads in terms of its finances.
We are about to conclude the negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the outcome of which will be decisive for the Union's financing capacity over the next seven years.
All EU institutions must now build on the efforts made so far to further improve the Union's financial management and to ensure that the EU delivers results.
As an external auditor, we offer an impartial assessment of the Union's policies and programmes and the quality of EU financial management within and outside the Union.
We are looking at whether EU expenditure is in line with the rules and whether the Union's policies and programmes ensure the best possible use of resources.
This activity report provides an overview of our work in 2019, in which we published a wide range of up-to-date special reports, analyses and opinions.
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances.
We hope that this information will be useful to you.
We are publishing our Annual Activity Report this year at a time when public health in the EU and its Member States is facing an unprecedented challenge due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our institution has reacted rapidly to this situation in accordance with the health and safety instructions issued by the Luxembourg Government.
I would like to thank all my colleagues for their good work and for their willingness to adapt flexibly to the current situation.
We must now stand together and do everything we can to continue to fulfil our role as external auditors of the EU in these difficult times.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President 6
7 2019 at a glance
8 Our Activities Strategy In order to continue to shape developments in the field of public financial control in a pioneering way, we rely on multiannual strategies to make long-term choices for our audit work and to advance organisational change initiatives with a view to continuous improvements.
At the end of 2019, we had completed the second year of our current strategy for 2018-2020.
In this three-year period, we have set ourselves the following strategic objectives: improving the added value of the Statement of Assurance; giving a stronger focus to the performance aspects of EU measures; and providing clear statements to our audience.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In order to implement our strategy in practice, we have agreed an action plan covering these objectives.
Over the last two years, we have made good progress in the implementation of our strategic objectives.
A number of initiatives and projects have been launched in all of the areas targeted, which have sometimes even gone beyond the objectives of the Action Plan, in particular: o a pilot phase of the assessment approach to the assessment of the Statement of Assurance, which has led to useful findings; o a significant increase in the number of economic reviews and analytical products and a wider range of issues, covering both expenditure and regulation in the EU; o better the maintenance of contacts with the European Parliament and greater visibility in traditional and social media.
During the year, a group of four Supreme Audit Institutions (Estonia, the Netherlands, Denmark and the United States) conducted a peer review of our strategy.
Our peers' report was published in March 2020, just in time to provide valuable impetus for our next strategy starting in 2021.
Good progress in implementing our strategy 9
Auditing the effectiveness and regularity of EU policies Auditing the performance of EU policies and programmes and the effectiveness of the audit and the audit of compliance.
The focus is on issues that reflect relevant issues for the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, the challenges of migration and global development, the internal market and the banking union, and ensuring that the European Union is accountable and accountable.
These audits will help the EU to better achieve its policy objectives.
Our audits of the accounts and our compliance audits lead to our statement of reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We may also carry out selected compliance audits to examine the budgetary and financial management of the Union or to assess whether the management and control systems established to collect and use EU funds comply with the applicable EU and national rules.
Our audits are in line with internationally recognised auditing principles for the public sector. 10
Work Programme Strategic Perspectives In 2019, we continued to embed the Strategic Perspective in our audit work in order to better address the key future challenges for the EU through a forward-looking approach.
To this end we have set up an Advisory Committee on Strategy and Perspectives.
One of the current tasks of this Committee, composed of five members, is to monitor the preparation of the post-2020 strategy.
Audit priorities related to issues relevant to the future of the EU Our work programme was published in October 2019, presenting in detail our audit priorities for the years ahead and the 41 reports and analyses, which are due to be published for 2020.
With our review plans for 2020 and beyond, we will continue to provide the citizens of the Union and policy-makers with independent reports on issues relevant to the future of the EU.
We are preparing the work programme for our audits in an independent way, but not completely isolated from our environment.
It is therefore of the utmost importance for us to work with our institutional stakeholders, in particular the European Parliament.
As usual, at the beginning of 2019, we asked all parliamentary committees to propose possible audit topics for our work programme. 11
Examination work on site The majority of our examination work takes place on our premises in Luxembourg.
Our auditors also carry out numerous audit visits to the European Commission – our main audited body – and also to the other EU institutions, the EU agencies and bodies, the national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, the EU delegations in third countries and the international organisations to which EU funds are directed.
We also carry out on-the-spot checks on recipients of EU funds both inside and outside the EU.
These audits enable us to track the audit trail and obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes and the collection or disbursement of EU funds, and also from the beneficiaries of such funds.
In line with the objective set out in the EU Financial Regulation, we aim to complete our selected audits within 13 months. 12
3 605 days of on-site examination work – inside and outside the EU Our examination teams usually consist of two to three examiners, and the duration of an inspection visit may be a few days, but also several weeks.
Within the EU, our on-the-spot audits are generally coordinated with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States concerned.
13 The frequency and intensity of our audit work in the individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of audit we carry out.
In 2019, our auditors spent 3,605 days (2018: 3,671 days) with on-the-spot audits, both in the Member States and outside the EU.
Furthermore, our auditors spent 2,504 days (2018: 2,723 days) with EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralised agencies and agencies throughout the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations and the OECD, as well as with audit firms.
To interact with our audited bodies, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as secure exchange of data and documents. 14
Audit reports, analyses and opinions Our audit reports, analyses and opinions form an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
They help the European Parliament and the Council to monitor and verify the achievement of the EU's policy objectives, and to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's financial management accountable, in particular in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
Special reports and analytical products In line with our strategy for 2018-2020, we have increasingly focused on assessing the performance of EU measures in recent years.
In 2019, we published 36 special reports and analyses addressing many of the challenges facing the Union in various EU spending areas, such as food safety, renewable energy, e-commerce, border controls, budgetary governance, and ethics frameworks in selected EU institutions, to name just a few. 15
16 In our special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved effectively and economically, and whether the EU policies have created added value, i.e. whether they have achieved more than could be achieved by action at national level alone.
We also make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste, or achieving better policy objectives.
Our analyses are intended to provide introductory descriptions and analytical considerations, often from a cross-sectional perspective and on the basis of previous tests or other publicly available information.
They can also be used to present our analysis of areas or issues that have not yet been examined, or to compile facts on specific issues or problems.
In contrast to examinations, they do not address, nor do they provide, any assurance of reliability.
17 Sustainable use of natural resources Analysis No. 01/2019: The EU's reaction to the "diesel scandal" In 2015, the deviations in diesel engines between the test bench and the emission levels of the road were detected.
Studies have shown that so-called " switch-off devices" have been used that caused lower emissions in official tests than in normal driving operations.
The type-approval authorities of some Member States reacted to the emissions scandal by re-testing diesel cars.
These tests showed that emissions from road transport from almost all light diesel commercial vehicles from the Euro 5 and Euro 6 emission classes exceeded the permissible NOx limits significantly, in some cases by more than 10 times.
We looked at the measures taken by both the EU and the Member States in response to the "diesel scandal".
We also included in our consideration the changes made in the exhaust emission measurement system after September 2015.
We noted that many legal changes to the EU system of vehicle type-approvals and emission tests were adopted to speed up the process.
The Commission is now empowered to review the work of the national type-approval authorities and to have vehicles tested and to revoke or suspend type-approvals.
Third parties concerned can now carry out emission tests.
The Commission also initiated infringement proceedings against certain Member States.
We also noted that in several Member States there has been an increase in willingness to restrict motor vehicle traffic in order to improve air quality, and in several European cities low-emission zones where car traffic is restricted or prohibited.
We presented our work results in the form of an analysis, as the changes made to the legislation will not have a measurable impact in the near future.
Our analyses do not contain any recommendations.
18 Investment for cohesion, growth and integration Special Report No 08/2019: Wind and solar energy for electricity generation: substantial efforts are needed to achieve the EU objectives Electricity can be generated either from non-renewable energy sources such as fossil fuels, non-usable waste and nuclear fuels in conventional reactors, or from renewable energy sources such as hydropower, wind and solar energy, biomass, etc.
Renewable energies also serve the heat and cooling production and the extraction of fuels for the transport sector.
Currently, 79% of the EU's total greenhouse gas emissions are due to the use of fossil fuels to generate energy.
A higher share of renewable energy in electricity generation will contribute to achieving the EU's target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Member States shall determine how best to use their energy resources and how to structure their energy supply.
The EU can support Member States' action through additional funds for investment in renewable energy projects.
We assessed the progress made by the EU and the Member States towards the targets set for the share of renewable energies in order to achieve the overall EU target of 20% by 2020 and 32% by 2030.
In Germany, Greece, Spain and Poland, we checked on the spot whether the promotion of electricity generation from wind energy and photovoltaics was effective.
We noted that significant progress had been made in terms of the share of renewable energy in the energy mix from 2005, but this trend slowed down after 2014.
The share of renewable energy in electricity generation in the EU has increased from around 15% (in 2015) to just under 31% (in 2017) and has thus doubled.
Wind and solar energy were the technologies that made the biggest contribution to this increase.
However, achieving the targets for around half of the Member States will be a major challenge.
We recommended that the Commission encourage the Member States to support the further development of the Commission through the organisation of auctions for the allocation of additional renewable energy capacity, the promotion of increased citizen participation, the simplification of the administrative procedures and the elimination of network deficiencies.
We also recommended that the Commission review the legal requirements for the Member States in order to improve the up-to-dateness of the statistical data.
19 External policies, security and justice Special Report No 24/2019: Asylum, resettlement and return of migrants: time for stronger measures to eliminate disparities between objectives and results In 2015, the European Union experienced an unprecedented influx of migrants, followed by an increase in asylum applications.
In recent years, immigration figures have fallen back to pre-crisis levels.
We conducted interviews with staff at the European Commission, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (commonly referred to as "Frontex").
Audit visits to national authorities and to international organisations and non-governmental organisations carrying out EU-funded projects and 20 EU support actions have been carried out in Greece and Italy.
Both Member States are particularly affected by these migratory flows.
We assessed whether the objectives of EU-funded support were achieved and whether asylum and return procedures were implemented effectively and expeditiously.
We also examined whether the targets and targets of the temporary emergency relocation arrangements have been achieved.
We found that the quotas in the hotspots had improved considerably in the registrations and fingerprints.
Nevertheless, a large number of migrants continue to move to other EU Member States, where they apply for asylum without their fingerprints being stored in the Eurodac database.
In both Member States, the implementation of the asylum procedures continues to be characterised by long processing times and bottlenecks.
A large proportion of the applicants were actually relocated (80% in Greece and 89% in Italy).
However, the relocation process in the countries receiving migrants has not been monitored by the Commission since February 2018.
As in the other EU countries, the return rates from Greece and Italy are low.
We recommended that the next Commission should take appropriate measures to improve the management of emergency aid.
In addition, the Commission should make use of the past experience in the development of future voluntary relocation mechanisms.
Finally, EASO support for asylum procedures should be improved and Frontex support for return operations adjusted.
20 Market regulation and competitive economy Special Report No 10/2019: EU-wide stress tests for banks: as much information about banks as ever, but stronger coordination and risk focus is needed The EU-wide stress test is designed to assess the potential effects that a common shock to the financial situation and the viability of large European banks could have.
It is the task of the European Banking Authority (EBA), in collaboration with the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) to initiate and coordinate the implementation of Union-wide banking stress tests.
Stress tests have been carried out in the EU since 2011, in the case of the bottom-up approach of all, the banks providing the results of the shock scenario based on the methodology approved by the EBA.
We evaluated the implementation of the EU-wide banking stress test under the mandate of the EBA.
We found that at the beginning of the procedure the EBA did not specify the risks or the degree of severity it considered relevant for the stress test procedure.
The ESRB, which developed the stress scenario, received a substantial input from the ECB as well as from the national central banks and authorities.
As a result, EBA lacked control over key phases of the procedure.
In the United States, supervisors rely on a top-down approach, giving them a much greater degree of control over the results achieved by banks.
Conversely, the role of EBA in the EU is limited to the introduction of stress tests, the provision of methodology, and the extensive coordination of stress tests.
The EBA's stress test assessed the vulnerability of the system and banks to a downturn rather than a severe financial shock affecting the system.
Although the EBA pursued the objective of broad coverage, certain risky banks were excluded from the stress test.
The bottom-up approach of EBA led to a limited reliability and comparability of the results achieved by the banks.
We recommended that EBA should strengthen its control over the stress testing process and develop a top-down approach that complements the current bottom-up approach.
In order to fulfil its purpose of assessing resilience to adverse market developments, future stress tests should, moreover, take due account of the risks posed by the EU financial system, ensure a minimum level of stress and provide clear statements on the resilience of banks.
Finally, the choice of banks for the stress test should be carried out not only according to size, but also according to risk.
21 Financing and administration of the Union Special Report No 14/2019: "Your opinion counts!"
While the Commission's public consultations involve citizens, there is a lack of public relations, the aim of "better regulation" is to ensure that policy decisions are prepared openly and transparently, that they are based on the best facts available and that citizens and other stakeholders, such as civil society organisations and representative associations, are supported, that they are fully involved.
The Commission is obliged to consult citizens and representative associations in all areas of Union action.
The guidelines for better regulation define stakeholder consultation, with citizens also ranking as "interest-makers".
Consultations with stakeholders, in particular in the context of public consultations, will seek information and opinions from citizens and other stakeholders when the Commission prepares a policy initiative or evaluates ongoing interventions.
The Commission carries out on average more than 100 public consultations per year.
We assessed whether the Commission's public consultations have effectively contributed to reaching out to the citizens and stakeholders and to making use of their contributions.
We examined the structure of the Commission framework, the way in which the Commission has prepared and carried out a selection of public consultations, and the way in which it has provided information on the consultation activities, and how it has used the consultation work.
We reviewed a sample of 26 Commission public consultations carried out by five Directorates-General between 2016 and 2018 and carried out an opinion poll to ascertain how satisfied the participants in public consultations were in fact.
We noted that the Commission framework for public consultation has a high standard.
Moreover, the Commission's overall public consultation sample was positive and the participants' perception of the sample was generally satisfactory.
Inadequacies have been identified in public relations and feedback. For example, the whole range of communication channels has not always been used, clear criteria have been missing for justifying why a questionnaire was not available in all EU official languages and some questionnaires have been long and complex.
We recommended that public advertising for the consultation should be made to a greater extent and more targeted to improve visibility and to allow more people to participate.
We also encouraged the Commission to report better on the follow-up to the public consultation.
Finally, there is potential for improvement in citizens' participation in the process of launching legislative proposals in the context of the European Citizens' Initiative.
Audit previews Audit previews provide information on ongoing audit tasks (in the area of the audit).
They are based on the preparatory work carried out before the start of an audit and are intended to serve as a source of information to all those interested in certain policy areas and/or programmes subject to an ongoing audit.
In 2019 we published 18 previews (2018: 12).
Annual reports and special annual reports The annual reports essentially contain the results of our Statement of Assurance on the European Union budget and on the European Development Funds (EDF).
The special annual reports contain the results of our annual audit of the accounts of the agencies, decentralised bodies and Joint Undertakings of the EU and the European Schools.
We also publish a report on contingent liabilities resulting from the tasks of the Single Resolution Committee (SRB). 22
Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2018 Every year, we review EU revenue and expenditure in order to assess whether the annual accounts are reliable and whether the underlying income and expenditure transactions are in line with the relevant EU and Member State legislation.
In addition, we provide specific assessments of all key areas of the EU budget, based on the (partial) headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020.
Furthermore, we analyse why and where errors have occurred, make recommendations for improvements, and examine whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been put into practice.
Finally, we provide information on budgetary and financial management and performance-related information.
This extensive work forms the basis for our Statement of Assurance, which we must submit to the European Parliament and to the Council in accordance with our mandate set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
EU general budget: full audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and revenue; limited audit opinion on expenditure In 2018, EU expenditure amounted to EUR 156.7 billion; this corresponds to 2.2% of total expenditure of the general government of the EU Member States and 1% of the gross national income of the Union.
Our auditors examined a sample of 728 payments made to beneficiaries from a population of around 120 billion euros to be examined, covering all areas of expenditure in the EU budget.
This means that we have assessed various cases where EU funds have been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.
For the financial year 2018, we gave a full audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and the revenues of the EU.
Furthermore, for the third year in a row, we were able to present a limited audit opinion on EU expenditure. 23
About half of the expenditure audited has no significant error rate As in previous years, we found that the errors in EU expenditure were not complete and that the payments were lawful and proper, except for the high-risk expenditure (mainly the complex expenditures for which the expenditures were subject to reimbursement and were subject to complex rules).
24 Overall, the Commission and the Member States were able to maintain the progress recorded in the two previous years with an error rate of 2.6% ( budget year 2017: 2.4%; financial year 2016: 3.1%).
We see this as an encouraging sign.
Mistakes – what does that mean?
An error or irregular payment is the amount of the funds that should not have been paid from the EU budget because they have not been used in accordance with EU or national rules and therefore do not comply with the objectives pursued by the Council and Parliament in accordance with the relevant EU legislation or with specific national rules in the Member States.
We estimate the error rate using statistical methods, based on quantifiable (i.e. monetaryly measurable) errors that we have identified by examining a sample of operations within the total audited population of expenditure.
The most error-prone MFF heading: Economic, social and territorial cohesion The most error-prone MFF heading, followed by "Natural resources" and "Competitiveness for growth and employment" was the area of "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" in the 2018 financial year. 25
Annual report on the European Development Funds EDF: full audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and revenues; limited audit opinion on expenditure 26 The European Development Funds (EDF) are the EU's main instruments of assistance in the context of development cooperation.
The EDF aims at overcoming poverty and promoting sustainable development and the integration of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States and the overseas countries and territories into the world economy.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States of the Union and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB).
As in previous years, we gave an unqualified audit opinion for the financial year 2018 on the reliability of the EDF accounts and on revenue and on a limited audit opinion on EDF expenditure.
Special annual reports on EU agencies and Joint Undertakings EU agencies are separate bodies with their own legal personality set up to carry out specific technical and scientific tasks and administrative tasks and thus contribute to shaping and implementing the policies of the EU institutions.
There are 43 agencies in total.
Joint Undertakings are EU public-private partnerships with industry, research groups and Member States, which play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy.
The European Commission is the public sector member of the Joint Undertaking and represents the EU.
A total of eight Joint Undertakings exist.
27 Note: The United Kingdom quit the European Union on 31 January 2020.
Full audit opinion for all agencies except one; full audit opinion for all Joint Undertakings Overall, all agencies (excluding the SRB) received a total budget of EUR 4.2 billion in the 2018 financial year, 20 % more than in 2017 (3.5 billion), representing approximately 2.9% of the total budget for 2018 (2017: 2.7%).
Overall, our audit of the accounts of the agencies for the financial year 2018 confirmed the positive results in the previous years.
We gave full audit opinions on the reliability of the accounts, the revenue and the accounts of the agencies, except for EASO, which has been given a limited audit opinion on the payments.
We also gave all the Joint Undertakings full audit opinions on the reliability of the accounts, the revenue and the expenditure.
Parliament's discharge procedure kicks off The publication of our annual reports is at the beginning of the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament – at the Council's recommendation – decides whether the Commission and other bodies have managed the EU budget satisfactorily.
In October 2019, we presented our annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the EDF to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, and subsequently also to the plenary of the European Parliament, the Council ("Economy and Finance") and the parliaments and national authorities of 21 Member States.
28 Other annual reports: contingency liabilities and European Schools We are obliged to report annually on all contingent liabilities incurred by the Single Resolution Committee, the Council and the Commission in connection with the performance of their tasks in the field of bank resolution.
In our 2018 report, we concluded that the Committee has improved the presentation of its financial statements, but that better reporting of contingent liabilities at the national level is needed.
We also publish an annual report on the annual accounts of the European Schools.
Our audit of the annual accounts for 2018 resulted in a significant error rate for one of the 13 European schools.
On the road to digital testing Digitisation is about harnessing the potential of technologies to provide more and better information for the accountability process.
Digital change is also of great importance for our audit work and our organisation.
We have set up a five-member Digitalisation Steering Committee to manage this transition process in the coming years.
As the first important initiative in the audit area, we launched a pilot in 2019 to automate the audit of the accounting of the executive agencies.
In this pilot experiment we will use traditional and digital instruments at the same time. 29
Opinions Opinions: a contribution to better regulation One way to strengthen the Commission's approach to better regulation is to publish opinions on the Commission's proposals for new or amended legislation.
If these are legislative proposals with significant financial implications, the Court's opinions are required under EU law.
In addition, other institutions may request us to deliver opinions on specific issues.
Our opinions will be submitted to the European Parliament and the Council.
In 2019 we published three opinions: on the proposal on the European Union Intellectual Property Office, on a proposal for the financial regulation of the Single Resolution Committee (SRB) and on the proposal for the financial regulation of the Community Plant Variety Office.
Our comments on the new MFF at the beginning of 2019 were also published in the summary of the EAFRH's comments on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027.
The focus of this summary was on the proposed procedure for setting expenditure priorities for the EU, the flexibility of the EU budget, the focus on performance and administrative simplification, and the accountability and audit arrangements.
The main basis for this analysis was a number of comments we made during 2018 on the Commission's proposals, as well as our recent thematic papers and other reports on the EU's finances.
Balanced number of publications throughout the year We have reached a relatively balanced number of publications throughout the year with a peak in October when we published our annual reports.
31 32 Fighting fraud against the EU's financial interests The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is at the forefront of the fight against fraud at the expense of the EU's financial interests.
We have adopted detailed guidelines for our auditors on how to deal with the risk of fraud.
We shall forward to OLAF any suspicion of fraud or any other illegal activity affecting the financial interests of the EU that arises in our audit work or is reported to us.
These cases will then be dealt with by OLAF, which will decide on possible investigations and, if necessary, cooperate with Member States' authorities.
In 2019, we also signed an administrative agreement laying down the operational rules for our cooperation with OLAF, including the coordination of training, workshops and staff exchanges.
10 cases of suspected fraud have been forwarded to OLAF We are the external auditor of the EU.
Our tests are not specifically designed to detect fraud.
Nevertheless, our auditors regularly identify a number of cases in which they suspect fraudulent activities.
In 2019, we sent OLAF 10 cases of suspected fraud (2018: nine cases), of which eight we encountered during our audits, as well as two cases which resulted from third party references.
Additional information on the nature of these suspected cases of fraud and on the resulting recoveries, as recommended by OLAF, can be found in our annual report on the general budget of the EU.
In 2019, we also published two special reports, which are closely linked to the fight against fraud in EU expenditure: Special Report No. 01/2019 "Combating fraud in EU expenditure: action must be taken" and Special Report No. 06/2019 "Combating fraud in EU cohesion expenditure: administrative authorities must strengthen detection, response and coordination".
33 Finally, we dedicated a special issue of the ECA Journal to the fight against fraud and corruption and to the protection of the EU's financial interests.
Focus on sustainability The UN Sustainable Development Goals at the heart of our audit work In the last years, in which we focused on environmental and climate issues, issues of sustainability were issues of outstanding importance in the audit work.
In 2019, our work in the area of sustainability was complemented by the analysis of sustainability reporting.
This analysis provided an overview of how the EU institutions publish sustainability information and how they contribute to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
We also organised a conference – the EurH Forum on Sustainability Reporting – to raise awareness of the issue and to bring important stakeholders together.
In July, we attended a meeting of SAIs presidents and stakeholders on the topic of "ORCs are moving something: a review of the implementation of the SDGs" at the high-level political UN Forum on the 2030 Agenda.
Finally, we published a special issue of the ECA Journal on the SDGs.
Audit team: analysis "Sustainability reporting: an inventory of EU institutions, bodies and agencies".
Institutional relations Continuous increase in presentations to the European Parliament, the Council and the national parliaments We work closely with the European Parliament (EP), the Council and the national parliaments in the Member States, because the impact of our work depends to a large extent on the benefits which these institutions derive from our audit findings and recommendations.
Our audit reports will be presented to the relevant committees of the European Parliament and the Council working groups.
In addition, we present our annual reports, as well as our special reports and analyses, to the national parliaments.
In 2019, the presentations of our reports for these institutional addressees continued to rise, mainly due to a marked increase in presentations to national parliaments.
At the same time, less presentations in the EP were held from mid-April to September 2019 due to the parliamentary break. 34
Meeting with the newly elected Presidents of the EU Institutions 2019 was a year of change at the head of many EU institutions: after their election, our President met with the President of the European Parliament, the President of the European Commission and the President of the European Council.

We also organised a series of workshops for the staff of the EP.
Finally, in October 2019, we established a publication portal which will allow more user-friendly access to our reports not only to members of the EP, but also to the general public. 36

This online portal provides information on the mandate, status, organisational structure, activity and output of the EU and its Member States' Supreme Audit Authorities.
Public Health Examination Board in the EU In December 2019, we published a second Public Health Examination Board on behalf of the Contact Committee, which provides information on examinations carried out across the European Union in the field of public health.
The Compendium provides background information on public health, its legal bases, its main objectives and related responsibilities at Member State level and at EU level, and highlights the main challenges facing the EU and its Member States in this respect.
It is based on current audit findings of the European Court of Auditors and the SAIs from 23 EU Member States.
In 2019, we started the preparatory work for a third test compendium, to be published in 2020, to address the issue of cybersecurity. 40
INTOSAI In 2019, the ECA continued its active participation in the activities of the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI), in particular in its role as Vice-Chairman of the Committee of Technical Standards (since December 2016) and as a member of the Sub-Committee for Auditing Accounting and Accounting, the Sub-Committee for Auditing Compliance with Legal Standards and the Sub-Committee for Economic Auditing.
We also participated in the activities and projects of other INTOSAI working bodies, in particular in the areas of environmental assessment, big data, financial modernisation and regulatory reform, and assessment of public policies and programmes.
We also participated in the INTOSAI task force for the professionalisation of auditors, the INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI) and in the revision project for the ISSAI 200, under the aegis of the Subcommittee for the Audit of Accounting and Accounting.
INTOSAI Congress (INCOSAI) in September 2019 in Moscow.
The conference discussed two main issues in detail: information technology for the development of public administration and the SAIs' contribution to national priorities and objectives.
EUROSAI We have also been active in the activities of the European Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI), the European Regional Group of INTOSAI, in particular in its working groups on the environment audit, IT audit and audit of disaster relief as well as in its task force on audit and ethics.
We also participated in several workshops and seminars, and, together with 14 other European SAIs, contributed to the publication of a joint report on air quality. In October 2019, we held the seventeenth annual meeting of the EUROSAI Environmental Assessment Working Group and a joint conference on biodiversity. Finally, we participated in the third joint conference of EUROSAI-ASOSAI on emerging issues and emergency situations in Israel in March 2019, as well as in the first joint seminar of EUROSAI-AFROSAI in Lisbon in November 2019, hosted by the Portuguese SAIs.

42 The SAIs of EU candidate countries and potential EU candidate countries We also support the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo*, Montenegro, Northern Macedonia, Serbia, and Turkey), primarily through a network comparable to the Contact Committee and through our support for activities coordinated by the OECD.
In 2019, 10 auditors from SAIs from the network took part in our internship program.
We also actively contributed to the network's meetings and activities, including the treatment of issues such as issues such as accounting policies with increased impact and digital auditing.
Peer reviews by other EU ORKB A peer review is an external independent review of one or more elements of the organisation and/or functioning of an SAI by a team of peer reviewers from one or more SAIBs.
It is not an examination, but an assessment and consultation by peers, which takes place on a voluntary basis.
In 2019, a peer review team led by our Secretary General, together with the SAIs of Poland and the United Kingdom, carried out a peer review of the SAIs of Lithuania.
The main objective was to assess whether the auditing practice of Lithuanian SAIs was in line with international auditing standards.
In December 2019, the final report was submitted to the Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas). * This designation does not affect the positions on the status and is in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999) and the opinion of the International Court of Justice on Kosovo's declaration of independence.
Our Management Members The ECA acts as a collegial body of members with one member in each Member State.
Each Member shall be appointed by the Council after his or her appointment by his or her respective national government after consulting the European Parliament.
We have no role to play in the appointment and appointment of members.
When they take office, they take up a solemn commitment to this before the Court of Justice of the European Union.

President The President's responsibilities include the institution's strategy, planning and performance management, communication and media work, the relationship with the other institutions, legal issues and internal audit.
The President also represents the Court in all its external relations.
The members shall elect the President from among them for three years, with the possibility of re-election.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected President in September 2016, and was re-elected in September 2019.

Examination chambers and committees The members are assigned to one of our five examination chambers.In the chambers the majority of our examination reports, analyses and opinions are prepared and accepted.
The Chambers are headed by a Doyen or a Doyenne elected by the Members of the Chamber from among them.
As of December 2019, the five examination chambers were headed by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Milionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Alex Brenninkmeijer and Lazaros S. Lazarou.
Danièle Lamarque was the quality control member in the audit area (until the end of her term of office in December 2019).
She was chair of the Quality Control Committee in the audit area.
The boards divide their tasks among the members.
Each member shall be accountable to the Chamber and to the Court for his or her own examination tasks.
The members are supported by a cabinet.
In addition to their role in the audit chambers, some members have also taken on further responsibilities: Oscar Herics had the head of the Ethics Committee, Samo Jereb the audit committee, Eva Lindström the steering committee of Digitalization, and João Figueiredo the advisory committee of Strategy and Perspective.
Rimantas Šadžius was the member responsible for institutional relations.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President. 45

Media Presence Continuous increase in social media coverage We follow media coverage of our work and our institution, which can vary considerably depending on the topic and complexity of a report.
At the same time, external factors can strongly influence the media's interest in our publications.
This may be the case, for example, if the date of publication of a report coincides with an important event or political development, with the potential for a significant increase in public interest in the topic in question.

Impact and performance of our work 88% of the stakeholders surveyed consider our audit reports useful We assess the likely impact and usefulness of our audit work based on feedback from our stakeholders from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, from EU agencies, the permanent representations of the Member States, Member States' public authorities and SAIs, NGOs, the scientific community, the media and from other parties.
Since 2018, we have been requesting feedback from our stakeholders via anonymous electronic surveys on a selection of special reports and analyses as well as on the annual report.
These surveys will also enable stakeholders to provide feedback on the quality of the reports and to make general proposals on the Court's work.
In total, 88% of respondents confirmed the usefulness of our reports for their work in 2019, and 81% acknowledged the usefulness of our reports.
52 Follow-up of our recommendations Almost all our recommendations implemented We determine the state of implementation of our recommendations on the basis of the follow-up carried out by our auditors.
For 2019, we analysed the recommendations we had made in our 2015 special reports and the annual report of the same year.
This analysis shows that 96% of the recommendations we made in our 2015 annual report and 94% of the recommendations in our 2015 special reports have been fully, largely or (at least) partially implemented. 53

54 In addition, 75 contract staff and 16 seconded national experts were employed at the Court at the end of the year (2018: 76 and 15, respectively).
Recruitment Our recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions. Our employees have a broad academic and professional background.
In 2019, the Court hired 77 staff (2018: 79 staff): 17 officials, 33 temporary staff, 21 contract staff and six seconded national experts.
We also provided 55 internship places (2018: 60) for university graduates for periods of three to five months.
Age profile Almost three quarters (74%) of active personnel at the end of 2019 are between 40 and 59 years old.

Equal opportunities The Court offers its employees equal opportunities at all levels of the organisation.
Overall, we have a balanced women's and men's share among our employees.
In 2019, around one third of our directors and executive managers are women.

Information technology, working environment and innovation Transition to cloud-based services A major milestone is the transition to cloud-based services, providing an easy-to-use system for various applications from end-users (IT, personnel, office equipment, security, etc.).
A new action plan on IT security has achieved many of its objectives, such as the more effective and regular removal of software vulnerabilities, the prevention of unauthorized access to cloud services, the verification of information security management and the improvement of our security monitoring capabilities.
Finally, an ambitious technical programme was implemented in 2019 to provide equipment and systems that allow all employees to work in a more flexible way, such as home office, teleconferencing and mobile work.

Building The yard currently has three buildings ("K1, "K2" and "K3") which form a single integrated technical unit.
K1 The K1 building, which was opened in 1988, has offices for up to 310 employees and meeting rooms.
The basements are equipped with parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, the library and the main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical facilities.
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 in order to bring it into line with national health, safety and environmental requirements.
As far as possible, the technology in the K1 building was adapted in order to make compatibility with the K2 and K3 buildings.
The basements have parking, technical facilities, storage rooms and the fitness centre.
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees and they also include meeting rooms, a conference room with interpretation booths, video conference rooms, a cafeteria and simple kitchen areas.
We are currently modernising the K2 building to optimise the organization of its work areas and to update certain technical facilities.
A detailed study of this project was carried out in 2019 and work began at the end of the year.
As approved by the European Parliament and the Council in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining budget of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation. 61
The basements have parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, discharging areas, waste storage facilities, printing works, kitchens and archives.
In addition, there are offices for 503 employees, meeting rooms and an IT room in this building.
Based on the world's leading method of assessing and certifying the sustainability of buildings (Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method, BREEAM), the K3 building was rated "very good". 62
Further increase of our security measures In 2019 we took a number of measures to increase security in our buildings in Luxembourg.
This included the establishment of a team of armed security personnel.
An agreement has been reached with the Luxembourg police to allow us to use their national training centres.
We have also agreed with the European External Action Service to assist our auditors in their visits to high-risk countries.

Environmental management As an EU institution, it is our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all activities.
We strive to continue to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions and regularly analyse the greenhouse gas emissions generated by our activities.
Our greenhouse gas emissions in 2018 amounted to a total of 10 178 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), which represents a reduction of 3% compared to 2017.
We are proud of our EMAS certification for environmental management and audit: We successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
In the last quarter of 2019, an external EMAS audit was carried out, which resulted in the renewal of our EMAS certification for the period 2020-2022.
New initiatives such as the "plastic-free EurH" initiative are progressing as planned.
In 2019, we also, in cooperation with the Luxembourg Ministry of Agriculture, set up four hives in our gardens.
The bees are cared for by volunteers.
We assume that this will have a positive impact on the sustainability of pollinators in our environment. 64
Court's accountability Financial information The Court is financed from the general budget of the European Union, the budget of which falls under the heading of administrative expenditure.
For 2019, our budget amounted to around €147 million, of which 98% was used throughout the year.
This represents less than 0.1% of total EU expenditure and around 1.5% of total EU administrative expenditure.

Internal and external audit Internal audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It provides independent and objective assurance and provides advisory services designed to add value and improve the Court's activities.
This department will also report to the Committee on Internal Audit, consisting of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee shall monitor regularly the progress made in the various tasks set out in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and shall ensure the independence of the Service.
In the course of 2019, the Internal Audit Service carried out three selected tasks: "Risks and challenges of the Audit Committee", "Travel expenses of members and senior officials, expenses of representation of members and the use of the Court's vehicle fleet" and "occupational training activities of the Court".
In addition, our risk management strategy and three annual declarations by subdelegated authorising officers were examined.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations by ensuring that the agreed action plans were implemented and by advising on the new internal control framework of the Court.
Our internal auditor did not identify any deficiencies which, because of their nature or scale, would seriously call into question the reliability of the internal control systems as a whole; these control systems had been established by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations in 2019.
External audit Our financial statements are audited by an independent external auditor.
We attach great importance to this audit as it shows that we apply the same principles of transparency and accountability to ourselves as to the bodies we audit.
The auditor's report – PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à.r.l. – on the Court's financial statements for the financial year 2018 was published on 4 April 2019. 67

THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS 2013 Brief information on the audit of the EU Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2014 ISBN 978-92-872-0998-6 doi:10.2865/23970 © European Union, 2014 Reproduction is authorised provided the source is acknowledged.
EN 2013 Brief information on the audit of the EU Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
President's Preface 02 Each November, the European Court of Auditors reports on the results of its annual audits of EU financial management during the previous financial year.
On the basis of the audit evidence obtained, the Court provides a guarantee of reliability for the use of EU funds and highlights the greatest risk of EU funds not being used properly.
The reports also contain recommendations for possible improvements in EU financial management.
In this way, the Court supports the European Parliament and the Council in the review of EU expenditure and contributes to the effective implementation of the Court's accountability of EU citizens.
This "in-depth EU audit in 2013" presents and explains the main findings in our 2013 Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget and the European Development Funds.
As in previous years, the reports show the extent to which the EU and national financial management actors have in their reports a true picture of the management of financial resources, ensured the application of the EU financial rules, and respected the basic principles of economy, economy and effectiveness.
2013 was the last year of a seven-year programming period, and we are publishing our annual reports on this year in a transition period, which is important for the EU and its finances.
As our reports show, a new European Parliament and a new Commission are facing both long-standing and new challenges for financial management and accountability, in the 2014-2020 programming period, which is now under way.
The continued pressure on EU and national finance requires careful management and control of EU funds and better forecasts of long-term financing needs.
In particular, our reports highlight the need for the Commission and the authorities of the Member States, in their EU financial situation, to pay more attention to the use of EU funds to achieve results that, in other ways, could not be achieved equally efficiently or effectively.
At the same time, the Court's audit results show that more can and should be done to ensure that EU spending is in line with the rules.
The Court will be happy to take the opportunity to assist the new European Parliament and the new Commission in solving these and other problems of financial management and accountability that exist at EU level.
To this end, we have also, on the basis of our audit experience, prepared two Landscape analyses, which highlight the key challenges facing the EU in the areas of accountability, audit and financial management.
Mr Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President of the European Court of Auditors

Overall Results 04 Key Statements Summary of the Statement of Assurance for 2013 The European Court of Auditors (EuRH, ‘the Court') gives an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the accounts of the European Union for 2013.
Overall, the revenues for 2013 are legal and proper.
Commitments for 2013 are overall legal and regular.
Payments for 2013 are severely affected by errors.
Therefore, the Court gives a failed opinion on its legality and regularity.
The text of the Statement of Assurance is set out in Chapter 1 of the Annual Report for 2013. ο The Court estimates the error rate in the 2013 payments of 4.7% in terms of the rate of irregularities, close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8%) and constant above the materiality threshold of 2%. ο Overall, the monitoring and control systems in question, with significant differences between Member States, ensured the regularity of payments due. ο The two expenditure areas for regional policy, transport and energy with an error rate of 6.9% and rural development, environment, fisheries and health with an error rate of 6.7%, were the worst.
In the case of shared management as a whole, i.e. including agriculture: market support and direct payments, as well as employment and social affairs, the estimated error rate was 5.2%. ο Corrective measures and recoveries by the authorities in the Member States and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Overall results 05 The correct use of EU funds The EU funds for 2013 Each year, the Court examines the EU's revenue and expenditure and, in its audit, assesses the reliability of the annual accounts and the compliance of revenue and expenditure operations with the rules and regulations in force.
In 2013, expenditure from the EU budget totaled 148.5 billion euros or around 290 euros per citizen.
These expenditures represent about one percent of the EU's gross national income and represent about two percent of the total public expenditure of the EU Member States.
The EU budget is adopted annually by the European Parliament and the Council on the basis of a seven-year financial framework.
The Commission's primary task is to ensure that the budget is spent properly.
At around 80% of expenditure, particularly in the fields of agriculture and cohesion, the Commission shares this task with the EU Member States.
Where do the funds come from?
The EU budget is financed from various sources.
The largest share is made up of payments made by Member States on the basis of their gross national income (EUR 110.0 billion).
Other sources include Member States' payments on the basis of the VAT they charge (14.5 billion euros) and customs and agricultural duties (15.4 billion euros).
The annual EU budget is spent in a wide range of policy areas (see Graph 1).
Payments are intended to support activities as diverse as research projects, training unemployed people or agricultural production.

Overall results 09 Errors, waste and fraud The Court's estimated error rate is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency, or waste.
It is a disaster in relation to funds that should not have been paid out because they have not been used in accordance with the existing legislation.
Typical errors include payments for ineligible expenditure or purchases for which the procurement rules have not been properly applied.
Fraud is an intentional act of deception with the aim of obtaining advantages.
The Court shall forward cases to OLAF (the EU Anti-Fraud Office), which it shall be responsible for carrying out any further investigations in cooperation with the authorities in the Member States, in which it is suspected of having fraud, in the course of its investigations.
A comparison of the error rates estimated for the different areas of expenditure is shown in Figure 5.
Higher quotas in research and other internal policies, administrative expenditure and related expenditure have been offset by lower quotas in the areas of rural development, environment, fisheries and health, as well as external relations, external assistance and enlargement.
As in 2012, the two areas of expenditure were the most flawed: regional policy, transport and energy and rural development, the environment, fisheries and health.
These two areas, together with the two other areas of shared management (agriculture: market support and direct payments and employment and social affairs), have an estimated error rate of 5.2 %.
For all other operating expenditure (mainly managed directly by the Commission), the estimated error rate was 3.7 %.
In addition, the Court found an estimated error rate of 1.0% of the administrative expenditure.
