Overall results 12 The Court analyses the contribution of the different types of error and the different areas of expenditure to the estimated total error rate (see Graph 6).
Expenditure that did not meet the necessary conditions to be claimed in the context of EU funded projects accounted for the largest share of the estimated total error rate (inclusion of ineligible costs in cost statements: 39 % or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
Second, projects where either the financed object/activity or the beneficiary should not have been eligible under the applicable rules (non-eligible projects/activities or beneficiaries: 22 % or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
As the largest expenditure area, the highest estimated error rate, regional policy, transport and energy are by far the largest contributors to the estimated overall error rate (44% or 2.1 percentage points of the estimated overall error rate).
Agriculture: market support and direct payments, in which expenditure was almost the same, contributes roughly half as much to the estimated overall error rate.
Corrective measures have a positive impact on the error rate Member States and the Commission are applying corrective measures to protect the EU budget in cases of ineffective control systems or in error of the EU budget.
If such corrective measures had not been taken in respect of the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate would have been 6,3 % instead of 4,7 %.
However, the estimated error rate could be significantly further reduced by better application of existing control systems and corrective measures.
The Court noted that the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information in order to detect and correct the errors in a large proportion of the error in the areas of shared management before applying to the Commission for reimbursement.
For example, this would have reduced the estimated error rate in the field of regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9% to 3.9%, in the field of rural development, the environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0% and in the field of employment and social affairs from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges for the presentation of reliable financial information Reporting of the corrective adjustments mentioned above does not clearly distinguish between the main types of corrective adjustments and the information is largely provided outside the accounting system.
This makes a more detailed analysis difficult and reduces the accuracy of the figures in the accounts and related financial reporting.
A further development is the increasing use of financial instruments to support investment in potentially economically viable projects in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms.
Due to its complex structure, financial instruments require special care in assessing and recording them in accordance with internationally recognised public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in the amounts to be financed from future budgets Among the main features of the financial management and management of the EU in 2013 are: ο a strong increase in the volume of payments to be made by the Commission by means of amending budgets: 9.6 % of the initial budget; ο a sustained increase in the commitments to be made in future (by 2.6%) despite the high volume of payments; ο an unchanged period (on average more than two years) between the initial commitment date and the date on which expenditure declarations are accepted by the Commission; ο only 37% of the funds made available to financial instruments were paid to final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; ο repayments, interest and dividends of EUR 259 million which have accumulated since 2008 were not recognised as revenue.
What are obligations and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements: obligations (payments to be paid in the current or coming years) and payments (covering the current year)
Payments can only be made against valid commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitments and payments are laid down in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and Parliament.
The nature of the EU spending programmes, in particular the long period between the commitment of funds and the payment, is putting increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This is reflected in a significantly higher budget for payments in 2013, and this trend will continue in a similar way in future budgets.
Overall results 14 How can financial management and management increase the level of information within traditional accounting systems? ο All financial instruments and financial instruments should be included and evaluated in line with internationally accepted accounting principles for the public sector, in particular by means of reliable means of identifying and recording impairments; ο Provide information on the means of cash management held by the final beneficiaries until payment; ο Develop and publish a long-term cash flow forecast, which will be updated annually; this would make it easier for the stakeholders concerned to identify future payment needs and to identify budgetary priorities. ο Improve? Do you want to know more?
Full information on the main audit findings can be obtained from Chapter 1 "Declaration of reliableness and related statements" of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Overall results 15 EU funds and EU funds should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, soundness and effectiveness).
Against this background, it is necessary to achieve good performance inputs (financial, human, material, organisational or regulatory resources necessary for the implementation of the programme), outputs (to be achieved within the framework of the programme), results (immediate changes caused by the programme for the direct stakeholders or for the direct beneficiaries) and impacts (long-term societal changes, at least partly due to the EU action).
The Court assesses these aspects in its economic audits.
The emphasis is not enough on performance The use of EU funds during the 2007-2013 programming period focused on absorption (use it or lose it – not use it) and compliance with legislation and not good performance.
For example, when selecting projects for EU funding, the need for the use of the available EU funds was the first priority, the second was the need to comply with the rules and the third was the need to achieve results and impacts, and only to a certain extent was the need to achieve results and impacts.
This lack of emphasis on performance is a crucial weakness in the way in which a large part of the EU budget is built.
According to the Commission, the priority for the 2014-2020 programming period is more on performance, with performance-related reserves being the main incentives.
By way of these reserves, the Commission will withhold 6% of the funds allocated to individual Member States until the performance is found to be satisfactory.
However, in practice, input and output indicators will continue to be largely decisive for the release of funds.
Results indicators will be used by the Commission only in a few areas.
Whether performance reserves work more effectively will depend on the success of the Commission in negotiating appropriate targets and milestones at the start of the programming period and in maintaining more accurate, reliable and up-to-date data from Member States in determining whether the targets have been achieved.
The reporting framework is not suitable for the desired performance culture Performance reporting is spread across several general reports at the level of the general budget.
These reports do not provide any information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 Strategy objectives, nor do they provide a comprehensive overview of the results in the form of EU added value.
However, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction in that it seeks to link the main financial programmes with the available performance information relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of the Commission's individual Directorates-General, performance objectives for the policy areas are defined in the management plans in their respective areas of responsibility, in which case the annual annual activity reports report them.
The Court's analysis of the management plans and annual activity reports of the Commission's Directorates-General shows that the reliability assurance is limited to aspects of regularity and internal control and does not take performance-related aspects into account.
Moreover, the objectives would be too general to be used for management purposes, and the selected indicators would not always be suitable for performance measurement.
Overall Results 16 The added value of EU expenditure is not always demonstrated The 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013 cover a wide range of issues in the impact assessments and assess whether the EU intervention has been carried out in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (efficiency, sound financial management and effectiveness).
The Court examined the lessons to be learned from its 2013 Special Reports on the development of the new programmes and projects for the 2014-2020 programming period and concluded that ο the EU added value could not always be ensured. ο In several cases, there were potential cash-take effects, i.e. the beneficiaries had carried out the activity without EU funding.
Example: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund compensates workers affected by mass redundancies.
The Court noted that one third of the funding was used for measures that would have been paid by Member States anyway (Special Report No 7/2013 ‘Did the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provide EU added value in the reintegration of redundant workers').
For example: Risk-Sharing Finance Facility The Commission had not sufficiently demonstrated that the EU funds made available under the Risk-Sharing Finance Facility (financial instrument to facilitate access to research debt funding) lead to higher investments than the beneficiaries would make without public funds (Special Report No 2/2013 "Have the Commission ensured the efficient implementation of the Seventh Research Framework Programme?").
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented The follow-up to the Court's recommendations of the follow-up to the audit of the audits is a key element of the accountability cycle and may have a positive effect on the effective implementation by the Commission of the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court analysed how the Commission's recommendations from eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010 have continued to be addressed and found that the Commission had implemented either in full or to a large extent 79 % of the recommendations.
The Court recommends to the Commission that the next revision of the Financial Regulation should streamline the framework for its performance reporting. ο The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report includes a summary report that provides all available information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. ο The Commission should continue to develop its performance management and reporting system to ensure that it can take on responsibility for the sound management of the budget and the contribution of the EU budget to political success. ο Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's evaluation of performance can be found in Chapter 10 "EU budget and output performance" of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the 2013 budget.
All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/en/ Pages/AuditReportsOpinions.aspx.
The contributions calculated on the basis of the gross national income (GNI) of the Member States and the VAT collected by the Member States accounted for 74% and 10 % of the revenue respectively in 2013.
Import duties and the production levy on sugar levied on behalf of the EU by the authorities in the Member States represented 10% of the EU's revenue and the remaining 6% came from other revenue.
Explanation on the audit of EU revenue EU revenue, which is based on GNI and VAT, is calculated on the basis of macroeconomic statistics and estimates provided by Member States.
The Court's audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions concerned the Commission's processing of these data, but not the initial collection of these data by the authorities in the Member States.
Consequently, the Court's conclusion concerns the impact, which the Commission may have on the total amount of revenue.
With regard to customs duties, the Court is examining how the Commission is dealing with the databases submitted by the Member States on the claims identified.
These data are not sufficiently harmonised among Member States.
A reservation is an instrument whereby the possibility of correction can be kept open for a disputed element in GNI data transmitted by a Member State.
There is a general reservation regarding the Greek GNI data for 2008 and 2009, as the data are still based on provisional estimates.
This aspect is part of a problem that affects Greece's national accounts.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 19 The customs authorities of the Member States shall carry out checks to verify that importers comply with customs and import requirements.
The Court noted that the quality of these checks was very different in the Member States visited.
This may result in importers deciding to declare goods in a Member State other than the Member State in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of checks and to make the levying of the duties due more difficult.
One example that appears to be the case is the case of an importer who unloaded Chinese textiles in Hamburg (Germany) and transported them to Rotterdam where they were declared for free circulation and then transported to Poland for final sale.
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should work to ensure that Member States harmonise their methods for the calculation of data on unobserved economic activity. ο The Commission should draw up a detailed action plan of clear milestones and monitor its implementation closely to tackle the problems of drawing up the Greek economic accounts. ο The Commission should establish minimum standards for the control of the Member States' customs authorities in order to ensure a more focused focus on high-risk importers. ο Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU revenue can be found in Chapter 2 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
20 This expenditure covers the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivity of agriculture, to ensure an adequate standard of living for the agricultural population, to stabilise markets, to ensure supply and to ensure that consumers are supplied at reasonable prices.
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with the Member States.
Yes Estimated error rate: 3.6% (2012: 3.8%) Control systems tested: Control systems tested: Control systems tested: Effective Most expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land.
Many quantifiable errors are the result of inaccuracies in the beneficiaries' applications, the most common of which is excessive area data (see example).
Example: Overdeclarations – Application for aid for non-eligible areas In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania*, some areas declared as permanent pasture for which payments were made were in fact covered in full or in part with non-eligible vegetation (density of bushes or trees).
No EU aid should have been paid for these areas which are not eligible for aid.
In Greece, this error occurred because such land was classified as eligible grassland and was included in the agricultural parcel identification system accordingly. * Note on the indication of Member States in the examples: the sample approach used by the Court does not assess operations every year in each Member State, recipient country and/or region.
Examples of errors should illustrate the most common types of errors.
They do not form the basis for conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned.
In all the EAGF direct aid schemes, the beneficiaries of EU aid are legally obliged to "compliance with other commitments" (cross compliance) relating to environmental protection, human, animal and animal health, and the preservation of land in good agricultural and environmental conditions.
Where farmers fail to comply with these obligations, their aid shall be reduced.
In the course of its audits, the Court found breaches of 25 % of the operations related to those obligations.
In the case of a significant number of error cases, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before the Commission had requested a refund.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2,5 %.
The Court's investigation of the integrated management and control systems (IPCoS) in four Member States (Germany, Ireland, France and Italy) revealed weaknesses in the management control procedures and the quality of the databases in three Member States (Ireland, France and Italy), weaknesses in the quality of on-the-spot checks in two Member States (Germany and Italy), weaknesses in the recovery procedures in two Member States (Ireland and Italy).
Despite the deficiencies detected during the examination, the IACOS contributes significantly to the prevention of errors in the expenditure covered by this system.
In the Member States that joined the EU in 2004 or later, producer groups in the fruit and vegetable sector can receive EU aid.
Certain conditions must be met for recognition as a producer group as regards the number and relative size of the member producers.
The Court found that nine out of the 40 producer groups examined in Poland did not meet these conditions.
In its 2013 Annual Activity Report, the Commission reported that it had reserved a risk amount of 25% of the total expenditure under the measure in question in Poland.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations: ο The Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the potential of the IACS is fully exploited; for example, they should ensure that the eligibility and size of the agricultural parcels are properly assessed and covered. ο The Commission should monitor the remedies related to the shortcomings of EU aid for producer groups in Poland. Do you want to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on market support and direct payments in the agricultural sector can be found in Chapter 3 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
22 This expenditure covers the policy areas "Rural Development", "Climate and Environmental Policy", "Maritime Affairs and Fisheries", and "Health and Consumer Protection".
Of the payments in this area, 88% are from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with the Member States.
The EAFRD will co-finance rural development expenditure in the relevant programmes of the Member States.
Expenditure covers land-related measures (such as agri-environmental payments and compensation payments to farmers in areas with natural handicaps) and non-area-related measures (such as modernisation of agricultural holdings and basic services to the rural economy and the population).
Yes Estimated error rate: 6.7% (2012: 7.9%) Control systems under investigation: Conditional effect Most errors were due to the fact that the eligibility conditions were not met: in particular, the following conditions: agri-environmental obligations (see example), special requirements for investment projects and public procurement rules.
Example: non-compliance with agri-environmental obligations A farmer in Sardinia (Italy) received compensation for the non-use of environmentally harmful plant protection products in the cultivation of artichokes.
In its on-the-spot checks, the Court found that the beneficiary had used such plant protection products 12 times during the period under review.
Therefore, the payment of aid was not considered.
Similar cases of non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments have also been identified in the Piedmont region (Italy) and in Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania.
A closer look at revenue and expenditure sectors 23 In the event of a significant number of error cases, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before the Commission had been asked for a refund.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2.0 %.
The Court's analysis of the control systems for rural development revealed the following: ο weaknesses in the controls on the conditions of aid, for example, non-recovery of non-eligible VAT amounts or the risk of double financing (in seven of the eight Member States investigated – Germany, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Malta, Romania and Slovenia; Poland was the exception); ο inadequate assessment of the plausibility of costs (in all four of the Member States examined – Italy, Latvia, Poland and Romania); ο inadequacies in the design and implementation of cross compliance controls (in all four of the Member States examined – the Czech Republic, Spain, Italy and Malta); in accordance with the cross-compliance obligations, beneficiaries must meet special conditions, such as environmental and social standards in order to qualify for aid; ο weaknesses in the control of award rules (in all three of the Member States examined – Italy, Latvia and Poland; see, for example).
For example, insufficient controls on the procurement rules by the Member State In Latvia, the paying agency was the beneficiary of EAFRD aid of EUR 2 million to finance its outsourced IT system, which was subject to public procurement rules.
The Court noted that several serious errors had occurred in the procurement process for the IT system and the subsequent data banks.
For example, instead of an open or open procedure, as provided for in the legislation, the paying agency applied a negotiation procedure.
As a result of non-compliance with the procedures, expenditure is not eligible for EU funding.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations for rural development: ο The Member States should improve the implementation of their existing administrative controls by making use of all relevant information available to the paying agencies.
In this way, most of the errors could be identified and corrected. ο Member States should ensure that the Action Plans to address the high estimated level of the rural development budget include all regions and take into account all measures, in particular investment measures, and that they take into account the Commission and the Court's audit findings. More details of the revenue and expenditure areas of regional policy, transport and energy EUR 45.5 billion Subject of our audit 24 This audit covered regional policy (which accounts for 96% of payments in this area of expenditure), mainly financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF).
The aim of regional policy is to strengthen economic and social cohesion in the European Union by reducing the disparities in development between the different regions.
Regional policy expenditure is subject to shared management by the Commission and Member States, and projects are co-financed under approved expenditure programmes.
The remaining 4 % of this audited expenditure is accounted for by transport and energy policies.
Transport and energy policy aims to provide European citizens and businesses with safe, sustainable and competitive transport and energy systems and services.
These expenditure shall be managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Most likely estimated error rate: 6.9% (2012: 6.8%) Control systems under investigation: Control systems under investigation: Conditionally effective The Court found serious errors in the award of public contracts, which represent 39% of the Court's estimated error rate.
The cumulative contract value of the 122 audited procurement procedures is estimated at EUR 4.2 billion.
Example: Unjustified free-hand contracts for additional construction work at the passenger terminal at an airport in Germany were awarded free-hand to the original contractor.
This additional work was necessary because of the work being done, the planning and implementation of the project, and not due to unforeseen circumstances.
In such cases, a free-hand award is inadmissible, so the additional work should have been advertised.
Similar cases of unjustified hands-free procurement were identified in projects in Belgium, the Czech Republic, elsewhere in Germany, Spain, Italy and Sweden.
More detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure 25 The Court's auditors are also examining whether EU state aid rules are being complied with.
Illegal State aid confers an unjustified advantage on the beneficiary bodies and therefore affects the internal market.
Errors related to State aid accounted for 17% of the estimated error rate in this area (see example).
For example, State aid for a profitable project for a small or medium-sized enterprise (SMEs) in Slovenia has been granted for research and development in the automotive industry.
However, the SME was entirely owned by large companies, and carried out its research activities exclusively for them.
As more stringent rules on public financing apply to large companies, the company was not entitled to the total funding.
Similar cases were found in Bulgaria and Hungary.
In the case of a significant number of error-related transactions, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before a request had been made to the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 3,9 %.
The Court's auditors also noted that in 2013 financial instruments continued to receive reduced quotas for disbursements to final beneficiaries.
The funds concerned will support companies or urban development projects through equity investments, loans or guarantees.
The funds will be allocated when their legal structure has been established and will be used to support projects.
A total of 940 financial instruments have been set up in 25 Member States with a budget of around EUR 12.6 billion.
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should require the Member States to ‐ explicitly confirm the effectiveness of the primary controls carried out by the managing authority and the certifying authority in their administrative declarations. ο The Commission should carry out a thorough evaluation of the continuing problem of primary controls carried out by authorities in Member States during the 2007-2013 programming period, as required by the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should analyse the reasons for the frequency of infringements of EU state aid rules. ο The Commission should reduce the continuing delays in the payment of EU funds through financial instruments. ο Would you like to know more?
The Court's full information on the audit of EU expenditure on regional policy, transport and energy can be found in Chapter 5 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Further analysis of the income and expenditure sectors of employment and social affairs 16.2 billion euros Subject matter of our review 26 The review covered the expenditure area of employment and social affairs, which forms part of the EU's cohesion policy.
The main objectives of spending in this area are to combat unemployment, to develop human resources and to promote integration into the labour market.
Employment and social policy is mainly implemented through the European Social Fund (ESF): 98% of the payments made in 2013 in this area of expenditure were to the detriment of the Fund.
The ESF supports investment in human capital in the form of training and other employment measures.
In a private school in Portugal, the full salary of the school director was charged to the EU project, although he had other tasks to perform.
Furthermore, the ceiling for the cofinancing of salaries has not been respected.
The Court also found similar findings in projects in Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
In the event of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before the Commission had been requested to obtain it.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure had been reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 1.8%.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 27 On the recommendation of the Court and with the aim of reducing the likelihood of errors and the administrative burden on the promoters, the application of lump sums and flat rates was extended in 2009 instead of the reimbursement of ‘actual costs'.
In its 2013 audit, the Court did not detect quantifiable errors in relation to the application of lump sums and lump sums.
This suggests that projects whose costs are reported using such payment options are less error-ridden.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission the following: ο The Commission should invite Member States to step up controls on procurement rules, non-project-related costs, or projects without EU added value. ο The Commission should ensure that Member States address the problem that, for EU projects, staff costs are claimed at higher rates than for projects financed by national funds. ο The Commission should ensure that Member States have taken into account all the simplification options provided by the regulations for the European Structural and Investment Funds for the 2014-2020 period. Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on employment and social affairs can be found in Chapter 6 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the 2013 budget.
28 This expenditure covers expenditure on external relations, development and humanitarian assistance, and measures for candidate and candidate countries.
Development projects are spread across more than 150 countries around the world and implementation bodies vary considerably in size and experience.
The support for projects from EU funds is conditional on compliance with conditions set out in specific financing agreements, as well as with other provisions, for example with regard to tendering and procurement procedures.
Expenditure is managed either directly by the Commission's Directorates-General – by the Commission's central services in Brussels or the EU delegations in the recipient countries – or jointly with international organisations.
Yes Estimated error rate: 2.6% (2012: 3.3%) Control systems under investigation: Estimated effectiveness Most errors related to non-eligible expenditure incurred at the level of the final beneficiaries, such as expenditure incurred outside the eligibility period, the inclusion of non-eligible expenditure in the expenditure items of the project (e.g. VAT, non-eligible personnel costs or overheads) and to non-eligible supporting expenditure.
The Commission validated pre-accession expenditure for a total of EUR 150 million, although it was not confirmed by evidence that the expenditure was incurred and eligible.
The validated amounts were based on Commission estimates rather than on incurred, paid and accepted costs, backed up by relevant evidence.
After the Court found this systematic error, the Commission corrected the transactions in the accounts in question.
Example: Unpaid expenditure The Commission signed an agreement of 9.5 million euros with the United Nations Development Programme to promote social development in Moldova.
In 2013, the Commission accepted contracts worth EUR 1.8 million for reimbursement for which no underlying expenditure had yet been incurred.
A closer look at revenue and expenditure areas 29 Commission Directorate-General EuropeAid manages the bulk of EU expenditure in the area of the external action of the budget.
The EuropeAid systems examined are assessed as conditionally effective.
In May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main identified shortcomings.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that the Commission ensure that the instructions to staff indicate that the final management of expenditure should be based on expenditure actually incurred and should not be based on own estimates.
The Commission has already agreed to an amendment to its final implementation procedure. Would you like to know more?

30 The main component of this expenditure area is research and innovation projects, which, in 2013, accounted for €7.7 billion in payments.
The other internal policies concern spending on a number of policy objectives, including education and culture, security, migration, and addressing the consequences of the financial crisis.
Most of the expenditure is managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated error rate: 4.6% (2012: 3.9%) Control systems under investigation: Ineffective with most payments in this area of expenditure, the Commission reimburses the costs claimed by recipients in project cost statements.
Errors arise when beneficiaries report ineligible costs which are not detected by the control systems prior to reimbursement by the Commission.
35 % of the estimated error rate is due to incorrectly calculated or ineligible personnel costs.
For example, the estimated and not the actual personnel costs and working hours, which were not used for the project, are claimed.
Apart from non-compliance with expenditure rules, the reimbursement of non-eligible costs is also hampered by the successful implementation of policy objectives, thus limiting the added value of EU support (see example).
Example: Ineligible expenditure reduces EU added value The EU provides funding to ensure efficient and effective controls at EU external borders.
The Court examined a project in Spain consisting in the purchase of four helicopters, which were to be used 75% for the surveillance and control of the external borders.
However, the Court found that only 25% of the hours of operations of the helicopters accounted for that purpose.
As a result, the EU should have paid a mere 25%, not the 75% actually taken over, of the costs of the helicopters.
More detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure 31 In the framework of the control system for research expenditure, the Commission monitors progress reports and cost statements on funded projects before payments are made.
The Court noted that the Commission did not always apply the procedures in a uniform manner, which could impair the efficiency of the programmes and increase the administrative burden on the beneficiaries.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission the following: ο The Commission should provide the beneficiaries and the authorities in the Member States with timely, coherent and clear guidance on eligibility rules and control rules for the new research programmes in the period 2014-2020 (Horizon 2020) and other internal policies. ο The Commission should make its control activities more risk orientated by focusing on high risk beneficiaries (e.g. less experienced bodies) and reducing the burden of control on less-risk beneficiaries.

In the context of the EDF, the European Union provides resources for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and the overseas countries and territories (OCT) States (OCTs).
It also aims to promote sustainable development and the integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the global economy.
The EDFs are funded by the Member States and are subject to their own financial regulation and are managed by the European Commission outside the EU's general budget.
The environment in which external assistance financed by the EDF is implemented is at high risk, in particular by the fact that the activities are geographically scattered and that the partner countries do not have sufficient institutional and administrative capacity.

Yes Estimated error rate: 3.4% (2012: 3.0%) Failure to comply with procurement rules was the cause of around half of the estimated error rate (see example).
Another significant source of error is the lack of evidence to support expenditure.
Example: non-compliance with the procurement rules by the beneficiary The Court examined the tender for IT equipment for a business information centre, financed by a micro and small business support programme.
The examination showed that the contract was not awarded to the tenderer with the lowest price offer, although the lowest price was the award criterion.
The error was not detected by the auditor who conducted the programme in accordance with the relevant framework contract with the Commission in the audit of the accounts.
A closer look at the revenue and expenditure sectors 34 A budget allocation from the EDF will also be granted where payments are directly entered in the budget of a developing country, provided that specific conditions are met.
The Court noted errors in transactions relating to budget support where the fulfilment of the conditions had been misassessed and where the wrong exchange rate was applied to the conversion of the payment into the local currency.
The Commission's Directorate-General for EuropeAid manages not only the bulk of the expenditure on external assistance from the EU budget but also almost all expenditures effected under the European Development Fund (EDF).
EuropeAid's systems under investigation are considered to be sufficiently effective.
However, in May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main shortcomings identified.

Background information 35 The audit approach at a glance The Court's audit opinions in the context of the Statement of Assurance are based on objective evidence obtained, in particular through audit procedures conducted in accordance with international audit principles.
The EU budget is complex.
The Commission's Directorates-General annually arrange hundreds of thousands of entries based on data from many different sources (including the Member States).
The Court considers that, in order to determine whether the underlying underlying transactions are in fact in fact and correctly recorded, and in order to determine whether they represent the financial situation in an appropriate way, it is necessary to determine whether the underlying transactions are in fact in fact recorded and recorded in the financial statements. The Court considers that, in the light of the statistical methods used, sampling of transactions is to be used by the Court's auditors as the basis for in-depth audits.
1 Payments recorded as expenditure are intermediate payments, final payments, and advances invoiced.
The implementation of the EU budget will provide millions of payments to beneficiaries within the EU and the rest of the world.
Most of these expenditures are managed by the Member States.
In order to obtain the necessary evidence, the Court conducts direct audits of revenue and expenditure and assesses the systems by which the payments are processed and controlled.
Further information on the audit process with regard to the establishment of the Statement of Assurance can be found in Annex 1.1 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Background information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the independent audit body of the European Union, based in Luxembourg.
It employs around 900 staff from all EU nationalities, made up of auditors and staff in horizontal services.
Since its establishment in 1977, it has raised awareness of the importance of EU financial management and has contributed to its improvement.
The Court's audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
Our results are used to hold the authorities responsible for the EU's financial management accountable, in particular in the discharge procedure.
This is mainly the Commission, but it also affects the other EU institutions, bodies and agencies.
Member States also play an important role in shared management.
Our main tasks are: ο audits of accounting and compliance audits, mainly with regard to the Statement of Assurance; ο accounting audits on subjects selected so that, with our work, we can achieve the greatest possible effect; ο opinions on legislation concerning budgetary management and other important issues.
We strive to use our resources to strike a balance between our various fields of activity in order to achieve sound results and to cover the different areas of the EU budget in an appropriate way.
Background information 38 Our findings We present the following results: ο Annual reports on the EU general budget and the European Development Funds; the annual reports mainly include the audit opinions issued under the statement of assurance and the audit results and will be published annually in November; ο Special annual reports on the audit opinions issued by the various EU agencies and agencies; 53 reports to be published in 2014; ο Special reports on selected audit topics published over the year; these mainly include economic audits; approximately 25 reports to be published in 2014; ο Opinions to be published by the European Parliament and the Council in the adoption of EU legislation with significant implications for financial management; ο Six opinions to be published in 2014; ο Landscape analyses on selected areas of EU policy in which the major challenges and long-term trends will be analysed; ο Annual activity report, information and explanations on our activities in the year under review.
Through our work, we contribute to raising awareness about EU financial management and to increasing transparency in this area, by providing a guarantee of financial management and by making recommendations for further improvements.
This is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union.
Information on the Court's audits of the agencies and other decentralised bodies of the European Union can be found on the specific annual reports on the financial year 2013, available on the Court's website.
The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the EU - custodians of EU finances In its annual reports on the EU budget and the European Development Funds, the Court gives an audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This briefing provides an overview of the main findings and conclusions.
The full text of the reports is available on the Court's website and will be published in the Official Journal of the European Union.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) Union competence under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) Responsibilities of the Agency (Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council; Commission Regulation (EU) No 838/2010; Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) Responsibilities and activities The European Parliament and the Council shall, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, adopt the measures for the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the establishment and functioning of the internal market.
The Union's energy policy, in a spirit of solidarity between Member States in the context of the achievement or functioning of the internal market and taking into account the need to preserve and improve the environment, pursues the following objectives: (a) to ensure the functioning of the energy market; (b) to ensure the security of energy supply in the Union; (c) to promote energy efficiency and savings, and to develop new and renewable energy sources; and (d) to promote the interconnection of energy networks.
The European Parliament and the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, shall adopt the measures necessary to achieve the objectives.
These measures shall be adopted after consultation of the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.
Objectives The Agency's objective is to assist national regulatory authorities to perform the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and, where necessary, to coordinate their actions.
Tasks - supplementing and coordinating the work of national regulatory authorities - participating in the drafting of rules for European networks - in certain circumstances of binding individual decisions on the modalities of access and operational security of cross-border infrastructures, - advising the European institutions on energy-related issues, - monitoring and reporting of energy market developments, - drawing up a proposal addressed to the Commission on the annual compensation amount for cross-border infrastructures in the framework of the ITC mechanism, - cooperation with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities for the monitoring of wholesale energy markets, - assessing the functioning and transparency of different categories of markets and different types of trade, - issuing recommendations to the Commission in relation to market rules, records of transactions, trading orders, standards and procedures to improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.
The Board of Directors Composition: The Board has two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Each member shall have an alternate.
Tasks: The Management Board shall adopt the Agency's annual work programme, adopt its budget and monitor its implementation.

1 2 year Court observations Progress of the corrective measure (completed/in progress/outgoing/outgoing/outstanding) 2012 The Agency has carried over to the following year commitments of EUR 1.7 million of the Agency's budget of Title II (buildings of the Agency and ancillary costs) (this corresponds to 81 % of the total budget committed under Title II) to the following year.
These transfers are mainly linked to the ongoing implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
As these implementing measures are part of the operational activities of the Agency, they would have been included in the budget under Title III.

Completed 2012 At the end of the year, the Agency had EUR 4.2 million in cash, including the 2011 budget surplus of EUR 1.6 million, resulting from an excessive budget call in 2011, the amount of which was recovered by the Commission in January 2013.

EN 1.12.2016 Official Journal of the European Union C 449/17 REPORT on the Agency's 2015 annual accounts for the cooperation of energy regulators, together with the Agency's response (2016/C 449/02) INTRODUCTION 1. The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), also located in Ljubljana, was created by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council (1).

COMMENTS ON THE BUDGETARY CURRENCY 18. The Agency transferred EUR 4.9 million and 86 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: EUR 1.4 million and 59 %).
As in previous years, these transfers were mainly in connection with the implementation of the REMIT regulation on integrity and transparency of the energy wholesale market(7) and amounted to 4.7 million euros in 2016 (2015: 1.1 million euros).
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency transferred EUR 1 million or 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million and 35% respectively).
19. The increase in transfers of funds is of concern and is contrary to the budgetary principle of the principle of annuality.
The higher transfer rate is directly linked to the conclusion or signing of procurement procedures and procedures at the end of the year, leading to a transfer of supplies and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 units were signed in November and December (5 976 122.47 euros and 40 % of the total value of the units closed in 2016 respectively).
The Agency may make use of separate budgets to better reflect the multi-annual nature of the activities as well as the inevitable divergences between signings, deliveries and payments.

At the European Council meeting of 29 October 1993 it was decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki.
In order to facilitate this move, certain changes have been made to the conditions of employment of the staff, some of which were not in accordance with the existing regulations.
The precise circumstances are explained in paragraphs 46 - 66.
In addition, a number of other cases where payments were not fully in line with existing regulations have been identified.

General comments Background 6. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No. 337/75 as the European Community's satellite body and is intended to promote vocational training at Community level.
Cedefop began its work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995.
The purpose of this Regulation is to "support the Commission to promote and promote vocational training and continuing training at Community level", to contribute "to the implementation of a common vocational training policy", and to promote "exchange of information and experience".
In the field of vocational training, the Centre has, in particular, the task of 'producing documentation, contributing to the development and coordination of research, ensuring the dissemination of appropriate documentation and information, promoting and supporting initiatives in order to achieve a coordinated solution (especially in the area of coordination of training levels and mutual recognition of certificates) and of a meeting place for the parties concerned'. 8. The Centre is managed by a Board of Directors of 48 members (costs of ECU 334 000 in 1995 in this regard). (i) Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75, published on 13 February 1975, OJ 1975, p.
The Management Board shall elect from among its members a Chairperson and three Vice-Chairpersons for a period of one year.
At the time of the audit (May 1996), the Chair of the Administrative Council was held by the Director General of DG XXII — Education, Training and Youth.
The Director of the Centre shall be appointed by the Commission on the basis of a list of candidates submitted by the Board of Directors.
9. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Director shall be responsible for the daily management of the Centre, while the Administrative Board shall be responsible for the overall management of the Centre.
The Management Board shall take decisions, adopt the work programme and the annual report, draw up the revenue and expenditure plan for the previous year and estimate the revenue and expenditure for the coming year.
The Commission's role, under the basic regulation, is not only to represent the Commission's senior officials within the Management Board, but also to adopt the work programme, to examine the annual report and the revenue and expenditure plan, and to forward the estimates of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament.
Article 23 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 * of 30 June 1993, requires all the Centre's commitments and payments prior to the actual payment (a) to receive a reasonable cost-benefit-benefit-benefit-benefit of the budget expenditure to support Cedefop; (b) to make the most efficient use of human resources and resources; (c) to provide high-quality products which meet the needs of Cedefop's clients; (d) to provide a clear and coherent role within the framework of the European Community's vocational training policy.
Financial data 14. For the 1995 financial year the Centre had a budget of ECU 16.50 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 10.11 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 4.67 million, the remainder being cancelled at ECU 1.72 million.
On the basis of the previous year's appropriations carried over, 2,16 million ECU was disbursed and 0,29 million ECU was cancelled. of the previous year's appropriations, 2,16 million ECU disbursed and 0,29 million ECU cancelled.
Annex 1 to this report gives an analysis of the use made of appropriations for the financial year and the appropriations carried over from the 1994 financial year.
Annex 2 gives an overview of the budget accounts for the financial year 1995 and of the balance sheet of assets and liabilities as at 31 December 1995.
Comments on the implementation of the budget Separate activities 15. Following the move to Thessaloniki, the Centre had not yet implemented adequate procedures for the separation of the activities of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the imprest administrator until the date of the audit (May 1996).
Thus, it was observed, for example, that the accounting officer was involved in the accounting of the imprest administrator.
Payments made without the approval of the financial controller are still high (in 1995 the figure was 60% without the salaries).
The strong use of the paying agency procedure is not in line with the spirit of the financial rules.
A more acceptable practice would be to handle only current expenditures and expenditures in a small amount, where the risk of irregularities is comparatively low, through the paying agency.
Transfers within the budget 17. Transfers between the various budget lines amounted to ECU 922,000 in 1995, i.e. 5.6 % of the initial budget compared to 10.9% in 1994.
13.3.97 transfers (ECU 570 000) were carried out in the last two months of 1995, while in 1994 the share was 33%.
18. The Centre did not make any transfers of funds between different titles in 1995.
Thus the remark made by the Court last year (2) was taken into account.
Transfers and cancellations of appropriations 19. The practice of transferring large amounts of funds already observed in previous years3 continued to increase in 1995.
In 1995, only 61% of the final available appropriations were disbursed compared with 73% in 1994.
The proportion of commitments carried over to 1996 was 28% (compared to 23% in 1994).
The proportion of decommissioned appropriations was 10%, compared with 5% in 1994.
Table 1 shows by title the appropriations carried over from the original 1995 budget and their subsequent use.
The transfers in the field of operational expenditure amounted to 53% of the initial appropriations compared to 40% in 1994.
As 8% of operational expenditure fell, the Centre paid out only 39% of its 1995 operational budget in 1995.
At the end of the first quarter of 1996, only 34% of the appropriations carried over from 1995 had been disbursed under Title 3.
As the budget and the cancellation of appropriations, and the size of the transfers to the next financial year, the high number of transfers of appropriations within the budget and appropriations, suggest that the work programme was not carried out as planned and that the principles of financial management were put at risk.
This fact and the lack of staff (see paragraphs 42 to 45) will have serious implications for the implementation of the 1996 budget.
The first tranche of ECU 2 300 000 was paid on 6 February 1995, followed by further tranches of ECU 2 400 000 on 20 April 1995, of ECU 2 500 000 on 28 June 1995, of ECU 2 800 000 on 5 October 1995, of ECU 5 875 000 on 22 November 1995 and of ECU 525 000 on 1 December 1995.
As in previous years (4), this rate of payment is not in line with the Court's annual report for 1994.
(3) Annual reports of the Court on the 1992 financial year, 1993 with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation of the Centre, according to which payments are to be made in the first half of each quarter and are to be adapted to actual needs.
Expenditure 23. After a decision had been taken to move the Centre to Thessaloniki, a new Deputy Director was appointed in 1994, who at that time lived and worked in Thessaloniki.
Staff moved to Berlin to receive a grant of two times their basic salary. Not even a year later, that is, after the move of the centre to Thessaloniki, the same staff again received a grant of two times their basic salary.
Since the transfer of the Centre was rapid, the duration of the stay of the operator concerned was only short (11 months) in Berlin; in addition, he spent part of this time in Thessaloniki, also receiving the full daily allowances (including the weekends) and the Court considers that these decisions are not in line with the principle of sound financial management and are contrary to Cedefop's principles.
24. The contract of another deputy director, who had already moved from Berlin to Madrid in July 1995', was approved by the Board of Directors with effect from 3 January 1995.
This staff member received a payment of ECU 71 030.
The Court considers that this decision of the Board of Directors does not comply with the principles of the economic management of the budget.
25. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993, allows the award of a contract by the public of a contract where the total of the contract does not exceed the amount of ECU 12 000.
At least 12 cases have been declared in respect of an amount greater than ECU 12 000 without respect for the procurement procedure described in Article 45 of the said Regulation.
In the last two months of 1995, almost 40% of the commitments for the 'pilot studies and projects' budget for the 1995 budget (ECU 300 000) were made.
An amount of ECU 150 572 was committed to the expenditure of the 'exchange of officials and experts' budget line for the remuneration of an expert who began his work at Cedefop on 1 February and for another expert whose contract was signed on 22 December 1995.
These commitments have been overburdened in order not to overburden the funds.
27. The rent for Cedefop's temporary premises for January 1996 (22 750 ECU) was already included in the 1995 budget.
Since these expenditures relate to the 1996 financial year, they should also have been recorded for the 1996 financial year, and for 1994.
The Court urges the Centre to draw up an up-to-date inventory as soon as possible, as required by Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993.
29. The balance sheet shall show an outstanding amount of ECU 3 134 of outstanding outstanding claims from the preceding financial year for an invoice issued in 1991.
The Court's comment made last year (5) was not taken into account, although the Centre had given a corresponding assurance in its reply.
The Court recommends that the Centre depreciate this amount until there is reason to believe that this amount will be recovered.
30. At the end of the year the Centre had a remaining cash equivalent of ECU 5.9 million.
The Centre is therefore responsible for the management of large amounts of cash, although it has little expertise in this area.
The Court reiterates its observation, made last year,6that this situation should be avoided by adapting the Centre's quarterly retrieving of funds to the Commission's actual cash requirements. The Commission should also ensure that the Centre receives a realistic cash preview before making its payments.
General comments ^B 31. At the European Council of 29 October 1993 it was decided to move Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki in Greece (7).
32. The actual transfer to Thessaloniki took place in August 1995, and in September 1995 the Centre began its activities in Greece.
According to the Court's calculations, the 1995 budget accounts contain some ECU 3 300 000 for the expenditure related to the move.
33. Since 1 September 1995, the Centre has been housed in a building of the Institute of Agriculture and Industry of Thessaloniki.
No later than 1 September 1999, the Greek State will provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation facility.
The Centre has signed four agreements--(i) Annual report of the Court for the 1994 financial year.
(6) Annual report of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 1994.
(7) Council Decision 93/C 323/01 of 29 October 1993, OJ C 323 of 30.11.1993, p. 1.
The basic agreement between Cedefop and the Greek State was signed in Thessaloniki on 22 June 1995.
The three other agreements, including an agreement between the Greek State and the whole construction organisation, form part of this basic agreement.
Provisional accommodation 34. An annual rent of 273,000 ECU is payable directly to the owner of the provisional building of the Centre.
35. In accordance with Article 1 of the Agreement between the Greek State and the Centre, the Greek State shall make the building with the provisional premises, including all the associated installations, available to Cedefop from 1 September 1995.
The Greek authorities are responsible for electrical and electronic cable connections and for telephone connections.
36. At the handover of the building, the Centre did not raise any written objections.
However, during the first four months of Thessaloniki (September to December 1995), the Centre had to invest ECU 120 000 to make the temporary premises of the building workable.
One of the reasons for this was the need to install electronic and electrical cable connections and telephone connections.
37. These investments were fully supported by the Centre and the corresponding costs were included in the 1995 budget.
The agreements do not give a clear statement as to who is responsible for these investments.
Final accommodation 38. The Greek State is obliged to provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation building by 1 September 1999 at the latest.
Cedefop will pay the Greek State a total amount of 6 879 750 ECU for the construction of the building, which will be paid in four equal instalments of 1 719 937 ECU each.
The first three tranches were set at 1 September 1995, 1 September 1996 and 1 September 1997.
The final instalment shall be paid at the final handover of the building.
The Centre has not ensured that these payments are linked to the actual progress of the works.
The Centre will have paid ECU 5 159 811 more than two years before the building was handed over.
The Court recommends the Centre to ensure that the interest is used for the first tranche for the benefit of the Community.
No. C 81/6 EN.E.K. Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 41. The Centre should make sure that the Employee Accommodation Organization (O.E.K.) is responsible for the overall implementation of the work undertaken by Cedefop.
Staff: General remarks 42. The 1995 establishment plan provides for 79 posts, of which 24À,11LA,15B,26Cund3D. At the time of the audit (May 1996) 37 actually worked for Cedefop (14 A, 7 B, 14 C and 2 D), 11 had been taken over by other EU institutions, 14 had left the centre before moving to Thessaloniki and 17 had had had been left to stay in Berlin.
In 1995 and 1996, many new employees had to be recruited, and this development will continue in 1996.
43. The 17 remaining persons in Berlin are free to work for public and private institutions or other EU institutions, and continue to receive their salary for up to a maximum of 18 months, depending on their seniority at Cedefop (each service is equivalent to one month's salary and the minimum service period must be 6 months).
At the end of this period, the parties concerned may either move to Thessaloniki or seek another solution.
This situation has resulted in Cedefop not being able to fill these 17 posts (May 1996) because they are blocked in the budget and cannot be filled, because the situation may be in the future and they will be able to move to Thessaloniki.
44. It is unclear what is to happen to those of this group of 17 persons who do not wish to move to Thessaloniki after the specified duration of their stay in Berlin.
Article 20 of the Staff Regulations provides that 'the official must take the place of his official's official's place of employment or at such distance from that place of residence that he is not disabled in the performance of his duties'.
Nevertheless, three cases of staff who were not prepared to move to Thessaloniki have already been brought to the EU Court of Justice.
45. This situation, where 17 important items in the budget are blocked by staff members who are not currently working for Cedefop, had a significant impact on the Centre's work already in 1995 and will continue to do so in 1996 and 1997.
Staff: Amendment of Article 13 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 of 10 February 1975, as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995, reads: "The staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Centre shall exercise over its staff the powers delegated to the Appointing Authority.
The Management Board of the Centre shall, after consulting the Commission, lay down the corresponding implementing rules."
Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 also repeals Council Regulation (ECSC, EEC, Euratom) No 1859/76 of 29 June 1976 laying down the conditions of employment for the staff of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training.
The amendment was necessary in order to "consistently manage the staff of the various decentralised bodies at Community level" (8).
While the Centre's staff have been appointed officials, the staff of the other decentralised bodies are, however, temporary staff.
47. The Court has examined the changes to the conditions of employment and other arrangements between the Board of Directors and the staff, and has found a number of irregularities, the most serious irregularities, from the Court's point of view, are described in paragraphs 49 to 66.
48. The Management Board has not submitted these arrangements to the financial controller in order to issue his endorsement.
However, all the appropriations resulting from these agreements were covered by the paying agency procedure and subsequently received the financial controller's endorsement.
The Centre has adopted the following measures to adapt the situation of its staff: — a first step to the appointment of all its staff members as temporary staff on 1 March 1995 (Article 2(b) of the Conditions of Employment of Other Officials of the European Communities) in the same grade and grade as staff in contract on 1 March 1995. — a second step to the appointment of its staff as EU officials on 1 April 1995 was the result of an internal selection procedure, which was ‘ar a) a result of certificates of competence'.
Infringement of the Staff Regulations of seniority in the initial appointment of Cedefop's former contract staff at the time of the appointment of seniority 50. In the initial appointment of Cedefop's contract staff at the time of the appointment of temporary staff on 1 March 1995, none of the staff should have been classified in a higher seniority than level 3 (or in step 4 in grade A 1 (8) Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 amending Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 on the establishment of Cedefop, fourth recital).

However, 33 of the 59 temporary staff members of Cedefop have been classified as higher than level 3.
The Centre published 15 linked job offers and announcements of internal competitions on 1 March 1995.
In accordance with the Staff Regulations, the purpose of an election procedure is to organise a competition between several candidates so that the vacancy can be filled with the best qualified candidates (Article 27(1) of the Staff Regulations).
A selection procedure is therefore by definition linked to a competitive situation and the risk of non-existence (10).
This means that appointments are to be regarded as illegal following a selection process that abuses of discretion are to be regarded as illegal ( n ).
The Commission's Legal Service reached the same conclusion as the Commission's note of 4 January 1995 as the Commission's Commission's notice of 4 January 1995 (c) (12).
57. Since the selection procedures concerned have been pursued with a different objective than the one set out in the Staff Regulations, it should be assumed that the selection procedures carried out by Cedefop have been subject to a misuse of discretion, which is why they should be regarded as illegal.
It is necessary to identify, in accordance with Article 31 of the Staff Regulations, the members of the staff of Cedefop to be appointed as officials as from 1 April 1995 as from: — officials in category A or in the category in which they were to be appointed — officials in category A or in the category in which they were to be appointed — officials in category A or in the category in which they were to be assigned (i.e. in category A or in category A or in category L) — officials of the other categories: officials in the category in which they were appointed or in the category in which they were appointed (i.e. in category Β 1, Β 3 or Β 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4) (Article 31, paragraph 2); — other members in the category in which they were appointed (i.e. in category Β 1, Β 3 or B 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4) with the exception, as far as half of the appointments, of other staff in the category in which they were to be appointed (Article 31, paragraph 2 b).
59. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, 32 out of 43 staff in a higher grade than the initial grade of their careers were appointed (13).

No. C 81/8 EN Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Failure to comply with probationary obligations 60. Before a member of staff can be appointed to a permanent official, he must be successful in completing a probationary period (Article 34 of the Staff Regulations), the probationary period must therefore be followed by an objective, retrospective probationary evaluation of the official.
61. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, the officials were informed, on trial, that their final appointment would take place; the trial period was clearly described in advance as necessary 'legal formalities', which were not really to be considered as a trial trial (paragraph 4.1 of the Framework Agreement, letter of 7 February 1995 to the officials on trial, the second subparagraph, and paragraph 1(f) of the Annex: the trial period is a legal formalities to be carried out as such by each official on probation). ·» Illegal secondment of the officials during the probation period 62. Article 38 of the Staff Regulations provides for secondment of officials to other institutions for their lifetime, i.e. officials who have already successfully completed the probation period.
65. This means that a system has been set up whereby up to 50% of the remuneration of staff is transferred to Thessaloniki in a currency to which a higher correction coefficient is applied (namely the correction coefficient of 111.4 %) is applied to Greece (a correction coefficient of 80.2% is applied to Greece ).
Irregularity with regard to other officials by introducing special mobility provisions 66. The Commission has committed itself to introducing specific provisions on mobility with regard to the Centre.
These provisions are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all officials.
Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 clearly provides that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants shall apply to the staff of the Centre.
This means that all the provisions contained therein shall apply to the staff of the Centre, including the point (c) of Article 29(1) of that Regulation, which concerns the taking over of officials by other institutions.
Thus, there is no justification for special treatment for mobility. Summary, 67. The Court's audit has shown that the Centre's work programme has not been carried out as planned, due to significant staff shortages.
This led to large-scale transfers and cancellations.
The audit has also shown that no functioning management and accounting procedures have yet been established.
68. Two Deputy Directors received remuneration equal to the basic salary for four months; these payments and a payment of ECU 71 030 to one of the Deputy Directors were not in line with sound financial management and the interests of the Centre.
69. At the time of the Court's examination, there were 79 approved posts, but only 37 were actually employed at the Centre.
17 officials had been appointed as EU officials,' although they had neither wanted to move to Thessaloniki nor had been taken over by another Community institution.
Conclusion 71. It is understandable that efforts have been made to keep staff in the institutions of the EU and to reduce the complexity of the move.
The problem is, however, that the regulatory framework, "within which the move had to be carried out, was not compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff, even after the changes to the employment conditions, and did not permit the smooth transfer of Cedefop to the staff without subordinating its activities.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 21 November 1996.
