The Management Board will follow the structure of the observations and conclusions of the Court of Auditors.
The Board of Directors has the right to expect that all institutions and decentralised institutions will be treated in the same way and on the basis of the same technical standards and procedures that ensure equal treatment.
The Management Board considers that the uniform presentation of the problems fails to mention the essential facts which could be summarised as follows: — The decision of the European Council of 29 October 1993 was taken without prior assessment of the effects of such a transfer.
At his first meeting with the staff, he expressed his firm determination to move to 1 September 1995, a timetable that CEDEFOP maintained despite the problems caused by the relocation of the Centre. — The Chairman of the Board of Directors sent a letter to the Commissioners responsible, Mr van Miert and Mr Ruberti.
On 18 November 1994 the Chairman and Vice-Chairmen of the Management Board of CEDEFOP were received by the members of the Commission.
The President urged the Commission to draw up accompanying social measures, in particular for those staff who were unable to leave Berlin.
In the light of the regulations in force, the Commissioners stated that they were prepared to examine the specific problems of some of the staff in a positive and pragmatic spirit.
They also expected this from the other institutions of the Community (European Parliament, Council, etc.) — the Administrative Council, at its meeting on 8 and 9 December 1994, was unable to decide on the date of the transfer, because it was not acceptable for the transfer of staff, who could not move to Thessaloniki, without simply dismissing a modern social plan.
At the same meeting, the Management Board instructed the Director to prepare a decision on the Management Council, to be taken at an extraordinary meeting on 27 January 1995, which provided for a socially acceptable transfer of the Centre to 1 September. "— In the second half of December 1994, the Council began to examine the Commission's proposal to amend Article 13 of the Regulation on CEDEFOP, which provided for the staff of the Centre to be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Director adopted this amendment on the basis of the formulation of the framework agreement on the social measures relating to the transfer of CEDEFOP to Thessaloniki.
On 23 January 1995, the framework agreement was signed with the staff.
The preparations were carried out in close cooperation with the European Commission, which proved to be very helpful throughout the transition period (1994 to 1996). — The Management Board decided to accept the framework agreement and to move the Centre to Thessaloniki on 1 September 1995.
Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/13
Under the framework agreement, staff who were unable to leave Berlin decided to make themselves available to other institutions of the EU or public/private organisations and to receive a salary from the Centre for a period of at least six months, with a monthly salary paid for each year started.
The principle of paying a monthly salary for each year of service largely corresponds to the social plans and usual procedures in Germany and neighbouring countries. — Early retirement was considered in 1995 for 17 employees (age over 55 with 10 years of service and age over 50 with 15 years of service).
These measures were not part of the framework agreement and were not proposed by the Commission following decisions of the Council of Ministers of 17 November 1995 to accept the'release' of officials in connection with the accession of new Member States only to officials of the European Parliament.
The Management Board will respond in more detail in its opinions on points 46-66.
In general, it should be stressed that the political aspects should be taken seriously and that subsequent criticism should be avoided.
The transfer of a complete Community body within the restrictive framework of a large number of different regulations and given a considerable amount of social and individual problems is truly unique in the history of the Community.
5. The Board of Directors will return below in this reply to the exception mentioned in the last sentence.
The costs of meetings of the Management Board in 1995 are due to the fact that two additional meetings (in January and June) had to be held in connection with the transfer.
Moreover, the meeting in December 1995 was costing higher costs due to the official start of activity in Greece.
Only two meetings are planned for 1996.
13. The Management Board regrets that the Court has not responded to the European Parliament's decision to postpone the discharge for the 1994 budget.
This raises serious questions as — the discharge for 1994 in the context of the Court of Auditors' report for 1994 and the Council's recommendation for granting discharge should be considered in accordance with the usual rules and procedures; — the assessment of the 1995 financial year by the European Parliament in the absence of a report by the Court of Auditors for 1995 on which the Management Board might have been able to give its opinion would result in the mixing of very different situations; — the Centre in 1995 was transferred to Greece.
The transfer was carried out smoothly and under acceptable conditions.
This transfer, due to the disruptions to which the staff members have been subjected, requires a transitional phase which can only be completed in 1997.
In this respect, there has been a marked improvement.
In the initial phase in Thessaloniki, staff helped each other in the completion of the work.
16. As pointed out last year, increased use of the paying agency procedure was made at the request of the financial controller, who justified this by the cost-benefit ratio.
The financial controller also had to act more frequently.
The use of the imprest account procedure for all expenditure which could require provisional commitments limited the administrative costs and avoided delays.
The situation is even more difficult due to the payment arrangements in Greece (most payments are made in cash or by cheque).
Invoices on which bank accounts are disclosed are rare and contractors collect their own claims.
The geographical distance to the financial controller and the lack of reliability of the mail delivery must also be taken into account.
In addition, DHL express deliveries may only be made once a week for cost reasons (3 000 Bfrs per shipment).
An amendment to the decision to set up the paying agency procedure will shortly be submitted to the Management Board to better take account of the Court of Auditors' wishes.
17. The transfers over the last two months are due to the need for optimum use of the budget (of which ECU 2 000 000 was deferred and was only released shortly before the Centre was transferred to Thessaloniki) and to the decision of the Governing Board (7/8.12.1995) to recruit national experts seconded to the Commission (including to advance the Centre's work).
19. The Management Board was aware that 1995 and 1996 would be years of transition and renewal.
A certain reduction in productivity is inevitable in this international relocation, which, in the opinion of the Board of Directors, has been carried out in an acceptable and smooth manner.
The Centre is still facing problems caused by the transition phase.
20. Since the centre was relocated with a greatly reduced number of employees, the work of the administration and of all other services slowed down.
For this reason, a non-automatic transfer of appropriations was requested and approved.
No C 81/14 D 不 Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 22. The Management Board notes that the Commission makes every effort to comply with the rules of Article 26 of the Financial Regulation for the Centre and to pay out the subsidy in accordance with the actual needs during the first two weeks of the quarter.
This was improved in 1995 compared to 1994.
However, due to the long internal procedures (in which the authorising authority, the financial controller and the accounting officer are involved) and the length of the bank's referral procedure, an overall delay in the processing period (on average 12 days in 1995) cannot be completely avoided.
Nevertheless, in 1995 three payments would have been made almost in accordance with the provisions of Article 26, since they arrived in the centre less than four days after the end of the first two weeks of the quarter.
If the processing period had been the same for all payments (between 9 and 22 days) as for the average period of 12 days, all payments would have been made in accordance with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation.
The first payment was not in line with the rules, but this payment must be preceded by the commitment of funds, which must take some time.
23. The deputy director moved from Thessaloniki to Berlin because there was uncertainty about the actual date of the transfer of the centre.
At the time of the appointment (1 October 1994) no decision had yet been taken on the date of the move (which could have been postponed even further).
It was hoped that his stay would be short, but his final duration was still unknown at that time.
For the usual family reasons, he moved to Berlin under the conditions of his status.
The daily allowances for missions were granted in accordance with the same procedure as for other servants.
As regards the second grant for the establishment, the Deputy Director paid the Centre back, although he would have had full entitlement, after the audit.
24. At its meeting in June 1995, the Management Board terminated its contract on 31 December 1995 and instructed the Director to implement this Decision and to arrange for payments to be made in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
The Management Board was pleased that the Deputy Director was prepared to participate in the implementation of the 1995 work programme and to support the Centre in its new start in Thessaloniki.
The compensation (payment of one third of the basic salary from the date of termination of the duty of service until the expiry of the contract) was in accordance with the contract and Article 47 of the CBSB.
25. In view of the difficulties of the initial phase and the large number of new contracts, the Centre was not able to carry out the usual tendering procedures in each case.
The call for tenders for longer-term contracts is currently under way or is planned for 1996.
In addition, in order to ensure balanced budgetary management in the course of the year, the Management Board will prefer to adopt the work programme in order to allow the services to have the necessary time for tenders, to make commitments, and to conclude the contracts in question during the first months of the financial year.
The 40 % of the commitments for the pilot studies and projects budget line (ECU 300 000) were made in the last few months of the year, reflecting the late release of appropriations in the 1995 budget by the budgetary authority and the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki.
The Centre had to act logically and consistently, and had no other choice, as it had to meet its financial obligations under Titles I and II and was only able to make further commitments under Title III after the funds had been decommissioned.
The possibility of seconding national experts was granted by the Management Board at its December 1995 meeting and could only be financed by the deferred funds.
The Director had to act quickly and within a short period of time to prevent funds (which became available very late) from falling.
The (Austrian) expert (who was officially supported by the government) was the subject of the application at the beginning of 1995.
27. The reason for recording rent for January 1996 in the 1995 financial statements was purely practical.
The contract states that the rent must be paid in advance in two instalments on 1 January and 1 July.
Since the first payment was only made in October 1995, and it would have been difficult to pay back immediately on 1 January 1996, the first payment was made for a period of five months including January 1996.
28. The inventory is being updated.
29. This will be met.
The Centre shall ensure that it submits to the Commission a realistic statement on cash flow.
The last payment in the year should be the largest since it should also be used to cover the first months of the following year, in which it is normally necessary to make larger payments.
The management of the Centre shall assess the costs of the transfer and assess the developments in order to gain a comprehensive picture of the costs and benefits of the transfer to Greece.
Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/15 36.-37.
Since it was expected that the Centre would resume its work immediately after the move, some additional investment and changes were needed.
As has been noted, the agreements do not give a clear statement of this, because the centre needed more power connections and stronger computer cables than the existing ones.
Other investments concerned additional security requirements and communications facilities, such as Europe by Satellite, in order to be able to receive broadcasts directly through the institutions.
However, the Centre has put questions concerning the provisional building on the agenda of the Steering Committee, which deals with the new and (if necessary) the provisional building.
The Management Board is aware that the content of the agreement on the new building entrusted the Greek Government with a great responsibility, which is currently in compliance with the agreement. The Board of Directors is aware of the fact that the content of the agreement on the new building entrusted the Greek Government with a great responsibility.
Two points are of particular concern: — ensuring the provision of a high-quality building at a reasonable price; — ensuring the timely completion of the building (if possible before 1 September 1998).
The fact that large payments were made in advance (half of the building has already been paid, although the construction work has not yet begun) can also have positive effects, since the actual construction work (after selecting the construction plan and the construction firm in October/November 1996) could advance rapidly due to the immediate availability of the necessary funds.
In general, the Board of Directors has fully understood the concerns of the Court, which have also been shared by Members of the European Parliament, Mr Kellet-Bowmann and Mr Tappin, who visited the Centre on 1 and 2 and on 14 and 15 May respectively.
The Management Board is prepared to act on this issue in accordance with the Commission's recommendations.
42. Due to the various social accompanying measures, the personnel situation was very complicated, but all the persons on the salary list of CEDEFOP who were not provided to other organisations or who were seconded to Berlin were working for CEDEFOP and its work programme.
43. The Management Board adopted the decision on the social measures relating to the transfer (Framework Agreement) in order to take measures to be adopted as soon as possible (see the declarations contained in the minutes of the Council).
The evaluation of measures must therefore take account of their political background.
The Centre is located in Thessaloniki, and the Board of Directors and the Director decide on the organisation of the work.
Obviously, some items are blocked, as long as the social accompanying measures are effective.
However, by the end of 1996 almost all the measures will end and CEDEFOP, with full capacity, will be able to operate on the basis of medium-term priorities (adopted by the Administrative Statistics in November 1996) and the 1997 work programme, which will also be based on these priorities.
CEDEFOP will therefore take a revitalised and new approach to the future from 1997 onwards.
44. Persons who, for social or personal reasons, cannot leave Berlin, when the specified duration of their stay in Berlin ends, have three alternatives.
In this respect, the President of the Court of First Instance declared three decisions rejecting the requests for transitional proceedings.
Such persons must move, withdraw from the service of the Centre or find solutions in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
45. The effects in 1996 are, of course, serious, but will be minimal after the first months of 1997.
The transfer had its consequences and costs.
However, when compared with a similar transfer at national level, such as that of the CEREQ (Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches sur les Qualifications) from Paris to Marseille (where only 21 of the 120 employees had moved with the Centre), the effects of an international transfer over a distance of almost 2 000 km had not been unduly negative to CEDEFOP.
Precautionary cost estimates indicate that cost neutrality will be achieved in 2000 and that work will be even more cost-efficient (mainly because of lower labour costs in Greece). 46.-66.
(a) As the Court points out in its conclusions (71) it is understandable that efforts have been made in support of the staff in order to encourage them to continue their activities for the EU institutions and in order to alleviate the difficult problems of relocation. (b) However, it is not the Board of Directors' failure to "contain the regulatory framework within which the relocation occurred [...] compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff and not allowing for a smooth transfer of CEDEFOP". (c) Following the Board's decision of 27 January 1995, on 6 February 1995 (Regulation (EC) No 251/95), the Council amended Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 in order that "the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and arrangements applicable to officials and other staff of the European Communities".
Council Regulation (EEC, ECSC, ECSC) No 269/68 (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the European Communities) (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the Communities of the European Communities)
(d) Since the Community legislation did not provide for transitional measures, the Management Board had no choice but to act on its own responsibility to safeguard the rights and interests of CEDEFOP staff.
(f) In view of these circumstances, the Management Board had the obligation to: — provide staff with a high level of safety with regard to their place of work (appointment to permanent staff), — ensure that their category, grade and step, and — assist staff wishing to find a different job. (g) The Management Board also wishes to point out that the posts approved by the budgetary authority of CEDEFOP were permanent posts.
(h) In addition, the wording of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 (the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities) clearly provides for the employment of officials.
Since the posts filled by the staff are of a permanent nature, the decision on the status of civil servants, rather than on temporary contracts, was appropriate and justified.
The Board of Directors would also like to comment on the specific points raised by the Court: 46. (last sentence) The Board of Directors had the choice to appoint its staff either as permanent officials or to offer them two-year contracts (see opinion (g) above).
It was considered unacceptable to require staff to move from Berlin to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract.
48. Although it is true that the Board of Directors has not officially submitted the declarations to the financial controller for approval, the latter has nevertheless been informed of the decisions taken.
At the time of signature of the agreement, the outstanding individual decisions of the staff members have not yet determined the exact financial impact of the agreement.
It provided a framework which provided the basis for individual decisions and which received the full approval of the financial controller during his visit to Berlin.
50-51.
In the light of the argument set out above (e), the decision taken (see remark, second indent) was the only possible one.
It was also in line with the Commission's clear statement (see last sentence of the declaration to the Council's Protocols in the Annex) 'that there must be no deterioration in the conditions of employment of CEDEFOP's staff'.
The considerations of the Commission's legal service, which are only partially quoted in paragraph 56, leave sufficient room for such a decision.
The Management Board reiterates that Article 29 of the Staff Regulations entitles the appointing authority to conduct internal selection procedures for the purpose of filling vacant posts in an institution (paragraph lb).
The competitions were conducted in full compliance with Annex III to the Staff Regulations.
The purpose and obligation of the Management Board was to ensure that the greatest possible number of CEDEFOP staff agreed to move to Thessaloniki.
It should be borne in mind that Regulation (EC) No 251/95 amended the rules applicable to staff with effect from 1 March 1995 and that the move to Thessaloniki took place in August of that year.
The Board's approach was based on the following considerations: — it was unthinkable to require the staff to move to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract (recital (g) and (46) above); — there was not enough time to carry out a general selection procedure before moving to Thessaloniki, and there was no realistic way of expecting the staff to move without a safe job.
3 3 97 I DE  ➀ Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/17 56.-59./ The Management Board has already explained (see above, remark below) that the move to Thessaloniki meant a sudden change in the place of employment, which inevitably caused social problems, and for a certain period of time impeded productivity.
In the case of the case of the case of the worker, to require the worker to move after the assignment of a low grade or step, the situation of the worker would have worsened even further.
The Commission's Legal Service's note, mentioned in paragraph 56, provides sufficient arguments in point (d) in order to justify the position adopted by the Centre. 60.-61.

62. According to note f), 3rd indent, above, the Management Board considered it to be its duty to help the staff in an acceptable manner.
This view was also taken by the Commission's Legal Service.
65. The provisions governing the transfer provisions of part of the remuneration allow for the possibility of increasing the percentage from 35 % to 50 % in individual cases in the event of justified reasons in accordance with Article 4 of the Regulation.
The framework agreement enabled the transfer of a higher percentage (> 35 % of the Staff Regulations, but < 50 %) in individual cases and for certain liabilities entered into before 29 October 1993 (the date on which the European Council decided to transfer the Centre).
The application of these rules is completely different in the case of CEDEFOP and concerns only a limited number of persons with high liabilities in Berlin.
66. The Management Board wishes to thank the Commission for the support it has provided in a number of cases in the search for alternative employment opportunities for staff unable to move to Thessaloniki and for any other assistance it has provided to the Centre almost daily during the move.

See in particular the general comments in points 46-66.
71. The Administrative Board regrets that the legislator has not included in Regulation (EC) No 251/95 any transitional legal arrangements in order to solve the difficult staff problems caused by the move to Thessaloniki.
In view of the lack of appropriate instruments, the Management Board was, all the more so, obliged to provide full support to CEDEFOP staff.
The Board of Directors believes that it has acted in the only acceptable manner in the present and truly unprecedented circumstances.
In the end, it was obvious that he had to make such an effort (as the Court acknowledges), as it was his duty as an employer to carry out the international work of an entire institution in a socially acceptable manner.
The Board of Directors, the Director and the staff acted in this positive spirit, possibly taking some risks but not in the exercise of abuse of power, nor in the exercise of unlawful acts.

Follow-up to previous observations Separation of duties 8. The Court repeats its observations made in previous years that the tasks of the authorising officer and the accounting officer are not sufficiently separated.
This is contrary to Article 15 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76, which states that the principle of ‘separation of the powers of authorising officer and of the accounting officer and the activities of the authorising officer, the financial controller and the accounting officer are (are) incompatible with each other'.

The Foundation has introduced a series of measures to separate the tasks of the authorising officer and the accounting officer.
The Court of Auditors has taken note of these initiatives in previous reports.
The only problem that remains in practice is the procedure by which the authorising officer records expenditure in the existing integrated accounting system.
This problem will be solved once the Foundation has acquired a new accounting system.
Following consultations in 1995, the Foundation, together with other EU agencies, took part in a joint tendering procedure for the acquisition of an appropriate accounting system in 1996.
The result, however, was that none of the candidates met the requirements of the institutions 100%.
After close contact with the Commission services, the Foundation is expected to acquire an appropriate accounting system from the Commission in 1997 after work on an appropriate system that meets the technical and legal requirements of the agencies has been completed recently.
The Foundation has set up links with the Commission's services with a view to finding solutions to the identified problem. 9. The Foundation has set up contacts with the Commission with a view to finding solutions to the problem identified.
The Foundation has now been informed that this question will be discussed between the Commission and the European Parliament in the context of the ongoing dialogue on the agencies' financial regulation.

The commercial accounting systems available on the market do not take into account the specific features of the Community financial rules.
For this reason, the agencies published a call for tenders in 1995 for a system in line with their needs.

Accounting for budgetary operations 1.6. It is true that the accounting system currently used by the OHIM allows subsequent changes to the accounts.

In 1995, the Office's budget was adopted in the light of a provision of ECU 2 million requested by Parliament for a general budget of ECU 10.1 million.
The provision was cancelled in two stages: — ECU 1 million in October 1995, — the balance in November 1995.
The temporary blocking of appropriations has of course had an effect on their use, particularly the appropriations under Title I of the Staff Regulations, since there was uncertainty as to whether the provisions would be effectively annulled.
OHIM was in no way in a position to recruit staff as long as the payment of salaries was not guaranteed by the end of the financial year.
After the release of the provisions, measures were taken to use the appropriations released to the budget lines, where the deadlines for the procedures for commitment of appropriations were still possible and where there was real need.
This is why the Office has requested a transfer from Title I to Title II in order to mainly create computerised material which was particularly urgently needed in the start-up phase of the Office.
It should be recalled that OHIM began its activities on 1 April 1996 and that since then more than 30 000 trade mark applications have been received, while the number of applications has been estimated at 15 000 for the whole financial year.
Inventory 1.8. At the time of the audit by the Court, OHIM had only just received the software for the computerised management of the inventory from the Commission; it was just installed at the time.
Division of tasks 1.9.

Balance-sheet accounting - The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
It has also played a crucial role in the introduction of a single system for the management of the budget and of the accounts in all the departments.
Discussions are under way with the Commission's responsible departments, which will enable the Court of Auditors to overcome all the concerns raised by the introduction of a new system for the management of the budget which will enter into force on 1 January 1997.
It should be stressed that, over the period under review, none of the amounts allocated had been exceeded.
It should be stressed that the advance payments were not used for all purchases of equipment or for participation in the real estate that constituted a significant part of the budget.
Moreover, the use of the general advance payments has at present been reduced in accordance with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation, and all accounting documents of a given month shall be sent to the auditor in Brussels within the 10th and the 20th of the following month, respectively.
Contracts On the one hand, the contracts under discussion, closely linked to the activities and projects of the Foundation's work programme, represent an extremely small proportion of the Foundation's activities, both in terms of number and budget.
On the other hand, it is true that the inclusion of the competition that led to these contracts was informal.
This procedure had been chosen at the time mainly because of the urgency.
In addition, the contracts under discussion had the task of organising conferences and seminars on behalf of and on behalf of the Foundation and under its strict control.
The corresponding budget was divided into two parts: the fixed part of remuneration (less than ECU 12 000) and the operating part, which was fixed by the Foundation in advance and remunerated on the basis of the supporting documents.
On the basis of these elements, the Foundation considered that the actual contract amount would not exceed ECU 12 000.
The Court of Auditors, when it became clear at the beginning of 1996, did not share this view, this system was abandoned.
Accountants The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.

Main comments on the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 Commission grant 1.5.
During the 1995 financial year, the Agency has only one part of the legislation contained in its budget ( ) OJ L 120, 11.5.1990, p. 4.
(2) In accordance with Article 13(3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts of all the Agency's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 1995 were drawn up by 20 June 1996, signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and forwarded to the Commission, the Management Board and the Court of Auditors.
These accounts were received by the Court of Auditors on 29 June 1996.
The tables in the annex to this report show these financial statements in the form of a abbreviated financial statements of the Commission (budget: ECU 12 million — appropriations recovered: ECU 6.2 million).
The Court considers that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the 1995 financial year for the balance outstanding (ECU 5.8 million) in order to meet the commitments carried over to the 1996 financial year (ECU 7 million in total).
Titles I (staff expenditure) and II (expenditure) of the budget (expenditure of the budget) resulted in several overruns of the budget totalling some ECU 0.4 million.
This amount, which could not be charged to the 1995 budget, is shown on the assets side of the balance sheet in a depositary account and must be charged to the 1996 budget (in breach of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Paying agency 1.7.
Almost all payments to be charged to Titles I and II of the budget have been settled through a paying agency.
The use of that paying agency is not compatible with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, as the paying agency administrator was at that time both the accounting officer's function and the fund manager of some of the budget lines.
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of the supporting documents have not been met and the availability of the committed appropriations for payments has not been verified.
This seems to be the main reason for the above-mentioned excesses.
Transfers 1.8.
As at the end of 1994, a very large proportion of the available appropriations was carried over at the end of 1995 (ECU 7 million — 57.2% of the total).
Most of the transfers concerned Title III (operational expenditure) (ECU 6.4 million — 90.3% of the appropriations entered in this Title).
A large part (ECU 1.8 million) of the 8.5 million ECU carried over from 1994 to 1995 had to be cancelled (21% of the carry-overs).
No C 81/44 'Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Subsequent referral to the Financial Controller 1.9.
A number of commitments of ECU 0.5 million were submitted to the financial controller after the end of the year.
In these cases, the financial control authority has refused the approval of the Board of Directors, which the Board of Directors has disregarded.
The Court stresses the obligation to comply with the financial regulation to make the request for commitment of the budget for all measures which may involve expenditure (Article 27 of the financial regulation for the Agency) subject to the application for commitment of the budget in accordance with the rules of procedure.
The division of tasks was not respected in the administrative department of the Agency.
Because of the lack of accounting staff, the same person was also the accounting officer, the staff manager and the manager of some of the budget lines.
Accounting systems 1.11.
Two systems, independent, not linked, are used for accounting for budgetary operations, and for general accounting.
Furthermore, the accounting system for budgetary operations does not provide for any sped ues if the available or committed funds are exceeded.
Financial controller 1.12.
The Management Board has appointed the financial controller of the Commission as the financial controller.
The Court considers it appropriate, on the basis of the current functioning of the Agency, to assign the Agency a financial controller, a report adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 28 October 1996.

• The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on the seat of the Agency had been delayed, the work of the Environment Agency had to be done very quickly at the start of its work.
Projects have been identified and commitments made before the end of the year, thanks to a large amount of work, but for obvious reasons, implementation of the commitments could hardly begin before the end of 1994.
In 1995, the Agency was faced with the difficult task of implementing not only the 1994 budget but also a new budget of ECU 10.5 million for 1995, before the regular staff of the Agency began their service.
The Agency's vacancies were advertised in November 1994, and after a lengthy selection process involving more than 7 000 applications, the first selected candidates began work in the summer of 1995.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work programme and had practically two budgets, but had only a very limited number of staff for this task.
Nevertheless, the work progressed and in 1995 major projects such as the Dobris Management Report and the revision of the 5th Environmental Action Plan were completed.
Five European thematic contact centres have been set up and the establishment of the EIONET has been progressing.
The Agency's regular staff increased by 1 person on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, such as national experts and auxiliary staff) and reached on 31 December 1995 the level of 22 regular staff, with 10 temporary staff remaining available.
The administrative machinery of the Agency has been gradually expanded as the same open recruitment procedure has been applied.
Nevertheless, in 1995, the Agency was clearly not sufficiently staffed to deal with the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
As far as the financial side is concerned, only one person was available in the first six months to work on the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme.
In June 1995, the Head of the Administrative Department began his duties, and only in early 1996 did the other financial and contractual staff of the Department of Administration join in.
Although the Agency was doing its job, in the area of finance and budget, some of the errors in terms of the prescribed procedures were made.
Overruns Some budget lines have been overrun.
On the one hand, this was because the Agency's budgetary control system did not function satisfactorily, and on the other hand some payments made were not recorded because the Agency's financial department was clearly understaffed.
As a consequence, a discrepancy between the accounts and the payments made effectively, which appeared as an overdraft of certain budget lines, arose when the accounts were closed.
As no settlement between different budget lines may take place after 1 January, these amounts must be included in the 1996 accounts, i.e. must be financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996, expenditure and the appropriations available under Titles I and II (i.e. the 1995 problem points) were carefully monitored to avoid an expenditure surplus.
Unobserved procedures (subsequent referral to the financial controller) A work programme was drawn up in the development phase of the Agency and its implementation was started before the administrative procedures were clearly defined and an appropriate administrative structure was available to monitor compliance with the procedures.
In some cases, this led to the commissioning and execution of work, excluding certain procedural rules.
In particular, work was commissioned without the approval of the financial controller in Brussels, which is a precondition for this type of operational expenditure.
The error was purely procedural and was justified in the fact that work had to be done, but the necessary administrative structures had not yet been set up to ensure compliance with the rules laid down by Brussels.
A clear delegation of powers of direction has been carried out, and staff are informed of the procedural rules.
Separation of tasks As in all public institutions, certain functions of a financial technical nature should remain separate with the Environment Agency.
One of the basic principles is that commitments and payment orders should not be made by the same person.
However, during the construction period of the Agency in Copenhagen, the number of staff was so low that this principle could not be respected.
This fact is rightly objected to by the Court of Auditors.
In the case of the Environment Agency, the Agency's financial controller and the Commission's financial controller shall be one and the same person, based in Brussels.
This would significantly impede the Agency's work.
The way out of this dilemma is to set up a paying agency.
I I m principle it works like a small cash reserve, although the amounts it covers are quite significant.
Instead of obtaining the prior approval of the financial control, the Agency orders the payment and sends the establishment of the procedures of the paying agency once a month for the subsequent approval of the financial control.
On the one hand, this will facilitate the work of the paying agency, but on the other hand, this will also be a two-sixth of a sword, since the agency's internal control and the financial department must be able to fulfil this additional responsibility.
The Court of Auditors' complaint is therefore understandable, but as long as the financial controller is located in Brussels, the Agency does not see any alternance as an extensive asset to the paying agency.
Computerised accounting system The Court of Auditors stresses the need for the Agency to implement a modern accounting system covering both general accounting and budgetary control.
Such a computerised system is essential for the EU's aggregated financial system if the intention is to avoid a large financial and budgetary commitment.
The Environment Agency wholeheartedly supports the conclusions of the Court of Auditors.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has repeatedly tried to find a solution to this problem.
It is in the same form, by the way, for the other EU agencies.
In 1996, the agencies issued a joint call for tender, but it was unsuccessful, i.e. it did not find a satisfactory system.
The Agency is currently working on the possibility of using the new Sincom 2 budgetary control system.
It is planned that it will be installed and operational in good time in order to implement the 1997 budget.
However, there will continue to be a soft to budget control and another to general accounting.
The Agency will continue to look for a suitable solution to these problems and will endeavour to coordinate this work with the other agencies.

The following remarks refer to the Court of Auditors' most important comments on the implementation of the EMCDDA's budget for 1994 and 1995 (points 1.5 to 1.11 of the Court of Auditors' comments).
The EMCDDA shares the Court's view that it would have been more appropriate to issue a recovery order for all all the funds entered in the balance sheet as the Commission's contribution, and that for the 1996 budget the budget was the same. b) The Portuguese Government (point 1.6 of the Court's comments) The EMCDDA acted in accordance with the Commission's budget control guidelines (which is also EMCDDA's financial control) in accordance with Article 54 of the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the European Communities and Article 82 of the Implementing Rules for the same (in line with the spirit of Article 142 of the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the European Communities).
However, the EMCDDA is aware that this can only be a temporary system (based on Excel-files) and that it needs a more efficient accounting system.
In this context, the decentralised agencies (including the EMCDDA), under the coordination of the European Training Foundation in Turin, published a call for proposals at the end of December 1995, with the aim of equipping themselves with an integrated integrated system of general accounting and accounting.
No. C 81/54  眇 EN     C Official Journal of the Communities 13. 3. 97 For the following financial years, the EMCDDA implements a plan for the programming and control of the implementation of the budget and its work programme, which aims to improve the use of the appropriations allocated and, in particular, to limit the transfers to exceptional cases. f) Separation of tasks (point 1.10 of the Court of Auditors' observations) C Due to its very limited staff in the years 1994 and 1995, the EMCDDA could not fully ensure compliance with the principle of separation of tasks, which the Court of Auditors pointed out.
The separation of the duties of the authorising officer, the financial controller and the accounting officer, as required by Article 16 of the financial rules of the OEDT for the duties of the authorising officer, has been fully complied with.
The EMCDDA is already trying to ensure the separation of tasks in the execution of the various tasks in question.
In this context, it shall, to the extent possible, take into account the requirements communicated by the Court of Auditors when defining their short-term staff requirements, in order to ensure the implementation of the administrative tasks referred to by the Court of Auditors (payment management, accounting, staff management and contracts) by different persons.
(g) Financial Controller (point 1.11 of the observations of the Court of Auditors) The EMCDDA's Management Board, when adopting the EMCDDA's financial rules in June, opened a negative decision on the delegation of the financial controller's duties to an EMCDDA staff member (in particular, on the basis of the European Commission's objections).
Since the European Commission's financial controller is also the EMCDDA's financial controller, it would also be up to the Commission to review the feasibility of a possible designation of a financial controller on the spot, taking into account the rules on this issue in the other decentralised agencies.

EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 1 of 5 Avis juridique important 31997Y0313(06) Report on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies Official Journal C 081, 13/03/1997 P. 0043 - 0048 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 81/06/) (For the period from 1 September 1994 to 31 December 1995) 1.1.
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in agreement with Article 13 (4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Court of Auditors has examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director in agreement with the requirements of Article 13 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. His responsibility includes the preparation and presentation of the accounts (2) in agreement with the internal financial provisions set out in Article 14 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community requires the Court of Auditors to audit these accounts.
This report constitutes the first audit of the Agency.
The Court conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are applicable in the Community context.
The Court carried out checks on the accounts and records and also applied search additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary in this context.
The main observations resulting from the Court's audit are presented in the second part of this report.
The financial statements for the financial years 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the underlying operations were carried out, on the whole, in agreement with the rules concerning legality and regularity.
Main observations concerning the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 The Commission subsidiary 1.5.
During the financial year 1995 the Agency used only part of the Commission subsidiary provided for in the general budget (ECU 12 million, of which ECU 6.2 million was drawn down).
It is the Court's opinion that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the financial year 1995 for the balance remaining due (ECU 5,8 million) in order to meet the commitments that were carried over to the financial year 1996 (totaling ECU 7 million).
Spending in excess of available intakes 1.6.
Several cases of expenditure in excess of available appropriations, expenditure to approximate ECU 0.4 million altogether, were found under appropriations I (staff expenditure) and II (administrative expenditure) of the budget.
This http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 2 of 5 amount, which could not be charged to the budget for 1995, was entered on the assets side of the balance sheet in a suspense account, and had to be charged to the budget for the financial year 1996 (contravention of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Imprest account 1.7.
Almost all payments charged to the budget under titles I and II were made via an imprest account.
The utilization of this account was not in accord with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, since the administrator of the imprest accounts was, at the time, both the Accounting and the Authorizing Officer for certain budget heads.
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of supporting documents were not met and the availability of approaches committed was not verified before payments were made.
This situation seems to be the principal cause of the cases of spending in excess of available approaches pointed out out above.
Approvals carried forward 1.8.
At the end of the financial year 1995, as was already the case at the end of the financial year 1994, the percentage of referrals carried forward was very high in relation to the referrals available (ECU 7 million - 57.2% of the total budget).
The majority of these carryovers concern title III (ECU 6.4 million, representing 90.3% of the appropriations under this title).
A large share (ECU 1.8 million) of the approvals carried over from 1994 to 1995, totalling ECU 8.5 million, had to be cancelled (21% of the approvals carried over).
A posteriori referral to the Financial Controller 1.9.
Several proposals for the commitment of funds totalling ECU 0.5 million were submitted, a posteriori, to the Financial Controller for his approval.
In these cases, the Financial Controller withheld his approval, but this refusal was overruled by the Management Board.
The Court wishes to emphasize the obligation to respect the Financial Regulation and to submit proposals for commitments in due form prior to 'any measure of a child which might lead to expenditure from the budget' (Article 27 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Separation of duties 1.10.
The separation of spouses within the administration of the Agency has not been observed.
Due to a ranking of staff in the financial accounting department, the same person was, at one and the same time, Accounting Officer, administrator of the imprest accounts and Authorizing Officer for certain budget headers.
Accounting systems 1.11.
The budgetary accounting and general accounting are carried out on two independent and unrelated computer systems.
The budgetary accounting system is, moreover, not programmed to refuse entries in the event of approximations available, or approximations committed, being exceeded.
The Financial Controller 1.12.
The Management Board appointed the Commission's Financial Controller as their own Financial Controller.
The Court regards it would be advisable, in respect of the Agency's present mode of operation, to address a full-time Financial Controller for the Agency.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg at the Court meeting of 28 October 1996. http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 3 of 5 For the Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President >TABLE> >TABLE> >TABLE> (1) OJ No L 120, 11.5.1990, p. 4.
(2) Contrary to the requirements of Article 13 (3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all revenue and expenditure of the Agency in respect of the financial year 1995 were not prepared until 20 June 1996, the date on which the accounts were signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and sent to the Commission, to the Board of Management and to the Court of Auditors.
These accounts were received by the Court on 28 June 1996.
The renewed version of these financial statements is presented in the tables annexed to this report.
THE AGENCY'S REPLIES The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted already on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on where to locate the Agency had been delayed a fast start was needed.
Through a significant effect, projects could be identified and the budget committed before the end of the year, but for previous reasons the execution of the commitments could be very start before the end of 1994.
Thus, in 1995 the Agency faced the daunting task of executing, not only the budget from 1994 but also a new budget for 1995 of ECU 10,5 million, and this before the regular staff of the Agency had taken up duty.
The vacant posts in the Agency were published in November 1994 and the selected candidates started coming on board in summer 1995 after a long selection procedure involving more than 7 000 applications.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work program and virtually two budgets to execute, but very limited staff for the task.
Despite this, work went ahead and in 1995 the Agency finalized major projects, like the Dobris assessment, the review of the fifth environmental action plan.
Five European topic centres were established and the build-up of the EIONET advanced.
The build-up of the Agency progressed with regular staff increasing from 1 on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, for example national experts and auxiliary staff) to 22 on 31 December 1995, still supported by 10 temporary staff.
The Agency's administration has progressively developed since the same open procedure to recruit was applied.
Nevertheless, it was clearly too understaffed in 1995 to handle the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
On the finance side only one person was available to handle the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme during the first half of the year.
In June 1995 the Head of Administration took up duty, and only in the beginning of 1996 did the rest of the finance and contract staff come on board.
The Agency rose to the challenge, but some topics of a procedural nature were made in the areas of finance and budget.
Overspending There was overspending on some budget lines.
The reason was, on the one http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 4 of 5 hand, that the Agency's budgetary monitoring system did not function in a satisfactory way and on the other hand some executed payments were not introduced due to the fact that the Agency was seriously understaffed in the finance department.
As a consequence, when the accounts were closed, the discrepancy between the accounts and the payments actually made, showed up as overspending on some budget lines.
Since no adjustment between budget lines can be made after 1 January, this has to be booked on the 1996 accounts, i.e. be financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996 the expenditures and the availability oftures in titles I and II, which was where the problems occurred in 1995, were carefully monitored in order to avoid overspending.
Procedures overlooked (Saisine a posteriori) During the build-up of the Agency, a work program was established and started being executed before administrative procedures had been well established and an administration in place to monitor that procedures were followed.
In some cases this led to work being ordered and carried out without all the procedures being observed.
In particular, work was contracted without the Financial Controller in Brussels having given his visa which is a prerequisite for this kind of operational expenditure.
It was not a question of finances being wasted or that the finances were not there.
The mistake was procedural and reflected that work had to be done and the procedures to ensure that this was done according to Community rules were not yet in place.
Procedures are now in place to avoid similar problems.
A clear delegation of authorizing powers have been established and staff informed of the rules.
Separation of functions In the financial framework of the Agency, as is the case in all public institutions, certain functions should be kept separate.
A basic principle is that the same person should not commit money and order payment.
However, during the period of establishment of the Agency in Copenhagen the number of staff in the Agency was so small that it was not possible to observe this principal.
This is legally criticized by the Court of Auditors.
However, once the staffing of the Agency started to increase this was corrected and these functions have been rigorously separated in the Agency since 1995.
Extensive use of imprest accounts The normal procedure for committing and ordering payments in the EU-system is to have prior approval by the Financial Controller in practice all cases.
In the case of the Agency, the Agency Financial Controller is the same as the Commission's and located in Brussels.
To send all financial transactions to Brussels for approval before they could actually be executed would be an excessively tiresome procedure.
It would seriously obstruct the working of the Agency.
The way out of this dilemma is the imprest account.
It works in principle as a petty-cash reserve oldough the amounts involved are important.
Instead of seeing prior acceptance from Financial Control, the Agency executes the payment and once a month the imprest account is sent to the Financial Controller to have the ex post acceptance of the payments which have been made.
On the one hand this ensures the functioning of the Agency, but, on the other hand, it is a double-edged word since the Agency's internal controls and the financial department must have the capacity to handle this additional responsibility.
Thus, the criticism by the Court of Auditors is understandable, but as long as http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 5 of 5 the Financial Controller is located in Brussels there is, in the Agency's view no alternative to an extensive use of the imprest account.
It is there with great interest that the Agency has noted the recommendation by the Court of Auditors that the Financial Controller of the Commission should place a Financial Controller in the Agency.
The Agency would welcome this step.
Computerized financial system The Court of Auditors underlines the need for the Agency to find an up-to-date computerized financial system which can integrate the accounting side with the budget monitoring side.
In the submitted financial system of the European Union such a computerized system is crucial to avoid having to tie down a lot of resources in financial and budgetary work.
The Agency supports wholeheartedly the conclusion by the Court of Auditors.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has again and again tried to find a solution to this problem.
It is a problem which the European Environment Agency shares with the other EU Agencies.
In 1996, the Agencies launched a joint call for tenders to find a solution but this call for tenders has not been successful, i.e. no satisfactory system has been found.
Thus, the Agency is at present pursuing the possibility of using the new budget monitoring system Sincom 2. The plan is to have it installed and operational in time to execute the 1997 budget on the basis of this system.
There will be still one software for the budget monitoring system and another for the general leather.
Nor will the imprest accounts be integrated in the software the Agency will continue to look for an efficient way of solving these problems and will endeavour to coordinate this work with the other Agencies.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/25 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Environment Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Agency's task is to establish an environmental monitoring network to provide the Commission, the Member States and the general public with reliable information on the state of the environment.
In particular, this information should enable the European Union and the Member States to take measures to protect the environment and to assess the effectiveness of these measures.
2. Table 1 summarises the Agency's terms and conditions.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 contain, for information purposes, essential information from the Agency's financial statements for the financial year 2006.
This declaration of confidence shall be submitted to the European Parliament and the Council pursuant to Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (2), and shall be based on the analysis of the Agency's accounts, which the Court shall carry out pursuant to Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The Agency's annual accounts for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (3) were drawn up in accordance with Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 by its Executive Director and forwarded to the Court, which shall declare the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying accounts.
5. The Court carried out its examination in accordance with the guidelines for financial control and the INTOSAI Code of Obligations and Code of Conduct and IFAC's international financial guidelines for the purposes of its purposes, insofar as they are applicable in the Community context.
The review was planned and carried out with a view to obtaining adequate assurance that the financial statements were reliable and that the underlying estimates are correct and correct.

C 309/28 EN Official Journal of the European Union 19.12.2007 ANSWER OF THE AGENCY The higher share of transfers to 2007 is mainly due to exceptional events in 2006, which led us to postpone intermediate payments to the thematic centres until the satisfactory delivery of the services.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/41 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Agency for Reconstruction (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EC) No 1628/96(1), as last amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 756/2006 of 28 November 2006 (2).
The agency, set up in 2000, was originally responsible for managing the European Union's aid programmes in Kosovo.
It was also extended to Serbia-Montenegro and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
The Agency implements programs to promote institution building and good governance to support the development of the market economy and basic infrastructure for civil society.
The Agency's mandate is in principle to expire on 31 December 2008.

C 393/2 EN I Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 THE FINANCIAL STATIONS OF THE EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF VOCATIONAL TRAINING FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1996 1. This report is addressed to the Council and the European Parliament in conformity with Article 12 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 (a) as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1946/93 (2).
2. The Court has examined the financial statements of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training for the financial year ended 31 December 1996.
In agreement with Article 18 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 (3) as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (4), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board.
This responsibility included the drawing up and presentation of the financial statements in accordance with the financial provisions as provided for pursuant to Articles 65, 67 and 68 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (4) amending Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 (3).
The Court of Auditors is required within the meaning of Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community to examine these financial statements.
3. The Court undertook its audit in agreement with generally accepted auditing standards, in so far as they are applicable in the Community context, and, appropriately, carried out search tests of the accounting records and search other auditing procedures as the Court deemed necessary in the circumstances.
4. In the opinion of the Court the financial statements for the financial year ended 31 December 1996'are reliable and the underlying transactions are, as a whole, legal and regular.
AUDIT OBSERVATIONS Introduction Background 5. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was l established by the Council Regulation EEC No 337/75 {) as a satellite body of the European Community with the task of promoting vocational training at Community level.
Cedefop-commenced operations in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Salonika in 1995.
6. The same Regulation defines its role as that of assisting 'the Commission in 'encouraging, at Community level, the promotion and development of vocational and in-service training', of contributing 'to the implementation of a common vocational training policy' and especially contributing 'the exchange of information and the comparison of expertise'.
Its main tasks in the field of vocational training are 'to compile documentation, to contribute to the development and coordination of research, to disseminate useful documentation and information, to enhance and support initiatives likely to facilitate a coordinated approach (specifically in respect of the approximation of standards and the mutual recognition of certificates) and to provide a forum for all those concerned'.
Scope of the audit 7. The Court carried out a financial audit of the 1996 accounts and has reviewed the Centre's decisions concerning its temporary and permanent prevalences and staff situation.
Financial data 8. Tables 1 and 2 summarize the financial statements of the Centre.
Available estimates for the financial year 1996 amounted to ECU 14.8 million.
Commitments entered into give rise to ECU 11.4 million in payments and ECU 2.1 million in carry-overs to the financial year 1997, the balance of ECU 1.3 million having been cancelled.
Approvals carried over from the previous financial year give rise to ECU 4.2 million in payments and ECU 0.6 million in cancellations.
Table 3 of this report gives an analysis of the utilisation of the procedures for 1996 as well as of those carried over from 1995.
Observations concerning budgetary implementation Separation of duties 9. The Centre has put in place adequate procedures for the separation of duties of authorizing officer, accounting officer and imprest holder (5).
Imprest account 10. A high proportion (in 1996 74%, including sales) of payments continue to be made prior to approval by the Financial" Controller.
Last year (5) the Court recommended that the use of the.imprest account be limited to starting or small expenses, where' the risk of irregularities is comparatively low.
A Management Board decision defining which kind of expenses may be paid threenph the imnrest account has been established and came into force on 1 January 1997.
Transfers of appropriations 11. The value of transfers of appropriations between different budget lines in 1996 was ECU 891 600 (6 % of the initial budget), down from ECU 922 000 in 1995.
29. 12. 97 1 EN I Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/3 12. Following consultations with and the approach of the different services in the Commission (DG IX, DG XIX and DG XX), the Centre transferred ECU 30 000 from budget line 117 6 'Other services and work sent out for translation and typing' to a newly created budget line 1 1 1 0 'Auxiliaries', and ECU 40 000 from budget line 1 1 0 0 'Basic sales' to a newly created budget line 1 1 1 2 'Local agents'.
These new budget lines were created by the Centre.
The Court acknowledges the reasons for making these transfers, but notes that they are contrary to paragraph 4 (a) of Article 21 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 which states: 'appropriations may be transferred only to budget heads for which the statement of expenditure has authorizedappro, or carried a token entry'.
The same budget lines are also included in the 1997 budget with approximation of the Budgetary Authority.
Carry-overs and cancellations of approvals 13. The volume of approvals carried over has decreased in 1996.
Almost 77% of final applications for 1996 were paid out in 1996 as compared with 61% in 1995.
The percentage of commitments made and carried over to 1997'was 14% (28% in 1995).
The percentage of cancellations was 9% compared with 10% in 1995.
Table 4 shows the carry-overs from the 1996 initial budget by title and their subsequent use.
Observations concerns the revenue and expenditure account and the balance sheet Revenue 14. The EU subsidiary for the Centre for 1996 was ECU 14 625 000.
The Centre actually requested and received ECU 14 410 000.
15. In 1996, for the first time Norway and Iceland paid the Centre ECU 9 6 1 3 5 as a contribution for their participation in the work programme.
Expenditure 16. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 stipulates that contracts may be made by direct agreement where the contract involves an amount not exceeding the limit of ECU 12 000.
In the case of at least 17 study contracts and five fixed scores asset purchases, contracts over that limit were made without following the tendering procedure as described in Article 45 of the Regulation, however all payments were approved by the Financial Controller.
17. The result of a study of delays in the submission of work by contracts for 1996 showed that 55 % of the contracts did. not respect the contract deadline.
None of the minutes of management meetings contained any evidence of a review of the performance of contracts in meeting contractual deadlines.
Balance sheet 18. The Centre made an up-to-date inventory list as.foreseen in Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 as attached by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (s).
Fixed assets of ECU 1 443 431 recorded in the 1996 balance sheet represent the historic cost of materials and veneers.
19· At the year end, cash balances hero by. the Centre were ECU 4.1 million, down from ECU 5.9 million in 1995.
The Centre is again taking responsibility for managing large cash balances.
The Court recommends the Centre make its quarterly drawings from the Commission on the basis of its actual cash needs.
20. The balance sheet includes an amount of ECU 483 308 related to 'VAT to recover', of which ECU 251 434 recovers to the year 1995 but not yet recovered due to the move to Salonika.
The Court asks the Centre to do the necessary to recover this amount as soon as possible.
With regards to the 'VAT to recover for 1996', the Centre is recommended to explain to the responsible tax authorities every detail related' to this procedure to avoid funds being cancelled or excellent delays in reimbursement.
Audit of the Centre's premises'and staff situation Temporary premises 21. As the Court observed last year (8), the Centre had to invest ECU 120 000 to fit out the premises to make the temporary building functional and'ready for use'.
At the time of the audit (May 1997), the Centre 'explained that these costs were incurred to improve the conditions for efficient functioning of the Centre', but was unable to explain who wasable to bear these costs.
Permanent premises 22. The Centre and the Greek State signed on 22 June 1995, a basic agreement regarding the construction of the permanent building.
According to this agreement, the Centre will pay to the Greek State ECU 6 879 750 in four equal events of ECU 1 719 937.
The first two were paid on 1 September 1995 and 1 September 1996
This third installation has to be approved by the Budgetary Authority and the last installation will be paid when the building is handled" over.
23. If approach is given by the Budgetary Authority before 1 September 1997, the Centre will have paid to the Greek' State ECU 5 159 811 for the construction of the permanent building.
The construction of the building was planned to commence on 30 March 1997.
At the time of the audit (May 1997), the tendering procedure, which is managed by the Greek authorities, was not yet finalized nor were any contracts signed.
As a consequence, no financial data or budget related to this investment was available for audit.
Staff 24. In 1996, the staff complement table authorized 81 posts (permanent and temporary positions), of which: 25 A, 11 LA, 15 B, 27 C and 3 D. At the time of the audit (May 1997), 78 persons were actually working in.
Salonika, of which: 60 officials and contemporary officials (25 A/LA, 10 B, 23 C and 2 D), 7 national experts, 5 local agents, 3 auxiliaries, 2 interims and 1'stagiaire'.
25. Another three persons are working at Cedefop's office in Brussels, one person is seconded to Eurostat for a cooperative project, three persons we're still in Berlin, This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors and 13 November 1997. four staff members are on special leave (CCP) and one person has been ill for many months.
Many new members of staff have been recruited during 1996.
26. The Court has been informed of an investigation by the Greek tax authorities concerning, among others, tax and social security payments for local staff put at the Disposal of Cedefop by a company in Salonika.
Conclusion 27. In the case of at least 17 study contracts and five fixed-asset purchases, contracts over the limit of ECU 12000 were made without following the tendering procedure as described in Article 45 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 as without Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (see paragraph 16).
28. The Centre once again holds large cash balances.
This situation should be anticipated by making quarterly drawings from the Commission on the basis of actual cash needs (see paragraph 19).
29. The Centre is recommended to make sure that the work concerns the permanent premises is progressing in conformity with the contract (see paragraph 23). in Luxembourg at the Court's meeting of 12 For the European Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President (!)
