EN C 434/20 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 2.29.
All agencies publish their tenders electronically via TED (Tenders Electronic Daily), the online version of the EU Official Journal for public procurement. In addition, the Commission launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). Most agencies had the electronic invoicing and the electronic invoicing for certain procedures by the end of 2017, but not the electronic submission of tenders.
Improvement in IT consulting services and project management at EMA and eu-LISA IT consulting services and project management at EMA 2.30.
In the course of the previous year's review, the Court analysed how the Agency manages advisory services.
The use of consulting firms in the field of consulting has led to a critical dependence of external expertise.
The Court also reported that the control of the project development and implementation was insufficient and that the projects were subject to serious delays and cost increases.
In 2017, the Agency took several measures to improve the situation.
However, it will take time to reduce the critical nature of the agency of consulting firms, and the effects of the actions taken will only be apparent over the years.
IT consulting services and project management at eu-LISA 2.32.
The agency uses advice mainly in connection with IT projects due to the nature of its activity.
In 2017, the Agency's IT projects were implemented within the financial and time frame.
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, whereby approximately 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by three contractors.
Although the IT projects are the property of the agency and are under its control, a model, in which the development of so sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent, entails the risk of a superior independence from the contractors.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/21 2.34.
At the same time, the low number of staff in the operational key sections creates a risk for the continuity of the establishment.
Public procurement is intended to ensure competition between economic operators and to make the most economic purchase possible, and is to operate in a transparent, objective, and coherent manner on the basis of the current legal framework.
The Court found in 14 agencies in the field of public procurement (BEREK, EPA, Chafea, eu-LISA, EASO, EBA, EEA, EFSA, EIGE, EUIPO, ERA, EASA, FRA and SRB) the EUIPO and the EUIPO, mostly in the field of services, which involve risks for optimal use of funds.
Among the most frequently identified reasons are the lack of a balanced relationship between price and quality aspects of the award criteria, the lack of optimal design of framework agreements, the use of framework agreements allowing the procurement of services, the description and/or price of which were not identified sufficiently, and the use of intermediate services.
Most agencies analysed the impact of Brexit 2.36. On March 29, 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, five agencies (ACER, B, B, B, EPA, ENISA, and EU-OSHA) did not undertake a comprehensive analysis of the potential impact of Brexit on their organisation, their operations, and their accounting operations.
Job postings could be published on the EPSO website 2.37.
Most agencies (ACER, Cedefop, EPA, Chafea, EASA, EBA, ECHA, EEA, EIGE, EIOPA, EIT, EMA, EMCDDA, EMSA, ENISA, ESMA, eu-LISA, Eurojust, Europol, Frontex, GSA and SRB) publish job vacancies on their own websites and on social media, but frequently not on the websites of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
An announcement on the EPSO website would increase transparency and publicity and would enable the citizens of Europe to see job vacancies of all European institutions and institutions.
The main reason the agencies are responsible for is that the EPSO requires the publication of job advertisements in all the official languages of the EU, which is associated with high translation costs.
Less comments on the legality and regularity of payments 2.38.
The number of comments on the legality and regularity of payments has been down to eight (2016: 11), which illustrates the ongoing efforts of the agencies to comply with the legal framework, in particular the provisions of the Financial Regulation and the framework Financial Regulation and the Staff Regulations.
While five comments were made again in relation to procurement procedures (EASO, EASA, EIGE and Frontex), three were related to recruitment procedures (EASO, Cedefop and Frontex).
The budget management has improved 2.39.
Budget appropriations granted for a given year can be transferred to the next year under certain conditions (19).
Although the Financial Regulation does not set the limits for the transfer of funds of this kind, the multi-annual nature of the activities does not justify the transfer. Nevertheless, the transfer of funds of this kind can be an indication of delays in the implementation of the work programmes or procurement plans, and can be contrary to the budgetary principle.
Illustration 2.4 shows how many agencies the Court reported in 2017 and in previous years about high funds transfers.
The return to only two agencies (Chafea and EU-OSHA) in 2017 is due to the fact that the transfers by the agencies were better and more transparently explained and founded, but also to the Court's changed approach for reporting 2017.
(19) The conditions for transfers are laid down in Article 13 of the Financial Regulation.
EN C 434/22 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.4 Less comments on the excessive or excessive transfer of funds Source: European Court of Auditors on the basis of information provided by the agencies.
In addition, the Court found that two agencies (Frontex and EUIPO) had cancelled the budget carried over from previous years.
This was an indication that the budget was too high, in particular on the part of the public authorities of Member States and other cooperating States.
Accountancy could be further improved 2.42.
In the course of these audits, the Court also reviewed the accounting of the agencies, which plays an important role in the preparation of reliable annual accounts.
Each agency has its own accountant, under the Financial Regulation. This has led to a total of 37 accounts being held responsible for 2% of the EU budget.
The main tasks of the accountant are the performance of the payments, the acceptance of the income and the collection of the receivables, the preparation and presentation of the annual accounts and the account management, the definition and validation of the accounting systems and the cash management.
In order to increase efficiency, the Commission's accountant asked all agencies in 2012 to delegate their accounting function to him on a contractual basis.
The first agency to accept this proposal was the EPO in 2014.
By the end of 2017, only three other agencies (GSA, B the BEREC and ACER) had joined this scheme.
The hierarchical position of an accountant within an agency may affect his independence.
In particular, accountants must be independent of persons who, (subordinately), are (authorized) to make commitments, to make legal commitments and to notify payments.
This observation concerns a total of 13 agencies (CdT, EACEA, EASA, EASME, EEA, EFSA, EIOPA, EMA, EMCDDA, ERA, EU-OSHA, Eurofound and FRA).
The appointment and annual assessment of the accounting officer should then also fall within the scope of responsibility of the Board of Directors.
According to the Financial Regulation, the auditors must confirm that the agencies' accounting systems function reliably (validation).
While the validation of the accounting systems of most agencies is up to date, the Court noted that the accounting systems of seven agencies (ACER, B, B, B, EPA, EASME, EIT, EMA and GSA) needed to be revalidated as a result of major changes.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/23 Illustration 2.5 The independence of the agencies' auditors and the revalidation of the accounting systems Source: European Court of Auditors based on information provided by the agencies.
In three agencies (EASO, CPVO and REA) award, grant and recruitment procedures were inadequately documented.
Three agencies (ACER, EIT and Frontex) identified M) angels for internal control for the implementation of the emergency control standard.
These angels could pose a considerable risk for maintaining business in the event of a disaster, as data could be irrevocably lost.

In 2017, the Court carried out a rapid analysis (20) of how the institutions and agencies of the European Union implemented their commitment to reduce the staff of their posts by 5% in the period 2013-2017 (for agencies 2014-2018).
The Court concluded that the agencies had implemented the reduction of staff by 5%, although with some reduction.
While decentralised agencies with traditional tasks managed to reduce their staff by 8.9%, the number of staff of certain decentralised agencies and executive agencies with new tasks and responsibilities increased by 19.9% and 42.9%, respectively.

Special Report of the Court on the SRB 2.51.
The Single Resolution Committee (SRB), based in Brussels, was set up in August 2014, as part of the political response to the financial crisis.
The task of the Committee is the resolution of insolvency-threatening banks which fall within its scope of responsibility.
In January 2017, the SRB was responsible for 139 banks, including 130 banking groups (21).
In the course of the survey (22) it was examined whether the committee was prepared to handle banks effectively. Particular attention was paid to the quality of the resolution planning for individual banks and the question of whether the committee was prepared to meet the legal requirements in the area of resolution planning and whether it had sufficient human resources to carry out its tasks.
The Court identified deficits in all these areas, but, as the establishment of the Committee as a completely new structure represented a huge challenge, the weaknesses in this context need to be seen.
The Court made a number of recommendations to the Committee with a view to the preparation of resolution plans and the implementation of its rules and guidelines, and to increasing the number of staff and improving the procedures for human resources management.
(21) On 1 January 2018, the number of banks and 119 banking groups decreased.
(22) Special Report No 23/2017: ăSingle Resolution Committee: First steps on the challenging path to the Banking Union have been taken, but there is still a long way to go, published on 19 December 2017.
DE C 434/26 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Special Court annual report on contingent liabilities resulting from the tasks of the Single Resolution Committee 2.54.
Under the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation (23) the Court must draw up a report on all contingent liabilities resulting from the Committee, the Council and the Commission performing their duties under the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation.
As at 31 December 2016, the Committee's contingent liabilities resulting from the pre-selected contributions amounted to EUR 842 million, which rose to EUR 1 420 million as at 30 September 2017.
In 2016, the Board did not initiate bank resolution, and therefore, for the 2016 financial year, no contingent liability related to resolution decisions had to be reported.
At the time the Court's 2016 report was published on contingent liabilities resulting from the Board's exercise of its functions, 90 legal proceedings against the Board had been brought before the Court of the European Union by the end of October 2017 on the basis of the resolution decision taken in June 2017 in relation to the Banco Popular Espa theol S.A., and 46 complaints had been filed with the SRB's Appeals Committee.
The Commission and the Council were informed of the 26 procedures submitted to the Court of First Instance in connection with the abovementioned resolution decision.

EN C 434/28 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE NETWORK OF THE EU AGENCIES The agencies report the Court's positive conclusions on the sufficiency of the Court's annual accounts and on the underlying accounts.
The network would like to express its concerns that the agencies will be forced to continue to use separate tools to assess, telework, flexitime and staff reporting, given the fact that the Commission will only be able to provide them with a basic package of modules in Sysper.
The IT landscape in the area of human resources management will therefore only partly become more uniform and even much less so as the Commission can decide.
The agencies also advocate the possibility of setting up a joint solution for the services concerned to support recruitment procedures that are not currently covered by Sysper.
In the field of procurement, there has been a definite trend towards the harmonisation of electronic tools over the last two years.
This development started in 2015/2016 when the tools for e-PRIOR/electronic procurement designed by DG DIGIT in cooperation with DG BUDG were developed.
Since then, this series of electronic modules has become more and more a standard for all phases of the procurement cycle, to which the agencies adhere.
In 2018, this trend continued as new modules for electronic submission and the ABAC LCK module were introduced and the agencies were introduced.
Gradually, the agencies are putting the use of their own isolated tools, some quick, some less fast, but regardless of how fast this development will take place, the trend in itself is no longer in place.
The proposed efficiency gains that could be achieved by transferring accounting tasks to the European Commission are difficult to achieve in practice.
The required workload does not only depend on the balance of the budget, but also on the fact that the annual accounts have to be completed in a narrow window of time at the beginning of each year.
Experience shows that for more than one package of annual accounts (i.e. for additional financing of delegation agreements) almost twice as much personnel is needed, although the corresponding accounts are smaller (and the financial accounts are smaller).
When these activities were transferred to the Commission, each agency would still need to need an accounting team, as accounting tasks still need to be carried out.
As long as this is the case, any staff savings would not correspond to a full-time equivalent.
In addition, the annual fee has to be paid.
For this reason, only a few agencies have decided to transfer this task to the Commission.
The network would like to point out that to date no investigation or risk assessment has been carried out, which could justify the conclusion that the independence of the auditor would be strengthened if it were to be submitted directly to the authorising officer and not to an authorised authorising officer.
Some agencies have decided to adopt a charter of accountants, including, but not limited to, regulations for reporting to the board of directors, if necessary.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/31 3.1.
We have carried out our testing in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing (ISA) as well as the professional behavioural requirements of IFAC and the International Standards of Supreme Audit Institutions (ISSAI) of INTOSAI.
Our responsibilities according to these standards are described in more detail in the section ăresponsibilities of our report.
We are independent in agreement with the Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants of the International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (IESBA Code) and with the professional behavioral requirements relevant to our agreement, and we have fulfilled our other professional behavioral obligations in agreement with these requirements and the IESBA Code.
We believe that the evidence that we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our judgment.
Responsibilities of the management and of the responsible for the monitoring 3.1.2.
Under Articles 310 to 325 TFEU and the financial regulations of the agencies, the management is responsible for the establishment and presentation of the financial statements on the basis of internationally recognised accounting grounds for the public sector, as well as for the legality and regularity of the statements underlying these financial statements.
This includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures as necessary for the establishment and presentation of an annual financial statement, which is free of material, intended or unintended, false representations.
The management of the agencies exercises the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the underlying assets of their annual accounts.
In drawing up the annual accounts, the management of the company is responsible for assessing the ability of the agencies to continue their activities, for the purposes of continuing the activities of the company,, and for applying the accounting principle of continuing the activities of the company, unless the management intends either to liquidate the company or to discontinue business, or has no realistic alternative.
Responsibilities of the investigator for the control of the annual accounts and the underlying accounts 3.1.5.
Our aims are to achieve sufficient certainty whether the annual accounts of the agencies are free of material false accounts and whether the underlying accounts of the agencies are legal and regulatory, and to present to the European Parliament and the Council or other competent discharge authorities on the basis of our examination on the basis of the annual accounts of the agencies and the legality and regularity of the underlying accounts.
False representations and understandings may be intended or unintentional and will be considered essential if they can be expected individually or as a whole to reflect users' economic decisions made on the basis of these annual accounts.
3.1.6.
With regard to revenue, we are reviewing the grants that the agencies have received from the Commission or cooperating States and we are assessing their procedures for collecting fees and other revenue, if relevant.
3.1.7.
As far as expenditure is concerned, we will examine the payment arrangements after the expenditure has been paid, recorded and accepted.
Advance payments are made after the beneficiary has proved their proper use and the agency has accepted their proofs by billing the advance payments in the same year or later.
3.1.8.
As part of a review in agreement with the ISA and ISSAI, we review the whole review of our discretion and maintain a critical attitude.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/37 REPLY OF AGENCY 3.2.8.
The Agency agrees with the outcome and clarifies that the Agency records all financial transactions in the financial system provided by the European Commission, updated, maintained and validated by the Commission.
With the outsourcing of the Service Accounting to the Commission from October 2017, the Agency will accept the validation of the accounting system provided by the Commission in 2018.
Since the ARIS primary site and the disaster management site were migrated to the internal ACER data centre in early April 2016, and integrated in a single site in June 2017 in order to optimise and improve performance and to improve the increasing space requirements, it is no longer possible to maintain operations.
However, it should be noted that the current situation, in which the maintenance of the plant cannot be ensured, has been imposed on the Agency by the serious reduction in its budget in the last two years.
The Agency has repeatedly warned the Commission and the budgetary authorities about the serious consequences of budgetary constraints, but has not achieved a result in terms of additional resources.
The Agency will continue to work to restore a site for disaster management for ARIS, but will not provide a financial contribution in 2018.
The restoration of the site for disaster management would require additional financial resources to the Agency.
Given that the risks associated with BREXIT were considered to be low and limited, the management only conducted an informal analysis of Brexit in 2017.

In 2014, the Management Board of the Agency adopted Decision AB No 15/2014 on the Agency's language regime.
Nevertheless, the Agency still needs to translate the job advertisements published on the EPSO website into all official EU languages.
Due to the very limited financial resources that the budget authority has repeatedly shown against the budget, the Agency is unable to raise the translation costs for every single job advertisement in all official EU languages for the publication of this call on the EPSO website.
In 2017, four out of nine job advertisements, including two public calls, were published on the EPSO website and were therefore translated into all official EU languages.
The remaining five notices of positions in operational departments were published only on the Agency's website, as they were, essentially, of interest to applicants, who were already active in the field and who as a rule follow the Agency's actions on our website.
This approach represents a pragmatic weighting between contacting potential applicants and the efficient use of limited resources.

COMMENTS ON THE THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.3.9.
In the course of this year's audit of the EU agencies, the Court analysed the accounting system, including the aspect of the timely (re)validation of the accounting systems.
In 2016, the B thero delegated its accounting function to the Commission's accounting officer.
In 2017, it introduced a new paperless system.
Although these events led to significant changes in the B to the B to B to B to B to B to B to B to B to B to B to B in 2013, the system has not been re-validated since 2013.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.3.10.
In December 2017, the B燃ro signed legal commitments and commitments of EUR 20 000 for a course of training planned for the end of March 2018.
The financing of 2018 activities from the 2017 budget is in contradiction with the budget principle of the year.
In August 2015, the B sucho launched an invitation to tender for a multi-service framework agreement in the cascade system, covering an estimated market volume of EUR 3 million to organise and plan events such as meetings, workshops, conferences, etc.
In addition, the competitive process only covered the bidder's administrative fees, but not the potential event costs.
The award procedure thus did not provide adequate price competition, which might not provide the most economically advantageous offer.
3.3.12.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (37) (38). In the light of the need for a corresponding framework for EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT framework covering all phases of public procurement procedures, with the launch of tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of procurement documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011), and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNT 3.5.8.
The Court considers it necessary to strengthen the independence of the accountant by direct reporting to the Director (administrative matters) and to the Board of Directors (functional matters) of the Agency. COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ACTIVITY OF THE PRINCIPLES 3.5.9.
Framework agreements are concluded with companies to establish the terms and conditions applicable during the period of the agreement for certain procurements (individual contracts).
For the provision of IT services of up to EUR 22 million, the Agency used a framework agreement with three contractors in the cascade system.
In this procedure, contractors are placed in a hierarchy (the cascade) following a competitive procedure, which must be respected in all individual cases.
However, the terms of the Framework Agreement were not specific enough to allow fair competition and to justify the establishment of a ranking of contractors for all future individual contracts.
In accordance with the provisions of the Financial Regulation(54), the individual items of the of those items must be awarded by means of a competitive procedure between the selected contractors.
3.5.10.
The Agency's financial provisions (55) must be approved by the Board of Directors, either in the Agency's annual work programme or through an ad hoc financing decision.
An IT framework agreement with a maximum amount of EUR 15 million has been tendered and signed, although the financing decision only covered EUR 5 million.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including EASA) with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software and on maintenance and support services (IT services).
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can provide the IT services.
Most of these IT services and the prices of these services were set out in the framework agreement concluded in the context of the competitive award procedure, but these set out the procurement of non-specific IT services.
In case of a paid payment of around 300 000 euros, the agency, via the contractor, had acquired IT services without a competitive process.

EUROPEAN CHEMICAL AGENCY (ECHA) INTRODUCTION 3.7.1.
The European Chemicals Agency (hereinafter ‘the Agency'), based in Helsinki (hereinafter ‘the Agency'), was established by Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council (68).
Its main task is to ensure a high level of protection for human health and the environment and to ensure the free movement of substances in the internal market while improving competitiveness and innovation.
The Agency also promotes the development of alternative assessment methods for the risks associated with substances.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/57 Highlighting a case 3.7.5.
Without questioning its judgment in paragraph 3.7.4, the Court would stress that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a fee from any company applying for the registration of chemicals, as provided for in the REACH Regulation (72).
The applicable charges are based on the size of the enterprises (smallest enterprises, small, medium, large enterprises) and the quantity of the registered chemicals (various quantity thresholds).
3.7.6.
As provided for in the implementing regulation(73), the Agency calculates and invoices the fees on the basis of information provided by the companies at the time of the application.
Since the first registrations in 2009, around 30% of the companies reported that they were micro-enterprises, small or medium-sized enterprises.
The agency has made considerable efforts to set up a system for ex-post processing, with which the information of these applicants on the enterprise size of the enterprise is ex-post processing.
Thus, the Agency was able to find that, on the basis of the above, some 55% of the above-mentioned companies, which according to their own data were micro, small or medium-sized enterprises (16 % of all enterprises), had misstated their size, leading to lower costs.
In order to remedy the situation, the agency has charged around 16.4 million euros in order to correct the situation in the course of the years, as a result of ex-post inspections.
However, the amount of overruling is substantially lower, and the remaining amount of required overruling was not known at the end of 2017 (74).
This observation shows the limitations of a system based on the claims of the applicants in too high a level.
The REACH Regulation stipulates that the quantities declared by the enterprises are the responsibility of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement.
The agency is therefore not involved in the revision of this second element for the calculation of fees.
Payments Judicial ruling on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.7.8.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.7.10.
The Agency's ex post surveys have shown that more than half of the companies that registered and reported chemicals were micro-enterprises and small or medium-sized enterprises that were wrong in terms of size (see paragraph 3 in paragraph 3 of this article for highlighting the issue of chemicals).
Some of this can be explained by the Commission's complex regulations for the determination of enterprise size (75) and partly by the financial incentive to indicate too small size, since registration fees for enterprise size are far higher.
As the original registration fees are collected on the basis of the stated company fees, incorrect information could have a significant negative effect on the Agency's revenues, if they are not discovered.

EN C 434/58 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.7.11.
If errors are detected, the Agency will charge the difference between the original amount paid and the final amount paid as well as an administrative fee.
On 31 December 2017, the amount to be recovered amounted to EUR 4.7 million, of which EUR 3.2 million was related to the amount of administrative fees.
However, it appears that the Agency is encountering difficulties in the recovery of administrative fees.
In its 2017 financial statements, the Agency recorded a reversal of EUR 2.8 million of irrecoverable claims (i.e. EUR 600,000 more than at the end of 2016).
3.7.12.
The exercise of control over the quantities declared by the undertakings is the task of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement and the Agency has no enforcement powers (see paragraph 3 of this paragraph for the clarification of the facts in paragraph 3.7.5).
The measures taken by the enforcement authorities of the Member States are coordinated by the Forum for the exchange of enforcement information.
On 6 December 2017, the Forum adopted new strategies and minimum criteria for the enforcement of the chemicals regulations (ăStrategies and minimum criteria for enforcement of chemical regulations), which provide a framework for the development of national enforcement strategies.
The Agency's ability to fulfill its mission depends on the effectiveness of the implementation of this framework by the national authorities.
In its general report for 2017, the Agency stated that about two-thirds of companies did not update the registered information on the quantities of chemicals they handle.
This concerns the effective implementation of the REACH Regulation and the accuracy of the calculation of the cost.
COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.7.13. The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but generally not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.7.14.
The Agency's income from fees is linked to the registration periods for chemicals in the EU, which are set out in the REACH Regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018).
The Agency therefore does not raise any notional expenses and has to struggle with a misrepresentation between relatively stable expenditures and more fluctuating, less predictable revenues, which makes budgeting more difficult.
The Agency is supported in dealing with this situation by a grant it receives from the Commission.
As the third and final registration period for chemicals expires in 2018 under the REACH Regulation, revenues from fees and charges are expected to fall from 2019 and the Agency will be dependent on the EU budget for the financing of the chemicals company from the EU budget.

In progress (1) In progress/excluded ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court observations The Court's estimates of the Agency's expenditures related to a new specific activity, the implementation of the Biocidal Products Regulation, were, in principle, covered by fees for the evaluation of the observations on registration of these products.
However, the fees collected in 2014 only covered 17% of this expenditure, so that the rest of the expenditure was actually financed by contributions from the Union (6.3 million euros) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euros) to the Agency's budget. At 10.1 million euros and 39% (2015: 7.3 million euros and 32%), the rate of committed appropriations committed to Title III (operational expenditure) in the following financial year (operational expenditure, REACH) was still high. Title IV (operational expenditure,, biocides, etc.) still covered 1.3 million euros and 68% (2015: 1.5 million euros and 74%).
Such a high transfer rate is in contradiction with the budgetary principle of principle of legality. The agency is able to use the austerely separate budgetary resources to better meet the multi-annual nature of the activities and the inevitable aberrations between contract signatures, deliveries and payments.
ECHA contributes to the functioning of the market for biocides and biocidal products.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the structure and practical implementation of the ECHA's internal control system in relation to the Agency's processes and activities under the Biocidal Products Regulation is effective and efficient.
Although no serious findings were made, the IAS still sees the need for improvement.
Unlike most other agencies, ECHA's Recommendation does not explicitly require periodic external evaluations of their activities, which are substantially more important for performance assessment.

EN C 434/60 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.7.10.
The relevant legislation (REACH (Regulation on fees) 340/2008) does not require the Agency to carry out an ex-post monitoring of the size of all SME registrants.
The Agency's Board of Directors approved a concept in which SME registrants with the largest financial impact (i.e. with most registrations within the largest volume range) are mainly ξover-presenced.
In 2017, the agency also focused on SME registrants from the United Kingdom, in order to give their company size before the United Kingdom leaves the European Union. In the United Kingdom, the agency focused on the size of its SME registrants. In the United Kingdom, the company size was also the size of the company before the UK left the European Union.
In the future, we will be increasingly carrying out the implementation of the SME implementation, based on the cost-benefit-principle.
3.7.11.
REACH Regulation (EC) No 340/2008 does not provide the Agency with the tools necessary for the enforcement of the collection of administrative fees of higher fees.
The Agency proactively reminds debtors of their obligation to pay. If this does not succeed, it commissions local law firms to apply their outstanding fees and fees directly in the Member States.
To date, the law firms have contacted 74% of the companies that have to pay more than the administrative fees, and the result of this initiative will be subjected to a cost-benefit analysis to determine the next steps.
Member States have the primary responsibility for the enforcement of the REACH and CLP regulations, in particular the obligation to register chemical substances.
The ability of the agency to fulfil its mission and to obtain the appropriate revenues from the fees depends on the effectiveness of the implementation of enforcement strategies by the national authorities.
Discussions with the Commission are being held to address this problem.
3.7.13.
The Agency takes note of the previous comment, which is a horizontal matter which concerns a number of agencies.
The Agency publishes job offers similar to other agencies on its own website, on social media, and on the website of the EU Agency Network (EUAN) (https://euagencies.eu/).
In order to increase transparency and publicity and to enable the citizens to view job advertisements, the Agency recommends that the European Agency for Personnel Selection (EPSO) refer for its part to the EUAN website.
3.7.14.
The previous remark is correct.
The Agency shall be financed from a combination of revenue from fees and charges and from a compensatory subsidy from the European Union.
The Agency has submitted a number of alternative financing proposals to the Commission, including the introduction of a regular fee, as has been the case with a number of other EU agencies.
The Agency points out that, according to its Communication, the Commission will examine all possible options to ensure the Agency's sustainable financing in the future, in the light of the review of the REACH Regulation of 5 March 2018 (COM(2018) 116 final).

EUROPEAN INNOVATION AND TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE (EIT) INTRODUCTION 3.9.1.
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter called the Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter referred to as the Institute of Innovation), and the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter referred to as the Institute of Innovation and Technology), based in Budapest (hereinafter referred to as the Institute of Innovation and Technology), was established by Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (82).
The aim of the Institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increase competitiveness by reinforcing the innovation capacity of the Member States and the European Union.
The Institute receives financial support from an increasing number of Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) which combine higher education, research and the economy and, in this way, support innovation and entrepreneurship.
The KICs coordinate the activities of hundreds of partners.

Other comments 3.9.7.
In December 2016 璝 shortly before the end of the period of funding (1 January 2016-31 December 2016)  - the EIT signed changes to the individual financial assistance agreements with the KIC EIT Digital, InnoEnergy, Health and RawMaterials.
The modification of the individual grant agreement with Climate KIC was even signed in January 2017, after the end of the grant period.
The increase in individual reimbursements agreed in these changes enabled the KICs to receive an additional 15 million euros in EIT financial support (6.0 million euros in addition for Climate KIC, 5.6 million euros for EIT Health, 2.2 million euros for KIC InnoEnergy and 1.2 million euros for EIT RawMaterials).
This approach contradicts the intention of strengthening the KICs' ability to tap into sources of finance and to encourage them to gradually reduce their financial dependence from the EIT.
It could also affect fair competition between the KICs, as the co-financing of the expenditure also plays a role in the annual grant decisions.
3.9.8.
Also due to changes in the business plans of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital, some in the original business plans not planned activities in the total value of about 3.3 million euros and 0.6 million euros in the total amount were added.
According to the Court, the activity added in the case of KIC InnoEnergy represents a significant change in the original business plan, on the basis of which the maximum amount of financial assistance in question was granted.
Since the amount of the grants granted to each of the KICs is the result of a performance-oriented over-the-counter procedure to which their original proposed business plans are subject, a further substantial change to these plans is to be made to the grant decisions and to the equal treatment of the KICs and, therefore, to Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation, which is incompatible with Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation.
3.9.9.
COMMENTS ON THE LIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.9.10.
In 2017, the Institute introduced a paperless payment system.
Although this resulted in changes in his procedures and his accounting system, the accounting system has not been revalidated since 2012.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.9.11.
To further strengthen the internal control system for financial assistance to KICs, the EIT has introduced centralised ex ante controls for the KIC partners whose cost statements exceeded EUR 325 000.
The controls were carried out by two economic operators on behalf of the EIT (86) and carried out at certified cost statements of the KIC partners.
The results of the ex post controls carried out by another EIT-managed economic operator confirm that the new approach to certified cost statements is effective and important as most of the material errors identified concerned cost statements that had not been subjected to these ex ante controls.
(86) In previous years, the certification process was carried out by many private economic operators on behalf of the individual KIC partners, whose submitted cost statements exceeded the threshold of EUR 325 000 (refund of actual costs and unit costs).
EN C 434/66 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.12.
The business continuity plan and the plan for re-launching following a disaster recovery plan of the EIT were adopted in 2013 and are outdated.
For example, more than half of the members of the crisis management team no longer worked for the EIT in 2017.
An updated version of the Pl晃ne has been in the process for two years, but it has not yet been adopted.
As in previous years, the KICs did not, in full measure, withdraw the financial support granted by the EIT.
The approved total costs of the KIC value added activities of the FFS, which were functional before 2016 ( KIC of the first and the second wave combined), were 15% lower than those of the individual financial assistance agreements concluded at the beginning of 2016 (87).
The fact that the funds were not used was mainly due to the fact that the grant agreements were approved at a later stage and the multi-annual nature of the KIC-activities due to the incomplete implementation of the business plans and the self-financing rate of the administrative costs, which were higher than planned for some KICs, was mainly due to the fact that the funds were not used.
Some of these funds have been used to increase the cost of the KIC value-added activities to specific specific reimbursements (see 3.9.7).
In particular, the KICs of the second wave (EIT Health and RawMaterials) had to struggle with the delay in the start of their activities.
The performance of Climate KICs was particularly insufficient in the KICs of the first wave, according to the EIT assessment reports.
3.9.14.
The EIT evaluated the implementation of the business plans and then calculated some corrections.
However, these corrections did not have any financial impact on KICs.
In line with the Horizon 2020 methodology for the calculation of the financial contribution, the EIT applies only the higher of the two in the case of corrections necessary for financial controls and performance assessments.
While this methodology is appropriate for individual Horizon 2020 projects, it is less appropriate for the grants granted to KICs to finance a wide range of different activities.
It is questionable whether it is justified to set aside corrections to be made based on performance, e.g. for educational activities, against corrections to be made on the basis of financial controls, which can, for example, affect innovation projects.
3.9.15.
In 2017, all KICs, in line with the EIT guidelines, have approved sustainable funding, with an important step towards the KIC's greater sustainability in the future.
Nevertheless, the first wave KICs still generated little revenue (between 2% and 6% of the costs of the KICs' value added activities) and little progress was made in 2017.
Co-financing by the KIC partners is also low (and less than the ones originally agreed): KIC value-added activities are still financed by 62% to 90% by EIT, depending on KIC-level.
3.9.16.
The EIT publishes job advertisements on its own website and on the DG Human Resources and Security website, but generally not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
3.9.17.
Under its framework financial regulation, agencies should establish a single regulation for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (88). Given that a corresponding provision also applies for the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT summary that covers all stages of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic call for tenders in the online edition of the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic submission of tenders (2015).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.9.18.
The current interim director of the EIT took office in July 2014.
A selection procedure for the appointment of a new director was launched in 2016, but was unsuccessful.
Since then, no new recruitment procedure has been initiated.
To fill this post over such a long period of time ad interim is contrary to the Statute, according to which a post may be temporarily occupied for a maximum of a year.

Article 5(1) of the Statute of the EIT shall be directly recruited by the EIT staff within the framework of fixed-term contracts of employment and shall apply to the staff of the EIT to the conditions of employment of other servants of the European Union.
The EIT can therefore offer temporary temporary workers temporary employment with a maximum duration of five years which can be extended by five years.
Those employees who have started their activity at the EIT shortly after its foundation in 2009 will reach the maximum contract period of ten years in 2020, which in the years to come could result in instigation of the continuity of the measures and the administration.

The model for the reimbursement of the costs of the universities is based on a combination of a lump sum of a maximum of 8 000 Euro/students (including the terms of the Erasmus Mundus programme) plus the actual costs, including a flat-rate calculated indirect costs.
On this basis, the universities received an average of 15 000 euros/students in 2015 (including the lump sum).
However, the model was not established at any time, and it is not possible to distinguish between the activities and the costs to be covered by the lump sum and the costs to be covered.
The Institute should switch to a clear and formally defined model, based on a single method, such as a single lump sum based on proof of costs.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/71 EN Court's comments The grants for the calendar year 2015 were only awarded in April 2015 and the grant agreements were signed in June and July 2015.

The Institute is an important player in the implementation of the Horizon 2020 programme, with a budget of 2.4 billion euros in the period 2014-2020.
The Commission has created a central support body for Horizon 2020 to ensure coherence between the relevant bodies in areas such as legal services, IT tools, grant management, dissemination and exploitation of research results, etc.
However, unlike the Commission's executive agencies and public-private partnerships, the institute does not have direct access to the support body, but, in any case, has to be approved by the Commission's superordinate directorate-general.
This specification influences the efficiency of the Institute's activities.

C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the KICs' legal entities, which are financed almost entirely by the Institute.
The Court paid particular attention to the procurement procedures carried out by these bodies, which it considers to be a highly risky area.
In accordance with the 2015 grant agreements, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must ensure that the best possible price/performance ratio is achieved in procurements, or that the lowest price criterion is applied where appropriate.
For all contracts of more than EUR 60 000, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must, according to the grant agreements, invite at least three economic operators to submit tenders and document the award procedure to demonstrate its transparency.
The Court carried out a sample of procurement procedures of around 7 million euros carried out by the legal entities of the KIC and financed by the EIT.
The examination revealed considerable differences, such as direct procurement, absence of essential elements in tenders, significant extensions of initial extensions in terms of duration and/or scope, additions without limitation of duration and/or scope, or quality/price weightings, which led to price competition.
The Institute had also established the allocation rules in the procurement procedures of a KIC legal entity and established an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KIC legal entities in the future.
Despite the significant increase in the budget from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to EUR 2.4 billion (2014-2020) and despite the fact that six and no longer three KICs have existed since the end of 2016, the number of posts granted to the Institute has barely changed (see Table 2).
As the Court noted in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have a sufficient capacity to deal with the increased workload.
The interim director of the institute pointed to this risk in the annual report of the institute for 2015.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/73 REPLY OF THE INSTITUTE 3.9.7.
The EIT should make it clear that changes to the individual grant agreements under the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements of the EIT can be submitted at any time during the period under review.
The amendments of the KICs were subject to a technical and financial assessment by the EIT and the prior approval by the European Commission.
Subsequently, the changes were signed in December 2016.
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC was formally informed of the approval of the amendment request on 21 December 2016 (i.e., within the period of application).
With regard to the increase in the individual reimbursements, the EIT points out that the KICs were not paid out any additional amount of financial assistance as a result of the changes to the individual financial assistance agreements in 2016.
The overall amount of the final financial assistance (241.8 million euros) was significantly lower than the initial amount (274.9 million euros).
With regard to the call for KICs to develop their own sources of funding and to become financially viable, please refer to our reply to section 3.9.15.
In the context of the assessment of the change, the EIT, after consulting the European Commission, concluded that the adjustment of the individual refund levels is in line with the applicable legal basis and does not affect the equal treatment of KICs.
The possibility of adjusting the individual refund amounts was open to all KICs on equal terms.
As regards the second observation, the EIT considers that the amendments were in accordance with Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation's implementing provisions, as they did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants and did not contradict the equal treatment of applicants.
It should be noted that there is no provision for a materiality threshold that indicates the change in a measure in the assessment of whether the change is relevant to the provision of the grant, to be considered as material.
Whether the inclusion of new activities is in line with the provision in question must be determined on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the entire KIC business plan on a case-by-case basis.
The EIT carried out the assessment before the approval of the change agenda and came to the conclusion that the changes did not call into question the decisions on the creation of grants.
Since each KIC had the possibility to incorporate new new opportunities into its changed business on equal terms, the equal treatment of KIC was also guaranteed.
Finally, the EIT points out that, in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity in question was only 3.9% of the revised budget estimate of the KICs budget.
At EIT Digital, this share was 0.6%.

3.9.12.

3.9.13.
The 2016 individual financial assistance agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed more recently than planned, as the framework partnership agreements had to be signed first.
The individual grant agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, so that the KICs were able to take up their activities in good time in the respective year.
Due to their dynamic and fast-moving nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly.
Some innovation projects or projects do not meet the expectations of their potential and must be stopped during the implementation of the grant agreements. Furthermore, some of the operational activities of the KICs, such as master and doctoral studies, or long-term research and innovation projects, are planned from the ground up for several years.
The EIT aims to address this problem after 2020 by entering into multi-annual grant agreements with KICs, provided that the EIT budget allocates corresponding appropriations to commitments in multi-annual tranches.
In fact, the EIT has followed the methodology prescribed in the legal basis ăHorizont 2020, for the calculation of the grant without restriction, and will continue to abide by the current legislation in the future.
The financial sustainability of KIC is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most difficult aspects of the EIT's mission.
In the meantime, some of the innovation communities can already have significant co-financing of their activities and generate significant revenue compared to their budgets.
For example, EIT Digital provided 26% (22 million euros) co-financing to cover the costs for the 2016 KIC value-added activities. In addition, the KIC's additional activities amounted to more than 200 million euros, and were provided and paid for by the partner organisations.
Another example is EIT Health: KIC's first year of operation generated more than EUR 6 million in revenue compared to the total funding it had received from the EIT (around EUR 19 million).

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.10.8.
In 2014, the Commission concluded, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), a framework agreement with a contractor on the purchase of software licenses and on maintenance and support services.
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can meet the agency's needs.
For these intermediate services, the contractor of the framework agreement adds two to nine percent to the supplier prices. In 2017, the contractor of the framework agreement made payments of a total of 1.7 million euros.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and prices with the offers of the companies and did not systematically compare the invoices issued to the Contractor of the framework agreement. DE ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court observations In 2016 the Agency plans to transfer the administrative staff from Heraklion to Athens.
The rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year is high for Title II (administrative expenditure) with EUR 0.3 million and 25% (2015: EUR 0.15 million and 22%).
This high rate is mainly due to transfers of funds to Title I (staff expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is mainly linked to IT investments and the purchase of a service car shortly before the end of the year.
As provided for in the Agency's financial rules, external evaluations of the Agency's performance for 2014 and 2015 were carried out, and the final reports were presented in October 2015 and May 2016 respectively.
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the operational core competences implemented under the 2014 work programme are clearly related to the Agency's legal mandate and that the Agency's effectiveness has been well evaluated.
However, it was noted that there was a need to improve the division of the agency between Heraklion and Athens, which resulted in too heavy work, and a lack of communication and cooperation.
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs meet the needs for network and information security across the EU and across Member States and that the Agency effectively fulfils the expectations of its stakeholders.
However, the report stressed the need to improve communication between the Agency and its stakeholders, and the Agency's mandate and scope are too limited.
The Agency is implementing an action plan which it has subsequently agreed with the Management Board.
In 2016, the Agency moved eight more employees to Athens, reducing the number of employees in Heraklion to 14 (1).
As the Court pointed out in its 2013 report, costs could probably be further reduced by pooling the entire staff at one location.

Payments Payments on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.16.6.
Emphasis on a case 3.16.7.
On 15 December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement of EUR 1.5 billion on the operation of the Galileo satellite system during the period 2017-2027.
The agreement was awarded following a public procurement procedure.
One of the tenderers involved brought proceedings before the Court of Justice of the European Union against the Agency to challenge the outcome of the award procedure.
The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union will determine the legality and regularity of the procurement procedure for the framework agreement and for all associated individual contracts and future payments.
The Agency has reported the facts in its 2017 annual accounts and has reported and reported that in 2017 49 million euros (7% of the 2017 budget, including the amounts received through the transfer agreements) were paid out in connection with the framework agreement.
Note 3.16.8.
The negotiations on an agreement on the details of the withdrawal are currently under way.
The Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom.
In the annual accounts, the Agency refers to the Commission's decision, adopted on 24 January 2018, to move the second location of the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) from the United Kingdom to Spain in the chapter on events following the closing date.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/101 EN ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court's comments Court's comments Property, plant and equipment (net book value: EUR 1.0 million) are not insured.
The accounting systems were last validated in 2012.
The promised validation of the systems has not taken place due to the expected major changes in procedures and in the flow of information after the relocation of the Agency.
The new invoicer plans the next validation for the year 2020.
The Agency has established Emergency Continuity Plans for the security sites in France, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.
However, there is no contingency plan for the headquarters in Prague and the agency in its entirety.
The Agency's annual work plan for 2015 was only adopted in March 2015, and the adoption of its multiannual work programme for 2014-2020 is still pending.
The late adoption of central planning documents involves risks for the achievement of the Agency's objectives.
In 2015, the agency had a high staff turnover with 14 outgoing and 26 new employees.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that no agency-wide annual risk assessment was carried out in 2016 and that the significant risks for the Agency are not recognised in its planning documents or in its annual reports.
In addition, the IAS noted that the terminology used for the various elements of the performance measurement system is not uniform, which makes performance monitoring more difficult.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures. At 2.8 million euros and 46% respectively (2015: 2.5 million euros and 42%), the rate of the committed appropriations for Title II (administrative expenditure) for the following financial year was high.
EN C 434/102 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.16.10.
The GSA agrees with the Court's comment.
In 2015, the GSA outsourced its accounts to the European Commission, so that the Commission's accounting officer (within the DG Budget) provides all services, including the validation of local systems, that are required under Article 50 of the framework financial regulation applicable to the agencies.
The validation approach is currently being implemented and planned within DG Budget services.
3.16.11.
The publication of job advertisements on the EPSO platform requires translation into all EU official languages, whereas English is the only working language of the Agency and the publication of vacancies in English is considered the most appropriate pre-selection step to ensure that our working language is first understood.
Furthermore, the translation of job offers into all EU official languages would mean an additional financial and time time of the agency, so that it would not be useful for the above reasons. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all job offers on the agency's portal, which the agencies consider to be equivalent to the EPSO and offers the EU citizens a sufficient amount of transparency.
In addition, the agency also publishes its job advertisements on specialized space websites.
Electronic communications in TED (presented by the Office for Publications) for the publication of contract notices, award notices, notices of corrections, notices of amendments, etc. are currently being used in the GSA whenever this is indicated in accordance with Article 264 of the provisions of the application.
The Agency also intends to use the e-Tendering system TED to create and publish tenders.
Against this background, the GSA is currently coordinating with the Office for Publications to register and create a system account.
With regard to high-value tenders (above the thresholds set out in Article 118(1) HO), the GSA is currently undertaking the necessary administrative steps to use the ăe Submission module in the information system ăe-PRIOR (provided by DG DIGIT) developed by the European Commission to ensure that the electronic system set up for the submission of all tenders meets all the requirements of the HO and AB.
It is pointed out that the module ăe-Submission is currently supported exclusively by open procedures and the GSA is therefore allowed to use it for such procedures only.
In this context, the GSA has already held an initial coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is in the process of concluding and signing an agreement with it with a view to establishing the framework for ăe submission and starting to implement it.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.17.8.

COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMIC PROTECTION OF BUDGETARY FOOD AND SERVICES 3.17.9. The EEA noted that one of the European Topic Centres (ETZs) implemented the action plan for 2016 with significant forgeries.
The Commission therefore did not accept some of the findings and rejected part of the costs claimed by the ETZ.
The correction of the amount of the final payment also shows that the financial and performance controls have been further improved in respect of the grants granted to the ETZ.
3.17.10.
Several proposals were found in several award procedures.
The Agency used several specifications for tenders, which did not include minimum economic and financial performance requirements for the selection criteria.
These criteria are not therefore the basis for determining whether a bidder fulfils the necessary conditions for the implementation of the contract, contrary to its objective.
3.17.11.
The price competition was based on the special profiles offered for some tenders with high value and not on the expected time required for the completion of the tasks.
Framework agreements were concluded with only one tenderer, although a renewed call for competition between different tenderers for better results with regard to individual contracts would be required.
3.17.12.
In accordance with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a common framework for the electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (147) (148). Given that a corresponding framework also applies for the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT programme that covers all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
3.17.13.
In particular, the decisions taken in the minutes of the selection committee were not sufficiently detailed.
The criteria used in the various stages of the selection process and the role of each of the members of the selection committee must be specified in more detail in order to improve the transparency and equal treatment of applicants.

COMMENTS ON THE BUDGETARY SUPPLEMENTARY SUPPORT AND SERVICES 3.17.9.
The Agency welcomes the fact that the Court wishes to further improve its management of the ETZ in terms of both financial and operational controls.
In order to address a repeat of the problem encountered in 2017 at the ETZ of inland, inland, coastal and marine waters, the task in question was removed from the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency.
The Agency seeks to maintain the current level of control of grants granted to the ETZ.
The Agency confirmed that it has amended the requirements relating to the financial performance of bidders during 2017 and that the bidders are now required to provide information on financial indicators (liquidity, solvency, and profitability), and that, in accordance with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the provisions on application (AB), a minimum turnover of at least twice the value of the required annual contract value is now required.
The Agency would like to stress once again that the decision to offer framework contracts to individual contractors has been taken consciously and taking into account the fact that competition is limited to the relevant markets, as well as the nature and complexity of the services to be provided.
When awarding individual contracts on the basis of the framework contracts, the Agency considers not only the contractually agreed days, but also the number of days required, on the basis of the execution of the tasks, to calculate a value for the budget of the budget required for a specific individual contract.
Only then will negotiations begin with the contractor on the details of his offer with the aim of achieving the best price-performance ratio.
In the event of a reopening of the call, the Agency shall have no control over any further negotiations on the bids of the bidders.
In accordance with the decision of the Board of Directors of 9 November 2015 to introduce an electronic Invoicing to the EEA for the electronic processing of the procurement procedures, the Agency, in the course of 2014, introduced electronic invoicing for certain procedures, and is now in the process of extending the application of this module to all its procedures, while the electronic call for tender has been in force since 1 January 2015 for all general calls for tender.
The integration of the electronic submission of tenders started in early December 2017 and the first call for tenders in which this module was used was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002   was the provision of publishing services for the EEA).
The Agency takes note of the Court's note and of the fact that it currently adapts its selection and recruitment procedures in the following points: a) The completion of the individual steps in the various phases (pre-selection, selection, interview and written examination) is, in addition, confirmed in the relevant documents with the time (not only with the date). b) The specified questions for the interview and the written examination are systematically, in the phase of the pre-selection, a written, expected answers. c) In order to improve the reporting, an electronic (paperless) procedure is introduced.
3.17.14.
EPSO has rejected a publication for the agency with the grounds that the precondition that all job offers are to be translated into all the official languages is not fulfilled.
However, the Agency does not, either, have the resources or the resources to respond to the request made by the EPSO.
In this case, not only all job offers should be translated, but the applications should also be processed in all official languages, which entails unsustainable additional costs.
Like most other EU agencies, the Agency has, therefore, sought an alternative to the EPSO website and, since May 2018, has been using a website for the same purpose, the Agency and the EU agencies' network of agencies to set up and maintain the Job Advertisement Board.
Additionally, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and its own Facebook pages to ensure the best possible distribution.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 OBSERVATIONS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER 434/119 OBSERVATIONS ON PAYMENTS AND ENTERPRISE INTERNAL CONTROLS The nature of its activities results in large risks for the European Union 3.20.9.

3.20.11.

3.20.13.

In addition, the B找ro has to manage a large number of sites and numerous management positions (department heads, unit heads, sector heads) are not filled.

3.20.6. and 3.20.13.
With regard to the systematic violations of the regulations in the B効活ro, the B",ro ", under the new leadership, the B", started to initiate the necessary steps to ensure that the observance of the regulations prevails and becomes the central element of culture and in the implementation of all of its measures.

3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12.

The Committee directly addresses the problem and, on the basis of a sound recruitment plan, on the basis of a need assessment, undertakes, with urgency, recruitment procedures to fill the posts and other relevant (operational and administrative) posts.
In addition, the firm make efforts in terms of employee satisfaction to solve the problem of staff turnover. Although in this context it is important to take into account that the low correction coefficient, compared to the fairly high cost of living in Malta, plays an important role in this, the firm acknowledges that efforts to improve employee satisfaction need to be made more.

In May 2015, the Interim Director of the Centre was appointed by a decision of the Management Board.
As at 31 December 2016, this vacancy exceeded the maximum period of one year by eight months provided for in the Staff Regulations.
This also resulted in 15 other transitional arrangements for other staff.
In its October 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed that, despite the Centre's ongoing efforts to reinforce its internal controls on procurement, the procurement process remains subject to significant controls.
The IAS concluded that the planning and monitoring of procurement procedures are weak and that procurement procedures are not always covered by the annual work programme or by a financing decision.
In addition, reference is made to the Court's report on the Centre's 2015 annual accounts and to the found accounts, which made the transparency of the procurement procedures the subject of the Court's report.
The Centre and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.

The Centre may adopt separate budgets in order to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of the activities, as well as the inevitable delays between the signing of contracts, deliveries and payments.

The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment. COMMENTS ON RELATIONSHIP AND RELATIONSHIP OF THE PROPOSAL 3.23.8.
The Institute was the defendant at the end of the financial year 2017 in four disputes brought before the Court of First Instance by rejected tenderers in connection with three award procedures.
In each of these cases, the applicant requested the annulment of the award decision and the award of damages.
The claim for compensation in these four cases amounts to EUR 700 000 or 9% of the annual budget of the Institute.
According to the evaluation of the Institute's external attorneys, a toll of EUR 75 000 (or 1% of the Institute's annual budget) was booked to cover the expected losses.
The judgment of the Court of First Instance in each of these cases will determine the legality and order of the procedures for awarding the contracts and the payments to be made.
In 2016, the Institute launched an open call for travel services.
The performance descriptions and the evaluation process did not provide a sufficient guarantee for the best price-performance ratio.
The formula and the pricing mechanism were not appropriate as they did not enable a reasonable evaluation of tenders submitted by the tenderers.
The framework agreement was concluded over a maximum duration of four years and a maximum amount of EUR 700 000.
In 2017, payments of EUR 137,000 were made in H及he.
3.23.10.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (180) (181). As a framework for the EU institutions is also in place, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT framework covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for procurement notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
According to the Commission, by the end of 2017, the Institute had introduced the electronic invoicing of certain procedures, but not the electronic invitation to tender and the electronic submission of tenders.
3.23.11.
The Institute publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), which would provide transparency and publicity, and enable the employers to consult job advertisements of the various European institutions and agencies.

Management of advisory services 3.24.15.
In the previous year, the Agency was involved in managing consultancy services. In particular, two selected projects for the implementation of the Pharmacovigilance Regulation (Regulation (EU) No 1027/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (189) and Regulation (EU) No 536/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (190) were undertaken, which required the establishment of complex EU-wide networks, required for the comprehensive technical IT development.
Since the number of posts in the agency's establishment plan was not increased, which would enable it to build up in-house the necessary expertise, the agency drew on consultancy firms for the completion of these tasks.
However, the re-use of consulting companies has led the agency to be independent of this external expertise in a critical manner.
3.24.16.
In order to bring the projects back under their control, the agency determined which functions should not be assigned externally, but should be perceived internally.
The agency also goes on to award consultant contracts no longer according to the criteria of time and resources, but on a fixed price basis.
In addition, it set up a more appropriate procedure for the approval of project changes.
3.24.17.
It will take time to reduce the critical complexity of the agency of consulting firms, and the impact of the measures taken will only become apparent with the years.

These tasks were transferred to the Agency at a time when it was expected to reduce its staff in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline of 2 December 2013.
The number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan has not been increased, which would allow it to acquire the necessary expertise in the areas of business and IT development.
Extensive use of external consultants Since the agency had only more than 13 employees in its IT delivery department, it had recourse to the services of consulting companies in the areas of business analysis, information technology, project management and quality assurance.
In the second quarter of 2016, 131 local advisors and 60 other advisors were active outside of the agency.
Since the start of the projects, the agency has been dependent on external expertise in critical areas, but does not have a strategy to regulate the use of consultants.
Insufficient control over project development and implementation When the agency was transferred the new tasks in 2012 and 2014, the agency did not use an appropriate method for managing projects in this framework.
In 2014, a new method was introduced, which had to be considerably introduced in September 2016.
In progress (see paragraphs [3.24.15-3.24.17])
