COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMIC AFFAIRS OF THE BUDGET AND SERVICES 3.26.8. The Agency had difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of tenderers in several medium-value procurement procedures in 2017.
3.26.9.
The Agency is currently managing three dedicated, non-integrated IT-Groups (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac) which process all data on the EU's policy area of freedom, security and justice.
This approach could prevent the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems.
The current changes to extend the Agency's mandate in the coming years to the management of several additional IT systems underpin the increasing urgency of this problem.
The Agency, in consultation with the Commission and the Member States, should establish a detailed cost-benefit analysis to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems.
3.26.10.
The project for the construction of a new building at the site in Stra§burg was significantly lost.
Although the Agency had already paid the full price for the construction work in 2016, these were still not completed at the end of 2017 and the progress reports on the works in progress were for only around 70% of the work.
Some of the agency's staff have already taken over the new building, although the work was still ongoing.
The Agency and the Contractor blame each other for the failures. In December 2017, the Contractor made financial demands for the Agency and filed a lawsuit.
The agency exercises its own legal claim against the contractor (205).
3.26.11.
3.26.12.
In accordance with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform regulation for electronic storage and the electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (206) (207). In view of the need for the EU institutions to do so, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT framework, covering all stages of public procurement procedures, with the launch of electronic invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011), and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
Counselling 3.26.13.
The agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects because of the nature of its activities.
According to the Agency's records, IT projects were implemented in 2017 within the financial and timeframes.
For the few development maintenance projects that complain somewhat behind the schedule, exceptional reports have been prepared.
(205) See also the Agency's 2017 annual accounts, section 2.1.5 ăEvents after the closing date或. (206) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Article 79 Electronic Administration (ăe-Government).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3,26.14.
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which approximately 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by contractors.
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system.
Payments to these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS.
Although all phases of the IT projects, from the definition of the requirements and the milestones to the commissioning of new system components, are the property of and are under their control, a model in which the development of such sensitive IT systems is outsourced to this extent, entails significant risks in terms of a superior dependence of the contractors.
This applies even more in the light of the limited number of potential contractors in operational and safety areas that can handle the systems of these areas and these requirements.
3.26.15.
At the same time, the low number of staff in operational key units, in particular in the ăReferat for Application Management and Maintenance, entails a significant risk for the continuity of the operation.
In the second half of 2017, the head of the AMM unit temporarily held the position of head of the operational department and the head of the department for operation and infrastructure and thus merged the three highest management positions in the operating department, which entails additional risks for the continuity.
3.26.16.
The framework agreements concluded with the consortia concerned for the operation of the main IT systems include not only normal maintenance, but also the developmental maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the cost estimates attached to the framework agreements.
The prices for the individual contracts are calculated by the Agency on the basis of a combination of the fixed price and the estimate of the time and resources, thus aiming for a solid cost control.
For the VIS contract, the agency also relied on the IFPUG (208) method, a standard method based on the function point analysis for determining the price for developmental abilities.
The agency could also use the IFPUG method for other systems in implementation.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.26.17.
The Agency committed a total of 69.9 million euros in global commitments in order to cover future expenditure on new tasks and IT systems to be transferred to it in 2017 but for which the legal basis had not yet been adopted by the end of the year (Eurodac recasting and the allocation system to Dublin) or only recently (Regulation on the system of entry to/exit of 30 November 2017).
The corresponding appropriations for payments have been reduced by two amending budgets of EUR 85.6 million, from EUR 153,3 million in the original budget, to EUR 85.6 million in the final budget.

EN C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANSWER OF THE AGENCY 3.28.8.
Europol employs over 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organisations.
The common working language of Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language arrangements adopted by the Management Board specify that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures are to be carried out in English.
For this reason, Europol's job advertisements are published in English.
Europol is implementing an effective and transparent recruitment process with a quota of 0% at the end of 2017. In the 89 recruitment procedures carried out in 2017, there were an average of 58 candidates per selection process.
For publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) the translation into the EU official languages is required in addition to the English version.
Due to the high number of job offers per year, translation into the EU official languages would entail high costs and the duration of the procedures would be longer.
Europol focuses on operational needs in budgetary expenditure, so the translation of job vacancies into all EU official languages, including EPSO publication, is only in certain cases (e.g. the Executive Director or Deputy Executive Directors).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/173 3.30.
EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE FRONTEX INTRODUCTION 3.30.1.
The European Agency for Border and Coast Guard (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), was set up by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (the new Council Regulation) repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 (229).
It has been expanded on the basis of the European Agency for the Development of Operational Cooperation on the external borders of the Member States, while maintaining the abbreviation "Frontex" and the Warsaw headquarters.
The new establishment regulation will extend the Agency's mandate; the Agency will also be entrusted with the task of providing the European level with an integrated border management at the external borders with a view to effectively managing the crossing of external borders.
This includes the fight against migratory pressure and potential future threats at these borders, while at the same time contributing to the fight against severe crime with a cross-border dimension, in order to ensure a high level of internal security within the Union, while fully respecting fundamental rights and respecting freedom in this area.

3.30.9.
In view of the migration crisis facing the Union, the mandate of the Agency was significantly extended in 2016.

Personnel increased by 18% in 2016 and by an additional 43% compared to the previous year.
The adaptation of the systems and procedures to the new mandate and the new situation is still under way.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment and are to be read against the background of the challenges the agency had to address.
COMMENTS ON RIGHTS AND RULES ON THE PROPOSALS 3.30.10.
Following an open invitation to tender, the Agency received four offers, covering the promotion of migrants within Greece.
After testing the selection criteria, three offers were retained and one was excluded.
The only criterion for the award was the price.
In April 2017, the Agency signed a framework agreement of € 2 million for a three-year period with the company that had offered the lowest price.
However, the contractor's coverage was limited from the season to the season, and he had problems to complete the order, so that the agency started the order at the end of 2017.
To ensure continuity of services, the agency for the remaining period signed a new framework agreement of EUR 1.8 million with the second-ranked bidder in November 2017, who had offered the second lowest price.
It did not negotiate the terms of the replacement contract with the tenderers ranked second and third but signed the new contract on the basis of the initial tender submitted by the second-placed tenderer.
The direct award of the replacement was contrary to the rules, since the original award procedure was completed and a negotiated procedure to agree the terms of the contract, which would apply until the conclusion of a new open procedure, did not take place.
No payments were made on this replacement order in 2017.
3.30.11.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff will be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234).
In 2017, the Agency hired two staff members (2016: 14) in higher AST grades.
(233) Special Report No 12/2016 ăThe use of financial assistance by agencies: not always adequate or demonstrably effective. (234) Article 53(2) of the Staff Regulations.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/175 COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
In 2017, the Agency of the Islantics guard provided financial support in connection with the deployment of an aircraft in Greece.
Before reimbursing the expenditure claimed by Iceland, the Agency requested invoices as proof of a category of expenditure declared.
Although the invoices were never submitted, the Agency reimbursed around EUR 440 000.
In this case, the ex-ante---berprunung was therefore ineffective.
3.30.13.
The Agency also co-financed the use of an aircraft used by the Spanish Guardia Civil.
In the absence of supporting documents for the costs claimed for inspection and maintenance work, the Agency reimbursed EUR 430 000 on the basis of average costs per flight hour.
These average costs were calculated on the basis of cost ceilings used in exchanges between Spanish authorities and private contractors for inspection and maintenance work.
There is a risk that higher costs will be reimbursed than actually incurred.
3.30.14.
Although the Agency has already received its current accounts in 2014, it has still not drawn up a comprehensive contingency plan approved by the Management Board.
COMMENTS ON THE BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The Agency again cancelled a large amount of committed appropriations carried over from the previous year for the reimbursement of the expenditure of States participating in joint actions, amounting to EUR 7.7 million and EUR 16.5% respectively (2016: EUR 5.6 million and 17.6%).
This shows that the cooperating states had once again clearly overestimated the expenses to be reimbursed by the Agency.
Although funds transferred for joint actions had to be cancelled in two consecutive years, in 2017, the Agency transferred €9.6 million from other budget lines to joint actions, which again transferred an amount of €40,5 million to the following financial year.
Joint actions represent 69% of the total amount cancelled in 2017 (EUR 11.1 million) and 46% of the total amount transferred in 2018 (EUR 87.6 million).
3.30.16.
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were spent on return operations. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available.
The Agency therefore paid back to the Commission EUR 13.5 million and EUR 20.3% (2016: EUR 23 million and 37.5%).
In addition, the Agency paid EUR 4 million of the budget of Title I of the Budget, as the number of new employees could not be employed as planned in 2017.
3.30.17.
The Agency's original budget for 2017 comprised 8.8 million euros for the required operational financial reserve to finance immediates for border security purposes and return operations (235).
However, in September and again in October 2017 the agency transferred 1.9 million euros (in the sum of 3.8 million euros) of its operating budget to finance other activities.
3.30.18.
After the transfer of appropriations from other budget lines and the establishment of an amending budget the appropriations entered in the rescheduling amounted to 24.7 million euros and 8.1% of the original budget.
However, the agency used the opportunity mainly to finance standard operations (8.4 million euros) and to finance a project for remote air monitoring (drones, 7 million euros), for which it had estimated only 1.1 million euros.
The estimate and use of unregulated complaints is incompatible with the principle of the specialised budget and is incompatible with the transparency of the budget.

C 434/178 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The Internal Security Fund was established for the period 2014-2020.
It comprises two instruments: the instrument for the financial support for external borders and visas and the instrument for the financial support for police cooperation: the EUR 2.8 billion (international borders and visas) and the EUR 1 billion (police cooperation) for the financing of borders.
Under the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, the Commission shall reimburse the Member States for the cost of equipment such as vehicles or ships, as well as operating costs such as fuel or maintenance costs.
The Agency shall also reimburse participants in joint actions for such costs.
There is therefore a risk of double financing (4) which is not taken into account.
Border-participating states shall determine the costs incurred on the basis of cost statements, which shall include ăFix-costs (depreciation and maintenance costs), ăvariable expenditures (mainly fuel) and ăU-costs (mainly expenditures and other expenditures for crew members).
The reported costs are based on actual values and correspond to national standards. Consequently, the approaches of the participating states differ and this leads to a particularly complex system for all participants.
In its Special Report No 12/2016, the Court recommended that the agencies make use of simplified cost options whenever this appears appropriate to avoid such inefficiencies (5).
The Agency's current current advisory regulation until 5 October 2016 provides for the funding of joint funding operations carried out with participating countries.
However, from January to October 2016, the Agency financed national return operations with a sum of EUR 3.6 million.
These payments are illegal.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff may be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (6).
In 2016, the Agency hired 14 staff in higher AST grades.
At 6.4 million euros and 43% (2015: 3.2 million euros and 38%) for Title II (administrative expenditure) and 67.3 million euros and 37% (2015: 40.2 million euros and 35% respectively) for Title III (operational expenditure), the rate of committed appropriations for the following financial year increased.
The Agency may adopt separate budgets in order to better meet delays that inevitably arise between legal obligations, order execution and obligations, and corresponding payments.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The main challenge is connected with the feasibility of commitments during a given year.
To avoid the risk of high cancellations, Frontex, in the fourth quarter of 2016, asked the clients to file their claims for final payment for the first half of the year, and for Frontex to carry forward their claims of costs for the current year (December 2016) or planned claims (January 2017) in the course of the 2016 operational activities for the first half of the year.
The main aim of these calls was to identify possible over-implementations, to reduce the corresponding SFD allocations and to re-use the funds in 2016.
Despite some positive results of this action, the transfer of funds was still high.
Therefore, despite a proper assessment of actual financial needs, Frontex needed additional funds to ensure the financial coverage of the investments in the autumn of 2016, since the cancelled funds of the terminated and ongoing operations were not available at that time.
The Agency has developed a simplified support scheme, which will be implemented from the 2018 operational cycle and which will be used, to a much higher extent, for increases of up to a year; and the Agency will not only step up the monitoring of the implementation of increases, but will also seek to reduce the cancellation of transfers.
Return Despite the repayment of funds to the Commission, the main objective of the Agency in the context of the Return Actions was achieved: it provided Member States with technical and operational support for return Actions and implemented specific measures in the pre-return period (to identify returnees, training/training, exchange of knowledge between Member States, etc.).
In 2017, the number of return actions coordinated by Frontex increased significantly: with an increase of 47% against the previous year, the number of migrants increased from 10,700 in 2016 to 14,200 in 2017.
This represents an overall 10% share of the total number of migrants actually returning from the EU to third countries (in 2014 the corresponding figure was 2%).
Recruitment Repayments of appropriations for staff expenditure were mainly due to difficulties and to the associated difficulties in recruitment procedures: protracted procedures, long deadlines, inadequate numbers of applicants and a lack of geographical balance due to a low correction coefficient.
Nevertheless, the Agency considers it to be a success that, within one year, over 250 new employees have been hired and hired.

In 2017, the Agency was the first year of implementation of the new ECC Regulation.
Article 75(13) obliges the Agency to include in its budget an operational financial shortfall of 4% of the budget of the operational budget to finance emergency operations for the purposes of border management (RABIT) and return operations.
On 1 October each year, at least one quarter of the year's pay should remain available in order to meet needs until the end of the year.
The required operational deficiencies were introduced so that during the year the agency can provide a certain reserve at any time for the implementation of immediate abatements for border protection purposes and for the cover of the necessary costs of such an immediate operation.
The European Parliament had amended the original text of the ECC Regulation proposed by the Commission by adding that by 1 October only one quarter of the had to remain available for the remaining three months of the year.
The ECC regulation is silent on what is to be done with the remaining three-quarters of the deficit after 1 October, this point is unclear.
The first transfer at the end of September was intended for the financing of reinforced operational measures in the air and at sea and the acquisition of own air monitoring services; the second transfer took place after 1 October.
The Board of Directors was informed in the monthly report on the transfers.
The Agency considers that the legislator should provide clarity.

The ECC Regulation entered into force in October 2016.
The Agency had to plan the detailed annual work programme 2017 (as part of the SPD 2017-2019) for the whole year 2016 without the final result of the deliberations on the ECFC Regulation and thus without a clearly defined legal basis.
Towards the end of 2016, the SPD 2017-2019 was already completed and was available for approval to the Board of Directors, which fully supported the creation of the non-obligatory endowment in the light of the transition to the European Border and Coast Guard.
The Commission stated in its opinion on the SPD 2017-2019, (C92016)8722, in paragraph 63: ăThe Commission stated that emergency planning has become a guiding principle for the preparation of the annual work programme and that the Agency intends to provide almost 10 % of its operational budget for the so-called ‘operational flexibilit the (...)'.
In this context, the Commission calls on the Agency to set up two separate separate complaints within its budget, the first fully in line with Article 75, paragraph 13, of the ECC Regulation, and the second provides the Agency with the possibility to maintain the operational flexibility, in order to deal with emergencies which are not immediate.

This was the first step in a cross-sectional evaluation of the four agencies in the field of employment, social affairs and integration(1).
The evaluators concluded that the significant restructuring of the Foundation had no significant negative effects since 2011 and that the internal and external stakeholders had a predominantly positive assessment, in particular in terms of strategy and effectiveness.

The Foundation prepared a plan to implement the recommendations of the evaluators.

EURATOM SUPPLY AGENCY INTRODUCTION 3.32.1.
The Euratom Supply Agency (hereinafter ‘the Agency') based in Luxembourg was established in 1958(244).
Council Decision 2008/114/EC, Euratom(245) replaced the previously applicable Statute of the Agency.
The main task of the Agency is to ensure the regular supply of nuclear materials to EU users, in particular nuclear fuels, in accordance with the principle of equal access to supply sources through a common supply policy.
3.32.2.
From 2008 to 2011, the agency was not allocated its own budget to finance its activities.
From 2012 onwards, the Commission has allocated the Agency its own budget, but the budget covers only a small part of its expenditure.

3.34.7.
In 2017, the Office cancelled EUR 3.2 million and 15.9% of the commitment appropriations carried over from the financial year 2016.
The Office continued to use fixed prices for services (258).
The prices used in each service are based on unit prices (price/persons' day, etc.) set out in framework agreements and the number of units used by each service.
The Office shall ensure that the unit prices are correctly applied in the case of the prices offered by the contractors.
3.34.10.
However, the list of services to be provided in connection with the framework agreement was not exhaustive in a framework agreement with a value of 80 million euros on general consulting, audit and project management services, as well as studies.
In view of the evaluation of the offers, the service descriptions included two business cases relating to the management of a project and a multi-project programme.
This framework agreement is a mixed multi-frame agreement, which is partly a cascade procedure (general advisory and project management services) and partly a renewed call for competition (prs and studies).
The stored units were predetermined by the Office, but the tenderers were asked to determine the distribution between the different profiles.
The framework agreement and also some of the associated individual agreements were therefore negotiated on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not on the expected number of number of units, which is another essential element in the calculation of a fixed price agreement.
3.34.11.
The framework agreement was awarded a single contract with a fixed price of EUR 145 447.50, which primarily concerns the provision of support services for the execution of a document management project.
The personal days required for the provision of these services cannot be derived from either the business cases described in the service descriptions or from the description contained in the individual contract.
A fixed price as set out in this individual order is therefore at risk of the service being provided in the most economical way.
3.34.12.
If not all the conditions for the provision of services for the award of the framework agreement can be established, the individual contracts are more appropriate to reopen to competition among several contractors of the framework agreement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/197 EN Year 2016 State of adoption of the correction (completed/in progress/outstanding/n. e. e. e. e.) Completed (3) ANNEX Follow-up to observations from previous years Court observations The Office's budget implementation rate was low at 89%, suggesting an inaccurate estimate of its expenditure in the 2016 budget.
As a result of the most recent changes to the Ordinance and the Office's financial regulations, it has become more important that the Office, if necessary by means of a amending budget, prepares a precise budget, since the budgetary budget-related mechanisms, including the allocation of financial resources to a more precise financial resources fund and the associated compensation mechanism, (1), are now associated with the budget.
In 2014, the Office launched an invitation to tender for a four-year framework contract covering an estimated market volume of EUR 30 million for the procurement of consultancy services covering a wide range of activities, including consultancy, project management, general advisory services and studies.
However, the procurement procedure and the subsequent use of the framework agreement were partly not adequately managed.
The objectives and the activities to be carried out had not been defined in sufficient detail to ensure that the volume of the framework agreement had been carried out in sufficient detail.
Thus, the credits of the framework agreement were exhausted after only two years and six months.
In addition, despite the variety of services to be procured and the very different costs per activity, no lots of lots had been used.
Using lots would encourage smaller enterprises to participate in the low-value process.
Finally, the price competition was neutralised and the dependentness of the contractor was increased because, using the framework agreement, fixed price offers were requested by a single contractor.
The Office should seek to conclude agreements with several suppliers and, if necessary, to call again for competition.
The Office's Ordinance stipulates that the translations required for the Office's work are made by the Translation Centre for the European Union (CdT), which means that the Centre's principal client office is the Centre's office.
The Office is increasingly using internal versions such as linguistic and translation memory as well as additional software.
These instruments are designed to improve the cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the Office.
However, from the perspective of the European Union, the current situation could result in a doubling of the expenditure and the corresponding costs.

EN C 434/198 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OFFICE'S COMMENTS ON THE BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.34.8.
While the cancellation rate is just over 15%, the amount of cancelled committed transfers of EUR 3.2 million is the lowest of the last ten years (since 2008).
The Office continues to work with national authorities to reduce the cancelled transfers by means of interim reports on implementation and half-year implementation with reinforced control measures, which constitute an integral part of each new cooperation agreement.
Further measures have also been implemented internally, such as awareness-raising measures through coaching, training, information notes and meetings with financial actors.
In addition, the Office had already expected the level of cancelled transfers to exceed 15%, and had proactively taken additional measures to reduce transfers to the next year.
The Office took note of the Court's observations.
In advance it should be noted that the scenarios described in the procurement documents for the future uses of the contract were aimed at being as vivid and representative as possible and were not expected of them as to be in the detail of each specific contract.
As regards the adequacy of the re-opening of the competition mechanisms and as stated in the Office's response to the 2016 audit, this concept has already been incorporated in the revised framework agreement on audits and studies.
The Office has compared the added value of this mechanism with the related administrative costs and, given the Office's intensive use of consultancy and project management services, has concluded that this is not the most efficient way of managing the latter types of services.
Taking into account the fact that the current framework agreement is valid until 2020, the extension of this mechanism to the advisory and project management services would require a new call at the time, which the Office does not consider appropriate.
In the existing cascade system for consulting and project management services, the Office repeats the answer to the 2016 audit for the use of the fixed price procedures.
The main reason for choosing this option is that proceedings against the Office before the Spanish labour courts are against the Office in relation to the non-rightful transfer of employees, which are inter alia related to the use of the former ăTime and Means-regulation.
In the case of the fixed price procedure (within the cascade system), the Office has experience in the evaluation of offers.
The EUIPO has set up a specific team, which is able, on the basis of previous practice and expertise, to include which resources are required to perform the tasks behind the fixed-price performance.
However, we believe that the Court's concerns can be addressed through other contractual methods than the ăfixed prize, for example through the ăQuoted Time and Means methods, a method that could, in the future, draw the Office in the process of individual cases.
The Office undertakes to provide further information and to document its own estimates of resources required to carry out the tasks of fixed-price services before issuing the request for information to provide proof of the above-mentioned experience of the Office in advance.

EN C 434/204 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE COMMITTEE 3.35.9.
The annual contributions to the Fund collected in advance shall be calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by credit institutions and certain investment firms.
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework that ensures the reliability of the information, the SRF is paying any attention to this aspect.
The data provided are provided on the basis of the data provided by the institutions in the previous year and the data contained in the ECB database.
Deviations are reported to the national resolution authorities who are asked to clarify the facts. This made it possible for the SRF to improve the quality of the data in the previous cycles.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot provide any details of any pre-investigation-based contributions per institution, as the calculations are of limited nature and, as a result, confidential information about other institutions would be disclosed.
However, the SRF has disclosed the calculation method as well as detailed calibrations to ensure transparency and cooperation.
3.35.12.
In 2017, the capacity of the financial team was not sufficient to ensure the efficient handling of all financial transactions, including bills, due to a combination of unexpectedly high workload, a regrettable staff turnover in the financial team, and general difficulties in finding experienced staff.
Since the fourth quarter of 2017, the team's capacity has been strengthened again and measures have been taken to ensure the timely processing of invoices.
By now, almost 98 % of the invoices have been settled within the deadlines set in 2018.
Any late payment case will now be examined closely to make further improvements in this area.
3.35.14.
The SRB's 2017 procurement plan was adopted in 2016, when the Committee was only in its second full-year in existence.
At that time, no resolution cases had yet been dealt with and the Agency had little experience on the basis of which its procurement plan could be drawn up.
As a new agency, the SRB could use various interinstitutional frameworks managed by the European Commission.
This led to the fact that several procurement procedures to be initiated by the SRB in 2017 were ultimately not implemented.
In 2018, the implementation of the procurement plan will be closely monitored and additional efforts will be made to improve the planning of procurement procedures.
In 2017, the SRB spent a total of EUR 20 million on providing legal advice.
Almost all negotiated procedures without prior publication of a contract notice concerned disputes (eight out of ten out of a total of EUR 10.9 million) which did not fall within the scope of Directive 2014/24/EU.
This also includes a large number of disputes brought before the ECJ after the first resolution procedure of the SRB.
The SRB therefore does not believe that it uses such methods in aberm that way.
As regards the economic and financial valuation of two of the two cases in 2017, the re-implementation of a competition proved unsuccessful. Therefore, the SRB was forced to resort to negotiating procedures.
Due to the subject matter of the contract and the need for the highest level of confidentiality, the contract notice was not published in accordance with the applicable rules.
3.35.16.
The online access to tender documents has been available to economic operators since the Committee was established on the SRB website and was fully integrated into the electronic tender platform since the end of 2017.
In June 2017, the SRB requested that the electronic submission of offers also be made use of. However, the Commission has not yet gained access.
The SRB has established that such publications on the EPSO website do not increase the quality or the number of applications and that they are also very expensive due to the mandatory translation of the job advertisements.
Therefore, the SRB publishes its job advertisements preferably on its own website as well as on EU_CV online and LinkedIn, and informs its stakeholders (central banks, finance ministries, national authorities, other EU agencies and permanent representations) about this.

Note 3.36.7.
The Centre's task is to provide the EU's agencies and agencies with translation services which they need for their services, and the Centre's task is to provide the EU institutions, which can use the Centre's services.
In the framework regulations of most agencies and bodies, it is planned that they will use the Centre's translation services.
Some agencies and agencies (which more than half of the Centre's revenue goes to) are increasingly resorting to in-house opportunities or other alternatives to the other.
However, this means that the capacity of the Centre will not be used to the maximum, that there will be a duplication in the development of systems and the running costs at European level, and that the business model and business development of the Centre will be the model used.
In 2017, an external assessment of the adequacy of the Centre's business model was carried out.
The final evaluation report had not yet been adopted at the time of the Court's audit (268).

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.38.8.
In the course of the annual review of the EU agencies, the Court analysed the accounting system, including the hierarchical position and the independence of the auditors, as well as the aspect of the timely (new) validation of the accounting systems.
The head of the agency's accountant is the head of the financial department.
The Court therefore considers it necessary to strengthen the independence of the accountant by directing it to the Director (administrative interests) and to the Agency's Steering Committee (functional concerns).
3.38.9.
In addition, the Agency's mandate was significantly expanded in 2014: it now manages EU measures in various areas in cooperation with seven Directorates-General of the Commission.
Despite significant changes in the Agency's procedures and a significant increase in its budget and staff, a revalidation of the accounting system was the latest in 2012.
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, the executive agencies should establish a harmonised definition for the electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (282). Since a corresponding definition also applies for the EU institutions and agencies, the Commission is currently developing an IT overview, covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for procurement notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
REPORTS OF THE INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICES 3.38.11.
The Commission's Internal Audit Service issued audit reports in 2017 on the management of COSME by the Agency and on the management procedures of the Agency's Human Resources Department (283).
The Agency prepared action plans to take measures in areas where there is a potential need for improvement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/215 EN ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court observations The amount of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year was high with Title II (administrative expenditure) of EUR 1 250 000 and 33% (2015: EUR 998 324 and 14% respectively) as well as with Title III (support to the operational activities of the Agency) of EUR 2 550 000 and 62 % (2015: EUR 4 million and 65% respectively).
In Title II, the transfers were mainly linked to rent (0.6 million euros) and the purchase of hardware, which had not yet been delivered at the end of the year (0.5 million euros).
The transfers under Title III concerned the evaluation and monitoring of the LIFE programme by external experts (EUR 1.5 million), ongoing ex-post inspections (EUR 0.5 million) and IT services (EUR 0.5 million), which were commissioned in 2016, but were only partially delivered at the end of the year and were not yet invoiced.
The Agency may adopt separate budgets in order to better reflect the multi-annual nature of the activities and the inevitable inflection between contract signings, deliveries and payments.
The high cancellation rate of appropriations for Title I (Staff expenditure) from the previous year (EUR 32000 or 8.3%) shows that the expenditure has been overestimated.

EN C 434/220 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANSWER OF THE AGENCY 3.39.8. Electronic submission of tenders is currently limited to open procedures (the threshold is set by Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement, and in 2017 amounted to EUR 135 000).
Since the Agency did not initiate such a procedure in 2017, and this will not be the case in 2018, the Agency was not in a position to initiate the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
Moreover, the use of electronic submissions of offers in accordance with the Commission's Roadmap will become mandatory for all EU institutions and agencies at the end of 2018.
Therefore, the start-up process was started in 2018, and the agency will be able to deploy the electronic submission of offers before the end of the year.
In the case of negotiated procedures, the Agency will use the electronic submission of tenders once the Commission has integrated this option into the module.
3.39.9.
According to the Action Plan to be prepared by the Agency and approved by the IAS regarding RP7 projects, all measures were implemented by the ERCEA and submitted to the Internal Audit Service (IAS) for follow-up on 9 April 2018.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/227 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous observations Court observations In its December 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the Agency's overall staff management is appropriate.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures for the finding included in the report.
In another May 2016 audit report, the IAS concluded that the Agency, together with the Commission, has established an efficient internal control system for the management of the grants granted under the Horizon 2020 programme.
The Agency and IAS agreed, together with the Commission, on a plan for corrective measures for the very important finding.
On behalf of the Commission, the Agency's performance underwent an external evaluation for the period 2012-2015, for which the final report was presented in May 2016.
The conclusion of the evaluation is that the Agency has carried out its tasks in the period considered in an effective, efficient and cost-effective way, that its mission is still relevant for the Commission and the managers of the Agency and that the transfer of operational tasks from the Commission to the Agency has been successful.
The evaluation experts, however, also made possibilities for an even more effective and efficient way of shaping the activities. The Agency and the Commission were invited to improve their internal dialogue and cooperation, communication, as well as certain aspects of IT and human resources management.
The Agency and the Commission agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
EN C 434/228 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.41.9
The introduction of the audited recruitment procedure, which identified weaknesses, took place in 2016. As a result, a reserve list was drawn up and adopted in 2016, which was used in 2017 to provide a job offer.
The selection process of REA for contract staff was revised and later implemented in 2017, taking into account the recommendation of the IAS of 2016.
The revised selection process for contract agents takes into account the demands for clearly documented search criteria for living life and responsibilities and for admission and selection criteria.
The search criteria used by the selection boards for the sighting of living animals are documented in their minutes of meetings.
The weaknesses raised by the Court in the amended procedure have therefore already been resolved.
In the field of procurement, the REA relies on service agreements with the Commission or on the Commission's framework contracts.
REA would only initiate a specific procurement procedure if there is a specific need not covered by these agreements or contracts.
In 2017, REA carried out only a procurement procedure for a low value contract.
The current tools for the electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders are applicable only to public procurement procedures the scope of which exceeds the threshold of 144,000 euros. As the REA has not yet started a procurement procedure the scope of which exceeds that threshold, it was unable to use the tools for the electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
In addition, the introduction of the electronic tender and electronic submission of tenders in accordance with the Commission's roadmap for all EU institutions and agencies in late 2018, and thus the implementation process only started in 2018.
The Agency is already using electronic invoicing and will also use the electronic call and the electronic submission of tenders in the event of the launch of a call for tenders, as soon as these modules also cover medium- and low-value modules.

The Agency cancelled EUR 0.2 million, or 17%, of the funds transferred from 2015 to 2016, which indicates that the Agency's needs had to be considered insufficient.

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors is the institution responsible for the audit of the European Union's (EU) finances under the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, we contribute to improving EU financial management and, at the same time, act as independent guardians of the financial interests of EU citizens.
More detailed information on our work can be found in the Annual Activity Report, which can be found on the website www.eca.europa.eu, as well as in the special reports on the EU's expenditure programmes and revenue, as well as in the opinions on new or amended legislation.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, covering the financial year 2014.
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately.
0.3.
The EU's general budget is adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report, together with the special reports, forms the basis for the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, following a Council recommendation, decides whether the Commission has carried out its discharge tasks satisfactorily.
At the same time as we transmit the report to the European Parliament and to the Council, we transmit our annual report to the national parliaments.
0.4.
The main element of our annual report is the statement of the reliability of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union and the legality and regularity of the transactions (hereinafter referred to as the regularity of the transactions).
We complement this Statement of Assurance with specific assessments of all major EU activities.
0.5.
The chapter structure now reflects the headings of the multiannual financial framework (MFF), so our report is even more relevant.
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 to determine the size and distribution of EU expenditure for the period to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to establish a link between the findings of our report and the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate annual accounts for each of the MFF headings and, therefore, the conclusions presented in the context of specific assessments are not audit opinions.
0.7.
This year's report is structured as follows: — Chapter 1 contains the Statement of Assurance and a summary of the results of our audit of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of transactions. — Chapter 2 presents our financial and financial management findings. — Chapter 3 contributes to our strategic objective of improving the EU's public accountability. The focus is on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and manage progress towards Europe 2020. — Chapter 4 contains our findings on revenue. — Chapters 5 to 9 (on the MFF headings 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5)(1) contains the results of our audit on the regularity of transactions and the audit of selected systems and annual activity reports.
0.8.
The Commission's replies (or, where appropriate, the replies of other EU institutions and bodies) to our comments are contained in the report, and our findings and conclusions are taken into account in the replies of the audited body.
However, as an external auditor, it is our sole responsibility to present our audit findings, to derive conclusions from these findings and to carry out an independent and impartial evaluation of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions.
(1) We do not provide specific assessments of the expenditure of the MFF Headings 3 (security and citizenship) and 6 (compensation payments).

DE C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 DE C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 RELEASE OF THE HIGH RELIEF RELEASE OF THE INDEPENDENT AUDITERS I. We have a) the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union, the consolidated annual accounts(1) and the aggregated annual accounts (2) for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015, and b) the legality and regularity of the operations on which the accounts are based, as referred to in Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
Management II's responsibility. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the establishment and proper presentation of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union on the basis of internationally recognised public sector accounting principles and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This responsibility includes the design, design and maintenance of internal control structures, as necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements, which are free of any material, intended or unintended misrepresentations.
The Commission bears the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
The responsibility of the auditor III. The responsibility of the auditor III. The responsibility of the auditor is to provide the European Parliament and the Council, on the basis of our audit, with a statement of the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
We have carried out our audit in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as well as the professional behavioral requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions of INTOSAI.
According to these standards, we must comply with professional behaviour requirements and to plan and carry out the audit in such a way that sufficient certainty is obtained as to whether the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union are free of material misrepresentations and whether the underlying transactions are legal and proper.
IV. An audit shall consist of the performance of audit acts in order to obtain audit evidence of the value estimates and other information contained in the consolidated annual accounts and of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The selection of audit acts shall be at the discretion of the auditor, including the assessment of the risks of material, intentional or unintended, misrepresentations in the consolidated accounts, and material, intentional or unintended, infringements of the European Union legislation in the underlying transactions.
In assessing these risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant to the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, in order to plan audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances in question, but not with the aim of giving an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit shall also include the assessment of the adequacy of the accounting policies applied, the representativeness of the estimated accounting values and the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements.
V. In the field of revenue, we use the macroeconomic aggregates relevant for their calculation as the starting point for our examination of the own resources derived from VAT and from gross national income, and we evaluate the Commission's systems for the processing of this data until the Member States' contributions are received and until the Member States' entry into the consolidated accounts.
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine the accounts of the customs authorities and analyse the tax flows until they are received by the Commission and until the amounts are recorded in the accounts.
1. Consolidated annual accounts shall include the balance sheet, the profit and loss account, the cash flow account, changes in net assets, and a summary of key accounting rules and other explanatory notes (including segment reporting).
EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/11 VI. In the area of expenditure, we review the payment transactions after the expenditure has been incurred, recorded and accepted. This review is carried out on all types of payments, except advances, (including payments for the acquisition of assets) only after they have been made.
Advance payments shall be examined if the beneficiary provides or is required to provide proof of their proper use and if the advance is or can be recovered.
VII. We believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and suitable to serve as the basis for our audit opinions.
In our assessment, the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union, for the year ending 31 December 2014, shall, for the year ending 31 December 2014, be the Union's financial and financial position, the results of its operations and its cash flows and the changes in net assets for the financial year ending that financial year in accordance with the Financial Regulation and the accounting rules based on the internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector, in all material respects as a whole.The legality and regularity of the operations underlying the annual accounts Revenues Payments The accounting opinion on the legality and regularity of revenue underlying the annual accounts IX. The annual accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 are on all material matters lawful and regular.

Our estimated error rate for the payments underlying the annual accounts is 4.4%.
Our conclusion is underpinned by the analysis of the risk levels presented by the Commission in the synthesis report.
Failure to give an opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts XI. 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 EN C 373/13 EN COMMENTS FROM THE HOF INTRODUCTION EU expenditure is an important instrument for achieving the policy objectives 1.1.
EU expenditure is an important instrument for achieving policy objectives.
Other important instruments include legislation, the free movement of goods, services and capital and the free movement of persons throughout the Union.
On average, EU expenditure amounts to 1.9% of total government expenditure in the EU Member States (see Figure 1.1).
In accordance with the Treaty, our role is, inter alia, to assess whether the use of the EU budget is in accordance with relevant laws and other legislation; — to deliver our audit opinion on the EU's annual accounts; — to report on EU expenditure's economy, economy and effectiveness (4); — to submit opinions on legislative proposals with financial implications.
With our audit work to support the Statement of Assurance, we are fulfilling the first and second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that affect economy, efficiency and effectiveness.
It also provides an important input to the opinions we give on the proposed financial rules.
(4) In Article 30(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union (OJ L 96, 30.4.2012, p.
1), these terms are defined as follows: ‘The principle of economy requires that the resources used by the institution concerned in its [sic] activities are made available at the right time, in sufficient quantity and appropriate quality and at the lowest cost.
The principle of economic efficiency concerns the optimal relationship between the resources used and the results achieved.
The principle of effectiveness is concerned with achieving certain set goals and achieving certain desired results.

REMARKS OF THE COURT 1.11.

REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.11.
The Commission notes that the error rate reported by the Court is an annual estimate that takes account of the accounting corrections of project expenditure made before the Court's audit is announced.
The Commission notes that it is bound by the Financial Regulation, which lays down in Article 32(2)(e) that its internal control system should, inter alia, ensure that its "appropriate management of the risks related to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions should take account of the multiannual nature of the programmes and of the nature of the payments concerned".
In the 2014 Synthesis Report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of corrective mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, which corresponds to 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
The Commission will continue to perform its monitoring function by making financial corrections and recoveries at a level corresponding to the level of irregularities and irregularities identified throughout the period and also after the closure of the programmes.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.12.
EU expenditure consists mainly of two types of expenditure programmes with very different risk patterns (12): — programmes based on payment entitlements, where payment depends on whether certain conditions are met; such programmes include grants for students and research grants (Chapter 5), direct grants for farmers (Chapter 7), direct budget support(13) (Chapter 8) and salaries and pensions (Chapter 9); — reimbursement schemes, for which the EU reimbursement of eligible costs for eligible activities, include research projects (Chapter 5), schemes for investment in regional and rural development (Chapters 6 and 7), training programmes (Chapter 6) and development projects (Chapter 8).
(12) Paragraphs 1.20-1.22. cover these different risks.
(13) Budget support payments are a contribution to the general budget of a State or to the budget allocated by the State to a specific policy or objective (see also paragraphs 8.7 and 8.8).
THE HOFES' COMMENTS A new audit approach...
For 2014, we redesigned our approach to quantify serious breaches of procurement rules.
This approach clarifies how we assess the impact of these infringements.
In particular, we have introduced a proportional approach to the calculation of errors associated with the modification of contracts.
1.14.
In order to ensure comparability of the results presented in this report, we have adapted the figures for 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and in Figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 in line with this new approach.
Annex 1.4 contains the unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rates for the period 2009-2013.
As a result of this adjustment, the estimated overall error rate in 2013 was reduced by 0.2% and by 0.3% in 2012.
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions that we reached in relation to those years, and it is still a clearly significant error rate.
1.15.
In 2015, we will align our approach to cross compliance with the revised regulatory framework for the common agricultural policy.
While we will continue to report on the information the Commission is presenting on cross-compliance, this will no longer be the subject of our audit proceedings.
This year we identified numerous cross-compliance errors with regard to one in four of the farms visited.
The share of these errors in our estimated total error rate is 0.2 percentage points (2013: 0.2)(14) and the error rate for the chapter ‘Natural resources' is 0.6 percentage points (2013: 0.5).
The Commission welcomes the change in the Court's approach from 2015.
For 2014, it reiterates its view that cross compliance infringements do not affect the conditions for aid for payments (see the Commission's reply to point 7.7).

Eligibility errors in the reimbursement schemes have the main part of the errors detected for 2014 (see also points 1.20-1.22, Figure 1.5, and Figure 1.6). (a) The estimated error rate for the reimbursement of expenditure is 5.5 % (2013: 5.6 %).
Typical errors in this field include: — inclusion of ineligible costs in the cost statements; — ineligible projects; — activities or beneficiaries; — serious infringements of the procurement rules; — serious infringements of the procurement rules during the execution of the contract (i.e. amendments to the contract and the award of additional works).

C 373/24 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION REPLY OF THE REMARKS OF THE HOFES Type of expenditure and error rates are closely related to 1.20.
We have analysed the relationship between the type of expenditure and the risk of error.
The extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on information provided by the beneficiaries themselves is characteristic of EU expenditure.
This applies to the largest category of payment entitlement-based expenditure schemes: the area-related aid paid to farmers.
This is particularly important in the area of reimbursement schemes: the beneficiaries must provide information in their application in order to demonstrate that they have participated in an eligible measure and that they have incurred costs eligible for reimbursement.
All types of management are affected (15).

The cash flows are grouped according to their nature.
The size of the circles in this figure is the proportion of total expenditure in each case, the respective positioning along the 45-degree line indicates the corresponding estimated error rate; the colour of the circles indicates whether the expenditure is based on entitlements or reimbursements.
1.22.
This figure includes both elements of mandatory discretion (assessment of the impact of systems and risks related to the type of operation — see Annex 1.1, point 1) and empirical elements (measurement of estimated error rates over a two-year period).
On the one hand, the aim is to meet the wishes of our target group for more information on the various risk profiles, on the other hand, to assist the Commission in taking action on areas of persistently high error rates.
1.20.
The integrated management and control system (InVeKoS), which includes the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), contributes significantly to the prevention of errors and the reduction of the error rate (see point 7.32).
LPIS is established and maintained by the national authorities.
Payments to final beneficiaries are only possible after their claim has been compared with the data available in the area identification system.
LPIS results in a lower error rate for area-related aid than for any other type of aid under shared management.
The Commission considers that Box 1.2 and Box 1.3 confirm this view.

C 373/26 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE REPLY OF THE THE REPLY OF THE COURT The results in the various areas of expenditure show different patterns of error 1.23. "Competitiveness (Chapter 5): The estimated error rate is 5.6% and is thus above the corresponding results for 2013 (4.0%(17). Most of the expenditure is paid for, and the errors in this area mainly reflect the different categories of ineligible costs (mainly personnel costs, other direct costs and indirect costs).
1.24. ‘Cohesion' (chapter 6): The estimated error rate is 5.7%, which is above the corresponding results for 2013 (5.3% (17)).
Almost all expenditure in this area takes the form of reimbursement.
The main causes of error include serious breaches of procurement rules (around half of the estimated error rate), followed by ineligible costs in expenditure declarations (more than a quarter of the estimated error rate).
Infringements of State aid rules and ineligible projects constitute the remaining part of the errors.
1.25. ‘Natural resources' (Chapter 7): The estimated error rate is 3.6%, down from the corresponding results for 2013 (4.4 % (17).
The European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) accounts for more than three quarters of expenditure in this area, and this fund is less prone to error than the rural development area, for which we have for a long time observed high error rates, in particular for expenditure incurred on the basis of reimbursement.
Overall, excessive area or animal numbers by farmers contributed about one third of the estimated error rate.
Errors related to non-eligible beneficiaries, activities or expenditure accounted for the second highest proportion (about a quarter of the estimated error rate).
The main remaining shares are cross compliance infringements (one sixth) and administrative errors (one sixth).

THE COMMENTS OF THE COURT 1.26. "Europe in the World" (Chapter 8): The estimated error rate is 2.7%, thus exceeding the corresponding results for 2013 (2.1%(18)(19).
Ineligible costs reimbursed by the Commission represent more than half of the total error rate.
Payments for unsuccessful works and services and deliveries for unsuccessful services account for a quarter of the total error rate.
The remainder is due to a lack of evidence (about a tenth of the estimated error rate), the incorrect calculation of expenditure and the lack of public procurement rules.
1.27. "Administration" (Chapter 9): The estimated error rate is 0.5%, which is a decrease compared to the corresponding results for 2013 (1.1%(18).
Most expenditure in this area relates to salaries, pensions and allowances paid by EU institutions and bodies.
A small number of errors in the allowances accounted for the largest share of the error rate in this area, which is, overall, not significant.
1.28.
As explained in the general introduction, we do not draw up a separate chapter for expenditure not covered by the MFF headings 1, 2, 4 and 5.
Therefore, the remaining expenditure of EUR 2.1 billion (1.5 % of the expenditure of our audit) is reported in this chapter (20).
Of the EUR 2.1 billion total, EUR 0.5 billion is spent on expenditure on and by ten agencies which are the subject of our special annual reports(21).
The main errors identified in this area were the reimbursement of ineligible costs (see Box 1.1).

C 373/28 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Box 1.1 — Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs of a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and citizenship of the Union" The subject of our sample was a payment of the Commission to a beneficiary who was the coordinator of a cooperation project under the "Fundamental Rights and Citizenship of the Union" programme.
The beneficiary public body assigned two permanent staff (officials) to the project on a half-day basis and charged part of its salaries in the project cost statement.
Deputies' staff only cause additional costs, on the grounds that additional staff needs to be recruited in order to replace the staff in their usual duties, and that this in fact costs them.
As the beneficiary body has not made provision for the replacement of officials, these costs are not eligible.
In total, the ineligible costs declared by the beneficiary entity amounted to EUR 58 000 of the total costs charged in the amount of EUR 237 000.
We identified non-eligible costs reimbursed by the Commission for eight of the 25 projects covered by the sample for the MFF heading 3.
Box 1.1 — Examples of errors in the reimbursement of costs of a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and citizenship of the Union" The Commission has been aware of the difficulties of the public bodies in complying with the eligibility rules applicable to staff costs for public bodies (committing other staff to replace the staff in their usual duties).
Therefore, from 2011 onwards, the Commission amended the eligibility rules applicable to the staff of public bodies, taking advantage of the flexibility provided by the implementing rules of the Financial Regulation.
Thus, the non-eligible costs identified by the Court in the above-mentioned grant (staff costs for staff in public-sector entities that are not assigned a replacement) would now be considered eligible.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/29 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE REMARKS OF THE HOFES There are many forms of corrective measures with varying effects 1.30.
Our study of "errors and corrections" aims to shed light on the complex mechanisms of implementing and recording corrective measures and to explain the many ways in which these mechanisms can shed light on our audit work.
In some areas of expenditure, new instruments will be available to the Commission when expenditure for the new programming period is made available.
Corrective measures 1.31.
We seek to take account of corrective measures taken by the Member States and the Commission in the run-up to the payment or our investigation.
We also take note of corrections which take place after our audit announcement. However, we cannot reduce the estimated error rate whenever the audit itself triggers the corrective action (24).
We review the application of these corrections (including recovery of beneficiaries and corrections at project level) and adjust the calculation of the error rate if necessary.
However, the impact of the corrective measures varies significantly depending on the expenditure area and on the corrective action.
1.32.
The Commission and the authorities of the Member States applied corrective measures to 24 of the operations examined in a sample in 2014, which had a direct impact on the operation concerned and were relevant to our calculations.
These corrective measures led to a reduction of our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (2013: 1.6 percentage points), which is about 1.6 billion euros.
Changes in the number of operations affected and the impact on our estimated error rate are no indication that the corrective measures are more or less effective: since these measures apply to a relatively small proportion of our sample, fluctuations are expected from year to year.
1.30.
The Commission considers that the Court's annual representative error rate should be considered in the context of the Commission's corrective capacity in the various annual activity reports and the synthesis report.
The Financial Regulation requires appropriate consideration of the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the control systems and the nature of the payments.
1.31.
Joint response to paragraphs 1.31 and 1.32: In the 2014 synthesis report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of corrective mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, corresponding to 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
For a breakdown of the figures by policy area see Table 1 in the synthesis report.
The Commission underlines that all types of financial corrections and recoveries exclude unlawful expenditure from the reimbursement from the EU budget (see explanatory note 6 on the financial statements).
(24) See points 1.19-1.37 of the Annual Report for the financial year 2012.
The Commission uses the terms 'financial corrections' and'recoveries' to cover a wide range of corrective measures applied both before and after the Commission's action (or reimbursement) of expenditure.
1.34.
Note 6.2.2 to the financial statements shows a total amount of EUR 3285 million for corrective measures for 2014.
Figure 1.7 shows how we map the corrections made at the various stages of the expenditure cycle.
A quarter of all corrective measures in 2014 consist of corrections and recoveries ‘which took place at the source', i.e. before the Commission carried out the related payment (25).
A further quarter will take the form of withdrawals and replacement of expenditure on cohesion projects (either during implementation or at the conclusion of operational programmes). 1.33.
The Commission considers that the terms ‘financial corrections' and ‘recoveries' are used in accordance with the legal framework laid down in the Financial Regulation and the relevant sectoral legislation.
Further detailed information on the various preventive and correction mechanisms provided for in the applicable legislation is provided in note 6 on the annual accounts of the EU and in the Communication on the protection of the EU budget.
