OF THE COURT'S COMMENTS 1.35.
The corrective measures discussed in this section of the annual report shall also include the work of the Member States' authorities and the recovery operations carried out by the national authorities and the Commission.
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 THE COMMENTS OF THE HOFES The impact of corrective measures is largely tangible at the time when the Commission accepts the expenditure 1.36.
All relevant sectoral regulations on shared management contain rules on primary controls to be carried out by national authorities or reductions in the amounts claimed by the final beneficiaries before the expenditure is certified.
In some cases, national authorities also agree to reduce or cancel certain costs, which, due to errors with long-term implications, appear constantly in the declarations (such as ongoing payments under a contract in which an error in the procurement rules exists).
Such adjustments can have a measurable impact on the amount of the refund requested for individual projects or on the aid paid to individual farmers and the correction will then help to reduce our estimated error rate.
1.37.
In the area of direct and indirect management, the ‘recoveries' covered by the Commission include the deduction of ineligible amounts in the cost applications prior to the approval of the payment.
The eligibility of the amounts shall be established on the basis of the examination of the file of the documents available or on the basis of the results of the checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7).
This also allows us to reduce our estimated error rate.
Conformity decisions ("financial corrections" in the agricultural sector) are often taken on a flat-rate basis.
In general, they relate to system deficiencies rather than to errors at the level of the final beneficiaries.
In the rarest cases, they result in recovery of the farmers concerned.
Such corrective measures are an incentive for Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of transactions at the level of the final beneficiaries and result in continuous improvements in the cost statements accepted by the paying agencies (see boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
The Commission services also carry out recoveries ‘at source' by deducting ineligible expenditure (as determined in previous or current cost statements) from payments made.
1.38.
Financial corrections made by the Commission on agricultural expenditure are intended to protect the EU budget and are imposed on the Member States.
They do not directly result in the recovery of farmers since the Commission does not pay the final beneficiaries directly but refunds the payments made by the Member States to the farmers.
However, if these incorrect payments are identifiable by the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect the Member States to continue to pursue these payments by means of recovery measures against the beneficiaries.
See answer to Box 1.3.
Payers implement conformity decisions by reducing future applications for reimbursement by the Commission for payments to farmers.
The Commission shall record the full amount paid out to farmers as expenditure, i.e. the adjustment shall not entail a reduction in the amount of the payments recorded.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and refunds to the paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26).
More than two thirds of the ‘financial corrections' in 2014 in the cohesion area consist of the replacement of new expenditures,...
1.40.
In the area of cohesion, ‘financial corrections' are cases where the authorities of the Member States reduce expenditure declared and replace expenditure by new expenditure, where more than two thirds of the total amount covered are covered.
In some cases, "reductions" no concrete projects can be recognised as being withdrawn.
Instead, Member States report additional projects and, in fact, receive a lower co-financing rate.
1.40. The Commission considers that any financial corrections, including those allowing Member States to introduce new projects and new expenditure to reuse the corrected amounts, to protect the EU budget from the illegal expenditure, and to encourage Member States to recover from the beneficiaries (and thus to contribute to the improvement of the management and control systems).
Nevertheless, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, in which Member States cannot reuse the corrected and recovered amounts and thus lose the funds, is certainly higher.
(26) For example, if an agricultural paying agency is subject to a 5% financial correction and makes payments of EUR 100 million to farmers, the Commission will refund it EUR 95 million, but the Commission, for its part, will record EUR 100 million of expenditure, which is offset by an assigned revenue of EUR 5 million.
C 373/34 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS OF THE HOFE... while net corrections are made less frequently 1.41.
If a replacement is not possible, the corrections for the Member State concerned will result in a loss of EU resources(27), in which case, albeit a relatively rare one, may occur if Member States are unable to provide sufficient eligible expenditure and if a replacement is no longer possible (28) or allowed (29).
The Commission expects that, as a result of changes in legislation, net corrections will become more widely applicable in the future. 1.41.
Following the example of the agricultural sector, the legislator has decided to apply a similar mechanism of net financial corrections for the 2014-2020 programming period to cohesion policy.
This will give Member States an additional incentive to prevent or detect and remedy serious deficiencies in the management and control systems before the annual accounts are sent to the Commission.
Otherwise, and if serious deficiencies continue to be identified by the Commission or the Court after the financial statements have been sent, the Commission must, under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, make net financial corrections, which means that the resources for the Member State are lost.
The Commission also considers that, under shared management, all financial corrections and recoveries, irrespective of the method of implementation, have a negative impact on national budgets.
In order to avoid loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace non-eligible expenditure with additional eligible operations.
This means that the Member State with its national budget has to bear the financial consequences of the loss of EU co-financing of expenditure deemed to be ineligible, unless it recovers the amounts from the individual beneficiaries.
(27) Either as a reduction in payments or in the form of a return to the EU budget in the form of assigned revenue (see Figure 2.2).
(28) After completion of the programmes.
(29) In the event of disagreement between Member States and the Commission (see point 1.25(b) of the 2012 annual report).

Box 1.2 – Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: control of land identification system The Commission has taken action to improve the identification system for agricultural parcels (LPIS) as the basis for payments to agricultural holdings, such as the single payment scheme (the largest single EU expenditure scheme).
This process took place at various stages, leading to the decline of the ‘permanent grassland' covered by the Greek LPIS, from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014.
Non-compliance with the requirements for permanent grassland, which is not eligible for EU aid, has been a key factor in our estimated error rate for natural resources for several years.
We took into account the impact of adjustments in respect of individual payments made to final beneficiaries, which were the subject of our sample of operations of the EAGF and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Another effect is that the paying agency rejected many ineligible applications, which resulted in the corresponding expenditure falling out of our sample.
Box 1.2 — Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: cleaning of the area identification system Other examples of the positive impact of action plans are given by the Court in Chapter 7.
Action plans are implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission monitors their implementation with great care and reports on the corrective actions taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
The area identification system shall prevent beneficiaries from claiming claims for land which does not exist or which does not meet the eligibility criteria, or for land for which claims have already been made by another beneficiary.
If properly implemented, it is a very effective tool to reduce the error rate.
It covers 75% of CAP expenditure.
As shown in the 2014 Annual Activity Report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development, the error rates for area-related payments are lower than for other measures.
C 373/36 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 EN REMARKS OF THE HOFES Box 1.3 — Example of the correction of compliance clearance procedures (30) — Compliance Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers In 2014, France accepted an adjustment of EUR 1.1 billion (984 million for the EAGF and EUR 94 million for the EAFRD)(31).
The national authorities declared that this would have no impact on farmers and that the amount would be on the national budget.
In previous annual reports, we pointed out that such an approach does not encourage beneficiaries to address errors (32).
The main reasons for the correction were deficiencies in the LPIS/GIS (695 million euros) and the exceedance of the ceiling for payment entitlements, resulting in excessive payments to farmers (141 million euros).
Another reason was, albeit to a lesser extent, violations of the cross compliance obligation of timely notification of movements of animals (123 million euros).
All these reasons are related to payments made between 2009 and 2013.
No adjustment was made for 2014, and the non-compliance with the ceiling for payment entitlements and the non-eligible areas covered by France's LPIS contributed 0.3 percentage points to our estimated error rate for ‘Natural Resources' this year.
Box 1.3 — Example of adjustments of conformity clearance procedures — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers Under shared management, Member States are responsible for ensuring that the control systems function properly.
The EUR 1.1 billion financial correction will be repaid to the EU budget in three annual instalments (2015, 2016 and 2017).
The Commission notes that, due to the nature of the conformity clearance procedure that applies ex-post, after the clearance of the accounts of the year and after a counter-dicatory phase, in which the Member State in question can make its own reasoning and calculation, it is very rare that a financial correction is already decided in the following year of the expenditure in question.
An ongoing conformity clearance procedure will protect the EU budget for 2014.
Box 1.4 — Example of corrections that resulted in additional expenditure: ESF — Romania In our annual reports on financial years 2012 and 2013, we pointed to corrective measures in Romania.
In 2013, we were able to reduce our estimated error rate in relation to a number of Romanian projects of the European Social Fund (ESF), as the national authorities had identified the impact of the corrections at project level.
This was also the case in 2014.
Some of the projects we have studied continue to be in error due to problems not covered by the corrections.
In its Annual Activity Report for 2014, the Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion (DG EMPL) notes that it continues to follow the implementation of the agreed action plan.
The financial corrections made do not necessarily mean that Romania will receive less EU funding, as Member States can make use of the possibility to make use of a larger amount of expenditure (33).

1.43.
Explanation 6 on the annual accounts is to a large extent a voluntary disclosure of information which is not necessary in accordance with the accounting rules.
A significant part of this information does not originate from accounting systems.
The explanation provides a description of the different impact of the different corrective adjustments on the EU budget, but not always in a quantified form.... and further improvements would allow a better analysis 1.44.
The Commission's capacity to improve the quality of expenditure is linked not only to the amounts concerned but also to their impact.
A rigorous assessment of the effects of corrective measures requires better information on the nature of the corrected error and on the way in which corrections are made (34).
When assessing the impact of their corrective action, the relevant Directorates-General of the Commission shall make the necessary adjustments to the figures given in note 6 (see point 1.55).
The Commission's synthesis report confirms an important error in operations 1.45.
Each Directorate-General of the Commission shall draw up an annual activity report.
This report includes — a report on the achievement of the main policy objectives (referred to in Chapter 3) — a management report of the Director-General to the College of Commissioners and — a declaration in which the Director-General ensures that the financial information contained in the report is accurate and that the transactions which fall within his/her area of responsibility are legal and regular.
1.43.
The legislator has provided the Commission with the instrument of financial corrections to ensure that illegitimate expenditure is not financed from the EU budget.
These financial corrections relate mainly to system defects which result in a risk of error.
It is the responsibility of the Member States and not of the Commission to determine the amounts to be wrong and to recover from the beneficiaries.
If this does not happen, EU funds will be replaced by national funds, as national budgets will have to bear the burden of the financial corrections.

THE COMMENTS OF THE COURT 1.50.
In line with the request of the discharge authority, the Commission further developed its internal guidance (45) on the presentation of information in Annual Activity Reports in 2014.
The Directors-General are now to present an "average revealed error rate" (46).
The application of this error rate to total payments of the year results in the calculation of the ‘risk amount'(47).
The synthesis report shows this amount together with the estimate of the future correction capacity of the ex post controls carried out by the Commission. The Commission acknowledges that the expenditure is substantially affected by errors...
1.51.
In the 2014 synthesis report, the Commission identifies the ‘risk amount' as the range of EUR 3.7 to 5 billion.
This represents between 2,6 % and 3,5 % of the payments for 2014(48) covered by the synthesis report.
These figures show that total expenditure is significantly affected by errors....... however, points to the estimated impact of future corrections 1.52.
The 2014 synthesis report provides an estimated total of estimated future corrections (correction capacity).
On the basis of the corrections recorded during the last six years(49), the Commission estimates that it will be able to identify and correct errors of around EUR 2700 million in the coming years (50).
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC(2014) 553).
(46) This is the detected or estimated error rate at the time of payment (not the residual error rate) i.e. without adjustment due to errors corrected afterwards.
